description: Thanks to a helmet camera, researchers discovered that a goshawk mixes its methods of chasing its prey.

title: Video Shows Los Angeles Police Shooting
description: Graphic video shows several police officers in Los Angeles struggling with a man suspected of robbery before one fatally shoots him.

title: As Milan Week Ends, a Buzz Gap
description: MILAN  It has been an odd, unsatisfying season in Milan. Parties and celebrities were thin on the ground; the biggest trends to emerge have been Lurex and fur for the feet (really: sheared-mink shoes will be big come September). The 80s are of interest to some. Rumors have swirled with no closure.

title: Kerrys Remarks to U.N. on Nuclear Talks
description: Secretary of State John Kerry discussed the Iranian nuclear talks, saying that Israels security is important, but so is the security of all the other countries in the region.

title: Family Tradition in the Saddle
description: The Wright family of Utah has a long history of ranching and rodeoing and hopes a combination of the two can provide for future generations.

title: Hedge Fund Suit Accusing U.S. of Misconduct Faces High Bar
description: When investigators arrive at the door of a hedge fund with a search warrant, the consequences can be devastating. Clients fear being linked to misconduct, and even a history of strong investment returns often cannot stem the tide of withdrawals if there is even a whiff of scandal.

title: Jonas Kaufmann Cancels Wednesdays Carmen at the Met
description: It was one of the hottest opera tickets of the year. With Jonas Kaufmann, the star tenor, scheduled to sing only two performances this season at the Metropolitan Opera  and in one of the most popular operas in the repertoire, Bizets Carmen  both sold out fast.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Giorgio Armani Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: Netanyahus Remarks to Aipac
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel addressed the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, saying that in his speech to Congress he would speak up against Iran and its tentacles of terror.

title: Gordon Dyal, Veteran Deal Maker at Goldman Sachs, to Retire
description: Gordon E. Dyal, a former head of Goldman Sachs mergers business and a veteran deal maker, is retiring, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Monday.

title: In France, Pesticides Get in Way of Natural Wines
description: TOURS, France  The task ahead of me was a two-day tasting marathon of wines with a welter of confusing labels: natural, organic, organic practice and biodynamic. But for Jean Bardet, a semiretired chef with two Michelin stars to his name, there was little confusion about the worthiness of such bottles.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Giorgio Armani Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: Nail Clipping
Gum Snapping
Gyora Benedeks Hidato
description: Our puzzles this week are several Hidato and a numeric puzzle suggested by Gyora Benedek, the Israeli computer scientist and adventurer. We first met Dr. Benedek, who invented the Hidato puzzle, about a year ago (see post here), and its a pleasure to have him back.

title: Nose Sniffling
The Brilliant Boris Nemtsov: A Reformer Who Never Backed Down
description: Eventually theyll arrest someone for murdering Boris Nemtsov, especially after President Vladimir Putin was said to be giving the case his personal attention. The authorities have already begun to spin conspiracy theories, including the outrageous suggestion that he may have been killed by political allies to create a martyr. What will remain is not a murder case, but the image of the opposition politician who had once personified so many of Russias hopes, lying dead within sight of the Kremlin fortress and the whimsical cupolas of St. Basils Cathedral.

title: Maggie Smith Says She Will Leave Downton Abbey After Next Season
description: The Dowager Countess is done and theres no use in trying to convince her otherwise. Maggie Smith, who plays the quip-ready matriarch on the hit British series that just finished its fifth season in the United States, said in an interview with The Sunday Times that she was done with the character following the upcoming season.

title: Knuckle Cracking
Lawyer Put Health Act in Peril by Pointing Out 4 Little Words
description: WASHINGTON  The first lawsuits challenging the Affordable Care Act were still in the early stages, but conservative lawyers were already working on a backup plan in December 2010 if the first line of attack failed.

title: For Richard Princes Fashion Series, an Unlikely Exhibitor
description: All nine of the artists rephotographed advertisements will be shown together for the first time at Nahmad Contemporary.

title: Clive Owen to Make Broadway Debut in Pinters Old Times
description: Clive Owen, an Oscar nominee for Closer who is now starring on the Cinemax series The Knick, will make his Broadway debut in the fall in a revival of Harold Pinters Old Times, Roundabout Theater Company announced on Monday.

title: Games on a Reservation Go By in a Blur
description: FORT DEFIANCE, Ariz.  The Navajo teenagers scamper out of the locker room as if their feet are on fire.

title: Stock Trading Platform IEX Hires Ex-N.Y.S.E. Regulatory Chief
description: IEX, the upstart stock-trading platform that rocketed to prominence last year after being featured in the Michael Lewis book Flash Boys, has hired a former New York Stock Exchange official as it seeks to become a full-fledged stock exchange.

title: 1965: Jets Blast North Vietnam
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam  More than 160 U.S. and Vietnamese Air Force planes hammered two targets in North Vietnam today [March 2] in the biggest air strike to date against the Communists in the North. The massive raid  described as a resounding success  was the first that has been launched as a purely offensive action. All previous U.S. air strikes on the North have been in retaliation for specific Communist attacks in the South.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 3, 1965

title: New Subway Etiquette Campaign: Please Dont Urinate in This Area
description: On a mezzanine level at the West Fourth Street subway station, near a billboard for the New York Lottery and a door that says Supervision Only, transit workers have posted several paper signs.

title: House of Cards Season 3 Episode 6 Recap: Shame On You, Mr. President
description: Season 3 Episode 6 Recap: Chapter 32

title: After Net Neutrality Vote, Wheeler Turns to Salesmanship
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Tom Wheeler has gone from policeman to salesman.

title: A Thin Line of Defense Against Honor Killings
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Faheema stood trembling in the courtyard of the large house, steeling herself for the meeting with her family.

title: Lowering Diabetes Risk After Pregnancy
description: About nine percent of pregnant women have gestational diabetes, which usually goes away after they give birth. But about half these women will develop Type 2 diabetes later in life. A new study suggests two ways to significantly reduce the risk.

title: Its Tough to Be the King Every Night
description: It has been an incredible season for James Harden. The Houston Rockets guard is leading the N.B.A. in scoring, dominated the All-Star Game and has found himself in the conversation for the Most Valuable Player Award. But the Rockets made quite a statement Sunday after an overtime win over the Cleveland Cavaliers when their Twitter account declared Harden the new King James.

title: The Tax Con Cometh
Springs Lightweight Suits
description: Whether slim-cut or slightly slouchy, the new relaxed suiting features a construction that lets you cut loose, anywhere, anytime.

title: Every Woman Who Has Served in the U.S. Senate
description: Of the 1,963 people who have served in the Senate, just 46 have been women, or about 2 percent. Senator Barbara Mikulski, a Democrat from Maryland who announced on Monday that she would not run for re-election, has served longer than any other female senator.

title: Gulf of Mexico Turns Deadly for Dolphins
Google Confirms Plans for Wireless Service
description: Its official: Google wants to offer a wireless service, but not like just any other phone carrier.

title: Bonnie Slotnick Finds a New Home
description: To Browse: Discovering a New Space to Find Old Recipes

title: Goodie Bags Filled With Memories
description: A welcome in-room amenity like a bottle of Champagne or fruit plate is standard at many high-end hotels, but some properties are going beyond the expected greeting by also giving their guests a gift at checkout.

title: Britain Had Wheat Before Farming, Study Says
description: DNA from an underwater site suggests that there was wheat in Britain 8,000 years ago  2,000 years before farming arrived in the region.

title: Good Thing Bumblebees Dont Have Car Keys
description: Bumblebees can remember the patterns, colors and scents of different flowers, researchers have discovered. But memory can fail in the bumblebee, just as it does in humans.

title: Why Schools Should Undermine Moral Teachings
description: The philosophy professor Justin P. McBrayer has lobbed up a fascinating question on the Opinionator blog:Are our schools not just failing to teach morals (something many parents would argue are best taught at home in any case), but actively undermining those teachings?

title: Britains Elite Still Enjoying a Tax Break 100 Years Old
description: LONDON  They are among the British moneyed elite: the head of the nations largest bank, a billionaire hedge fund manager and the owner of some of Londons most luxurious nightclubs.

title: Near or Far, Head South to Escape the Winter
description: We seem to be trapped in a winter of extremes  cold snaps, snowfall that feels fit for a Disney movie, droughts that have farmers almost looking at storms in the Northeast with envy. If you just want to run away from it all, youre not alone. The Travel section has you covered, just in time for spring break.

title: Disclosure Can Produce Meaningful Change
description: In a recent The Trade column, Jesse Eisinger of ProPublica criticizes Justice Louis Brandeiss advice that Sunlight is...the best of disinfectants for social problems. He describes the reliance on transparency and disclosure as an ineffective regulatory crutch, saying that if lawmakers want to end a bad practice, ban it. Having them admit it is not enough.

title: 3 Attica Guards Resign in Deal to Avoid Jail
description: Three guards accused of beating an inmate at the Attica Correctional Facility so severely that doctors had to insert a plate and six pins into his leg each pleaded guilty on Monday to a single misdemeanor charge of misconduct. The last-minute plea deal spared them any jail time in exchange for quitting their jobs.

title: Bangladeshi Police Arrest Suspect in Bloggers Killing
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  Security officials arrested a suspect in the killing of a Bangladeshi-American blogger known for his antipathy toward religion, who was hacked to death in Dhaka, the capital, on Thursday.

title: Hillary Clinton Aides Issue Talking Points on Rebutting Attacks
description: Aides to Hillary Rodham Clinton circulated a series of talking points to allies on Monday to help them respond to a spate of negative news accounts in recent weeks about the Bill, Hillary and Chelsea Clinton Foundation.

title: 3 Israelis Are Charged on Suspicion of Supplying Materials to Hamas Militants
description: JERUSALEM  During Israels 50-day war against Hamas in Gaza last summer, residents of Israels border communities lived in fear of rocket or mortar attacks, or the possibility that Hamas militants could attack Israelis through tunnels.

title: The Nuclear Talks With Iran, Explained
description: What the United States and Iran want out of discussions over Irans nuclear development.

title: In Richard Prince's 'Fashion' Series, A Beautiful  and Prescient  Radicalism
description: The contemporary art market is almost a fraud, the billionaire art dealer David Nahmad famously said to the Independent on Sunday several years ago, following another interview in Forbes in which he called the work of artists like Jeff Koons and Richard Prince luxury products. Asked about his comments, another member of the prominent clan weighed in: I dont think Richard Prince decided to waste his life making trash, so to someone theyre worth something, Helly Nahmad, of the eponymous London-based gallery, told the Financial Times in 2011. What theyre worth is a different argument.

title: Soup Slurping
Ticket Resellers Asking High Prices for Final Grateful Dead Shows
description: The last time Chicagos Soldier Field hosted a Grateful Dead show, there was no such thing as StubHub.

title: 2 Killed in Latest Bombing to Strike Cairo
description: CAIRO  An explosion outside a central courthouse killed two people and injured at least nine others on Monday, extending a series of small bombings around Cairo. Security officials said most of those injured were policemen.

title: Why Warren Buffett Is Worth $72 Billion and Youre Not
description: Consider these two truthful sentences:

title: My Friend Has a Son Who Is Autistic
description: When I attend a school function to watch my 11-year-old, who has a language-based learning disability, I am content to stand solo. I love keeping an eye on him from a distance as he sings in a concert or runs around with his classmates.

title: Tech Deals That Are Poor Fixes for Limp Sales
description: A $15 billion technology M.&A. spree is a poor fix for limp sales.

title: Snip, Snap, Slurp: Misophonia Makes Them Unbearable
description: Popcorn munching? Gum chewing? Knuckle cracking? What sound most grates on your nerves?

title: Questions to Ask a Prospective Financial Adviser
description: Theres a fight brewing in Washington. While fighting in Washington isnt new, the cause of this particular fight might shock you. People are arguing about financial advice. Last week, the debate gained national attention as President Obama waded into the discussion.

title: Five More Years for Judge Judy
description: LOS ANGELES  Judge Judith Sheindlin has signed on for five more televised years of sorting out rancorous rent disputes, adjudicating stranger-than-fiction dognapping cases and, as ever, zinging litigants as coming from a long line of idiots.

title: India Begins Campaign to Eliminate Elephantiasis
description: India recently began one of the biggest drug-distribution campaigns in its history in an effort to eliminate elephants foot disease, also known as elephantiasis or lymphatic filariasis.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Goes on Charm Offensive for Internet.org
description: BARCELONA, Spain  In front of a packed audience here, Mark Zuckerberg turned on the charm.

title: A 125-Year-Old Textiles House Teams Up With a 60s-Inspired Fashion Label
description: When Natasha Garnett profiled the 125-year-old textile company Schumacher for Ts Fall 2014 Womens Fashion issue, she illustrated the brands historic and steadfast dedication to designer collaborations, helmed by its creative director Dara Caponigro. And its latest, a 13-piece capsule collection created with Lisa Perry, is available in New York beginning today at the designers Madison Avenue boutique. The tunics, dresses, pants, coats and skirtare a mashup of the two houses greatest hits: the designer recreated a handful of her signature styles using a selection of Schumachers most popular fabrics. Despite their throwback roots, the resulting looks  60s-inspired silhouettes printed with bright colors and fauna-inspired motifs (zebra stripes, prancing deer, leopard spots)  are youthful and refreshingly modern.

title: Readers Respond: On How We Learned to Kill
description: Timothy Kudos Sunday Review piece, How We Learned to Kill, a reflection on killing from a veteran of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, drewan extraordinary number of comments from veterans of wars past and present.

title: Police Are Criticized for Use of Force in Shooting in Los Angeless Skid Row
description: LOS ANGELES  A line of tents and people huddled in blankets filled the sidewalks of San Pedro Street on Monday in the heart of this citys Skid Row. The occasional police car drove by. In the middle of the block, flowers were piled next to a note bidding goodbye to a man who had called this piece of sidewalk his home until Sunday afternoon.

title: Vitamin-Packed With Promises
description: In the late 1800s a disfiguring and often fatal disease became epidemic in the South. Called pellagra (Italian for rough skin), it caused diarrhea, mental confusion, and severe scaling and flaking of the skin. By 1911, pellagra had become the leading cause of death in asylums. Eventually, the Public Health Service dispatched the physician Joseph Goldberger to determine its cause.

title: Two Strains of H.I.V. Cut Vastly Different Paths
description: Thirty-four years ago, doctors in Los Angeles discovered that some of their patients were succumbing to a normally harmless fungus. It soon became clear that they belonged to a growing number of people whose immune systems were hobbled by a virus, eventually known as human immunodeficiency virus, or H.I.V.

title: Saving Big on Energy Bills, People Take It to the Bank
description: Sometimes, even the supposed experts can lose track of a billion dollars or two. Or, in this case, $100 billion.

title: In Performance | Pinkins and Wiest
description: Tonya Pinkins and Dianne Wiest play co-workers at odds in Joel Drake Johnsons play Rasheeda Speaking. The New Group production was at the Pershing Square Signature Center in 2015.

title: Researchers Link Syrian Conflict to a Drought Made Worse by Climate Change
description: Drawing one of the strongest links yet between global warming and human conflict, researchers said Monday that an extreme drought in Syria between 2006 and 2009 was most likely due to climate change, and that the drought was a factor in the violent uprising that began there in 2011.

title: Termites: Guardians of the Soil
description: The giant termite mounds that rise up from the sands of the African savanna are so distinctive its tempting to give them names, like Art Deco Skyline or Trumpeting Elephant or Flagrantly Obvious Fertility Totem.

title: Infinite Monkey Cage Brings Playful Science Series to U.S.
description: Do not be scared of science. That is the message of The Infinite Monkey Cage, according to one of its hosts, the comedian Robin Ince. The science-meets-comedy radio show, which has been broadcast on BBCs Radio 4 since 2009, has also become one of Britains most popular podcasts, and is gaining a following in the United States. This month, Mr. Ince and his scientist co-host, Brian Cox, are taking the show on a brief American tour, kicking off on Thursday night at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts in New York, where the guests will be the astrophysicists Neil deGrasse Tyson and Janna Levin, the comedian Lisa Lampanelli and the actor Tim Daly.

title: Shooting Style
description: Marie Rime photographs the uniforms of Swiss gun culture.

title: Review: Lucky Alan, Jonathan Lethems Dreamlike Tales of Seclusion
description: In two of the stories in his superfluous new collection, Jonathan Lethem uses the snow globe as a symbol for isolation and removal from the hustle and bustle and Sturm und Drang of ordinary life. Its a favorite image, which has popped up in earlier books like Motherless Brooklyn and Chronic City, and an apt metaphor for the separation that so many of his characters feel, whether its Dylan Ebdus in The Fortress of Solitude, who was bullied as a child, or Lionel Essrog, the detective with Tourettes syndrome in Motherless Brooklyn.

title: Nemtsovs Partner Says Russia Held Her Against Her Will
description: MOSCOW  They met three years ago, by some accounts on a vacation to Turkey, and soon enough became a couple.

title: Saving a River Giant, and a Livelihood
description: In the Brazilian Amazon, conservation efforts have led to a resurgence of the pirarucu, one of the largest freshwater fish in the world.

title: Study Says Pregnant Women in India Are Gravely Underweight
description: NEW DELHI  Her first child survived eight months before succumbing to pneumonia; her second was stillborn; her third, delivered in a rickshaw, gasped for an hour before dying.

title: Extra Sleep Linked With Stroke Risk
description: Sleeping more than eight hours a day is associated with a higher risk for stroke, a new study has found.

title: A Quest to Solve Ceres Mysteries
description: What are the bright spots on Ceres, the largest known asteroid? No one knows, including scientists working on NASAs Dawn mission, which begins orbiting Ceres on Friday. The two reflective spots, in a 57-mile-wide crater, could be ice or salt, the scientists speculate. The team is really, really excited about this feature, because it is unique in the solar system, Carol Raymond, the missions deputy principal investigator, said in a news conference Monday. The mystery will be solved, but it is one thats really got us on the edge of our seats.

title: A Surgery Standard Under Fire
description: What she wanted, the patient told the geriatricians evaluating her, was to be able to return to her condominium in Boston. She had long lived there on her own, lifting weights to keep fit and doing her own grocery shopping, until a heart condition worsened and she could barely manage the stairs.

title: Netanyahu in Washington: High Stakes
description: To the Editor:

title: Attention, All Scientists: Do Improv, With Alan Aldas Help
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y.  Martha Furie stormed into the room and huffily sat down in a chair.

title: Rick Perry Steps Up PAC Staffing
description: Rick Perry, the former Texas governor who ran unsuccessfully for the Republican presidential nomination in 2012, is continuing to put the pieces in place for a 2016 campaign.

title: Should Pregnant Women Eat More Tuna?
description: For years pregnant women have been warned about eating tuna because of concerns about mercury exposure. But a federal panel has reignited the debate about the benefits and risks of eating tuna and other seafood during pregnancy.

title: Gaining Altitude
description: Etihad and the other Persian Gulf airlines operate the latest-generation airplanes, hire younger flight attendants and offer onboard perks that stretch the definition of first class.

title: Arming the Immune System Against Cancer
description: James P. Allison is the chairman of the immunology department at the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. His seminal research opened up a new field in cancer treatment: immunotherapy. Instead of poisoning a tumor or destroying it with radiation, Dr. Allison has pioneered ways to unleash the immune system to destroy a cancer.

title: An East Hampton Bookstore Pops Up in Manhattan
description: To coincide with the Armory Show, the annual contemporary and modern art fair that opens this week in New York, the East Hampton-based bookshop and gallery Harpers Books (Reed Krakoff is a fan) will bring some of its rare inventory to Manhattan for a three-day pop-up at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: Hospital Rating Systems Differ on Best and Worst
description: Four popular national rating systems used by consumers to judge hospitals frequently come to very different conclusions about which hospitals are the best  or worst  potentially adding to the confusion over health care quality, rather than alleviating it, a new study shows.

title: Harrington, 43, Beats the Yips and, in a Playoff, a Rival Half His Age
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Rory McIlroy was not going head-to-head against Rickie Fowler for the Honda Classic crown in a duel of young, photogenic players that no doubt would have piqued the casual sports fans interest in golf. The top-ranked McIlroy missed the cut in the weather-plagued event, and Fowler finished outside the top 40.

title: Venezuela Tells U.S. to Reduce Embassy Staff
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  With diplomatic relations fraying rapidly between the United States and Venezuela, the government of President Nicols Maduro has given the American Embassy here 15 days to come up with a plan to drastically shrink its staff, Venezuelas foreign minister announced Monday.

title: Reactions: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety Advocates Want Harsher Penalties for New Yorks Drivers
description: After Allison Liao, 3, was killed by a car in Queens, the man who was behind the wheel, Ahmad Abu-Zayedeh, was not charged. But last month, his drivers license was revoked by the state, after a long campaign by the girls parents, Amy Tam-Liao and Hsi-Pei Liao.

title: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
description: Theres soccer everywhere you look this week. Unless youre not looking, in which case theres mostly basketball and, here in the Northeast, snow.

title: Shooting of Boris Nemtsov Draws Comparisons to Death of Another Putin Foe
description: LONDON  The fatal shooting in Moscow last week of a Russian opposition leader, Boris Y. Nemtsov, has prompted comparisons with the 2006 poisoning of Alexander V. Litvinenko, another foe of President Vladimir V. Putin, who fled to Britain in 2000 and secured British citizenship weeks before he died of what was almost the perfect poisoning.

title: A Few Reasons to Love Bleeding
description: Q. Does donating blood improve health?

title: Slow Start for The Heidi Chronicles on Broadway
description: Ticket sales were off to a slow start last week for the new Broadway revival of Wendy Wassersteins The Heidi Chronicles, starring Elisabeth Moss of Mad Men fame, according to box office data released on Monday. The Heidi Chronicles, which won both the Tony Award for best play and the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1989, grossed $305,345 for eight performances, or 34 percent of the maximum possible amount  on the low side for a well-known play with a star performer. Ms. Moss is an Emmy Award nominee for her years as the copywriter Peggy Olson on Mad Men.

title: Review: The Man in the Womans Shoes, a Mikel Murfi Solo Play
description: If Mikel Murfi ever fails as an actor (and this seems highly unlikely), he could make a killing at childrens birthday parties. The man has a rare talent for animal sounds. In the brief span of The Man in the Womans Shoes, at the Irish Arts Center, he voices chickens, bees, sea gulls, songbirds, sheep, a pig, a dog and a dying turkey, that last with enough realism to put you off drumsticks for life.

title: Pierre Hardy Shares His Favorite Hometown Haunts in the City of Light
description: Pierre Hardy shoes are as Parisian as escargot. And as Fashion Week kicks off in the City of Light, the revered accessories designer  who has also logged stints at Dior, Herms and Balenciaga and collaborated with Gap, Frdric Malle and Nars  is as excited to be there as any visitor. I love to just hang out in town; I rarely go away for the weekend, he says. Paris is always, in any season, a great relief, and a source of pleasure to look at. Here, the native and Marais resident opens up his Paris black book for T.

title: State to Seek Death Penalty in Killing of Students in North Carolina
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Prosecutors will seek the death penalty for the man charged with the killings of three Arab-American students in a Chapel Hill, N.C., apartment complex, the district attorneys office handling the case said Monday.

title: House of Cards Season 3 Episode 7 Recap: Nothing Is Forever
description: Season 3 Episode 7 Recap: Chapter 33

title: A Refugee Embraces a Visual Language
description: As a young refugee unfamiliar with a new language, Sylvia Plachy learned to watch her surroundings. A new retrospective tracks 50 years of her journey.

title: Court Skeptical of Arizona Plan for Less-Partisan Congressional Redistricting
description: WASHINGTON  An independent redistricting commission created by Arizona voters in 2000 seemed to be in trouble on Monday at the Supreme Court. Several justices suggested that the commission, meant to make the process of drawing congressional district lines less partisan, crossed a constitutional line.

title: Review: Vienna Philharmonics Familiar and Fierce Show of Brahms
description: After City of Dreams, the adventurous and arduous three-week festival that the Vienna Philharmonic presented at Carnegie Hall and elsewhere around the country last year, the orchestra may be forgiven for having reverted to a tidy package of core repertory for its annual weekend in New York. Namely, music of Brahms: It performed his First and Third Symphonies at Carnegie on Friday evening, the Second and Fourth on Saturday evening and the German Requiem on Sunday afternoon, all conducted by Daniele Gatti.

title: Review: In Billy & Billie, a Step-Sibling Romance Tests Taboos
description: Take the time restrictions off of a playwright  Dont worry about saying what you have to say in two-and-a-half hours or less  and what do you get? Something that looks like Billy & Billie, a new half-hour, 10-episode series about stepsibling romance from Neil LaBute that begins Tuesday on DirecTVs Audience Network.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Ukraine and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Review: Alice in Wonderland, by Unsuk Chin, Told With Restraint
description: LOS ANGELES  Beginning with a subterranean, almost inaudible rumble, Unsuk Chins Alice in Wonderland isnt quite the madcap spectacle you might expect from an opera based on Lewis Carrolls novel. While there is ample zaniness in the two hours of music that follow, it is the scores sober core that keeps the operas mood pleasurably disconcerting.

title: Paul Beatty, Author of The Sellout, on Finding Humor in Issues of Race
description: Even in elementary school, the novelist Paul Beatty knew how to make waves with words. At a cafe in the West Village recently, he recalled attending a summer camp in Santa Monica, Calif., where he and other children decorated the outside of a bus in a hippie style. Mr. Beatty painted a poem about the police near the top of the bus, and once on the road his verse attracted the attention of the actual police. I wish I could remember the poem, he said. Something pigs, fuzz. The thing must have been four lines. They made me get out and erase one or two of the words.

title: Billionaire Grocer Is Said to Be a Suitor for The Daily News
description: A few weeks ago, John A. Catsimatidis, the billionaire owner of the grocery chain Gristedes, met Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The Daily News in New York, for lunch at Casa Lever, an Italian restaurant in Manhattan.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Milan Fashion Week Street Style
description: Fashionable men and women at the fall 2015 collection shows.

title: March 2, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Ukraine, Russia, South Africa and China.

title: Los Angeles Police Chief on Shooting
description: Charlie Beck, the Los Angeles police chief, said that in video of a fatal police shooting of a homeless man, a rookie officer can be heard saying, He has my gun.

title: Tatiana TrouvUnwinds History in Public Art Project
description: As a pastoral sculpture socked into the heart of a metropolis, Central Park has fascinated and provoked artists for decades. Claes Oldenburg hired gravediggers to excavate and refill a hole in it, to form an invisible monument. Christo and Jeanne-Claude gated and orange-ified it. Diane Arbus used her camera to draw deeply from its well of the weird. Robert Smithson, creator of the monumental Spiral Jetty in the Great Salt Lake, suggested that the idea belonged to the parks beginnings: He called Frederick Law Olmsted, its chief designer, the first earthwork artist.

title: Milan Fashion Week Street Style
description: For more street style photos, go to nytimesfashion Instagram account.

title: Review: Romantic Piano Quartets, From Chamber Music Society
description: Not every work of music written during the so-called Romantic period fits the most common definition of that word: describing something expressing, or conducive to, amorous feelings. Perhaps the Highly Strung period would be a more accurate way to characterize the 19th century, when raw sensitivity and indulgence in heightened emotions  be they anger, foreboding or desire  prevailed in music.

title: Review: New Releases by Kelly Clarkson, Sannhet and Asleep at the Wheel
description: KELLY CLARKSON

title: The Fashion-Forward Gun Clubs of Switzerland
description: The Swiss photographer Marie Rime grew up with a rifle in her hands. The daughter of a sport shooter, she took up the pastime at 14, and soon won a state championship in riflery. On Saturdays, she says, I would just put my rifle on my back, get on my bike and go to the shooting range.

title: At JPMorgan Chase, Business Tilts Toward the Consumer Side and Away From Wall St.
description: A reversal of fortunes within the financial industry is illustrated in few places more vividly than JPMorgan Chase.

title: Bjrk at MoMA
description: An immersive sonic and visual show that covers more than 20 years of her career.

title: BjrkIs on Display, Up Close and in 3-D at MoMA
description: At the Museum of Modern Art on Sunday afternoon, Bjrk was seemingly everywhere. An artist known as Shoplifter sewed strands of hair onto Bjrks face. Around the corner, a textile conservator restrung pearls onto a topless wedding gown by Alexander McQueen, which was also worn by Bjrk. Nearby, Bjrks crystal-encrusted face floated in midair. A miniature Bjrk was on her way.

title: Tena Stivicic Wins Blackburn Drama Prize
description: The playwright Tena Stivicic was to be awarded the 37th annual Susan Smith Blackburn Prize on Monday night for her play 3 Winters, a dark, era-hopping drama about a Croatian family in post-World War II Zagreb. At a ceremony at Playwrights Horizons, Ms. Stivicic was to receive $25,000 and a numbered print by the artist Willem de Kooning.

title: In Homeland Security Funding Standoff, Business Travelers Face Uncertainty
description: IS this any way to run a government?

title: Merrill Lynch Hires Tax Expert From Credit Suisse
description: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has hired Lewis Steinberg, a senior banker from Credit Suisse, to serve as its in-house tax expert, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Monday.

title: The Cry Being Heard Around Washington: I Need a Netanyahu Ticket
description: WASHINGTON  For Senator Lindsey Graham, the only ticket more in demand than a seat inside the House chamber for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus address to Congress on Tuesday morning would be if it was Garth Brooks  maybe.

title: Nurse Who Contracted Ebola in the U.S. Sues Her Hospital Employer
description: The nurse who was the first person to contract Ebola in the United States filed suit on Monday against the Dallas hospital where she worked, saying it knowingly left workers without the training or equipment needed to handle the disease.

title: Gaining Altitude
description: Etihad and the other Persian Gulf airlines operate the latest-generation airplanes, hire younger flight attendants and offer onboard perks that stretch the definition of first class.

title: Embrace the Adventure, and Find an Even Keel
description: EVEN as a child, I took a couple flights a year. Ive learned to love everything related to flight, so business trips dont bother me.

title: Saudi Award Goes to Muslim Televangelist Who Harshly Criticizes U.S.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  He has publicly declared that the Jews control America, that apostates can be killed, that the United States is the worlds biggest terrorist and that the Sept. 11 attacks were an inside job by President George W. Bush.

title: Prison Terms Are Reduced for Amish in Beard-Cutting Attacks
description: A federal judge on Monday reduced the prison sentences for the leader of a breakaway Amish sect and seven followers who were convicted in a series of beard-cutting attacks on rival Amish in 2011.

title: New York Sponsor of Port Authority Reform Bill Rejects a New Jersey Compromise
description: ALBANY  A legislative sponsor of an effort to overhaul the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said on Monday that a possible compromise bill suggested by a leading New Jersey Republican would not be acceptable in New York, all but dooming its chances as currently imagined.

title: Custers First Stand
description: In July 1864 Lt. Gen. Jubal A. Early led 14,000 battle-hardened and enthusiastic Confederate veterans to within six miles of the new Capitol dome in Washington. Six months and several crushing defeats later, Early found himself wintering in Staunton, Va., with fewer than 2,000 dispirited troops.

title: Removing an Artists Lifework
description: After 40 years in the diamond district of Manhattan, the Ney family is being evicted on March 19. Joel Ney is rushing to move about 4,000 pieces of his fathers artwork from the premises.

title: Under Law, Christie Can Use Exxon Settlement to Help Balance Budget
description: A debate over New Jerseys proposed $250 million settlement of what had been an $8.9 billion pollution lawsuit against Exxon Mobil Corporation has highlighted an obscure provision of a state law that would appear to allow Gov. Chris Christie to apply most if not all of the settlement toward balancing the state budget.

title: Bjrk at MoMA
description: An immersive sonic and visual show that covers more than 20 years of her career.

title: Islanders Trades Bolster Their Roster for the Stanley Cup Push
description: The playoff-bound Islanders made several deals on the N.H.L.s trade deadline Monday.

title: Central Figure in the Atlanta Schools Cheating Scandal Dies
description: ATLANTA  Beverly L. Hall, the former superintendent of the Atlanta public schools who was awaiting a criminal trial for her alleged participation in a conspiracy to alter students standardized test results, died Monday after an extended battle with breast cancer, her legal team said.

title: For the U.S. and China, a Test of Diplomacy on South Sudan
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United States may have midwifed the birth of South Sudan, the worlds youngest nation. But China has quickly become among its most important patrons, building its roads and pumping its oil.

title: A Viral Defense of Russian Imperialism, Addressed to Obama
description: A Russian video bloggers strident defense of his nations invasion and occupation of its neighbors, in the form of an open letter to President Obama uploaded to the web on Saturday, has become an instant hit among Russian nationalists, but raised alarm bells in other former Soviet republics.

title: Senior Myles Mack Doesnt Regret Choosing Rutgers
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Favorite day? The senior guard Myles Mack did not hesitate on that one. It was Dec. 29, 2011, when Rutgers upset No. 10 Florida in a double-overtime thriller during his first season. A heralded class of talented freshmen led the way. Fans stormed the court and celebrated well after workers began to clean up.

title: China Names 14 Generals Suspected of Corruption
description: BEIJING  Chinas military authority on Monday released a list of 14 generals who are under investigation or have been convicted of graft, among them the son of one of Chinas once highest-ranking generals.

title: Cleveland Mayor Apologizes for Language Used to BlameTamir Rice for His Death
description: Moving to stem fresh anger over how Cleveland has handled the killing of 12-year-old Tamir Rice, Mayor Frank G. Jackson apologized on Monday for language that the citys lawyers used in court filings to assert that the boys death was his own fault.

title: Terrorism Case Against Pakistani Man Is Going to Jury
description: As arguments in Abid Naseers trial on terrorism charges came to a close on Monday, jurors had heard from British intelligence officers in disguise, an F.B.I. attach who observed Osama bin Ladens dead body and Mr. Naseer himself arguing that he was an innocent man.

title: Hillary Clinton Used Personal Email Account at State Dept., Possibly Breaking Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Rodham Clinton exclusively used a personal email account to conduct government business as secretary of state, State Department officials said, and may have violated federal requirements that officials correspondence be retained as part of the agencys record.

title: A Yankee Hurler Shows Great Mechanics
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees, who this season will be counting on a starting rotation that appears to be held together by duct tape and baling wire, on Monday employed a pitcher who could throw all day (and all night, too) without wearing out knee cartilage, elbow ligaments or shoulder sockets.

title: A Warning From Buffett About Banks
description: Money-shufflers dont come cheap.

title: New York Fire Dept., Diversifying Ranks, Is Set to Swear In First Lesbian Chaplain
description: Maybe it is her short, spiky hair, or the cigarettes, which she gives to the men repairing the wiring in her Brooklyn apartment. Maybe it is because she swears. For whatever reason, the Rev. Ann Kansfield does not fit the stereotype of a minister.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 2, 2015
description: March 2, 2015

title: Climate Change Researcher Offers a Defense of His Practices
description: The scientist at the center of a controversy over fossil-fuel funding for climate research denounced his critics on Monday and said that he would be happy to comply with possible additional disclosure requirements from scientific journals publishing his papers.

title: Senate Democrats Block Joint Negotiations on Homeland Security Funding
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats on Monday blocked a House attempt to force joint negotiations over legislation to fund the Department of Homeland Security through the fiscal year.

title: Europe Unlikely to Meet Climate Goal, Study Finds
description: BERLIN  The European Union will fail to meet an ambitious goal of significantly reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 unless it takes more aggressive measures to limit the use of fossil fuels and adopts new environmental policies, according to a report scheduled for release on Tuesday.

title: Libyan Generals Promotion Could Hinder United Nations Peace Talks
description: MISURATA, Libya  The speaker of Libyas internationally recognized Parliament named Gen. Khalifa Hifter on Monday to the recently created position of commander in chief of the army, potentially hindering United Nations-sponsored talks to end the countrys internal strife.

title: Massachusetts: Boat Is Subject of Sparring in Bombing Case
description: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the defendant in the 2013 bombing of the Boston Marathon, said Monday that they wanted the jury in his trial to view the entire boat in which he hid while the authorities searched for him several days after the bombing, not just cut-out panels on which he is said to have written a message. During a hearing at Bostons federal courthouse, William Fick, a defense lawyer, called the boat a powerful piece of evidence and compared Mr. Tsarnaevs lying in it to the way a body might lie in a crypt, adding that he did not see why the boat could not be brought to the courthouse. Prosecutors said that the suggestion was impractical, in part because the boat is still covered in blood and broken glass, and that many photographs of it exist. Judge George A. OToole Jr. said he may wish to view the boat himself before making a decision. Also Monday, defense lawyers filed their fourth change-of-venue motion with the court. The jury is to be seated on Tuesday, and opening arguments are expected to begin Wednesday.

title: Sentencing for Former Principal at Bronx High School Is Delayed
description: A former principal at Cardinal Hayes High School who was charged with stealing thousands of dollars from the Bronx institution was given an extra two weeks on Monday to pay about $8,200 in restitution to avoid going to jail for one year.

title: Review: The Mystery of Love and Sex Looks at Identity and Secrets Too
description: The detective work in The Mystery of Love & Sex, a perfectly wonderful new play by Bathsheba Doran that opened on Monday at the Mitzi Newhouse Theater, extends well beyond the matters of high importance referred to in the title. In this tender and funny exploration of the lives of two couples from two generations, Ms. Doran also probes such fertile mysteries as the fluidity of identity, our ability to keep secrets from both our family and even ourselves, and the difficulty  and the rewards  of forgiveness.

title: Gamblers Last Words
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Each generation likes to think they invented stuff. Nothing angers a young person who thinks they have come up with a spiffy and original idea more than to find out that someone in the past had thought of it first. I believe thats because we, as a species, are still hunter-gatherers at our core and the biggest piece of meat always went to he who felled the animal.

title: Some Owners of Private Colleges Turn a Tidy Profit by Going Nonprofit
description: After a recent government crackdown on the multibillion-dollar career-training industry, stricter limits on student aid and devastating publicity about students hobbled by debt and useless credentials, some for-profit schools simply shut down.

title: 2 Veterans and 2 Rookies Seek Mets Last Bullpen Slot
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Around 11 a.m. Monday, on one of the main fields at the Mets spring training complex, Matt Harvey toed the rubber for his latest bullpen session. A horde of fans watched his every move. General Manager Sandy Alderson, Manager Terry Collins and several other members of the teams hierarchy made sure to be there, too.

title: Monroe Freedman, Influential Voice on Legal Ethics, Dies at 86
description: Monroe H. Freedman, a dominant figure in legal ethics whose work helped chart the course of lawyers behavior in the late 20th century and beyond, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Toronto Police Say Tunnel Mystery Is Solved
description: OTTAWA  Torontos mystery tunnel has turned out to be a place for a couple of guys to get away from it all, more a man cave than a terrorist threat.

title: Giants Pierre-Paul Gets Franchise Tag; Lions Suh Does Not
description: In a move that was expected, the Giants on Monday designated defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul as their franchise player, a maneuver that virtually ensures that he will remain with the team at least one more season.

title: Australia to Send More Troops to Iraq as Trainers in ISIS Fight
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Australia on Tuesday expanded its commitment to the international coalition fighting the Islamic State extremist group, with Prime Minister Tony Abbott announcing that an additional 300 troops would be sent to Iraq to train local forces.

title: Better Call Saul Recap: Of Sound Mind
description: Season 1, Episode 5: Alpine Shepherd Boy

title: Rangers Mats Zuccarello Gets New Deal, Then Gives Signature Effort
description: An important player made his Rangers debut on Monday, but the team relied on an established, popular commodity to defeat the N.H.L.-best Nashville Predators, 4-1, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Obama Calls for Changes in Policing After Task Force Report
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday called for prompt action to change police practices across the country after the deaths of unarmed black men in Ferguson, Mo., and Staten Island at the hands of white officers exposed frustrations about law enforcement in minority communities.

title: Bruised Hip of Nets Teletovic Leads to Blood Clot Awareness
description: It was in mid-December that Mirza Teletovic of the Nets first began feeling, in his words, weak, weird and kind of dizzy. Initially, though, there was no discernible reason.

title: Playing a Game One Way: Fast
description: Recent basketball matchups between two high schools on the Navajo reservation in Arizona showcased the up-tempo style known as rez ball.

title: Ernie Hemmings, Founder of a Bible of Classic Cars, Dies at 88
description: In 1945, when Ernie Hemmings took over the auto parts business his father had founded in Quincy, Ill., Model T and Model A Fords were still too contemporary to be called classics.

title: Playing a Game One Way: Fast
description: Recent basketball matchups between two high schools on the Navajo reservation in Arizona showcased the up-tempo style known as rez ball.

title: Larger-Than-Life Advertising Imagery, Brought Down to Size
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: David Letterman: A Look Back
description: After 33 years as the cigar-chomping, larger-than-life face of late-night television, David Letterman, 67, will count down his last top-ten list when the final episode of "Late Show with David Letterman" airs in May. The Indianapolis native grew up worshiping Johnny Carson, and after getting his start as a wisecracking TV weatherman, went on to host both "Late Night" on NBC and "Late Show" on CBS. Renowned for his biting wit and hard-nosed interview style, Letterman has made his name poking fun at his employers and quarreling with guests like Madonna and Cher. Now, as he prepares to say goodbye to the Ed Sullivan Theater, a look back at the career of TV's most lovable misanthrope.

title: In Buenos Aires, a Hub of Local Culture Under One Exquisite Roof
description: Over the weekend, a hybrid concept space called Casa Cavia opened its doors in the upscale Palermo Chico neighborhood in Buenos Aires. The building, which dates back to 1927 and was originally built as a two-story residential home, retains much of its original design but was recently upgraded by its new owner, the restaurateur and film producer Lupe Garcia. Inspired by local cafes from the 1920s and 1930s, she recruited KallosTurin architects to integrate marble, brass, leather and terrazzo floors into the space, which now houses a restaurant and bar, patisserie, flower shop, perfumery, bookstore and publisher all under one exquisite roof.

title: A New Chapter
description: In the reassembly of a books torn-out pages, the artist Mark Hagen finds a symbol of rebirth to echo the poet Michael Dickmans sonnet about welcoming a child into the world.

title: Figures From U.S.-Led Coalition Show Heavy 2014 Losses for Afghan Army
description: WASHINGTON  The Afghan Army lost more than 20,000 fighters and others last year largely because of desertions, discharges and deaths in combat, according to figures to be released Tuesday, casting further doubt on Afghanistans ability to maintain security without help from United States-led coalition forces.

title: Word of the Day | demographic
description: demographic  \de-m-gra-fik, de-m-\  noun and adjective

title: A Polarized Court, Weighing a Reversal of the Safety Net
description: The Supreme Court has become a more partisan institution in recent decades, more closely resembling the other branches of government than it once did. This week will start to show just how partisan the court has become.

title: The Health Care Supreme Court Case: Who Would Be Affected?
description: A look at the major issues at stake in King v. Burwell and the results of the ruling.

description: FRONT PAGE

description: I cannot go back home, because they will kill me.

title: Obama Expresses Concern Over Chinas Rules for Tech Firms
description: Chinas regulations on foreign technology companies are attracting criticism from the highest levels of the United States government  including, now, from President Obama.

title: Leaving and Cleaving
description: So much of life is about leave-taking: moving from home to college, from love to love, from city to city and from life stage to life stage.

title: Finding Refuge in a Visual Language
description: Sylvia Plachys approach to photography has remained constant, even if her gear or technique has changed at times. She tries to make everything disappear, to forget who she is. For one, she does not like to talk when she takes pictures. Of course, you have to with people, she said. Sometimes. But I usually prefer just to smell it and be there and understand it through instinct.

title: Will the Supreme Court Say No to Gerrymandering?
description: The citizens of Arizona  like so many others nationwide  were long fed up with their elected officials drawing skewed electoral districts to keep themselves, and the majority party, in power.

title: How Warren Buffett Does It
description: Fifty years ago, a young investor named Warren Buffett took control of a failing textile company, Berkshire Hathaway. I found myself ... invested in a terrible business about which I knew very little, Buffett relates in his annual letter to shareholders, which was released over the weekend. I became the dog who caught the car.

title: Need for New Antibiotics
description: To the Editor

title: Diet Advice and Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Are You Really Allergic to Antibiotics?
description: NOVI, Mich.  ALLERGIC reactions to antibiotics can be severe, including symptoms ranging from hives and wheezing to anaphylactic shock. People with such allergic reactions are right to steer clear. The problem is that many, and probably most, people who say theyre allergic to antibiotics actually arent. For penicillin, the most commonly reported allergy, many studies have estimated that up to 90 percent of claims of allergies are not legitimate.

title: To Hurt ISIS, Squeeze the Cash Flow
description: The fight against the Islamic State must be a multipronged effort, designed to counter the terrorists, their ideology and their murderous strategy on every level.

title: The Education of Jihadi John
description: LONDON  LAST week, the man called Jihadi John by the worlds media was unmasked as Mohammed Emwazi, a Kuwaiti-born Muslim and naturalized British citizen from London. Not only that, but the Islamic States most notorious Western recruit was identified as a graduate in computer science from the University of Westminster.

title: Test Yourself | The Winter That Wont End
description: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 27 article, With White-Knuckle Grip, Februarys Cold Clings to New York.

title: Confessions of a Pebble Thief
description: During my first year of therapy with Dr. Conger, I began what started as a random gesture and soon became a ritual. After each session, on the short, pebbly path from his home office to the street, Id secretly pick up a small rock and pocket it.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE ARTIST (2011) George Valentin (Jean Dujardin, in an Oscar-winning performance), a silent-screen star, finds his luster fading when he refuses to speak on film with the arrival of sound, while Peppy Miller (Brnice Bejo), a young extra he helped get a break, becomes the next big thing. Then Peppy insists that Valentin star in her next movie. This film, written and directed by Michel Hazanavicius, also won for best director and best picture. Though its protagonist mourns the arrival of sound, The Artist itself is more interested in celebrating the range and power of a medium that can sparkle, swoon and suffer so beautifully that it doesnt really need to have anything to say, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, choosing the film as a critics pick. And because of the expressiveness and dexterity of Mr. Dujardin and Ms. Bejo  they dance beautifully and also portray emotion with just the right blend of naturalism and melodramatic exaggeration  The Artist is more than a clever pastiche of antique amusements, he wrote. It may be something less than a great movie, but it is an irresistible reminder of nearly everything that makes the movies great.

title: What Makes a Good Teacher
Barclays Logs $268 Million 2014 Loss, After Charges for Potential Legal Costs
description: LONDON  The British bank Barclays said on Tuesday that it fell to a loss in 2014, its annual results dragged down by charges related to potential fines and litigation costs for conduct by its employees. It also posted lower income in its investment bank as it continues to shrink that business.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Natures Fighter Jets With Flapping Wings
description: In Natures Fighter Jets With Flapping Wings, James Gorman writes about new research on how hawks capture their prey.

title: What Sounds Annoy You?
description: Gum snapping? Soup slurping? Dog barking? Popcorn munching?

title: Simon Rattle to Return to His Roots, Taking Over the London Symphony
description: Their long flirtation is over, and now they are engaged: Simon Rattle, the Liverpool-born maestro who rose to become chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic, said on Tuesday that he would return to Britain in 2017 as music director of the London Symphony Orchestra.

title: Driven | 2015 Volkswagen Golf TSI
description: The classic silhouette of the Volkswagen Golf hasnt changed much in 40 years, but its high-end touches and fuel-efficient power make it a good value.

title: Video Review: 2015 Volkswagen Golf, a Crowd-Pleaser in Many Forms
description: THE Volkswagen Golf was introduced in 1974, effectively replacing the original peoples car, the Beetle. Now, 40 years later, Golf is not as beloved (theres no reboot of The Love Bug with a Golf as Herbie, is there?), but this seventh-generation hatchback deserves immense respect. It has won nearly every award, including North American Car of the Year and World Car of the Year.

title: BlackBerry Announces Leap Phone, Moving Back Toward Touch Screens
description: BARCELONA, Spain  After returning in force to its keyboard roots last year, BlackBerry jumped back into touch-screen phones this week at the Mobile World Congress here, announcing the five-inch BlackBerry Leap.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: David Vanns Aquarium
description: David Vanns new novel, Aquarium, about a lonely young girl who meets an old man at the Seattle Aquarium, begins on a deceptively light note. Its cinematic quality is due largely to a series of lovely, well-curated fish photographs that accompany 12-year-old Caitlins observation of the exotic fauna. But the momentary lightness of these early pages soon unspools into psychological darkness  and the intricate, colorful pictures diminish  as Caitlin moves away from the tranquillity and beauty of the aquarium and into the more dangerous spaces of a world populated by humans.

title: Neil Gaimans Trigger Warning
description: If there is any contemporary cognate to the kind of literary celebrity once enjoyed, in a vastly different cultural setting, by Charles Dickens or Leo Tolstoy, it is surely found in Neil Gaiman. A wildly popular tale-spinner as well as a writer of considerable gifts and transcendent ambition, Gaiman has been embraced by critics even as he has amassed a Kardashian-scale Twitter following. He has written novels for children and comic books for adults (advancing both forms in the process), and vice versa.

title: Ascap Topped $1 Billion in Revenue Last Year, Lifted by Streaming
description: Ascap, the music licensing agency, is in one sense fighting for its survival, seeking to change decades-old rules to fit the economics of online music. In another, it is finding ways to distribute more money than ever to its thousands of songwriters.

title: New York Today: Boys of Spring
description: Good morning on this chilly Tuesday.

title: 20 Killed as Bus Falls Off Cliff in Central China
description: BEIJING  The weeks around the start of the Lunar New Year are busy ones for entertainers in China, like acrobats and traveling opera troupes. But the journeys of one such group during the nascent Year of the Sheep ended in disaster when a bus carrying 33 members plunged off a cliff in central China on Monday night, killing 20 people on board and injuring the other 13.

title: European Banking Regulator Postpones Next Stress Tests to 2016
description: LONDON  European banks will have another year to prepare for the next round of stress tests that will examine the ability of the regions lenders to survive a potential financial crisis or severe economic downturn.

title: In Congress, Netanyahu Faults Bad Deal on Iran Nuclear Program
description: WASHINGTON  With dark warnings and a call to action, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel used one of the worlds most prominent venues on Tuesday to denounce what he called a bad deal being negotiated with Iran and to mount an audacious challenge to President Obama.

title: Cross Section of Democrats to Snub Netanyahus Speech to Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Some are standing with President Obama. Some are protesting the actions of the House speaker, John A. Boehner. Still others say they do not want to be props in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus re-election campaign.

title: For Netanyahu and Obama, Difference Over Iran Became a Chasm
description: WASHINGTON  Over six years of bitter disagreements about how to deal with the Iranian nuclear threat, President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel kept running into one central problem: The two leaders never described their ultimate goal in quite the same way.

title: In Chapel Hill, Suspects Rage Went Beyond a Parking Dispute
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  On the last day of Razan Mohammad Abu-Salhas life, it was too cold to run.

title: Man Convicted of Rape in Delhi Blames Victim
description: NEW DELHI  In the months after the death of a young woman who was brutalized and gang-raped on a moving bus in New Delhi in 2012, thousands of politicians, activists and ordinary citizens crowded Indias airwaves and its public spaces to say their piece about the crime.

title: The Loser Edit That Awaits Us All
description: If you have ever watched a reality TV show and said, Hes going home tonight, you know what the loser edit is. I imagine it started as a matter of practicality. If you have 20 contestants, they cant all receive equal airtime. When an obscure character gets the heave-ho, the producers have to cobble together a coherent story line. Intersperse the snippets across the hour, and we can identify sins and recognizable human frailty that need to be punished. Anyone tuning in for the first time catches up quickly. The loser edit is not just the narrative arc of a contestant about to be chopped, or voted off the island, whatever the catchphrase. It is the plausible argument of failure.

title: Letter of Recommendation: LaCroix Sparkling Water
description: I was introduced to them at work, the same place where most of us worry about contracting respiratory viruses. Id just landed a job in sunny Los Angeles, where I ate breakfast, lunch and dinner at a standing desk in a windowless office. I was paid more money than Id ever made before, which was just enough that I could never stop counting it, over and over until it lost meaning, like that thing that happens when you do acid and stare at your hand.

title: Larry Wilmore Has No Beef With Bill OReilly
description: The Nightly Show host talks about white privilege, his In Living Color days and the pressure of replacing Stephen Colbert.

title: Today in Politics
South Korea Tightens Rules Against Gifts to Fight Graft
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The National Assembly of South Korea passed an anticorruption law on Tuesday that calls for up to three years in prison for public servants, journalists and teachers who accept single cash donations or gifts valued at more than a million won, or about $900.

title: Florida Records Raise Questions About Jeb Bushs 2008 Vote
description: In the final stretch of the 2008 presidential campaign, Jeb Bush appeared in a television ad urging Floridians to support John McCain, the Republican nominee, at the polls.

title: A Team Goes Decades Between Innings
description: Members of New York Universitys first varsity baseball team in 41 years may be too young to understand the magnitude of the challenges they face.

title: Jurors Chosen for Dzhokhar Tsarnaevs Trial in Boston Marathon Bombings
description: BOSTON  Dzhokhar Tsarnaev sat in the federal courthouse here on Tuesday in front of 64 prospective jurors who were waiting to see who among them might decide whether he would live or die.

title: Morning Agenda: Buffetts Warning on Banks
description: BUFFETTS WARNING ON BANKS | Warren E. Buffett has long ridiculed the financial industry. But his annual letter to shareholders seemed to amp up the pugnacity and was clearly noted by the industry, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. Mr. Buffett used his letter, published over the weekend, to warn his followers about the Streets denizens. He criticized investment bankers for urging acquirers to pay up to 50 percent premiums over market price for publicly held businesses and railed against spinoffs.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Feb. 24-March 2, 2015
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Refresco Gerber Plans I.P.O. in Amsterdam
description: LONDON  Refresco Gerber, one of Europes largest bottlers of soft drinks and fruit juices, said on Tuesday that it planned to pursue an initial public offering in Amsterdam.

title: WNYC and BAM Announce RadioLoveFest Lineup
description: A teen-queen convergence, a Mexican musical tribute to Morrissey, and the financial pillow talk of artistic power couples are on the schedule for the second RadioLoveFest, produced by WNYC and the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Words We Love Too Much
description: We are very fond of the word swath, using it well over 200 times a year in recent years. Unfortunately, as my colleague Gina Lamb points out, many of those uses are at best distantly related to the words precise meaning. And sometimes we mix it up with a different word, swathe.

title: In Performance: Tonya Pinkins and Dianne Wiest of Rasheeda Speaking
description: This weeks video features the Tony Award-winning actress Tonya Pinkins and the Oscar-winning actress Dianne Wiest as co-workers at odds in Rasheeda Speaking, written by the playwright Joel Drake Johnson. In this scene, Jaclyn (Ms. Pinkins), an African-American receptionist, learns that Ileen (Ms. Wiest), her white co-worker, has been named the office manager. Directed by Cynthia Nixon for the New Group, the show is at the Pershing Square Signature Center through March 22.

title: Netanyahu Speech Has Eager Audience in Iran
description: TEHRAN  The tensions between the United States and Israel over how to address Irans nuclear program and a politically divisive speech Tuesday by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to the United States Congress are playing to an eager audience in Tehran.

title: Holocaust Survivor Band
description: This short documentary profiles two elderly Holocaust survivors in Florida who recently formed their own klezmer band.

title: Holocaust Survivor Band
description: Like many survivors of the Holocaust, after World War II, Saul Dreier and Reuwen (Ruby) Sosnowicz moved to America, started families and careers, grew old, and retired to Florida. For these octogenarians, settling near Boca Raton could have been the last chapter in their story.

title: Daily Report: Chinas Rules for Foreign Tech Firms Draw Concern From Obama
description: Chinas regulations on foreign technology companies are attracting criticism from the highest levels of the United States government  including, now, from President Obama, Gerry Doyle reports.

title: An Armenian Hero at the Garden
description: Dear Diary:

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Citigroup to Sell Its Subprime Lender OneMain to Springleaf for $4.25 Billion
description: Citigroup is selling its subprime consumer loan unit to Springleaf Holdings, another large subprime lender, for $4.25 billion.

title: In Fact and Fiction, Mayor de Blasio Becomes a TV Fixture
description: He is the politically correct mayor on Law & Order: Special Victims Unit, resented by hard-boiled detectives for his liberal views.

title: Martin OMalley Snuffs Out Speculation on a Senate Run
description: Former Gov. Martin OMalley of Maryland moved quickly on Tuesday to stifle speculation that he might run for the seat of Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, who announced the day before that she was retiring.

title: Last-Minute Spring Break Trips, Away From the Party Set

title: Iraqi Campaign to Drive ISIS From Tikrit Reveals Tensions With U.S.
description: BAGHDAD  Tensions between Iraq and the United States over how to battle the Islamic State broke into the open on Tuesday, as Iraqi officials declared that they would fight on their own timetable with or without American help, and as United States warplanes conspicuously sat out the biggest Iraqi counteroffensive yet amid concerns over Irans prominent role.

title: A Reading of New Things by Michael Dickman
description: The American poet Michael Dickman ruminates on fatherhood.

title: The Doom of the American System?
description: Voxs Matt Yglesias hasan essay this weekmaking an extended, detailed version of a casethat he (and others) have made before: That our era of partisan and ideological polarization is exposing weaknesses inherent in Americas presidential system of government, and that those weaknesses may threaten the stability, if not the survival, of the American constitutional order. Its an essay that I suspect will be dismissed unread by a number of conservatives as just the latest iteration of the America the ungovernable/the systemhas failed the president genre popular among liberal writers in the waning days of strugglingDemocratic administrations. (Well, Jimmy Carters, in particular.) But Yglesiass argument, to his credit, isnta lament for brilliant liberal reforms thwarted by filibustering bad guys and Madisonian mistakes; instead, heargues that President Obama has found ways to govern in the face of gridlock, mostly by the creative/Caesarist application of executive power to domestic policy, and that the next president, Republican or Democratic, will probably find ways to do the same. His point is that governance is increasing happening outside constitutional norms, not that it isnt happening at all, and that its happening that way for reasons that are independent of particular chief executives and whose influence neither political party is likely to soon roll back.

title: House Approves Homeland Security Budget, Without Strings
description: WASHINGTON  The fight over funding the Department of Homeland Security that began with Republicans thundering about a lawless president abusing power to change immigration policy ended with a quiet capitulation Tuesday when the House voted to fund the agency and avert a partial shutdown.

title: In Buenos Aires, a Hub of Local Culture Under One Exquisite Roof
description: The new Casa Cavia features a patisserie, flower shop, perfumery, bookstore, publisher and, of course, restaurant and bar.

title: Two Minutes to Midnight for the Worlds Tiniest Cetacean  Mexicos Vaquita
description: If there were a Doomsday Clock for species on the brink of extinction, the minute hand for the vaquita  a tiny porpoise restricted to waters near the Colorado River delta in the Gulf of California  would be nudging midnight.

title: At Geneva Auto Show, Worry About Silicon Valley
description: GENEVA  Dieter Zetsche, the chief executive of Daimler, began a meeting with reporters at the Geneva International Motor Show on Tuesday by half-jokingly asking them not to spend too much time talking about Apple.

title: Indian State Bans Possession and Sale of Beef
description: MUMBAI, India  The state that includes Mumbai, Indias financial capital, this week became the latest state to ban the possession and sale of beef, imposing fines and up to five years in prison for violations.

title: 1940: Stained Glass Stored for War
description: Some 18,000 square meters, or nearly five acres, of Medieval stained glass from the churches and cathedrals of France has been packed in more than 7,000 cases and stored away for safekeeping, it was revealed yesterday [March 3] with the publication of reports given at the last meeting of the Commission of Historic Monuments. In addition, 236 historic buildings have been reinforced in their most vulnerable parts by nearly 2,000,000 sandbags. Works of art from churches and museums have been shipped to various parts of the country. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 4, 1940

title: Petraeus Reaches Plea Deal Over Giving Classified Data to His Lover
description: WASHINGTON  David H. Petraeus, the best-known military commander of his generation, has reached a plea deal with the Justice Department and admitted providing his highly classified journals to a mistress when he was the director of the C.I.A.

title: Filmmaker on Indian Rapists Comments
description: Leslee Udwin, a British filmmaker who interviewed one of the men convicted of raping and killing a woman in a brutal 2012 gang attack on a New Delhi bus, said Mukesh Singh blamed the victim.

title: Government Declassifies Surveillance Court Documents on Raw Take Sharing
description: In response to Freedom of Information Act lawsuits by The New York Times and the Electronic Frontier Foundation, the government has declassified a set of previously secret motions and rulings involving the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. The documents relate to the spy courts then-secret decision in 2002 to eliminate a rule that required the Federal Bureau of Investigation to remove names and irrelevant information about innocent Americans picked up as part of wiretapping under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act before sharing information with the National Security Agency and the Central Intelligence Agency  and, starting in 2012, the National Counterterrorism Center.

title: Memorial for Nemtsov, Assassinated Critic of Putin, Draws Thousands

title: Developing Baby, Developing Dad

title: 1965: Congo Jails Unesco Teacher
description: LEOPOLDVILLE  A UN-sponsored teacher in the Congo was behind bars today, two others in hiding, three awaiting imminent expulsion, and one in refuge in the Polish embassy. It was a part of continuing Congolese police harassment of United Nations employees here, UN sources said, in spite of Premier Moise Tshombes order that such harassment stop. A senior UN official said the situation would be comical if it werent so tragic. The incident came 11 days after 13 United Nations teachers and their 22 dependents were expelled, only to be invited back to the Congo hours after their plane left for Athens.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 4, 1965

description: The coffee climate in Paris has changed. In the last two years, the caffeinated brew has evolved from much-maligned to much-adored by a burgeoning set of specialty coffee aficionados. But with new openings every few months, its ironically becoming a greater challenge to seek out an above-average cup in the rapidly maturing market. Once you get past the familiar allure of a place  colorful ceramic mugs, La Marzocco machinery, distressed wood interiors, artisanal cakes and tattooed baristas  how do you determine what is actually good?

title: An Easier Way to Fight Bullying?

title: Restaurant Review: Via Carota in the West Village
description: Hanging from Via Carotas ceiling, menacing a large farmhouse table that had been surrounded by smiling customers just a few minutes earlier, was a row of long iron spikes, bent into hooks at their ends. Theyd been retrofitted with light bulbs to make a functional if terrifying chandelier, but what was their original purpose? Several possibilities suggested themselves, from medieval torture device to a particularly inhumane way of catching fish.

And now, just as the theoretical-minded Constellations is winding down its run at Manhattan Theater Club this month, the club announced on Tuesday that it will produce another new play this spring that has echoes of quantum mechanics  this one by Mr. Stephens.

description: Films covering subjects as diverse as sake and nuclear power plants will be in competition at this years Tribeca Film Festival, organizers announced Tuesday. The world narrative competition will feature 12 films, with James Franco, Faith Hill, Richard Gere and Olivia Wilde among the stars. The dozen films in the world documentary competition include new work from Albert Maysles, Ricki Stern and Annie Sundberg. And the Viewpoints section features 27 films from around the world raising questions of identity.

title: Even Composting Comes With Sticker Shock
description: EVERETT, Wash.  The most bedeviling problem for the company that turns most of the Puget Sound regions kitchen waste into compost is on a piece of fruit. Almost every piece of fruit.

title: The Contemporaries Looks Forward at the Ever-Changing Art World
description: When Roger White, the artist and co-founder of the art journal Paper Monument, went to California to meet with the conceptual art pioneer Stephen Kaltenbach, he saw much of the artists life there: his home in Davis, his studio, his unfinished projects. Kaltenbach told White about his early career in New York, living in SoHo back when it was in its artistic prime. Kaltenbach even explained how, after a number of LSD trips, he began to hear what he interprets to be the voice of God. I was hearing God, he was telling me things that were going to happen, and they would happen. It was just not possible.

title: Ferguson Police Routinely Violate Rights of Blacks, Justice Dept. Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Ferguson, Mo., is a third white, but the crime statistics compiled in the city over the past two years seemed to suggest that only black people were breaking the law. They accounted for 85 percent of traffic stops, 90 percent of tickets and 93 percent of arrests. In cases like jaywalking, which often hinge on police discretion, blacks accounted for 95 percent of all arrests.

title: Tips to Reduce Food Waste
description: Being a better cook is more than mastering recipes. Its also getting the most from your food, wasting little and repurposing leftovers in creative, even ingenious ways. Below, Food reporters and editors share their ideas for improving kitchen storage and using up odds and ends. Have a suggestion? Post it in the comments section.

title: Starve a Landfill
description: SEATTLE  The nations first citywide composting program based largely on shame began here in January.

title: Citigroup to Benefit From Losing Its Most Profitable Unit
description: Trust Citigroup to benefit from getting rid of its most profitable business. The huge bank has at last sold its subprime consumer finance unit OneMain Financial to a rival, Springleaf, for $4.25 billion. The unit has generated returns that far exceed anything else at Citigroup. And yet the deal provides all manner of relief for the lender run by Michael L. Corbat.
