title: Countries Questioning Indonesias Push to Execute Drug Offenders
description: JAKARTA  Declaring illegal drug use a national emergency, the Indonesian government has embarked on a campaign of executions of drug offenders, most of them foreigners convicted of smuggling. The executions have alienated the countrys allies and set off diplomatic disputes on three continents.

title: Germany to Bolster Investment in Cities and Towns
description: BERLIN  Germany announced on Tuesday that it would commit an additional 5 billion euros to helping the countrys needy municipalities, sweetening a 10 billion, or $11.2 billion, investment plan announced last fall.

description: ITHACA, N.Y.  After one of his final basketball practices at Cornell, Shonn Miller sat in the bleachers at Newman Arena, his eyes fixed on teammates who were still shooting jumpers.

description: The brownstones off Tompkins Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant are lined up like stripes of Neapolitan ice cream: brown, white, pinky-beige.

Burwell, the case that could decide the fate of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, the landmark Obamacare legislation passed by Congress in 2010. Emily Bazelon, a staff writer for the magazine, and Adam Liptak, The Timess Supreme Court correspondent, have been exchanging emails about whats at stake in the case and how the court might approach its decision.

description: Was it a delayed reaction to the Reagan era, eight years of watching a cowboy president ride horses on his California ranch? Something, anyway, made the early 1990s an exceptionally rich time for unconventional westerns.

description: President Obama said that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel didnt offer any viable alternatives on Iran during his address to Congress.

title: Review: Eberhardts Fierce Ride, in The Nomad
description: Shoulders back, chin out, the young woman in the fez is bemused, defiant, yet intrigued by her circumstances. I am dead; this is the state of things, Isabelle Eberhardt sings at the start of The Nomad, and she seems curiously willing to make the most of it.

title: Upholding Internet Sales Tax Law, a Justice Invites a New Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday handed a victory to a trade group challenging a Colorado law seeking to aid state authorities in the collection of sales taxes on out-of-state purchases made online.

title: First Draft Focus: A Clean Bill for Homeland Security
Review: Sarah Manguso Offers Crumbs Relating to Her Diary
description: Sarah Mangusos best book, The Two Kinds of Decay, came out seven years ago. Its about her long battle with a crippling neurological disease, one that forced her during her 20s to have her plasma replaced more than 50 times. Its a harrowing book. Its also a funny one. A boyfriend visits her in the hospital and declares her condition greasy but stable.

title: New York City Plans to Study the Diversity of Its Cultural Groups
description: In a major study to be undertaken this summer, the de Blasio administration will review the diversity of the boards, staffs and audiences of New York City cultural organizations, such as museums, orchestras and dance troupes.

title: Mr. Netanyahus Unconvincing Speech to Congress
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel could not have hoped for a more rapturous welcome in Congress. With Republicans and most Democrats as his props, he entered the House of Representatives to thunderous applause on Tuesday, waving his hand like a conquering hero and being mobbed by fawning lawmakers as he made his way to the lectern.

title: Review: Roman Rabinovich Plays Bach and More at SubCulture
description: Sometimes a concert appearance by a young artist results from winning a competition. Mostly, though, artists are engaged because the director of a hall is interested.

title: Review: Ekmeles Performs John Cage at the Avant Music Festival
description: In 2006, Trogen, a Swiss town, began hosting a series of performances of the complete choral works by Bach, with their sequence determined by the liturgical calendar for which they were written. According to the Swiss J. S. Bach Foundation, which is behind the project, the series will have covered all of his cantatas, masses, oratorios and motets by 2030.

title: Karl Lagerfeld on Fur (Yea), Selfies (Nay) and Keeping Busy
description: MILAN  Karl Lagerfeld, arguably the most recognizable fashion designer in the world, is in a back office at Fendis headquarters on the Via Solari, receiving from an assistant a gift someone has sent for his Birman, Choupette.

title: U.N. Moves Closer to Sanctions in South Sudan Conflict
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Security Council on Tuesday unanimously adopted a resolution to impose sanctions on those who disrupt efforts to restore peace in South Sudan, but it stopped short of barring the warring factions from buying more arms.

title: Seeing Stars at Anthony Vaccarello
description: The constellation prize for todays shows in Paris went to the hairstylist Anthony Turner and the makeup artist Tom Pecheux for the beauties they sent down the runway at Anthony Vaccarello. For Turner, the off-duty look they collaborated on was dictated by casting. All the girls are beautiful, he says, so it wasnt about creating characters or turning them into something they are not. For tousled rock-n-roll strands, Turner worked LOreal Professional PLI from roots to ends, letting each models hair part naturally. Pecheux, for his part, was feeling more Chrissie Hynde and less David Bowie with the tattoo-looking designs he created under one of each of the models eyes. Inspired by the clothes, he drew the shape of a star out of the corner of the eye  but we have seen that before, he says. So he began erasing the stars lines until he arrived at a more subtle geometric touch. And despite the heavily-lined eyelids, Pecheux didnt use a drop of mascara; he didnt want the models to look too bourgeoisie.

title: What Do Unions Know About Running Schools?
description: The charter school movement got its foothold two decades ago by promising that independently operated schools would outperform their traditional counterparts if they were allowed to receive public money while being exempted from some state regulations  including the requirement that they be unionized. Charter advocates made the deal more compelling by vowing that charter schools would be closely overseen and shut down when they failed , in contrast to traditional schools, which were allowed to fail in perpetuity without consequence.

title: Clock Ticks for Paul Rudolphs Orange County Government Center
description: This week, lawmakers in Goshen, N.Y., have a last chance to save an archetype of midcentury modernist architecture  and themselves from going down as reckless stewards of the nations heritage.

title: A West Indian-Style Oceanfront Villa in Anguilla
description: The house, which has three bedrooms and a guest cottage on the islands northern shore, is on the market for $3.4 million.

title: Americans Arent Saving Enough for Retirement, but One Change Could Help
description: Here is something every non-rich American family should know: The odds are that you will run out of money in retirement.

title: Review: The Lesson Is a Test of Conscience and Patience
description: We first encounter Nade (Margita Gosheva) in the classroom, preceded by the sound of chalk on the blackboard. An English teacher in a provincial Bulgarian town, she is stern but not without a hint of warmth. At the moment, though, she is preoccupied with finding out which of her students has been stealing money from unattended backpacks. This turns out to be a sign of worse trouble to come.

title: The 17th Armory Show, New as Ever
description: Whats that old adage about New York real estate? Location, location, location. So how is it that the Armory Show, which opens its 17th iteration this week, absolutely thrives on Piers 92 and 94  which sit on the West Side Highway at 55th Street, otherwise known as Manhattans Siberia? The secret: its director, Noah Horowitz, who swooped in four years ago to save the fair from what was widely regarded as its hemorrhaging status. At the age of 35, Horowitz, who penned the art-market manual Art of the Deal and is a faculty member at Sothebys Institute of Art, commands expert status in the ways of the contemporary scene, and has made the fair his own. Overall, I think the feeling is of renewed strength to the fair. Weve made a huge emphasis on quality, in the stature of the galleries themselves  and I dont mean just blue-chip galleries, but also young and mid-career ones, too, he explains of his strategy. Since finding its foothold in 1999, the Armory Show, which draws its namesake from the Park Avenue Armory and its inspiration from the 1913 exposition accredited with bringing shock of the new modernism to America, has always emphasized, well, evolution. One of the challenges in the market we operate in these days is things have become very flat, and a lot of things start looking the same, says Horowitz, who stresses his investment in new artists and galleries.

title: What You Get for ... $1,250,000
description: This weeks properties include two cottages in Hawaii, a modern house in Oklahoma and a 19th-century house in Maryland.

title: Dangerous Passage and Multiplying Fines as Ice Is Left Uncleared
description: There was no safe way across the thick slab of ice on the sidewalk.

title: Broadchurch, a Mystery Series, Returns to BBC America
description: Two years ago I was on the conservative end of the spectrum in my praise for the British mystery series Broadchurch, using the words superior entertainment but also intelligent but not particularly original.

title: Review: My Citys Just Not That Into Me, a Real Estate Series on FYI
description: Television already has more real estate shows than necessary, but if you cant get enough of peering inside strangers houses, FYI offers a new series on Wednesday night that at least varies the formula. The only trouble is, you have to watch it as if you were touring a fixer-upper. Envision a real estate agent whispering in your ear, Pay no attention to those holes.

title: Review: In CSI: Cyber, CBS Digitizes the Forensics Formula
description: CSI: Crime Scene Investigation, now chugging along in its 15th season, keeps leaving its spinoffs in the dust. CSI: Miami gave up after 10 seasons, CSI: NY fell away after nine. But the hope for advertising dollars springs eternal, so here we have CSI: Cyber, making its debut on CBS on Wednesday night.

title: Living on Sutton Place
description: The affluent neighborhood has many longtime residents, but it is also attracting younger people.

title: A Conversation With Winston C. Fisher
description: Mr. Fisher, 42, is a partner of Fisher Brothers, a New York-based family real estate company, founded in 1915, with around 1.5 million square feet of space currently under development, largely in Manhattan and Washington. Mr. Fisher is a partner along with his cousins Kenneth and Steven Fisher and his uncle Arnold.

title: Members of Newtown Shootings Panel Recall Toll Their Work Took
description: In the emotional weeks after the shootings at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., in December 2012 that left 20 first graders and six faculty members dead, Gov. Dannel P. Malloy assembled 16 experts  emergency workers, psychiatrists, trauma specialists, teachers, a pediatrician, a mayor  to examine the event.

title: Scooter LaForges Paintings Suit Walter Van Beirendonck (and Beyonce, Too)
description: Like so many modern relationships, the collaboration between the designer Walter Van Beirendonck, one of the famous Antwerp 6, and the New York artist Scooter LaForge started on Facebook. Beirendonck began following LaForges public profile several years ago, and the rest will sound familiar: One day, we started to chat, Beirendonck says. After asking the artist to paint an invitation and poster for an earlier collection, the designer more recently commissioned several paintings from LaForge with imagery relating to topics I wanted to refer to in the Whambam! collection, Beirendoncks spring/summer 2015 line. LaForges paintings depicting a shark, birds of paradise, a bloody beach, a machine gun, a warplane and a kitten were then scanned digitally and translated into woven fabrics.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Pictures of the Day: Chile and Elsewhere
description: Chile and More  Pictures of the Day

title: American Crime, John Ridleys New Series on ABC
description: A father receives a call in the middle of the night that his son is dead. Killed.

title: March 3, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Chile, Russia, China and India.

title: Trey Gowdy Calls Hillary Clintons Email Use Troubling
description: Representative Trey Gowdy, Republican of South Carolina and the chairman of the special House committee created to investigate the 2012 terrorist attacks in Benghazi, Libya, offered harsh criticism Tuesday of Hillary Rodham Clintons use of private emails during her tenure as secretary of state.

title: Recent Commercial Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Photos Hopscotch Through Cortzars Paris
description: For the centennial of Julio Cortzars birth, Hugo Passarello took portraits of the Argentines writers fans and friends in Paris, the setting of his novel Hopscotch.

title: An Upside to Gout: It May Offer Alzheimers Protection
description: Gout, a form of arthritis, is extremely painful and associated with an increased risk for cardiovascular problems. But there is a bright side: It may be linked to a reduced risk for Alzheimers disease.

title: Lindsey Graham Walks Back Joke About Nancy Pelosi Face-Lifts
description: Discussion of Irans nuclear arsenal turned petty on Tuesday when Senator Lindsey Graham suggested that Representative Nancy Pelosis disgust at Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus speech was masked by her plastic surgeries.

title: Scott Walker Says He Would Sign Ban on Abortions After 20 Weeks
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin said Tuesday that he would sign a ban on abortions after 20 weeks, coming out strongly on an issue important to social conservatives that he played down in his re-election campaign last year.

title: Britain: Man Linked to Militants in Yemen Is Extradited to the U.S.
description: A Vietnamese man accused of helping develop online propaganda for Al Qaedas affiliate in Yemen has been extradited from Britain to face trial in Manhattan, United States prosecutors said Tuesday. The defendant, Minh Quang Pham, 32, had been living in Britain. He went to Yemen in 2010; swore an oath of allegiance to the group, Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula; and provided it with expert advice and assistance in photography and graphic design of media, an indictment charges. In Yemen, he worked with an American citizen who helped produce Inspire, an English-language online magazine published by the group, the authorities said. The indictment does not name the American, but he appears to have been Samir Khan, who was later killed in a drone strike. Mr. Phams lawyer did not respond immediately to messages seeking comment.

title: For White House Spokesman, Clinton Emails Trump Netanyahu Speech
description: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, found himself spending nearly his entire news conference Tuesday discussing  Hillary Rodham Clintons use of a personal email account when she was secretary of state, rather than the speech delivered earlier in the day by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

title: Namibia: President Is Awarded $5 Million Prize for Good Governance
description: Namibias departing president, Hifikepunye Pohamba, has been awarded the 2014 Ibrahim Prize for Achievement in African Leadership. In making the announcement on Monday in Kenya, the prize committees chairman, Salim Ahmed Salim, said, President Pohambas focus on forging national cohesion and reconciliation at a new stage of Namibias consolidation of democracy and social and economic development impressed the prize committee. The Ibrahim Prize, the largest annually awarded prize in the world, is worth$5 million over the first 10 years, followed by a stipend of at least $200,000 a year. The Mo Ibrahim Foundation, established in 2006 by a Sudanese-British telecom mogul, makes the annual awards. Mr. Pohamba, 79, has served two terms as president and is due to hand over power at the end of the month. He was a founding member of the governing party, Swapo, which fought for Namibian independence from South Africa in 1990. Since the prizes inception, four former presidents have received it. In the past two years, no prize was awarded.

title: Supreme Court May Be Open to Hotel Registry Checks
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday seemed inclined to let the police in Los Angeles inspect hotel and motel guest registries without permission from a judge.

title: Hotel Market Staggers in New York City
description: On 41st Street near Times Square, a Hyatt Place hotel is under construction. The shell of a Hampton Inn sits one block to the west. Nearby, scaffolding heralds a Holiday Inn.

title: Ethiopia, Long Mired in Poverty, Rides an Economic Boom
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  The bulldozers, tractors and cranes are busy day and night, paving new roads, building tall glass buildings and constructing a new light rail system to stitch together the citys ends.

title: Equity Firms Are Lending to Landlords, Signaling a Shift
description: In the aftermath of the financial crisis, large private equity firms spent tens of billions of dollars buying foreclosed homes across the United States to operate them as rental properties.

title: Drugs Using Testosterone Will Label Heart Risks
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday that manufacturers of testosterone drugs used by millions of Americans will be required to change labels for the drugs to warn that they could increase the risk of heart attacks and strokes and should not be prescribed to treat symptoms in men brought on by age, such as declining sexual drive.

title: Police Officials Visit City Council in Changed Climate, and Civility Reigns
description: Lawmakers cheered new training programs for officers. Police officials were praised for allowing this conversation to happen.

title: Target Plans to Cut Jobs to Help Save $2 Billion
description: Target said on Tuesday that it would cut several thousand jobs over two years, mostly at its headquarters in Minneapolis, as it struggles to overcome a string of difficult years.

title: Pension Funds Trail Individuals in Embracing Index Funds
description: More individuals are pouring money into so-called passive investing or index funds, which aim to match the performance of the main stock and bond markets, but larger institutions like pension funds and endowments have been slower to follow suit, despite the potential for higher returns and lower fees.

title: Netanyahus Nuclear Deceptions
description: UNITED NATIONS  In the address on Tuesday to the United States Congress by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, we witnessed a new peak in the long-running hype over Irans nuclear energy program. Yet all his predictions about how close Iran was to acquiring a nuclear bomb have proved baseless.

title: Japans Growth inSolar Power Falters as Utilities Balk
description: MAKURAZAKI, Japan  Rice fields, golf courses and even a disused airport runway. All over the southern Japanese region of Kyushu, unexpected places gleam with electricity-producing solar panels.

title: Nextdoor Social Network Digs Deep Into Neighborhoods
description: Internet companies have been trying desperately for years to court people like Isaac Gonzalez to use their services.

title: Alabama Court Orders a Halt to Same-Sex Marriage Licenses
description: The Alabama Supreme Court on Tuesday night ordered probate judges around the state to stop issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples, ruling in direct opposition to a federal judge that the states ban on same sex marriage did not violate the United States Constitution.

title: Toute La Vie, Song for French Charity, Strikes Discordant Note
description: PARIS  The song was supposed to raise money, not a ruckus. But because it features a group of young singers whining and another group of older singer-celebrities reproaching them, the recording, made for a French charity, has provoked a storm of anger and laid bare a generational divide in French society.

title: Bettina Graziani Dies at 89; Supermodel of Fashions New Look
description: Bettina Graziani, one of the worlds first supermodels, who in her midcentury heyday was known as the most photographed woman in France, died on Monday in Paris. She was 89.

title: Portugal, Algarve Cups Host, Says Event Is Our World Cup
description: LAGOA, Portugal  For the past 12 years, the home team at the Algarve Cup has treated itself like an interested visitor.

title: Three States and Two Tribes to Get $27 Million to Fight Childhood Hunger
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, as part of a broader push to address persistent poverty and childhood hunger in rural areas, said Tuesday that it would provide millions of dollars in grants to help several economically distressed communities.

title: Confessions From New Yorks Era of Fury Show Their Cracks
description: On Monday, Pascal Carpenter, age 42, left prison after serving 25 years, his sentence for being the lookout in a mugging that became a murder. Under New York law, if someone is killed during the commission of a felony  say, a robbery  everyone who took part in the lesser crime can be held liable for the homicide. Its not just New York; some states execute the lookouts.

title: Columbia Graduate Students Push for a Labor Union
description: Im Anna. Im in the history department. I want a union because I want to be able to do this work I love and have a safety net.

title: Virginia: Womens College Will Close Over Finances
description: Sweet Briar College, a century-old womens liberal-arts college near Lynchburg, announced Tuesday that it will close in August. The college, which has 700 students and 329 employees, cited insurmountable financial problems and the shrinking number of students interested in a rural women-only college. Sweet Briar will be the third liberal-arts institution in the state to fold in the last two years, after Saint Pauls College and Virginia Intermont College. There is no decision yet on what will become of the 3,250-acre campus.

title: What Bibi Didnt Say
description: Now that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has made his case on Iran before Congress, with all the circus atmosphere it involved, lets get to the serious questions:What is Americas interest in striking a deal with Iran? Because our interests and Israels are not fully aligned. What is the minimum we need to satisfy our interests? And how should we balance the critiques of our policy from the serious Bibi versus the cynical Bibi?

title: And the End Came
description: As the Civil War entered its final spring, its history already needed to be told. Fittingly, one of the earliest attempts came from the man whose election to the presidency, four years earlier, had precipitated the conflict.

title: Netanyahu Event Similar to a State of the Union Address, but More Electric
description: WASHINGTON  It had the trappings of the State of the Union address: a packed and rapt House chamber, suffocating security, lawmakers lining the aisles, a powerful world leader at the microphone  and a partisan chasm over the words and the man delivering them.

title: Duke Defends Actions in Players Dismissal
description: One day after a report suggested that Dukes athletic department knew of two sexual assault allegations against the junior guard Rasheed Sulaimon for as long as 10 months before his dismissal from the team, the programs athletic director attempted to tamp down speculation that Coach Mike Krzyzewski, or any other athletic official, had mishandled the case.

title: Manslaughter Charges in Beating Death of Transgender Woman in 2013
description: A Brooklyn man was charged with manslaughter on Tuesday in the killing of a transgender woman who died after a vicious beating in Harlem in 2013, a crime that galvanized anger among transgender people in New York about violence directed toward them.

title: Netanyahu Speech Raises Burden for Obama on Iran Nuclear Talks
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas task of selling a potential nuclear agreement with Iran to a skeptical Congress became far harder on Tuesday after an impassioned speech by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to lawmakers already nervous about the deal.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 3, 2015
description: March 3, 2015

title: M.L.S., Facing Possible Strike, Finds Labor Strife at Its Door
description: The 20th season of Major League Soccer is scheduled to start Friday, and with it, the start of eight-year television deals with Fox, ESPN and Univision worth $90 million a year.

title: Study of Whales
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  Jeff Stillman made his debut in the New York Times crossword a little more than a year ago, and he returns today with a puzzle that re-imagines four phrases as fictional movie characters in their sequels.

title: Substantial Outfielder Shows Off Bat for Yankees
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  It has been nearly 15 years, but C. C. Sabathia had no trouble recalling his first spring training game in a major league camp. The first batter he faced was his boyhood idol, Ken Griffey Jr.

title: A Muslim Chaplain Caught in the Middle
description: PIERREFITTE-SUR-SEINE, France  Salah Hamidi describes himself as a piece of meat on a cutting block, being whacked by a butcher.

title: Alternate-Side Parking Rules Are Suspended on Wednesday and Thursday
description: Because of snow removal and Purim, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday and Thursday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: David Wright Takes On New Role With Mets: Clubhouse Disciplinarian
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Early in the Mets intrasquad game Tuesday, David Wright made a backhand play on a ground ball and then threw smoothly to first for the out. Wright has made that play hundreds of times. But this time, it was a small reminder that Wrights left shoulder was healthy again after a season of discomfort and that he was at full strength for a 2015 campaign that he has said he hopes will end the Mets long run of futility.

title: Using Private Email, Hillary Clinton Thwarted Record Requests
description: WASHINGTON  In 2012, congressional investigators asked the State Department for a wide range of documents related to the attack on the United States diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya. The department eventually responded, furnishing House committees with thousands of documents.

title: Justified Recap: Ava and Boyd Go A-Hunting
description: Season 6, Episode 7: The Hunt

title: Slim Hopes Are Dashed as Rutgers Fizzles Out Against Maryland
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Rutgers had lost a dozen consecutive games, but there was a sense, for a few moments, on Tuesday night that the Scarlet Knights could upset 10th-ranked Maryland.

title: Mets Daniel Murphy Addresses Possibility of Gay Teammates
description: Billy Bean, Major League Baseballs first inclusion ambassador, made an appearance at the Mets camp to spread his message of acceptance. He found a welcome audience, and a particularly supportive voice in General Manager Sandy Alderson, but he also drew some respectful but pointed words from second baseman Daniel Murphy.

title: For Knicks, There Is One Plus: Games Over
description: In losing to the Sacramento Kings, 124-86, on Tuesday night, the Knicks were terrible as a team. But that shouldnt disguise the fact that individually, they were also terrible.

title: Debate Over Redskins as Nickname Trickles Down to Buffalo Suburb
description: LANCASTER, N.Y.  Hundreds of people in this Buffalo suburb braved a freezing rain Tuesday night to pack into the Lancaster Central High School cafeteria and debate an issue that has ranged for years over the American sports landscape, from scholastic leagues to the N.F.L.: the use of Redskins as a teams nickname.

title: Word of the Day | whimsical
description: whimsical  \hwim-zi-kl, wim-\  adjective

title: Whats On TV Wednesday
description: 8:05 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE DREAMERS (2004) Louis Garrel (top), Eva Green (center) and Michael Pitt (above) portray the points of a photogenic triangle in this drama from Bernardo Bertolucci (Last Tango in Paris) about an American who befriends French twins in Paris during the 1968 student riots. This adaptation of Gilbert Adairs novel The Holy Innocents is disarmingly sweet and completely enchanting, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. The sex in this movie is, as measured by the display of body parts and the amount of time the actors spend out of their clothes, more explicit than even the most notorious scenes in Last Tango, he said. But it is hard to imagine a voyeur more benevolent than Mr. Bertolucci, whose eager scrutiny of the eros of the young is, like Jeremy Ironss in Stealing Beauty, less a matter of prurience than of an honest, nostalgic appreciation of natural human vitality.

title: New Site for a Debate
description: Several hundred people attended a meeting Tuesday at a high school in Lancaster, N.Y., outside Buffalo, to discuss whether to change the schools Redskins nickname.

title: Delivering Unwelcome Species to the Mediterranean
description: The Mediterranean Sea is among the worlds great environmental jewels. The sea is highly saline, almost entirely enclosed by land and contains immense biodiversity. Scientists have long worried that its health is imperiled. Swelling coastal populations and ship traffic have brought overfishing and pollution. Climate change threatens to roil the waters still further.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: It doesnt block Irans path to the bomb. It paves Irans path to the bomb.

title: Corrections: March 4, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Photos Hopscotch Through Cortzars Paris
description: Hugo Passarello was young and starry-eyed when he first encountered Hopscotch by the Argentine novelist Julio Cortzar. Like most readers, he was enthralled by the stream-of-consciousness narrative that shattered notions of structure. Set in Paris and written episodically, the novel boasts 155 snapshots which Cortzar gives readers three options to move through: progressively; hopscotching with instructions; or blazing a unique path.

title: Chinas Military Budget Increasing 10% for 2015, Official Says
description: BEIJING  The Chinese military budget for 2015 will be about 10 percent bigger than last years, a senior Chinese official said on Wednesday, meaning that such spending is growing at a pace faster than the overall growth rate of the Chinese economy.

title: Mohonk Preserves Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: Vermont Heroin Epidemic
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: What Hillary Clintons Emails Really Reveal
description: HISTORY will be the judge: Thats the line leaders often use when making difficult decisions. Historians, after all, have the benefit of hindsight and archives full of once-secret files. But how will history judge a generation of leaders who dont preserve the historical record?

title: Las Vegas Gets a New Act
description: LAS VEGAS  LATELY, a chronic question in Las Vegas is how to make our city more livable. Look at any online list to see what defines livability and youll find categories like best foodie cities, best golf cities and best places to retire, cities where work and cars dont seem to exist, but craft breweries are abundant.

title: Keeping Disputes Private: Antidotes to Going Viral
description: To the Editor:

title: Hillarys Messy Habits
description: Hillary and Bill Clinton have one home in Washington, D.C., another in Chappaqua, N.Y., and a whole wide world that opens its arms and wallets to them.

title: Establishment Populism Rising
description: Larry Summers, who withdrew his candidacy for the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve under pressure from the liberal wing of the Democratic Party in 2013, has emerged as the partys dominant economic policy strategist. The former Treasury secretarys evolving message has won over many of his former critics.

title: Abuse at Attica Calls for Federal Scrutiny
description: The Justice Department, which went to court in December to stop an epidemic of brutality in New York Citys jail system, may need to scrutinize New York States prisons as well. That seems fairly obvious from two recent articles published by The Times and The Marshall Project exploring a case of prison guards who beat an inmate nearly to death within view of witnesses at the infamous Attica prison in western New York in 2011.

title: Hillary Clintons Use of Personal Email
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons decision when she was secretary of state to use only her personal email account to conduct official business was a disturbing departure from the normal practice of relying primarily on departmental emails for official business.

title: May (or May Not) Cause Weight Gain
description: In the fall of 2014 the author decided to quit the prescription medications she has been taking to treat her anxiety, depression and insomnia, and began the process of gradually reducing her dosages. In Going Off, a series of Anxiety posts in the coming weeks, she will chronicle the challenges she faces from both the drugs and the withdrawal in her pursuit of a drug-free life.

title: Their Dying Wishes
description: I met Mr. C. because he was dying and his wife needed someone to sit with him Saturday nights while she attended Mass. I was a relatively new hospice volunteer, not long out of training, and Mr. C. was my first assignment with a patient at home, rather than in a hospital or health care facility. He had been given a diagnosis of Parkinsons disease 25 years before I first entered their small apartment in the Baruch housing projects, which stand where the Williamsburg Bridge meets Manhattan.

title: Test Yourself | The History of the Monopoly Game
description: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 13 article, Monopolys Inventor: The Progressive Who Didnt Pass Go.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Games on a Reservation Go by in a Blur
description: In Games on a Reservation Go by in a Blur, Michael Powell writes about the power of high school basketball on a reservation in Arizona.

title: When a Candidate Leaves the Pack Behind
Europes Digital Chief Vows to Intervene on Technology Abuses
description: BARCELONA, Spain  For many American technology companies, it often feels as if Europe is out to get them.

title: The Hardest (and Most Important) Job in Afghanistan
description: Early one cold January morning on the high plains of eastern Afghanistan, Maj. Mohammad Qasim and a few of his officers gathered in the rundown barracks that serve as a district headquarters for the Afghan National Police in Baraki Barak. Qasim and his officers were the only government security available to the 100,000 people living in a district roughly twice the size of Manhattan, and about half of the district was now controlled by the Taliban. Kabul is just 40 miles away, but the Afghan National Army had not been to Baraki Barak in two years. The ceiling in Qasims office leaked when it rained, and the electricity was out indefinitely, so the men had taken to sitting on floor cushions around the wood stove in Qasims bedroom, drinking green tea from smudged glass mugs and dealing with the problems of the day. This morning, the first problem was the death of Hajji Khalil.

title: New York Spring Spectacular Brings High Kicks to Radio City Music Hall
description: Two monumental puppets representing Patience and Fortitude, the lions guarding the entrance to the main branch of New York Public Library, tapped their paws and swished their tails onstage at Radio City Music Hall the other day. It was break time during rehearsals for Radio Citys New York Spring Spectacular, and in an orchestra seat, Randy Weiner, one of the shows creative directors, leaned back and began formulating, aloud, a few interesting notions.

title: The Strategist: Brent Scowcroft and the Call of National Security
description: In foreign policy, every success is just the start of the next crisis. Brent Scowcroft has pointed this out often in his four decades at the top of the American national security establishment. When the Soviet Union was conceding defeat in the nuclear arms race, he wondered if Gorbachev would instead kill us with kindness. When the Evil Empire was crumbling, he fretted about loose nuclear weapons and ethnic slaughter. When American troops were routing Saddam Hussein in the Persian Gulf war of 1991, he worried that Iraq could fall apart, leaving us to pick up the pieces. Again and again, this taciturn Mormon has been the Woody Allen of American foreign policy.

title: How Do You Express Yourself Creatively?
description: Do you play an instrument? Draw? Take photos? Write poetry? Dance?

title: Deadly Blast Rocks Coal Mine in East Ukraine
description: KRASNOARMIRSK, Ukraine  An explosion ripped through a coal mine in the separatist-held eastern city of Donetsk, Ukraine, early Wednesday morning, killing several miners and leaving dozens more trapped underground and feared dead.

title: A Lawyer Taking Aim at the Health Care Act Gets a Supreme Court Rematch
description: WASHINGTON  The lawyer Michael A. Carvin is blunt-talking, rumpled and passionately libertarian. When he urged the Supreme Court on Wednesday to dismantle President Obamas health care law, Justice Sonia Sotomayor  an ardent liberal  could not get in a word.

title: In Chase of Apple, Smartphone Makers Shift Strategies
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Big phones, small phones, cheap phones, expensive phones, curved phones  and all of them hoping to take a chunk out of the iPhone.

title: Mayor de Blasio Seeks Stronger Ties With Jewish Voters
description: Two weeks ago, Mayor Bill de Blasio stood shoulder to shoulder with Frances chief rabbi at the Park East Synagogue and challenged European leaders to break their atmosphere of indifference toward anti-Semitism. A few days later, he slipped out of New York City to attend the wedding of a Hasidic leaders grandson. Last week, he loosened city regulations on a medically questionable ultra-Orthodox circumcision ritual.

title: More Foreigners Move to Top Ranks at Toyota
description: TOKYO  Toyota Motor on Wednesday appointed a Frenchman to the position of executive vice president, the most senior job at the carmaker after the president and the chairman, and the highest rank to which a non-Japanese has risen in its history.

title: Snowden Seeks to Return Home to U.S., His Lawyer Says
description: MOSCOW  Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive and former American intelligence contractor, would like to return to the United States after nearly two years in exile in Russia, according to his Russian lawyer.

title: Standard Chartered Profit Fell 37% in 2014
description: LONDON  The British bank Standard Chartered, which generates most of its earnings in Asia, said on Wednesday that profit fell 37 percent in 2014. It cited higher charges for bad loans and other credit risks, an accounting charge on its Korean business, and a previously announced settlement with the United States authorities.

title: One Twin Exercises, the Other Doesnt
description: Identical twins in Finland who shared the same sports and other physical activities as youngsters but different exercise habits as adults soon developed quite different bodies and brains, according to a fascinating new study that highlights the extent to which exercise shapes our health, even in people who have identical genes and nurturing.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: Real-Life Civics Class
description: Good morning on this gloppy Wednesday.

title: Our Kids, by Robert D. Putnam
description: Robert D. Putnam is technically a Harvard social scientist, but a better description might be poet laureate of civil society. In successive versions of Bowling Alone (as a 1995 article and an instant-classic book), Putnam argued, to bipartisan acclaim, that civic life is declining with ominous consequences. Bill Clinton brought him to Camp David. The campaigns of Al Gore and George W. Bush sought his advice. Barack Obama gave him a medal.

title: The Supreme Court Has the Power to Deepen a National Health Divide
description: The Supreme Court has the potential to radically reshape the Affordable Care Act, creating a result profoundly different from that imagined by President Obama and the laws drafters in Congress.

title: Solicitor General Will Try, Again, to Keep Health Care Law Alive
description: WASHINGTON  Three years ago this month, Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr. stood before the Supreme Court to defend President Obamas health care law against a constitutional challenge that threatened to destroy its central provision. His oral argument drew harsh reviews, but in the end he managed to persuade five justices to accept his backup argument, saving the law.

title: Daily Report: Nextdoor Banks on Trust to Build Microcommunities
description: Internet companies have been trying desperately for years to court people like Isaac Gonzalez to use their services. He is 34 years old, married, a father and a well-regarded leader of his neighborhood association in Sacramento. Local government officials and business owners know who he is, Mike Isaac reports.

title: British Government to Sell Eurostar Stake for $1.16 Billion
description: LONDON  The British government said on Wednesday that it had agreed to sell its 40 percent stake in Eurostar International, which operates high-speed trains connecting London with Paris and Brussels through a tunnel under the English Channel, for about 757 million pounds, or $1.16 billion.

title: Bristol-Myers Squibb Enters Drug Licensing Deal With Danish Biotechnology Firm
description: LONDON  The Danish biotechnology company Bavarian Nordic said on Wednesday that it could receive up to $975 million under a licensing agreement with Bristol-Myers Squibb for Prostvac, a treatment for advanced prostate cancer that is in clinical trials.

title: Can I Hide My Beliefs During Jury Selection?
description: I live in a Midwestern state that has the death penalty. I am scheduled to be a juror for the first time in March, and Im afraid I will face a difficult ethical choice if I am selected for a capital case. Though I consider myself an atheist, I was brought up Quaker and still hold dear many of those values  nonviolence, a belief in the goodness of each person, peace and simplicity, to name a few. I believe that the death penalty is inherently wrong,unethical and unjust. Should I be put on a capital case, I am considering hiding my beliefs to improve my odds of selection so I can subvert an unfair system. I know it is unethical and possibly illegal to lie to the judge and lawyers, but do the means justify the ends in order to save a life? NICO

title: Mary Cain Is Growing Up Fast
description: Editors Note: Dec. 6, 2019Mary Cain recently spoke out about her career as a runner at Nike that has added significantly to our understanding of her experience there. Cains comments can be seen in this video.

description: Paris

description: Despite having raised billions of dollars and attaining a valuation of over $10 billion, the Indian e-commerce giant Flipkart isnt necessarily the biggest name in Silicon Valley.

title: Lemaire: Fall 2015 RTW

title: Morning Agenda: Equity Firms Push Into Landlord Loans
description: EQUITY FIRMS PUSH INTO LANDLORD LOANS | In the aftermath of the financial crisis, large private equity firms spent tens of billions of dollars buying foreclosed homes across the United States to operate them as rental properties. Now, three big firms  the Blackstone Group, Colony Capital and Cerberus Capital Management  are providing loans to smaller investors who are looking to do something similar, Matthew Goldstein reports in DealBook. These firms are betting that so-called landlord loans to small and midsize investors will become the next big opportunity to profit from the rebound in the United States housing market.

title: Private Equity Firm HGGC Raises $1.3 Billion for New Fund
description: The men whose names were once on prominent display at HGGC may no longer work there. But the private equity firm has still managed to raise a second investment fund without them.

title: Paris Seeks 3 Suspects in 1982 Attack on Jewish Deli
description: PARIS  For more than three decades, the case, at the time considered the deadliest anti-Semitic attack in France since World War II, remained unsolved, stumping investigators and haunting the Jewish community in Paris.

title: Areva Plans to Cut Costs While Mastering Difficult Projects
description: PARIS  Areva, the struggling French nuclear giant, said on Wednesday that it would embark on a major cost-cutting plan to bring its finances in order as it braced for another difficult year in 2015.

title: Netanyahu May Gain Only a Fleeting Lift From His Speech, Experts Say
description: JERUSALEM  Shortly before Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus highly anticipated and contentious speech to Congress, the Hebrew news site Ynet posted an old column written by him and published in its mother publication, the popular newspaper Yediot Aharonot, warning about the Iranian nuclear threat.

title: What to Expect on the First Day of Paris Fashion Week
description: PARIS  The sight of the Eiffel Tower and the Tuileries Gardens are the stuff of treacly tourist postcards, but for the world-tour-weary fashion flock, there are fewer more welcome visions than Paris after several weeks on the road. There are highlights, no doubt, at New York Fashion Week, in London and in Milan, but Paris when it sizzles is what the circuit is all about.

title: Challenge to Health Overhaul Puts Obscure Think Tank in Spotlight
description: WASHINGTON  In the orbit of Washington think tanks, the Competitive Enterprise Institute is an obscure name with a modest budget that belies its political connections to conservative titans like the Koch brothers.

He founded Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide in 1995, elevating brands like Sheraton and Westin while creating the chic W Hotels in 1998. (I was inspired to do W by my trips in Asia where I saw that the hotels were meeting places, Mr. Sternlicht said.)

title: Broadcast of India Gang Rape Documentary Is Banned by Court

title: Hirshhorn Museums New Curator Brings a Different Perspective
description: WASHINGTON  Two days into his job as chief curator at the Smithsonians Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, Stphane Aquin is, as he would say, dpays  away from home and off kilter. Heading out to our breakfast meeting, he makes the mistake of hailing a cab which, in classic Washington fashion, takes him all over town before depositing him at his destination  a few minutes walk from where he started out. At a grill, hungry for an egg sandwich, Mr. Aquin is offered such a dizzying array of options that he switches his order to sausage, which arrives as pancake-shaped patties of meat. Not quite the saucisse hed have been served at any bistro in his native Montreal.

title: Voters Unlikely to Care Much About the Hillary Clinton Email Furor
description: The report Monday that Hillary Clinton exclusively used a personal email account to conduct government business as secretary of state raises a number of important questions about government transparency and access to public records.

title: Oprah Winfrey Wont Do Marsha Norman Play on Broadway
description: Oprah Winfrey has decided against making her Broadway debut in a revival of the Pulitzer Prize-winning play night, Mother, she told The Hollywood Reporter for an article published on Tuesday, saying that the material was too dark for her.

title: Hermosa Beach, Calif., Voters Give Thumbs Down to Oil Drilling
description: LOS ANGELES  Voters of Hermosa Beach, a small community on the Pacific Ocean south of here, ended a highly contentious campaign Tuesday with an overwhelming vote to deny permission for the construction of up to 34 oil wells on a 1.3 acre municipal parking lot in the center of town. According to unofficial returns, the measure was defeated 3,799 to 1,016.

title: At Least One Justice Is in Play as Supreme Court Hears Affordable Care Act Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday took up the Affordable Care Act in one of the most anticipated arguments of the term, and it seemed closely divided over the fate of President Obamas signature legislative achievement.

title: What Netanyahu Chose Not to Say in Speech Signals a Slight Shift
description: WASHINGTON  For all of the attention focused on what Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said in his high-profile address to Congress on Tuesday, what may be just as important is what he did not say.

title: Michael Kimmelman on Architecture Criticism and Dangers of Demolition
description: Michael Kimmelmans column this week, about the debate over plans to demolish a midcentury Paul Rudolph building in Goshen, N.Y., makes the case for why it should be saved. It is only one example of his taking up a cause. As The Timess architecture critic, he has not been shy about advocacy.

title: Sutton Place, Cozy Enclave by the East River
description: The cozy, affluent enclave of Sutton Place and its extension, Sutton Place South, has many longtime residents, but it is starting to attract younger people, too.

title: McDonalds Moving to Limit Antibiotic Use in Chickens
description: McDonalds said on Wednesday that it would begin using chickens that are not raised with antibiotics used to treat humans, a move likely to put pressure on competitors of the fast-food chain, which now sells more chicken than beef.

description: WASHINGTON  When hes not legislating, Senator Jon Tester, a Democrat, is a wheat, barley and alfalfa farmer in Big Sandy, Mont. That makes him a good bet to support President Obamas trade agenda, which is generally backed by agriculture interests.

title: 1890: Forth Bridge Is Completed
description: EDINBURGH  The great railway bridge that now spans the Firth of Forth, to-day [March 4] received from the Prince of Wales its formal dedication. Here, amid wind and a drizzling rain the last rivet was driven home, the Prince using a silver key to turn the valve of the hydraulic riveting machine. The Prince, with some difficulty, made his way to the end of the platform and declared the bridge open. The Forth Bridge, without doubt, is the highest effort of engineering skill in metal construction that the world has seen. An international significance attaches to the event from the presence of a large number of distinguished foreign guests.  The New York Herald, European Edition, March 5, 1890

title: Alibaba Expands in Silicon Valley With Its First U.S. Data Center
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Chinas largest Internet company, Alibaba, is adding to its modest presence in Silicon Valley, but not in the way many expected.

title: What the Feds 2009 Transcripts Reveal About Its Handling of the Recession
description: In the early months of that year, the Fed pressed ahead with the bold measures it had initiated in 2008 to arrest the financial crisis. By summer it had largely succeeded.

title: 1994: Eurostar Tunnel Links Britain to the Continent
description: CALAIS, France  There was fog in the English Channel on Friday, but the Continent was not cut off. Queen Elizabeth II traveled through the Channel Tunnel in a gleaming Eurostar express to meet President Franois Mitterrand and inaugurate the first land link between England and the Continent.

title: Ludo Lefebvres Roasted-Carrot Salad
description: I used to cook for critics, Ludo Lefebvre said, standing next to the narrow open kitchen at Petit Trois in Los Angeles, where producers and script wranglers and people who go on auditions eat steak frites with barnaise sauce, then lurch back to studio lots for meetings and naps.

title: David Hallberg Out for American Ballet Theaters Spring Season
description: David Hallberg, the American Ballet Theater principal dancer, is injured and will not perform during the companys Metropolitan Opera House season, the company announced on Wednesday. Mr. Hallberg, who is also a principal dancer with the Bolshoi Ballet, had foot surgery last fall.

title: Jean-Michel Othoniel Shares His Process in a Small but Poignant Exhibition
description: For his second American museum exhibition, the French artist Jean-Michel Othoniel says he shares the hidden part of my work. Secret Flower Sculptures, on view beginning March 12 at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, explores the artistic process he began developing four years ago, when he was an artist in residence at the Gardner. (It was then that he also discovered an 18th-century book, The Art of Describing Dance by Raoul-Auger Feuillet, which informed the new Water Theater grove design he created in collaboration with the landscape architect Louis Benech, which opens to the public at the garden of Versailles this spring.)

title: With Eye on 2016, Rand Paul Courts Sheldon Adelson
description: Rand Paul said Wednesday that he met with the Las Vegas casino magnate Sheldon Adelson this week while Mr. Adelson was in Washington for a congressional address by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

description: Anatoly G. Kucherena, a lawyer for the former American intelligence contractor Edward Snowden, said he was in talks with American and German lawyers about his clients return to the United States.

description: Goldman Sachs is moving a top executive, David Z. Solomon, from a post working with the banks hedge fund clients to a new position that entails working on one of Goldmans in-house hedge funds.

description: Once a symbol of our militarys readiness, the army green field jacket has been scrubbed of its martial connotations to become a fashion staple.

description: A surprising new line of argument has emerged: Financial regulation is working, Dodd-Frank is one of the major accomplishments of the Obama administration, and the banks are even humbled.

description: Perhaps its about injecting Hollywood glamour into New Yorks classical musical world. Or maybe its about a local boy coming home to make good. Or maybe its just about getting a name in granite.

description: WASHINGTON  The revelation that Hillary Rodham Clinton conducted government business entirely on a private email account as secretary of state has blindsided the Democratic establishment.

description: An injured miner explained how he fled from a burning mine in the eastern Ukrainian city of Donetsk after an explosion, as he and other miners received treatment at a hospital.

title: 1940: French Develop Pursuit Planes
description: The French aviation industry has developed a pursuit plane whose speed exceeds that of the renowned Messerschmitt 110, it was learned yesterday [March 4]. According to an official source the plane will be in mass production by the end of June. A spokesman of the Air Ministry said the development of this craft would not mean the curtailment of purchases of Curtiss pursuit planes in the United States. He said the Curtiss ships are equal in speed to the Messerschmitts and far more maneuverable and would supplement the French production.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 5, 1940

title: Actaviss Bond Sale Demonstrates Investor Hunger for High-Yield Debt
description: Actavis is showcasing the value of being barely investment grade. The company, a drug maker that has been making many acquisitions, attracted huge demand this week for $21 billion of bonds it is selling at a mere notch above junk status. They yield less than a bigger and higher-rated debt issue that Verizon did in 2013. Buyers of top-tier debt cant help but keep looking further downward.

title: Alabama Halts Gay Marriages After Ruling
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  The curtain abruptly fell Wednesday on Alabamas brief experiment in same-sex marriage.

title: Aids for the Indecisive, When Options Abound
description: FOR the indecisive among us, help is on the way. A new generation of apps meant to help with day-to-day decision making is here. Assuming you can decide which to use, these apps may help bring some order to your life.

title: 36 Hours in Rome
description: The old collides with the new in Rome, where visitors can sample both traditional and creative cuisine, classic architecture, avant-garde galleries and endless nightlife options.

title: 36 Hours in Rome
description: Paolo Sorrentinos mesmerizing film La Grande Bellezza (The Great Beauty), which won an Oscar for best foreign-language film in 2014, sparked controversy and endless conversation about the current state of the Italian capital. But one fact was indisputable: Rome, as the films seductive backdrop, was gorgeous. This is true in every season, but especially in colder months when the summer flood of tourists ebbs. From outlying neighborhoods that beckon with new restaurants and bars, to the historic center, where Mr. Sorrentinos protagonist, Jep, wandered through so many scenes, Rome remains poised to prove that its beauty runs deep.

title: Male Statuary, Illustrated
description: From a series for T in which the artist Leanne Shapton makes new artworks from pictures in old books.

title: Darren Wilson Is Cleared of Rights Violations in Ferguson Shooting
description: Offering the most definitive account yet of the shooting of an unarmed black teenager that stirred racially charged protests across the country, the Justice Department has cleared a Ferguson, Mo., police officer of civil rights violations in the death last August of Michael Brown.

title: Virginia Ponders Laws on Horse Tripping, Pet Monkeys and More
description: Its true, conceded the lawmaker who sponsored a bill in Virginia to prevent horse tripping, there was no evidence of rampant intentional equine toppling throughout the commonwealth.

title: Even With an Unfavorable Court Ruling, Much of Obamacare Would Live On
description: The case before the Supreme Court this week will not wipe Obamacare off the books.

title: Putin Says Boris Nemtsovs Brazen Murder Was Politically Motivated
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Wednesday that the slaying of Boris Y. Nemtsov, a Kremlin critic, had a political subtext, and he called on law enforcement agencies to halt such crimes.

title: Readers React to the Hillary Clinton Email Article
description: It is a truth universally acknowledged that no story involving Hillary Rodham Clinton may be published without vociferous criticism of one kind or another following close behind, Margaret Sullivan, The Timess public editor, wrote on Tuesday.

title: High Rent, Low Wages
description: Recently, gasoline prices have been falling, and pulling down inflation with them. But prices have also dropped for a range of other consumer goods, including new and used cars and trucks, appliances and furniture, groceries and alcoholic beverages. It is possible to chalk up oil prices to volatile movements that are as likely to go up as down. But falling inflation more broadly is a sign of economic weakness, because in a healthy economy, prices rise along with improving conditions.

title: Rochas: Fall 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Classical Playlist: Schumann, Bach, Prokofiev and More
description: SCHUMANN: String Quartets No. 1, 2 and 3Ying Quartet(Sono Luminus DSL-92184)Though the 200th anniversary of Schumanns birth was celebrated in 2010, this year, for whatever reasons, has seen a burst of new Schumann recordings, especially of the four symphonies. Now the impressive Ying Quartet offers this rewarding recording of Schumanns three string quartets (No. 1 in A minor, No. 2 in F, No. 3 in A). The ensemble, originally comprised of four siblings, came to attention in 1992 upon the members graduation from the Eastman School of Music. (Three of the siblings remain; Ayano Ninomiya has been first violinist since 2010.) These insightful performances balance Romantic impetuosity with refinement and intelligence. (The album comes with a standard CD and an additional Pure Audio Blu-ray version.) (Anthony Tommasini)

title: Doug Wrights Posterity, With John Noble and Hamish Linklater
description: Characters with thorns, plucked from history in all their contrariness, have been an abiding source of inspiration for Doug Wright. A Marquis de Sade in extremis was the central figure in Quills, which won Mr. Wright an Obie Award in 1996.

title: Indian Official on Rapists Interview
description: The Indian home minister Rajnath Singh said that his government would try to block the screening of a British documentary that includes an interview with a man convicted in a gang-rape case from 2012.

title: Iraqis Want Lead Role in Driving ISIS From Mosul
description: BAGHDAD  Underscoring the Iraqi governments determination to control the timetable and tactics in the battle against the Islamic State, the countrys defense minister declared on Wednesday that the most challenging operation, driving the militants from Mosul, Iraqs second-largest city, would be planned, timed and executed by Iraqis.

title: JPMorgan Promotes Two to Run Mergers in North America
description: JPMorgan Chase has elevated two relatively young bankers to become co-heads of mergers and acquisitions for North America.

title: Bouchra Jarrars Paris Short List
description: Like Paris itself, Bouchra Jarrars clothes fuse traditional elegance with contemporary cool. The designer founded her namesake line, which includes both haute couture and ready-to-wear collections, in 2010 after a decade and a half spent in some of the citys top ateliers, including stints as Nicolas Ghesquieres studio manager at Balenciaga and as head of couture design at Christian Lacroix. Her fastidiously tailored daywear has since achieved cult-favorite status thanks to such signatures as couture-grade motorcycle jackets and expertly cut pants.

title: European Court Upholds British View on Euro Clearinghouses
description: LONDON  In a judgment with political and financial ramifications, a European court on Wednesday ruled that the European Central Bank cannot require financial houses that clear trades of euro-denominated securities to be in eurozone countries.

title: Is There Life After Herms?
description: PARIS  Christophe Lemaire, the whispery, whiskery designer of Lemaire, is an odd avatar of steel-spined grit. Hes a philosophe of fashion, given to long pauses for thought as he chews over how and why he makes the clothes he makes. He dresses plainly, in Japanese-denim work shirts tucked into Japanese-denim jeans. He doesnt broadcast bravery.

title: Chrissie Hynde to Publish Memoir
description: The golden women of rock n roll have more stories to tell.

title: Ben Bernanke Has an Impressive Passive-Aggressive Streak, and Other Things We Learned in the New Fed Transcripts
description: The annual release of transcripts of Federal Reserve meetings is a time to take stock of how some of the nations top economic policy makers made their decisions, with the comfortable advantage of five years of hindsight.

title: Children Return to School in Liberia as Ebola Outbreak Ebbs
description: Ebola cases have receded into the single digits in Liberia, but fear of the virus and a depressed economy have dampened a back-to-school campaign.

title: Back to School, Though Not Back to Normal, in a Liberia Still Fearful of Ebola
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  A couple of dozen students sat quietly inside the C.D.B. King Elementary Schools dim and dusty auditorium on their first morning back. Despite the stuffy heat, many of the children wore long sleeves and trousers that covered as much skin as possible.

title: Children Return to School in Liberia as Ebola Outbreak Ebbs

description: Department of Justice report into the shooting death of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., in August.

description: Scientists at the University of California, Santa Barbara, and at Google reported on Wednesday in the journal Nature that they had made a significant advance that brings them a step closer to developing a quantum computer.

title: Interview Renews Horror of New Delhi Gang Rape
description: A new documentary that includes an interview with one of the men who raped and brutalized a woman aboard a private bus in New Delhi in 2012 has reignited passions about the case.

description: Josh Earnest, White House spokesman, questioning the basis for the case against the Affordable Care Act heard Wednesday at the Supreme Court.

title: U.S. Jury Convicts Man Charged in a Britain Bomb Plot

title: Charlie Hebdo Documentary to Be Shown in New York
description: Two months after the deadly terrorist attack on the Paris office ofCharlie Hebdo, a 2008 documentary about that satirical newspaper will be screened at New Yorks IFC Center on Monday. Bob Mankoff, cartoon editor of The New Yorker, will introduce the film.

title: A Review of Digital Tools for Artists, Photographers and Writers
description: For a budding artist, a simple pen and paper may seem a bit old-fashioned in the age of iPad animation tools. Today, there are smart notebooks that can turn drawings into digital concepts, new types of camera gear that can work a smartphone and keyboards made for the multitasker.

title: British Property Secrecy Could Hide Crimes, Report Says
description: LONDON  Foreign companies registered in offshore tax havens like the British Virgin Islands own 36,342 buildings in London that could be used for illegal purposes, a report by Transparency International said on Wednesday.

title: Atomic Dilemma: Debating How to Prevent Iran From Developing Nuclear Weapons
description: Overview |  The United States, Israel, Saudi Arabia and other allies agree that Iran must not be allowed to develop a nuclear weapon. But beyond that consensus, there is a fundamental split in what is the best way to achieve that goal. Is it diplomacy? Is it punishment, in the form of economic sanctions, and threats, in the form of imminent military action? And even if negotiations yield an agreement, will a country like Iran, with which the United States has had no formal relations since 1979, abide by an agreement, or will it simply use the accord as a cover for producing a breakout weapon? These are tough questions. And the best answer is up for debate  the kind of complex real-world debate students can participate in, write about and learn from in this lesson.

title: In Lincoln Exhibit, Witnesses to History
description: Notes from Abraham Lincolns autopsy will be on display at the Fenimore Art Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y., starting April 1.

title: Senate Fails to Override Obamas Keystone Pipeline Veto
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday failed to override President Obamas veto of a bill that would have approved construction of the controversial Keystone XL oil pipeline.

description: Wall Street is on edge as it awaits the release of the results of the Federal Reserves stress tests.

title: Dinosaurs Forever
description: New picture books include "Dinosaur vs. Mommy" and "If I Had a Triceratops."

title: Jittery Alex Rodriguez Gets a Hit and Fist Bumps in His Spring Debut
description: TAMPA, Fla.  A fly ball had barely settled into the glove of Yankees left fielder Ramon Flores  the final out of the top of the first inning  when Alex Rodriguez popped out of the dugout and into the on-deck circle. He was taking practice swings with a weighted bat before all of his teammates had made it off the field.

title: Review: American Crime, a Series Where Justice Is Far From Black or White
description: The crime doesnt seem to be about race. But everything around it  the rage of the accused, the grief of the victims families, the investigation, the defense and the prosecution  is tinged with prejudice of one kind or another.

title: Syrian Opposition to Post Dead Detainees Photos
description: WASHINGTON  The Syrian opposition on Wednesday began posting about 4,000 photographs of detainees who have died in President Bashar al-Assads prisons so that family members can try to identify the victims and potentially serve as plaintiffs in war crimes cases that could be filed in courts in Europe and possibly the United States.

title: Outdated Encryption Keys Leave Phones Vulnerable to Hackers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A government policy that forbade the export of products with strong encryption in the 1990s has years later left users of devices like Android and Apple phones vulnerable to hackers when they visit one-third of all websites, including whitehouse.gov and nsa.gov.

title: The Supreme Court and the Fate of American Health Care
description: In 2012, the chief justice of the United States, John Roberts Jr., saved the Affordable Care Act by a single, surprising vote. On Wednesday morning, the chief justice was again expected to hold the decisive vote as the Supreme Court heard extended oral argument in the latest assault on President Obamas signature health care law.

title: Clash of Views on Netanyahus Speech
Herringbone Hits the Runways for Fall 2015
description: Herringbone, traditionally a mens wear suiting pattern, is no stranger to the womens wear runways. And for fall 2015, designers are pushing long, dramatic lengths of it, nearly from head to toe. Back in New York, DKNY and Marc Jacobs introduced it on a large coat and ladylike cape, respectively. And in Milan, Prada went for a more masculine shape befitting the fabrics roots: a retro suit accented with bright gem tones in keeping with the houses colorful show.

title: First Draft Focus: Making It Official
More Children Eat Fruit in School, Study Shows
description: WASHINGTON  Changes made to government-subsidized meals by the Obama administration to get schoolchildren to eat more fruits are having their intended effect, according to a study released on Wednesday.

title: Ferguson Police Tainted by Bias, Justice Department Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department on Wednesday called on Ferguson, Mo., to overhaul its criminal justice system, declaring that the city had engaged in so many constitutional violations that they could be corrected only by abandoning its entire approach to policing, retraining its employees and establishing new oversight.

title: Big Sean Opens at No. 1
description: The 26-year-old rapper Big Sean is a protg of Kanye West, and gets plenty of paparazzi attention as the boyfriend of the pop starlet Ariana Grande. Now he has another claim to fame: a No. 1 album.

title: F.D.U.-Florham, Division III Champion, Sets Its Sights on Repeating
description: Marc Mitchell was born and raised in Newark. Now 46, he has coached New Jersey basketball teams  recreation league, middle school, high school and college  for more than 20 years.
