description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Bhumika Arora before (left) and after (right) makeup by Aaron de May and hair by Anthony Turner.

title: Cosmos to Lead Return to Post-Embargo Cuba
description: The New York Cosmos will play the Cuban national team in June in Havana, becoming the first American professional team to play on the island in 16 years and the first since the United States government announced that it would restore full diplomatic relations with Cuba in December.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (Comedy Central) NIGHT OF TOO MANY STARS: AMERICA COMES TOGETHER FOR AUTISM PROGRAMS Jon Stewart hosts; Larry David, Martin Short, Larry Wilmore, Fred Armisen, Andy Cohen, Ilana Glazer, Abbi Jacobson and Susan Sarandon oversee the phone banks; and Bill Burr, Louis C. K., John Oliver, Paul Rudd, Amy Schumer, Steve Buscemi, Steve Carell, Gilbert Gottfried, Maya Rudolph and Sarah Silverman, above, perform in sketches taped at the Beacon Theater in this telethon on behalf of autism awareness and education.

title: Kenzos Battle-Ready White Shadow
description: At the Kenzo fall 2015 show, the labels co-creative directors (and co-founders of Opening Ceremony) Carol Lim and Humberto Leon celebrated the collective conscious. We wanted a look that would be symbolic of the womens strength and give an element of protection, Lim says. The hairstylist Anthony Turner interpreted this as almost Amazonian, he said backstage, by giving the models deep side parts lined up with the outer edge of the brow and slicking hair into long, thick, low ponytails with a blunt edge. By contrast, the makeup artist Aaron de May brought the free-spirited warrior women to life with dewy, pearlescent complexions, glassy lips and a thick swath of opaque white shadow applied with a chopped-up paintbrush to create an erratic edge. The makeup feels like they took something from nature and put it on with their fingers, Leon says. It looks like the girls did it themselves, de May adds.

description: Paris

title: 22 Arrested in Killing of Rape Suspect Who Was Pulled From Jail by Mob in India
description: NEW DELHI  Photographs and videos on social media of an enraged mob that seized a man accused of rape from a jail in the northeastern Indian state of Nagaland, dragged him through the streets and beat him to death helped lead to the arrests of 22 people over the weekend, the authorities said.

title: Clinton Impersonation Steals Saturday Night Live Spotlight
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has become a master at deflecting questions about her presidential aspirations, but on Saturday she got an early dose of the comedic treatment she can expect if she runs.

title: Not There Campaign Removes Women From Ads for International Womens Day
description: Women across New York had vanished.

title: 1965: Marines Land in Vietnam by Sea, Air
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam  Two battalions of U.S. marines today [March 8] landed by sea and air in South Vietnam to guard the strategic Da Nang air base, about 80 miles from the North Vietnamese border. Viet Cong guerrillas fired at the U.S. transport planes carrying many of the troops, but apparently the only result was a bullet hole in the wing of a C130 aircraft. No Marines were hurt. South Vietnamese government troops had spent the weekend flushing out Viet Cong guerrillas in the area to make the region around Da Nang as safe as possible for the 3,500-man Marine force to land. But the Marine deployment around the air base could soon lead to the first ground fighting between U.S. combat units and Communist guerrillas in Vietnam. U.S military men have been serving as advisers to South Vietnamese Army and Marine outfits in the field. But until now, there have been no American ground combat formations in South Vietnam. Spokesmen for the U.S military mission in Saigon said the Marines would remain under U.S. control, but their duties would be assigned after consultation with South Vietnamese military officers.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 9, 1965

title: Review: The New York Philharmonic Highlights Nordic Works
description: The Contact! new-music concerts were among Alan Gilberts first ideas at the helm of the New York Philharmonic, and they remain some of his best. At times, the series has seemed a missed opportunity, stuck in sleepy Manhattan halls and too focused on prominent composers. But high hopes have often been musically fulfilled.

title: Review: Michael Meyers In Manchuria Documents a Changing Rural China
description: In Chinese, the region that was once the cradle of the mighty Qing dynasty is today rather prosaically known as Dongbei, the Northeast. Home to 110 million people, it has smoggy cities and bitingly cold weather. It can seem drab or worse to a visitor. But Michael Meyer has a more refined sense of history and poetry, and with his new book, In Manchuria: A Village Called Wasteland and the Transformation of Rural China, he seizes the opportunity to dig beneath the regions gritty surfaces.

title: Akris: Fall 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Job Growth for Hispanics Is Outpacing Other Groups
description: WASHINGTON  With the economy adding nearly 300,000 jobs in February, its clear that the labor market is on a roll. And, perhaps surprisingly, there is no group for whom that is truer than Hispanics.

title: Visiting Nurses, Helping Mothers on the Margins
description: MEMPHIS  When it came time to have the baby, Shirita Corley was alone. Her mother was at the casino, her sister was not answering her cellphone, her boyfriend had disappeared months earlier, and her father she had not seen in years.

title: Review: Hozier at Beacon Theater With Somber Songs of Love and Other Futilities
description: Hozier, the Irish songwriter who performed at the Beacon Theater on Friday night, is a somber phenomenon. His songs ponder passion, mortality, compulsion and sin. His voice is a richly melancholy moan, with echoes of Van Morrison and Jeff Buckley; his music is grounded in blues, soul and Celtic ballads, and its full of minor chords, starkly syncopated guitar picking, blunt tom-tom beats and moody drama. Yet Hozier, whose debut album was released last fall, is also a hitmaker who was greeted, between his doleful songs, with the squeals and whistles of pop adoration and female voices calling out, I love you!

title: Review: The Legend of Mulan Choreographs a Chinese Folk Tale
description: Mulan, the girl who disguises herself as a man to join the army in place of her frail father, is beloved by Disney fans. But does it work as a dance? The Hong Kong Dance Company, in residence at the David H. Koch Theater, presented its version of that Chinese folk tale on Thursday with a four-act production of The Legend of Mulan.

title: Apple Watch Demonstration, Questions for HSBC and Greeces Bailout
description: Here are some of the top business stories to pay attention to in the coming week.

title: Review: St. Paul Chamber Orchestra Opens Its New Concert Hall
description: ST. PAUL  While the world has many splendid opera houses and orchestra halls, performance spaces ideally suited to chamber orchestras of, say, 30 to 35 players, are rarer. These ensembles are like hybrids between chamber groups and full orchestras. Whats needed is a hall that allows clarity and detail in the playing to come through while providing orchestral resonance and bloom.

title: On the Fall 2015 Runways in Paris, Black Patent Leather Coats Are Slicker Than Ever
description: Patent leather, in all its glossy glory, has made a return to the runway in a big way for the fall/winter 2015 season  from a prim and proper skirt suit at Emilia Wickstead and J.W. Andersons ode to the 80s in London to thigh-high boots at Versace. In Paris, especially, weve seen lots of black patent leather outerwear. First, Jonathan Andersons flirtation with the decade of excess at Loewe included a loose coat. At Maison Margiela, John Gallianos debut prt--porter collection for the brand featured a sleek, floor-grazing belted coat. Finally, at Dior, Raf Simonss interest in the material (as evidenced by his couture presentation in January) was again demonstrated by a netted black patent coat.

title: Review: Kronos Quartet, in an Emotionally Packed Performance
description: The Kronos Quartet offered a program of new and recent works full of ideas in the Late Nights at Zankel Hall series on Saturday, and the composers program notes were sometimes more compelling than the music.

title: Givenchy: Fall 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Review: The Peggy Spina Tap Company at the Spina Loft in SoHo
description: It has been many years since lofts in SoHo were the province of musicians, dancers and artists. There are holdouts, though, and on Friday one of them invited the public in. Passing the high-end stores on Prince Street, audience members climbed a rickety staircase to sit on folding chairs in Peggy Spinas loft. Ushers took care to keep slush-wet shoes off the wooden floor. That was reserved for footwear with metal on the soles. Ms. Spina is a tap dancer.

title: G.O.P. Is Divided as Budget Bills Start Piling Up
description: WASHINGTON  In their first major test of governing this year, Republicans stumbled, faltered  and nearly shut down the Department of Homeland Security.

title: Review: In Hunter Gatherers, a Couples Dinner Grows Increasingly Bizarre
description: Plays that mix realism and absurdity can be difficult to stage effectively. The director and actors have to figure out how to do that Durang-ian swing between could happen and deliriously improbable.

title: Jack White to Release Elviss First Recording
description: The musician Jack White portrayed Elvis Presley in Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story in 2007. Now, hes bringing Elvis back to life in another way: by releasing Elviss first-ever recording on Third Man Records, Mr. Whites label, after paying $300,000 for the acetate disc. Billboard reported that Mr. White was the anonymous bidder who bought the 1953 recording at a Graceland auction this January. The record features two covers of ballads, My Happiness and Thats Where Your Heartaches Begin, and was recorded by an 18-year-old Presley in Memphis three years before his breakout single, Heartbreak Hotel. Third Man Records will release the recording on April 18, Record Store Day, as a 10-inch, 78-r.p.m. facsimile. Mr. White has broken a few vinyl-related records recently. On Record Store Day last year, he set the worlds fastest time (3 hours, 55 minutes and 21 seconds) for recording, pressing and releasing a vinyl disc, and his 2014 album, Lazaretto, is the biggest-selling vinyl album since 1994.

title: At Cline, Phoebe Philo Moves the Jewelry to the Feet
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: 6 Stabbed at Migos Show
description: Six people were stabbed at a concert by the rap group Migos on Friday night in Albany, said Steven Smith, the public information officer for the Albany police. The concert, at the Washington Avenue Armory, took a violent turn between 12:50 and 1:35 a.m. None of the injuries were life threatening. In addition, a 19-year-old woman reported that she was robbed and assaulted in a venue bathroom by six women. She sustained minor injuries to her head and face. The police are investigating, but no arrests have been made. In October, three people were shot, one fatally, outside Club Hive in Queens, following a Migos after-party at the site.

title: Lederer Memorial Trophy Winners in London
description: Experts like to receive an invitation to the Lederer Memorial Trophy in London, which started in 1945. It mixes a social atmosphere and top-level bridge.

title: Review: In The Returned, the Dead Return as if Nothing Happened
description: Be careful what you wish for. Thats the message of The Returned, a spooky series that debuts on Monday on A&E about dead people who suddenly come back to life for no apparent reason and with no memory of having been absent.

title: Virtual Realitys Potential Displayed at Game Developers Conference
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For game designers, virtual reality became a real business last week when the virtual reality equivalent of Apples app store for iPhones and iPads opened its digital doors.

description: BARCELONA, Spain  When Francisco Gonzlez started working as a software engineer for IBM in the 1960s, the worlds of technology and consumer banking were miles apart.

title: Entertainment
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  When you have children, BOARD GAMEs become very important. They exist as a mechanism for family bonding, a way to show young children the importance of taking turns and a source of wholesome entertainment. Most importantly, however, they exist as a valuable reminder to adults that life, no matter how you play it, is never fair.

title: European Official Not Ready to Stiffen Russia Sanctions

title: Race, History, a President, a Bridge
description: As our van in the presidential motorcade reached the crest of the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala., and began the descent toward the thousands of waiting faces and waving arms of those who had come to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Bloody Sunday, the gravity of that place seized me, pushing out the breath and rousing the wonder.

title: Jets Running Back Is Injured in a Shooting
description: Jets running back Chris Johnson was in stable condition after being wounded in a shoulder early Sunday in a drive-by shooting that left one man dead and another injured, according to the sheriffs office in Orange County, Fla.

title: Netanyahu Comments Cast Doubt on Stance Toward Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said in a campaign statement Sunday, There will be no withdrawals from the occupied West Bank and no concessions to the Palestinians, renewing questions about his declared commitment to the two-state solution.

title: Some Supreme Court Justices Cite 2012 Argument Against Health Care Law as Defense for It Now
description: WASHINGTON  In 2012, the Supreme Court declared that Congress had put a gun to the head of states by pressuring them to expand Medicaid, and it said that such economic dragooning of the states violated federalism principles embedded in the Constitution.

title: Report Says Doping Was Ignored to Shield Armstrong
description: For years, cyclings top officials turned a blind eye to doping, operating in deference primarily to one rider  Lance Armstrong  according to a reform commission that spent the past year excavating the sports doping problems.

title: A Long Island Goodbye
description: The ushers at Nassau Coliseum are institutions at the arena, which is the home rink of the Islanders until next season.

title: Mets Tap Michael Cuddyer, a Former Substitute Teacher, to Fill a Void
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Back in late 2002, Michael Cuddyer was 23 years old, talented and full of promise. He was just establishing himself with the Minnesota Twins. The baseball world was at his feet.

title: Afghan Peace Efforts Reopen Wounds Over Pakistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  On the surface, much of the Afghan public has lined up behind President Ashraf Ghani in his bid to bring the Taliban to peace talks.

title: In a Test of Wills, Japanese Fighter Pilots Confront Chinese
description: NAHA, Japan  Once a sleepy, sun-soaked backwater, this air base on the southern island of Okinawa has become the forefront of a dangerous test of wills between two of Asias largest powers, Japan and China.

description: Prove that you know more than your cellphone, or at least more than other readers, by testing your knowledge of local geography.

title: As Hillary Clinton Stays Quiet About Private Emails, Republicans Seize Moment to Criticize Her
description: One of the best-known photographs of Hillary Rodham Clinton taken in the past several years is that of her in 2011 jetting from Malta to Tripoli aboard an Air Force C-17, wearing dark sunglasses and typing on a BlackBerry.

title: DC and Marvel, Beware: Valiant Is to Make Films
description: DCs Justice League and Marvels Avengers are going to have to make room for even more heroes coming to the big screen. The independent comic book publisher Valiant Entertainment and the Beijing-based DMG Entertainment announced on Sunday a nine-figure investment and partnership for feature-film financing as well as publishing, television and licensing opportunities. Valiants library of characters and concepts include X-O Manowar, an alien abductee from the past thrown into the present with high-tech armor, and the series Harbinger, about teenagers with special abilities at odds with a corporation out to shape the destiny of the world. Comic superheroes are profitable and highly sought intellectual properties for film franchises, said Dan Mintz, the chief executive officer of DMG, in a statement, so taking a stake in the last independent massive comic universe is a strategic investment for DMG that will produce movies and TV that are both appealing and relevant to a global audience. In addition to developing films for release in the United States and China, the two companies will develop Valiants characters for new audiences in China and the Asia-Pacific region. There are plans for Chinese-language publishing, animation and theme parks, as well as toys and apparel.

title: Yankees Skipper Plugs Holes in a Leaky Ship
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Joe Girardi could be forgiven if he feared his head was about to spontaneously combust.

title: Providers Dispute With Viacom Highlights Skirmish Over the Cable Bundle
description: An email from a lobbyist landed in Eric Rouses inbox one afternoon last December, catapulting Mr. Rouse, a commissioner of rural Lenoir County in North Carolina, into the middle of one of the fiercest battles being waged across the media business.

title: In New Exam for Cabbies, Knowledge of Streets Takes a Back Seat
description: The trip from Kennedy Airport to La Guardia is a straight shot on the Van Wyck Expressway, with a little jog on the Grand Central Parkway at the end. Canal Street may be the shortest route from the Holland Tunnel to the Manhattan Bridge, but traffic can make it feel like the longest. And all even-numbered, one-way streets in Manhattan run west-to-east, except for the handful that do not.

title: Popular Demand
description: The Finnish company that created Clash of Clans makes only six apps, but it was the worldwide revenue leader in January, just ahead of King, which makes Candy Crush Soda Saga and 27 other apps.

title: The Song That Drove Sherman Crazy
description: By the time Maj. Gen. William T. Sherman arrived in Boston for the 1890 national encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic, he was already sick of hearing Marching Through Georgia, a song commemorating his historic 1864 campaign from Atlanta to the Atlantic coast. The opera singer Clara Louise Kellogg, a friend of his, later asserted that Sherman had always hated it above all songs, but something snapped in the old generals mind that day in Boston. We can only imagine his growing discomfort as he stood on the grandstand and heard no less than 250 different bands parade by playing the tune. Although Sherman kept his composure at the time, rumors quickly spread that he vowed then and there to never attend another reunion without a guarantee that no one would play it.

title: Two Portrayals of Patz Suspect: Manipulative, or Mentally Ill
description: The man on trial in the kidnapping and murder of Etan Patz has never said in court that he should be acquitted because of mental illness. Yet questions about his sanity have run through nearly all of the testimony so far.

title: Race in Iraq and Syria to Record and Shield Art Falling to ISIS
description: BAGHDAD  In those areas of Iraq and Syria controlled by the Islamic State, residents are furtively recording on their cellphones damage done to antiquities by the extremist group. In northern Syria, museum curators have covered precious mosaics with sealant and sandbags.

title: A Nexus for Titles Has Its Day
description: MACON, Ga.  Macon Coliseum, a no-nonsense box of concrete planted about 80 miles southeast of Atlanta, has hosted seemingly every form of entertainment known to man since it opened in 1968, including arena football, professional wrestling, monster truck rallies and Elvis Presley.

title: The Ferry: A Civil Rights Story
description: Weeks before Selmas Bloody Sunday in 1965, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. urged residents of Gees Bend, Ala., to vote, and fed a continuing fight over a small ferry that would last for decades.

title: Martin Luther Kings Call for Voting Rights Inspired Isolated Hamlet
description: To find Gees Bend on a map of Alabama, you would do well to put your finger on Selma and trace an imaginary line roughly 35 miles to the southwest. Selma is famous, of course, especially on this 50th anniversary of events that earned it an indelible place in civil rights history.

description: Her Majesty will see you now.

title: New York City Officials Cite Progress on Womens Issues at March
description: Chirlane McCray, Mayor Bill de Blasios wife, and several New York commissioners joined hundreds of people on Sunday in a march in Midtown Manhattan to recognize International Womens Day, reinforcing the citys partnership with the United Nations to address gender inequality and violence against women.

title: M.L.S.s Newest Clubs Make Ugly Debut, but Sellout Crowd Sees Plenty of Charm
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Midway through the first half of the first game in New York City F.C. history, David Villa, who had not received a pass he called for, clasped his hands to his face and tilted his head skyward. It was an obvious expression of frustration from a player used to a much higher level of soccer.

title: Crypt at St. Patricks Cathedral Is Made Ready to Receive a Cardinal
description: Underneath the gold altar at St. Patricks Cathedral, two small copper doors, turned green by time, provide passage to the cathedrals crypt, a sanctuary within a sanctuary.

title: Hillary Clinton Faces Test of Record as Womens Advocate
description: MIAMI  It was supposed to be a carefully planned anniversary to mark one of the most important and widely praised moments in Hillary Rodham Clintons political career  and to remind the country, ahead of a likely 2016 presidential campaign, about her long record as a champion for the rights of women and girls.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 8, 2015

title: Wisconsin Dominates, Flustering Ohio State and Its Star Freshman
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Midway through the first half of No. 6 Wisconsins obliteration of No. 23 Ohio State on Sunday, DAngelo Russell, the Buckeyes star freshman, zipped a pass under the basket to his teammate Marc Loving.

title: Lawrence R. Scanlon Jr., Union Leader, Dies at 65
description: Lawrence R. Scanlon Jr., a behind-the-scenes power in organized labor whose fund-raising elevated the political profile of public employee unions, but who had mixed results in fending off recent efforts by Republican governors to limit unions bargaining rights, was killed on Feb. 27 in a car accident near Beaufort, S.C. He was 65.

title: A Coach Woven in Syracuses Fabric Oversees Its Unraveling
description: Just in time for the beginning of March Madness, the N.C.A.A. has hit a prominent member, Syracuse, with harsh penalties. The episode reminds us, once again, of how far programs will go to achieve and maintain athletic success.

title: Dodgers Yasiel Puig Moves to Match Swagger With Heads-Up Play
description: GLENDALE, ARIZ.  Before their game here on Sunday, the Los Angeles Dodgers practiced cutoffs and relays from the outfield. In past spring trainings, this was less a demonstration of fundamentals and more the Yasiel Puig Show. But times are changing.

title: Rededicated to His Game and Himself, Dustin Johnson Prevails at Doral
description: DORAL, Fla.  The player who has emerged as a favorite to capture next months Masters won an important tuneup Sunday, but it was not Rory McIlroy, the world No. 1, who can complete a career Grand Slam with a victory at Augusta National.

title: Snow on the Sidelines
description: With the court finally free of slush and ice, a group of friends played handball at Sara D. Roosevelt Park in Manhattan on Sunday.

title: As The Jinx Airs, Inquiry Into Death of Dursts Friend Is Said to Be Reopened
description: Over the course of 33 years, Robert A. Durst, the wealthy, peripatetic son of a New York real estate family, has been an elusive suspect in the deaths of three people in three states.

title: N.C.A.A. Mens Conference Tournament Previews
description: With Selection Sunday right around the corner, here is a look at some of the top story lines at this weeks major conference tournaments and who should be moving on to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Grizzlies at Wizards
description: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 9:10 A.M. (HBO Signature) ATONEMENT (2007) Saoirse Ronan (above with James McAvoy) received an Oscar nomination for her portrayal of Briony, a 13-year-old aspiring playwright who accuses the son (Mr. McAvoy) of a family servant  and the lover of her older sister (Keira Knightley)  of a crime in this drama directed by Joe Wright and based on the Ian McEwan novel. Romola Garai and Vanessa Redgrave play Briony at different times in her life. The main casualty of the films long, murky middle and end sections is the big moral theme  and also the ingenious formal gimmick  that provides the book with some of its intensity and much of its cachet, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. As the title suggests, Atonement is fundamentally about guilt and the attempt to overcome it, and about the tricky, tragically imperfect power of art to compensate for real-life crimes and misdemeanors. The film received six more Oscar nominations, including one for best picture, and won for Dario Marianellis score, featuring the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet and a clacking typewriter.

title: University of Oklahoma Fraternity Closed After Racist Video Is Posted Online
description: Sigma Alpha Epsilon, one of Americas largest college fraternities, closed its chapter at the University of Oklahoma late Sunday after a video posted hours earlier appeared to show fraternity members singing a racist chant. The university administration said it was investigating.

title: Word of the Day | plutocracy
description: plutocracy  \pl-t-kr-se\  noun

title: Corrections: March 9, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: When Food Is Wasted, Many Ills Come to the Fore
The Worlds Problem With Sex Ed
description: ONTARIO was thrown into an uproar recently when officials presented the first changes to the provinces sex-education curriculum since 1998. Starting in the fall, second graders will learn about saying no and improper touching; third graders will be introduced to gender identity and sexual orientation; and seventh graders will learn of the dangers of sexting and of sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Our Navy Is Big Enough
description: AT General Dynamics Bath Iron Works in Maine, workers are completing a warship unlike any the world has seen. The $3.3 billion Zumwalt destroyer uses all-electric propulsion, employs stealth features, carries a huge arsenal of guided missiles, and mounts advanced cannons that can hit targets 63 miles away. Most likely it will never be tested in battle, because no other nation is even attempting to build a warship like the Zumwalt, which symbolizes the gigantic advantage the United States Navy enjoys.

title: Partying Like Its 1995
description: Six years ago, Paul Ryan, who has since become the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee and the G.O.P.s leading voice on matters economic, had an Op-Ed article published in The Times. Under the headline Thirty Years Later, a Return to Stagflation, he warned that the efforts of the Obama administration and the Federal Reserve to fight the effects of financial crisis would bring back the woes of the 1970s, with both inflation and unemployment high.

title: No Cause to Delay the Afghan Pullout
description: Last year, the Afghan Army lost more than 17,000 troops and civilian employees as a result of desertions, combat deaths and discharges, leaving a force that is authorized to employ 195,000 people significantly understaffed. In the fight against the Taliban, Afghan forces have been getting killed and injured at a significantly higher rate than in 2014, exacerbating attrition levels that appear to be unsustainable.

title: A Complicated Future for a Banlieue on the Outskirts of Paris
description: PANTIN, France  Life in my neighborhood, a banlieue on the northeastern edge of Paris, has been changing for a while. In October, the local green market moved to a new public square that has a new bistro with cafe tables and a lavish new bakery, even a new vendor selling organic kale. Pantin, dubbed the Brooklyn of Paris because of its booming cultural scene, seemed to be turning into a French version of Williamsburg.

title: A Reckless Call From the Senates Leader
description: For all his partisan animus toward President Obama, it is still shocking to see the Senates majority leader, Mitch McConnell, urge the nations governors to undermine the Obama administrations efforts to regulate power plant emissions of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas responsible for global warming.

With a combination of still images, video, text and informational graphics, it seeks to use as many different tools to capture the readers imagination. But what it really is aiming for is something that is time-tested: to create a community.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  The value of a wristwatch is typically defined by its materials, design, features and brand. For the new Apple Watch, all those factors will apply, but so will something else: apps.

description: WASHINGTON  It is fair to say the life of Representative Steve Russell, Republican of Oklahoma, became considerably more sedate after he was elected to Congress.

description: LONDON  The Dutch food producer Wessanen said on Monday that it had agreed to sell the maker of Little Hugs, the brightly colored fruit drinks in barrel-shaped bottles, to the buyout firm Brynwood Partners for about $55 million.

title: The Far-Reaching Effects of a Fall
description: Although statistics show that most falls occur in the home and that older people, especially those with chronic illnesses or failing senses, are the most frequent victims, there is no shortage of such mishaps on wintry streets for both young and old. Especially not this winter, and especially not in cities and towns like Atlanta where experience negotiating ice and slush under foot is limited.

description: MADISON, Conn.  Mac Bohonnon, then 15, was on Facebook catching up with his longtime friend Kiley McKinnon.

title: What to Expect on the Sixth Day of Paris Fashion Week
description: PARIS  Start gargling saltwater, all ye who were out late at Givenchy last night, and empty out your leather purse into a cloth tote or something, because at 10 a.m. Stella McCartney, the groovy Beatle daughter and mum of four, is showing her winter collection with vegan shoes and probably some faux furs at the Opra Garnier.

title: With Ebola No Longer Raging in Sierra Leone, Normalcy Slowly Returns

title: Daily Report: Square, the Payment Start-Up, Bolsters Its Services for Small Businesses
description: Square, the six-year-old payments start-up, began by offering small, square-shaped credit card readers that plug into smartphones or tablets. The device helps small businesses easily accept credit card payments.

title: Greystar Real Estate Partners to Buy London Student Housing Portfolio
description: LONDON  Greystar Real Estate Partners has agreed to buy a portfolio of student housing from the British real estate investment firm Round Hill Capital for 600 million pounds, or about $902 million, according to a person familiar with the discussions.

title: ClassPass and the Joy and Guilt of the Digital Middleman Economy
description: Each month, I pay $99 to a company called ClassPass for the luxury of taking an unlimited number of fitness classes in and around Brooklyn, where I live. In the depths of this winter, regular exercise  a key to calming my hyperactive and anxiety-prone brain even when its less awful outside  has become crucial enough to maintaining my sanity that I find myself prioritizing my ClassPass bill over other splurges, like ordering in, taking cabs and expensive nights out.

title: Greeces Tense Talks With Its Creditors Escalate to the Next Phase
description: BRUSSELS  Greeces debt negotiations with its international creditors will proceed to the next, more technical level later this week, as a result of an agreement reached on Monday by eurozone finance ministers.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | March 9, 2015
description: Updated: March 10, 2015

title: Today in Politics: Common Core to Hit Iowa Airwaves
description: Good Monday morning from Washington, where spring is in the air and alleviating (real) gridlock is on the agenda. Hillary Rodham Clintons emails continue to be the talk of the town, and former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida is enlisting his son to help fill his would-be campaign war chest. We start off the week with a look at what future Iowa caucusgoers will be seeing a lot of: Common Core ads.

title: Morning Agenda: Stress Tests Threaten Goldman Profit
description: STRESS TEST RESULTS THREATEN GOLDMAN PROFIT | After Goldman Sachss poor performance on Federal Reserve stress tests, analysts and investors are worried that the bank could be barred from buying back its own stock or increasing dividends, an important profit source for the bank, DealBooks Nathaniel Popper writes. The bank has used dividends and share buybacks to appeal to investors, which generally increase the amount of profits attributed to every share, at a time when other elements of the banks business have faced challenges. The Fed will publicly give its final verdict on Goldmans buyback plans on Wednesday.

title: When a Presidential Nominating Contest Isnt a Contest
description: The Democratic Party is on the cusp of a primary-election campaign unlike any in memory. It does not have an incumbent president running for re-election. It does not even have a sitting vice president with an easy path to the nomination. Yet the party may conduct one of the least competitive nominating contests in modern political history.

title: G.M. to Buy Back $5 Billion of Its Stock
description: DETROIT  After a rough 2014 punctuated by a record number of safety recalls, the last thing General Motors needed was a prolonged proxy fight with unhappy shareholders.

description: Alcoa, the big metal manufacturer best known for aluminum, is expanding its reach into the aerospace business.

But its true that recovery was a long time coming. Why?

title: Hillary Clinton Is More Vulnerable in 2016 Than You Think
description: Hillary Clinton is a primary candidate whose strength has little precedent, one who seems poised to sweep the primaries without facing any serious challenge.

title: U.N. Reveals Alarmingly High Levels of Violence Against Women
description: UNITED NATIONS  The evidence is ubiquitous. The gang rape of a young woman on a bus in New Delhi sets off an unusual burst of national outrage in India. In South Sudan, women are assaulted by both sides in the civil war. In Iraq, jihadists enslave women for sex. And American colleges face mounting scrutiny about campus rape.

description: A week after installing a new chief executive, McDonalds announced on Monday that sales continued to fall in February.

title: Leon Wieseltier Takes New Humanities Post at Brookings
description: The Brookings Institution was founded in 1916 with the mission of becoming the first private organization devoted to analyzing public policy issues at the national level. Now, the think tank known for its work on economics, governance and foreign policy (and a steady drip of news releases with titles like Innovation and manufacturing labor: a value-chain perspective) will be adding the humanities to its portfolio.

description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank began its long-awaited bond-buying program on Monday, an unprecedented 1.1 trillion euro bid to help revive the eurozone economy.

description: After six years of covering theater for The Times, Im trading in Broadway opening nights for a role on our 2016 presidential campaign team. The politics of theater is giving way to the theater of politics.

description: So how many people in how many states could be affected by the big Supreme Court case about Obamacares insurance subsidies? Good question.

title: Japanese Women Play Without Their Superstar
description: VILAMOURA, Portugal  The players of the Japanese womens national soccer team went through a training drill here last week, scooting short passes in from the wings before sprinting toward the penalty area and blasting shots on goal. One after another after another they went, mostly working in silence except when they broke into loud cheers after a player hit a particularly pretty shot that found the side netting. The mood was upbeat  the sunny weather on Portugals south coast surely helped  but also serious and focused.

title: Mall Owner Simon Property Bids for Rival Macerich to Aim at High-End Shoppers
description: Across America, many shopping malls are dying. Stagnant middle-class incomes, overbuilt retail space and competitors like Amazon.com and Costco are turning these former fixtures of the retail landscape into abandoned boxes, devoid of clients or customers.

title: Unions Suffer Latest Defeat in Midwest With Signing of Wisconsin Measure
description: MADISON, Wis.  For decades, states across the South, Great Plains and Rocky Mountains enacted policies that prevented organized labor from forcing all workers to pay union dues or fees. But the industrial Midwest resisted.

title: In Forecasting Health Costs, Let Technology Be Your Guide
description: The expansion of health care insurance can drive the development of new technologies that can drive up health care spending. But it doesnt have to.

title: New Research on Antidepressants and Pregnancy Finds No Link to Asthma
description: Many women with a history of depression who take antidepressants assume that once they get pregnant, they should try to wean themselves off their meds to avoid negative side effects for the baby. A new large study published in the journal Pediatrics challenges one reason behind that assumption. The research found that taking selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (the antidepressants also known as S.S.R.I.s) while pregnant does not increase the risk of asthma in the resulting babies. What is associated with an increased risk of asthma? According to this study and other research, untreated prenatal depression.

title: How to Get More Women to Join the Debate, Part II
description: Many people asked good questions in response to my article about how only 25 percent of comments in the New York Times are made by women. Here are responses to several of them.

title: Wet and Ever-So-Slightly Wild Ponytails at Stella McCartney
description: Its really quite directional in an effortless way, says the hairstylist Eugene Souleiman of the look he created for the Stella McCartney fall 2015 fashion show. The collection is really very beautiful, so I didnt want to do romantic, I didnt want to do pretty, I didnt want to do glamorous. I wanted to do something that wasnt so refined. Backstage at the Paris Opera House, Souleiman spritzed models dry hair until damp and used his fingers to work through piles of mousse to achieve a wet-look effect with texture and hold. After pulling hair into a ponytail at the crown of the head, he matted wisps around the face. We wanted to make it look as if the girls pulled their hair back into a ponytail after they had been swimming, he says. We havent dipped our feet into the water, we dove right in.

title: Secede? Separatists Claim Texas Never Joined United States
description: HOUSTON  The Republic of Texas is unlike any other volunteer organization in what used to be the Republic of Texas.

title: 1915: U.K. Wants Power Over All Factories During the War
description: LONDON  Great Britain is the main arsenal of the Grand Alliance. This aspect of the war received new emphasis from Mr. Lloyd George in his speech in introducing the Amending Defence of the Realm Bill in the House of Commons this afternoon. The Chancellor said it is of vital importance to the country that the Government should be given every facility for the output of munitions of war. Under the act of 1914 the Government obtained the power to take over any works where war material is being produced. It now asks for power in respect to works where war material is not being produced at present, but which are capable of being used for the purpose.  The New York Herald, European Edition, March 10, 1915

title: Herblocks Sharp Pen, and Others, to Go on Display at Library of Congress
description: The Library of Congress  will showcase the power and punch of the political cartoon in the exhibition Pointing Their Pens: Herblock and Fellow Cartoonists Confront the Issues, which opens March 21. Herbert L. Block, who died in 2001, was the chief editorial cartoonist for The Washington Post for more than half a century. His work forms the core of the exhibition, which focuses on six subjects that inspired some of his most memorable cartoons: World War II, the McCarthy era, the Cold War, the Vietnam War, Richard M. Nixon and the Middle East. Each will have two cartoons by Herblock and three by his contemporaries.

title: 1965: Alabama Brutality Condemned
description: WASHINGTON  President Johnson today sharply condemned brutality against Negro demonstrators in Alabama but urged both sides in the voting-rights dispute to observe law and order. Mr. Johnson also said he has directed the Justice Department to act as a friend of the court in seeking a ruling that would permit Negroes to exercise what he termed their right to walk from Selma to Montgomery in order to focus attention on their efforts to secure the right to register and vote.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 10, 1965

title: With Simple Bow, Public Mourning for Cardinal Egan Begins
description: Just before 10 a.m. on Monday, the normally frenetic scene in front of St. Patricks Cathedral, on Fifth Avenue in Midtown Manhattan, went silent. A Cadillac hearse pulled up, and traffic was halted by the police. The great double doors of the cathedral swung open, and a small procession of priests, along with Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the sitting archbishop of New York, emerged into the sunlight.

description: LONDON  In an open letter published by The Financial Times, 33 of the worlds leading opera directors and managers voiced support for the beleaguered English National Opera, which has been beset by infighting among its top administrators as well as budget cuts and probationary measures imposed by Englands leading arts funding body, the Arts Council England.

description: NORMAN, Okla.  The University of Oklahoma severed ties to one of the nations largest college fraternities on Monday, and ordered the campus chapter to vacate its fraternity house, after videos surfaced that appeared to show fraternity members singing a racist song.

title: $25 Million to Support the Arts in Miami and South Florida
description: Visitors to the Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami, which opened in a temporary location four months ago, have more to look forward to than the construction of the museums permanent home, which is set to break ground later this year.

title: Pi Day of the Century
description: Happy  Day! Saturdays 3.14.15 comes around only every hundred years, so lets have some fun acknowledging the most famous ratio in mathematics. (In case you missed it, check out yesterdays crossword by Tom McCoy, a sophomore linguistics major at Yale.)

description: A protest was held on the University of Oklahoma campus in Norman after a video was posted online appearing to show members of the Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity singing an antiblack chant.

title: First Draft Focus: League of Cities
A Time to Avoid Anxiety Drugs
description: People sometimes take Valium or Ativan to relieve anxiety before surgery, but a new study suggests that these benzodiazepine drugs have little beneficial effect and may even delay recovery.

title: Brooklyn Style, Transported to the Suburbs of Connecticut
description: Brooklyn might be the cradle of the maker movement, with its deep appreciation for all thats handcrafted and artisan-made, but predictably that cultural aesthetic has increasingly found a home in the boroughs surrounding suburbs. Case in point: Gather, a recently opened fashion and home dcor shop tucked away in the front-porch-loving town of Old Greenwich, Connecticut. Co-owned by Rebecca Karson, a former prop stylist who grew up in Brooklyn Heights, the 80-square-foot space is tiny (even by New Yorkers standards) and filled with a well-edited selection of small batch goods, including porcelain clay pottery hand-carved by the artist Elizabeth Benotti; Jess Browns rag dolls, which are filled with sustainable corn fiber and dyed using Persian black tea; slim, delicate gold jewelry sculpted by Rebecca Peacock (who works out of her farmhouse studio in the Catskill Mountains); and delicate clothing from Nuthatch, which hails from Maine and employs local mills. In other words, its a mix you can imagine browsing, matcha tea in hand, at the Brooklyn fleas. Still, Karson didnt set out to curate her shop that way. She simply scouts for pieces that catch her eye. Ive always gravitated towards things that are handmade or vintage, she explains. They tell a more interesting story.

title: Obama Opens U.S. Effort to Fill High-Paying Tech Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama kicked off an initiative on Monday intended to train more people for higher-paying jobs in high-technology services as he seeks to counter wage stagnation in an economy that has otherwise been improving.

title: Lisa Bonchek Adams: She Did as Much as She Could for as Long as She Could
description: Lisa Bonchek Adams lived her life on her own terms, regardless of her diagnosis. She fought long and hard against death, and she refused to be silenced, even when others questioned her decision to live her cancer out loud  and to die out loud. Her death on March 6, 2015, was not unexpected by any who followed her, nor was it expected. Lisa always told her readers when things were bad. But she never gave up, or at least, not publicly. In every update, no matter how grave, Lisa looked forward to spring.

title: A New Tool to Investigate Inside Tippers
description: The British philosopher Francis Bacon is attributed with saying that knowledge is power, and Wall Street pours enormous resources into obtaining information in the hope that greater knowledge will provide an edge on the market. But recent charges against a corporate officer show that passing along confidential information can be perilous, even if the intent is something other than insider trading.

description: ONEIDA, N.Y.  College athletics officials have engaged many types of nefarious characters over the years  the booster with the slush fund for Southern Methodist football players, the man who paid Michigan basketball players to help conceal his gambling profits, the now-imprisoned investor who lavished millions on athletes at Miami.

description: A new exhibition at Museum of the Moving Image highlights, among other aspects of the shows production design, its strikingly precise 60s-era wardrobes.

description: HBO has linked with Apple for the start of its much-anticipated Internet streaming service, uniting two premium brands from the media and technology worlds in a quest to reinvent the way people watch television.

title: Obama Order Freezes Assets of 7 Officials in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Citing an extraordinary threat to the national security of the United States, President Obama on Monday signed an executive order freezing any American assets belonging to seven Venezuelan law enforcement and military officials who it said were linked to human rights violations.

title: Farmers Put Down the Plow for More Productive Soil
description: FORT WORTH  Gabe Brown is in such demand as a speaker that for every invitation he accepts, he turns down 10 more. At conferences, like the one held here at a Best Western hotel recently, people line up to seek his advice.

title: Putin Contradicts Claims on Annexation of Crimea
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has publicly indicated for the first time that the planning to reclaim Crimea from Ukraine started weeks before the Crimean referendum on the issue, which he had cited repeatedly as the main reason for Russias annexation.

title: Herms: Fall 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Blocking the Paths to Suicide
description: Every year, nearly 40,000 Americans kill themselves. The majority are men, and most of them use guns. In fact, more than half of all gun deaths in the United States are suicides.

title: Discerning Plant Picks Its Pollinators
description: When it comes to pollinators, plants are not usually picky. But one tropical plant seems able to choose its suitors, a new study found. When Heliconia tortuosa resisted researchers attempts to pollinate it by hand, they tried introducing the plant to six species of hummingbirds and a butterfly. Only two types of the hummingbirds  those with the longest bills and that travel most extensively  were consistently successful in getting pollen from the plant. Writing in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, researchers at Oregon State University and the Smithsonian suggest this coyness may be a way for the plants to ensure genetic diversity.

title: Art in Residence
description: On Saturday evening in the City of Light, the worlds of art and fashion collided, as theyre wont to do, for cocktails at the residence of the American ambassador to France, which was transformed into a one-night-only art exhibition. Works on loan from Galerie Perrotin and Galerie Thaddaeus Ropac  by artists Erwin Wurm, Daniel Arsham, Alex Katz, Tom Sachs, Not Vital and Xavier Veilhan  set the scene for the party, which the U.S. ambassador Jane D. Hartley hosted in honor of T magazine.

title: Supreme Court Sides With Amtrak, With Some Distaste
description: Washington  The Supreme Court on Monday unanimously handed Amtrak an interim victory in a lawsuit challenging the power it wields over competitors. The ruling was a setback for a trade group that had challenged a 2008 federal law giving Amtrak, which carries passengers, a role in setting standards for freight railroad companies.

title: Stricter Oversight Ordered for Animal Research at Nebraska Center
description: A federal animal-research center in Nebraska will not be allowed to start any new experimental projects until it strengthens its procedures and internal oversight, the secretary of agriculture, Tom Vilsack, said Monday.

title: Obama Did Email Clinton, but Was Unaware of Details of Her Address
description: President Obama did trade emails with Hillary Rodham Clinton while she was secretary of state, the White House said on Monday, but he did not understand that her messages were not being made available to the government in some form.

title: Mystery Surrounds Offer to Sell Michelangelo Documents Stolen From the Vatican
description: ROME  The man approached Cardinal Angelo Comastri, prefect of the Fabric of St. Peter, with an odd proposition: Would the cardinal be interested in two documents written by the hand of Michelangelo, the Renaissance master?

title: Woman as Warrior, From Kenzo
description: PARIS  A motley, emo kind of bunch was gathered in the parking lot outside the Paris Event Center in the 19th Arrondissement before the Kenzo show at 10 a.m. on Sunday, bolting coffee in paper cups distributed from a truck and snatching chocolate-chip cookies from trays. Among the many slouchy knit caps boldly bobbed one red turban.

title: A Splash of Flash
description: In a season of underdone hair, a little adornment can make all the difference.

title: The Most Memorable Costumes of Mad Men Get the Museum Treatment
description: As compelling as the storylines and characters on Mad Men  which airs the second half of its final season beginning April 5 on AMC  are the shows meticulously researched 1960s-era costumes. (In many instances, the outfits  Ginsbergs stained shirt, Megans Zou Bisou Bisou dress  almost feel like characters themselves.) Now, a new exhibition opening March 14 at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Matthew Weiners Mad Men, brings the shows wardrobe, and the rest of its creative process, to life. More than 25 of the ensembles developed by the shows costume designer, Janie Bryant, will appear alongside props, advertisements and other ephemera from the shows production department, giving fans the chance to see such garments as Joans blood-stained dress from the lawn-mower episode and Sallys first minidress up close. Bryant worked closely with the museums curators to assemble the collection, even going so far as to track down clothing that had since disappeared into Hollywood costume houses. To see a costume in full action on screen and then see it standing still, she says, is a whole different kind of visual experience.

title: Keeping Your Hair in Chemo
description: Hair loss is one of the most obvious side effects of cancer treatment. Now, a growing number of breast cancer patients are freezing their scalps as a way to preserve their hair during chemotherapy.

title: Rubio-Lee: Promise and Problems
description: Last week, Senators Marco Rubio and Mike Lee released the outline of a comprehensive tax reform, which adds changesto corporate and investment taxes to their earlier proposal for a more pro-family revision of the individual code. The plan earnedgenerally favorable comments from Yuval Levin, Ramesh Ponnuru and James Pethokoukis, all writers associated with the tendency werecalling reform conservatism,but the addition of tax cuts on the business side drew praise from a wider range of conservative and libertarianpolicy writers and economists as well. The reformist interest in reorienting Republican tax policy toward middle-class families has created tensions with the partys supply-side wing, but because it reforms the corporate/business code the Rubio-Leeplan clearly has the potential to be a politically-unifying vision, marrying pro-family and pro-growth policywhile putting the era of 9-9-9 and Fair Tax-style unicornsin the rearview mirror.

title: New Umberto Eco Novel, Numero Zero, Coming This Fall
description: Umberto Eco, the Italian writer and philosopher best known for novels like Foucaults Pendulum and The Name of the Rose, will publish a new novel in the United States this fall, with Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.

title: G.O.P. Senators Letter to Iran About Nuclear Deal Angers White House
description: WASHINGTON  The fractious debate over a possible nuclear deal with Iran escalated on Monday as 47 Republican senators warned Iran about making an agreement with President Obama, and the White House accused them of undercutting foreign policy.

title: Sam Simon, 59, Dies; Guided The Simpsons, Then Shared His Profits
description: Sam Simon, who was one of the major creative forces behind The Simpsons and who left the show after its fourth season in a lucrative arrangement that allowed him to spend much of the rest of his life giving his money away, died on Sunday at his home in the Pacific Palisades area of Los Angeles. He was 59.

title: Fighting Back Against Malware
description: Q. My husband recently asked me to download a boat manual onto my Dell laptop. Not only did the manual not load, but all of a sudden I am getting too many pop-ups that make working from my laptop all but impossible. And theres now a search tool bar atop the screen and instead of Mozilla, the default page is Yahoo search. Is there a solution?

title: Former Sarkozy Aide Charged in Fraud, as Inquiry into Illegal Campaign Funding Continues
description: PARIS  An investigative judge filed preliminary charges over the weekend against a former interior minister and top aide to former President Nicolas Sarkozy in an inquiry into allegations of illegal funding of Mr. Sarkozys 2007 presidential campaign by the Libyan government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: No Cure for Bad Timing
description: No matter what I do for Robert, it is never enough.

title: Letters to the Editor
Militants Kill Three Police Officers in Egypt as Violent Attacks Spread
description: CAIRO  Unidentified militants killed three police officers on Monday in the North Sinai, shot and injured two others outside a Catholic school in the Nile Delta, and attacked two banks in Alexandria, Egyptian state media reported, in a continuing surge of low-level violence aimed at businesses and security forces.

title: Review: Discontent and Its Civilizations: Mohsin Hamid at Home in Three Lands
description: The central characters in Mohsin Hamids novels are all outsiders, caught on the ever-shifting margins of class, values and national identity  caught between their ambitions and memories, their aspirations and resentments, and finding the lines between the personal and the political, the private and the public continually blurred.

title: Verbatim: Biden Offers Some Advice
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. joked at the International Association of Fire Fighters convention in Washington, which several potential Republican presidential candidates are scheduled to attend on Tuesday. Mr. Biden, a noncandidate (for now), offered this advice: Make a judgment: Do they understand you? Do they get who you are? Do they get what this is about?

description: Hillary Rodham Clinton avoided questions about her use of private email at the State Department as she left an event for the release of a Clinton Foundation report, No Ceilings, on the status of women and girls across the globe.

description: Simon Property Group is putting its hostile tendencies to the test again. Frustrated by being ignored in private negotiations, the biggest shopping center owner in the United States announced to the public its $22 billion offer to buy rival Macerich Company. Simon has used similar tactics before with mixed results. Real estate tends to require some aggression, but it can backfire.

description: What smells so good? an audience member wondered as she perused the fantastically unhealthy buffet laid out for Saturdays matinee performance of Little Lords Bambi______/Kaffeehaus at the Brick. (The title includes an obscenity.)

description: Can it really be that there are no more new works to hear from the prolific Elliott Carter?

title: A Path to ISIS, Through a Porous Turkish Border
description: GAZIANTEP, Turkey  Under pressure from its allies in the West, Turkey has made it harder for would-be jihadists to slip across the border and join the ranks of the Islamic State group at its base in northern Syria.

title: Sanne Vloet Transforms at Esteban Cortazar
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Sanne Vloet before (left) and after (right) makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Eugene Souleiman.

title: Daughter of Pilots, and Master of the Overhead Bin
description: BOTH of my parents were private pilots, and my mother worked as a flight attendant, too. I grew up with plane travel, so business travel isnt something that makes me crazy at all.

title: Review: The Liquid Plain, a Naomi Wallace Drama at the Signature Theater
description: In The Liquid Plain, the soggy play by Naomi Wallace at the Signature Theater, a pair of runaway slaves eke out a living on a dock in Rhode Island, desperately hoping to escape across the sea to Africa. Adjua (Kristolyn Lloyd) and Dembi (Ito Aghayere) are lovers determined to forge new lives for themselves, and they sustain each other with ardent affection and dreams of a future that will ease memories of the brutalities they endured in the past.

title: Life and Warmth in Fed Transcripts: Reporters Notebook
description: Every so often I get an admiring note from a reader who is impressed that I have published an article about some new report almost as soon as the report was released. Sometimes I just say thank you. Sometimes I tell them the secret: I got the report in advance, on condition that I would not publish an article until it was released publicly. It was not magic; it was just careful choreography.

title: Randall Miller, Film Director, Pleads Guilty in Midnight Rider Manslaughter Trial

Ms. Jones was killed by a freight train on the Georgia set of Midnight Rider last year.

description: By now it should be obvious that a vocal segment of Congress is determined to do whatever it can to undermine President Obamas attempts to negotiate an agreement that would restrict Irans nuclear program. House Republicans invited Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to denounce the pact in a speech to Congress, and a bipartisan group of senators is pushing legislation that could set new conditions on a deal and force a congressional vote.

description: Tall and stately, the elderly woman leaned on a cane, heading down in the elevator after a matinee of Ferenc Molnars Fashions for Men at the Mint Theater. When I was in high school, Molnar was the hottest thing going, she told her companion.

title: Review: Woyzeck, FJF Is a Quixotic Adaptation at the New Ohio Theater
description: Georg Bchner, who died in 1837, was a playwright so ahead of his time that the theater is still playing catch-up. Before his young demise, he wrote the historical epic Dantons Death, the odd comedy Leonce and Lena and perhaps his trickiest play of all, the unfinished Woyzeck, which exists only in jumbled fragments. A definitive text, production or even an ordering of scenes proves elusive.

title: Walkabout: Snow in New York, Not So Much in Alaska
description: Mush A lack of snowfall in Alaska has moved the starting point of the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race from Willow to Fairbanks, more than 200 miles north. The weather pattern that slammed parts of the Northeast with snow this winter has left Alaska fairly warm. (The New York Times)

title: Review: In Powers, Bad Guys With Superhero Status
description: For a show that exists as an offshoot of a video-game console, Powers plays less like a video game than you might expect, or fear. The new 10-episode series  available beginning Tuesday through Sonys online PlayStation Network, console not required  is action-oriented, with doses of violence and crude language, but its a television show, not a first-person shooter. And its a reasonably entertaining one in its CW-style, low-rent, formulaic way.

description: On a clear afternoon about 100 years ago, a large British passenger ship started sinking off the coast of Ireland, listing violently as it was sucked down into the ocean.

The United States has spent $9 billion supporting that governments efforts to defeat the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, one of the longest-running insurgencies in modern history.

description: MOSCOW  Facing Western sanctions and low oil prices, Russian companies are lining up for subsidies from the government. But the demand for bailouts is quickly outstripping the supply of money, raising the prospect of an economic crisis here if the funds run out.

description: WASHINGTON  Late last month, William Schubert, the president of a small infrastructure export firm outside Houston, led a group of Texas business leaders to meet with Senator Ted Cruzs chief of staff.

title: Review: The Manchurian Candidate, Eagerly Awaited, Has Premiere in St. Paul
description: ST. PAUL  The Manchurian Candidate, the much-anticipated new opera by the composer Kevin Puts and the librettist Mark Campbell that had its premiere on Saturday night by the Minnesota Opera, is based on the 1959 novel by Richard Condon. This tale, a political thriller about a sergeant during the Korean War who is brainwashed and turned into an oblivious assassin for a Communist conspiracy, is best known from the 1962 film version directed by John Frankenheimer.

description: LONDON  A parliamentary committee grilled HSBC executives on Monday about leaked documents showing the bank helped clients evade taxes from 2007 and before.

title: Missouri Court Assigns a State Judge to Handle Ferguson Cases
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  The Missouri Supreme Court, citing the need for extraordinary action to restore trust in Fergusons court system after the Department of Justice blasted it for routinely violating constitutional rights, assigned a state appeals court judge on Monday to oversee all municipal cases.

description: Flustered over Sudans longstanding refusal to extradite its leader for trial on charges of genocide and other crimes in the Darfur conflict, the International Criminal Court on Monday asked the United Nations Security Council to take necessary measures to enforce compliance.

title: Hillary Clinton Prepares to Address Her Use of Private Email as Secretary of State
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Rodham Clinton is preparing in coming days to address her use of a private email account while serving as secretary of state, according to people close to Mrs. Clinton, even as she continued to avoid questions about the matter on Monday after speaking at a Clinton Foundation event in New York.

title: Russias Endgame in Ukraine
description: How Russia aims to achieve its goal of keeping Ukraine isolated from the West.

title: Neighbors of Nigeria Take On Boko Haram
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Troops from Chad and Niger launched an offensive against Boko Haram militants in neighboring Nigeria, military officials from both countries said Monday, two days after the Islamist terrorist group killed scores in bombings in northeastern Nigeria.

title: Clinton Puts Spotlight Elsewhere at Foundation Event
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton spent most of Monday focused on a thick data report for the No Ceilings project run through her foundation, an effort that was roughly a year in the making.

title: F.B.I. Interviewed Harry Reid Last Year in Menendez Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic leader, was interviewed last year by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as part of its continuing inquiry into Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, who federal officials say is likely to face corruption charges.

title: Extramarital Dating Site Unsettles the Land of Discreet Affairs
description: PARIS  In a country recently transfixed by the trial of a  famous politician that revealed details of his orgy escapades, and where the president was found to be cheating on his live-in partner, an ad promoting extramarital affairs might not seem like such a big deal.

title: Apple Watch Displays Your Digital World, at a Glance
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Apple unveiled its watch last fall, the company showed only demo models of the new device  polished prototypes of the hardware running nonworking loops of the software.

title: Assembly Democrats Reject Cuomos Education Reform Plans
description: ALBANY  In an emerging sign of possible budget-battle lines, Democrats in the New York Assembly rejected proposals on Monday by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo linking an increase in statewide school aid to an array of his proposed changes. They also sided with Mayor Bill de Blasios bid for longer-term mayoral control of New York Citys schools.
