description: LONDON  Britains spy agencies did not break or try to circumvent the law by harvesting huge amounts of electronic data about private communications, but the relevant laws need to be overhauled, a parliamentary oversight panel said on Thursday.

title: The Scene Before a Snowstorm
description: Dear Diary:

title: Finding Neverland and the Pop Heart Inside J. M. Barrie
description: Gary Barlow has a clear message for Americas musical-theater composers and lyricists: Hes not after your jobs.

title: French Win Latest Battle of Waterloo
description: LONDON  It was to have been a commemoration that would have placed Frances humiliation at the Battle of Waterloo in every Europeans purse or pocket. Instead, it turned into a tussle of a different kind, redolent of historys long shadow, in which France finally emerged triumphant.

title: Broadway Dreams in Astoria, Queens
description: Like many girls with Broadway dreams, Hannah Peterson played the lead in Annie. Her run was five years ago at the Alban Arts and Conference Center near her home in Charleston, W.Va.

title: Buccellati Celebrates Its New York Flagship With Art-Inspired Jewels
description: Since 1919, generations of Buccellatis have produced highly elaborate, often gem-centric jewelry from the familys design studio and boutique in Milan. Today, the jewelry house opens the doors to its new five-story flagship store on Madison Avenue and unveils its new Art collection. Co-designed by Lucrezia Buccellati, who at age 25 happens to be the first female designer for the brand, the five signature, one-of-a-kind pieces were inspired by rare works privately owned by her husband, David Wildenstein, a gallery owner and avid collector. He loaned the same five paintings  one each by Claude Monet, Pierre Bonnard, Winslow Homer, Mikhail Larionov and Odilon Redon  to the flagship boutique, where they are on view in a temporary gallery space on the fourth floor.

title: 14 Million Children Suffering as Result of War in Syria and Iraq, Unicef Says
description: GENEVA  Around 14 million children are suffering hardship and trauma from the war in Syria and Iraq, the United Nations childrens agency said on Thursday, highlighting the needs of children struggling to cope with severe violence, and the danger to the rest of the world of failing to help a generation preyed on by extremist groups.

title: How to Find Old or Expired Websites
description: Q. Sometimes Ill go to an old website and find its been replaced with a page of advertising. Where do all the original sites go?

title: American and British Aid Workers Infected With Ebola in Sierra Leone
description: A worker from Partners In Health, the prominent American medical aid organization, and an emergency worker from the British military have been infected with the deadly Ebola virus in Sierra Leone, health officials said Thursday.

title: Erik Larson: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of Dead Wake: The Last Crossing of the Lusitania, keeps a book full of photographs of miniature dioramas of bloody crime scenes on his shelves. A gift from a friend.

title: Martin OMalley Dodges Questions on Clinton Emails
description: Martin OMalley deflected questions on Thursday related to Hillary Rodham Clintons email habits, joining many of his fellow Democrats in avoiding criticism of the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: A Different Kind of Political Spin
A Stay-at-Home Parent Is Not a Luxury
description: He looked at me from across the table and said, Well, you are lucky you have the luxury to stay at home.

title: Two Officers Shot in Ferguson
description: Witnesses and the St. Louis County police chief described the scene after two officers were shot on Thursday during a protest that began only hours after the police chief in Ferguson, Mo., resigned.

title: F.C.C. Sets Net Neutrality Rules
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday released extensive details of how it would regulate broadband Internet providers as a public utility, producing official wording that almost certainly sets the stage for extended legal fights.

title: New Wing at Corning Museum of Glass Invites the Light
description: CORNING, N.Y.  The first thing the architect Thomas Phifer did after being awarded the commission for the Corning Museum of Glasss new 100,000-square-footContemporary Art + Design Wing here was to go back to his downtown Manhattan office and take an Alvar Aalto vase out on Varick Street. Aaltos Savoy vase  the classic wedding gift for an architect  has thick glass walls that bend and curve, and a footprint that looks a little like a splotch. It was a really sunny day, and as we looked at that vase in the light, it began to really glow, Mr. Phifer said. The more light you pushed into it, the more it glowed.

title: Ken Watanabe Moves From Samurai to The King and I
description: In the wrong hands, The King and I, with all those adorable children scampering about, could feel a little Disneyish. And then theres the Yul Brynner problem. The show was originally written for Gertrude Lawrence, fanning the embers of her career, but it was Brynner, with his gleaming head and firm torso, who put his stamp on it when the show opened in 1951 and made a lifetime job of playing the King of Siam. He was still doing the role just months before his death in 1985, at the age of 65, and for all we know hes doing it still.

title: Iowa Straw Poll, Loved and Loathed, Is Moving to Boone
description: The Iowa Straw Poll, a tradition loved but sometimes loathed by Republican presidential candidates, will take place Aug. 8 in Boone, the state party announced on Thursday.

title: Roof Collapse Kills Workers in Bangladeshi Cement Factory
description: NEW DELHI  The roof of a cement factory collapsed Thursday afternoon in the southwestern Bangladeshi city of Mongla, killing at least six people and leaving scores more in the wreckage, a government safety official said.

title: HP375 SETTLEMENTS
description: HP375 SETTLEMENTS

title: Faye Toogoods Radical, Genderless, Brand-Free Concept Space at Selfridges
description: Can retail ever really be radical? Thats the question raised by a new concept space opening today at the Selfridges department store in London. Agender is the brainchild of Faye Toogood, the protean British designer whose artisanal approach to interiors has seen her recruited by the likes of Herms, Comme des Garons and Alexander McQueen. Set across three levels of the store, this string of cagelike structures towers above the existing shop floor like a primeval Tardis. Its ambition: the kind of genderless, brand-free shopping thats the stuff of normcore dreams.

title: Vacation Photos, by Pros
description: High-quality vacation pictures are the most memorable souvenirs  at least according to Flytographer, a new service that connects visitors with more than 200 local photographers in 130 cities around the world, including Istanbul, Buenos Aires, Dubai, Hong Kong and Orlando.

title: Review of New York Shelter System Finds Hundreds of Violations
description: A New York City homeless shelter system that was supposed to provide a refuge for families with children instead forced some of them to live in squalid conditions that included a dead rat in an apartment; garbage strewn in hallways and stairways; and a puddle of urine in the only working elevator of one building.

title: Amateur Videos of Ferguson Shooting
description: Videos posted online are said to show the moment two police officers were shot as bystanders took cover in Ferguson, Mo.

title: My Coach, My Father
description: Georgia State Coach Ron Hunter and his son, R. J., are experiencing a hodgepodge of emotions as their college basketball journey together is apparently approaching the finish line.

title: 1958 | Claude Sitton Goes to War
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: F.C.C.s Net Neutrality Rules
description: Two weeks after voting to regulate broadband Internet service as a public utility, the Federal Communications Commission on Thursday released a 313-page document detailing what would be allowed.

title: G.O.P. Letter by Republican Senators Is Evidence of Decline, Iranian Says
description: TEHRAN  Irans highest leader issued a sharp response Thursday to a letter to the countrys leadership by Republican lawmakers, deriding it as an indication that Washington is disintegrating from within.

title: Mercenaries JoinNigerias Military Campaign Against Boko Haram
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Hundreds of mercenaries from South Africa and other countries are playing a decisive role in Nigerias military campaign against Boko Haram, operating attack helicopters and armored personnel carriers and fighting to retake towns and villages captured by the Islamist militant group, according to senior officials in the region.

title: Hillary Clinton Tackling an Urgent Task: Building a Press Team
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons team of advisers is moving quickly to build a communications team that will handle her campaigns messaging and play a crucial role in responding to attacks from opponents and critical news coverage, tasks that have grown more urgent after a month in which she has been forced to deal with controversies involving her email use and foreign donations to her familys foundation.

title: Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, Pays a Royal Visit to the Downton Abbey Set
description: LONDON  The Dowager Countess has been outranked.

title: The Husband-Wife Musical Duo Who Hit a Note for Lars von Trier and Ai Wei Wei
description: The Los Angeles minimalist musical duo OOFJ was bred from a chance meeting and an unprecedented tragedy. Back in the 90s, the Danish producer and multi-instrumentalist Jens Bjrnkjr, a classically trained saxophone player, was attending conservatory in New York; but disillusioned with jazz standards, he quit the New School in his third year. Several years later, he happened to attend a production of Twelfth Night starring the South African vocalist (and then-acting student at Stella Adler Studio of Acting) Katherine Mills Rymer. By then, Bjrnkjr had begun to craft electronic music and had just contributed to the score of Melancholia, Lars von Triers metaphysical 2011 drama  a great pickup line, he says over the phone. Rymer hums in agreement. She recalls that he wore all beige that night, a restful thing to the eye.

title: A Railway Catastrophe in the Making
description: So far, Americans have been spared the kind of terrible tragedy that occurred two years ago in the small tourist town of Lac-Mgantic in southern Canada. On a midsummer morning, a row of tank cars filled with crude oil suddenly slammed into the center of town and exploded, killing 47 people in what bystanders called a tsunami of fire.

title: Lumber Liquidators Offers Flooring Customers Free Air Tests for Formaldehyde
description: Lumber Liquidators said on Thursday that it would provide free air testing to consumers after a report that accused the company of selling laminate flooring from China that contained high levels of formaldehyde.

title: 1940: Soviet-Finnish Pact Concluded
description: Following a day of rumors, American short-wave stations broadcast a message from the official German news agency late last night [March 12] asserting that a peace treaty had resulted in Moscow from the four-day negotiations between the Finnish delegation and the Soviet government. According to the Berlin report, the peace treaty contained the following three points: an immediate armistice; cession of the Carelian Isthmus to the Soviet government; and granting of a military base to Russia on the Hango Peninsula.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 13, 1940

title: Report on Violations in Homeless Shelters
description: The Department of Investigation found family shelters in New York City are too often unsafe and unhealthy for children and families, according to its report. But these problems are the result of decades of neglect, the report said.

title: De Blasio, at Rikers, Unveils a Plan to Reduce Violence and Smuggling
description: Faced with surging violence at Rikers Island, Mayor Bill de Blasio visited the New York City jail complex on Thursday for the second time in three months to unveil a 14-point plan focused on curtailing inmate fights and stopping the smuggling of drugs and weapons.

title: Hong Kong Finds Small Amount of Radioactivity in Sample of Japanese Tea
description: HONG KONG  A sample of powdered tea imported from the Japanese prefecture of Chiba, just southeast of Tokyo, contained traces of radioactive cesium 137, the Hong Kong government announced late Thursday evening, but they were far below the legal maximum level.

title: Wondering What the Feds Statements Mean? Be Patient
description: patient adj. bearing or enduring pain, trouble, etc. without complaining or losing self-control; refusing to be provoked or angered, as by an insult; forbearing; tolerant; calmly tolerating delay, confusion, inefficiency, etc.  Websters New World College Dictionary

title: What Yoga Taught Me About the Balanced Life
description: I had been drinking the Life in Balance Kool-Aid for decades now, seeking to embrace the power of now; to eat, pray and love. So why was I suddenly not so sure?

title: Iraqi Premier on a Battle With ISIS
description: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi talked in Baghdad about Wednesdays successful efforts by Iraqi security forces against the Islamic State in the city of Tikrit.

title: Hillary Clinton in Fine Company With Time Magazine Horns
description: Time magazine posted to Twitter on Thursday the cover of its latest issue, promoting an article, The Clinton Way, by David Von Drehle.

title: Netanyahu and the Settlements
description: The Israeli leaders settlement policy resembles his predecessors, but it is a march toward permanence at a time when prospects for peace are few.

title: Throwback Thursday | The Pi Day of the Century
description: What will you be doing on 3/14/15 at 9:26:53?

title: S.E.C. Chief Defends Agencys Handling of Bank Punishment
description: One of Wall Streets top regulators on Thursday shot back at criticism that the nations biggest banks enjoy special treatment in Washington, delivering a sweeping defense of the government while also rebuking the financial industrys repeated and disturbing violations of law.

title: With a Big Sale Looming, a New View of Rothko
description: It was one of lifes small contradictions. On Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Annie Cohen-Solal, the author of Mark Rothko: Toward the Light in the Chapel, just published by Yale University Press as part of its Jewish Lives series, was presenting her view of the artist as a man of constant displacements, wedded to an artistic vision with the messianic goal of mending the world and deeply hostile to the commercial side of art.

title: Back in Camp, Sidelined Pitchers Find Hope and Worry
description: SURPRISE, Ariz.  Kris Medlen could not help noticing Matt Harveys spring training debut last week. Medlen was in the Kansas City Royals camp here, watching on MLB Network, when it all came rushing back.

title: Banks Can Now Prep for a Tougher Exam
description: Ater an arduous couple weeks of putting their institutions through a series of stringent stress tests, Americas top bankers might want to kick back and earn some money, perhaps even whistling to the possibility of higher interest rates. If only it were so easy. The only suitable tune would be Led Zeppelins bluesy stomp, When the Levee Breaks.

title: Lagers Enjoy a Renaissance
description: Spring training for Major League Baseball is well underway, and you might say Ive begun my training for spring, jettisoning reflexive winter moves and reawakening old impulses.

title: 1915: U.S. Outrage Over Sinking
description: LONDON  Despatches from New York state that great indignation has been caused throughout the United States by the sinking of the American sailing ship William P. Frye, which was sent to the bottom by the German auxiliary cruiser Prinz Eitel Friedrich, one of the last of Germanys commerce raiders. The Daily Telegraphs correspondent at Washington states that, according to reports received by the Treasury and Navy Departments, the destruction of the William P. Frye is the most wanton example of flagrant disobedience to all rules of international law that has been presented for fifty years.  The New York Herald, European Edition, March 13, 1915

title: Josh Edgins Elbow Injury Raises Questions for Mets Bullpen
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets announced Thursday that Josh Edgin, their top left-handed reliever, had a stretched ligament and tendinitis in his left elbow. Within the next day or two, he is expected to decide how to proceed.

title: The Americans Recap: Never Break the Chain
description: Season 3, Episode 7: Walter Taffet

title: The Kleiner Perkins Lawsuit, and Rethinking the Confidence-Driven Workplace
description: When a group of men and women took a science exam and scored the same, the women underestimated their performance and refused to enter a science fair, while the men did the opposite.

title: Alibaba Is Said to Invest $200 Million in Snapchat
description: Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce giant, has invested $200 million in Snapchat, according to three people with knowledge of the deals terms.

title: Uncertainty Weighs on Endos Higher Bid for Salix Pharmaceuticals
description: Endo International leapt over Valeant Pharmaceuticals deal to buy Salix Pharmaceuticals on Wednesday by offering about $1.2 billion more than the $10 billion that was already agreed to.

title: An Unlikely Driver of Evolution: Arsenic
description: Around 11,000 years ago, humans first set foot in the driest place on Earth.

title: Lines Are Blurred in Donor Event for Jeb Bush Super PAC
description: A super PAC controlled by allies of Jeb Bush is organizing a donor conference that he will host next month in Miami, according to an invitation sent to supporters, an example of how Mr. Bush and other candidates have blurred the lines between their nascent presidential bids and supposedly independent outside groups.

title: Le Marcage
description: West Africa meets the Caribbean at this East Village restaurant.

title: Sharing Their World With You
description: Le Marcage: the Swamp. It is an unexpected name for this elegant little restaurant, chastely dressed in lace curtains tied with twine and glowing inside, with dark live-edge wood tables under hand-carved lamps whose luminous craters look like honeycomb in the making.

title: Egypt Arrests 75 in Connection With Recent Attacks
description: CAIRO  Egypts Interior Ministry on Thursday announced its first arrests in connection with a series of attacks on businesses and utilities over the past several months.

title: Commerzbank of Germany to Pay $1.5 Billion in U.S. Case
description: Pursuing a trail of illicit money from Geneva to Paris with stops in London, the United States authorities built a sweeping crackdown on some of Europes biggest banks.

title: General in El Salvador Killings in 80s Can Be Deported, Court Rules
description: In a decision setting a significant human rights precedent, an immigration appeals court has ruled that a former defense minister of El Salvador, a close ally of Washington during the civil war there in the 1980s, can be deported from the United States because he participated in or concealed torture and murder by his troops.

title: Red-Light Camera Debate Is a Stew of Anger, Revenue and Safety
description: GETTING a $50 ticket for missing a red light is unpleasant enough. But when it is received in the mail without warning, generated from an unmarked camera, it can cause resentment.

title: In 'Backcountry' and Other Movies, a Bear Makes a Mean Co-Star
description: On the big screen, bears can be a punch line or a predator.

title: Review: The Plains Indians, Americas Early Artists, at the Met
description: Some of the earliest surviving art by native North Americans left America long ago. Soldiers, traders and priests, with magpie eyes for brilliance, bundled it up and shipped it across the sea to Europe. Painted robes, embroidered slippers and feathered headdresses tinkling with chimes found their way into cupboards in 18th-century London and Paris, and lay there half-forgotten. Now, in The Plains Indians: Artists of Earth and Sky at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, some of those wondrous things have come home.

title: What Net Neutrality Rules Say
description: Excerpts from and analysis of rules and explanations released by the Federal Communications Commission regarding an Open Internet.

title: Happiness Gap May Favor Liberals
description: Conservatives are happier than liberals, or so decades of surveys that ask about life satisfaction would suggest.

title: At Manischewitz, the Private Equity Owner Keeps Kosher
description: Private equity firms have plenty to worry about when buying companies, including improving revenue and keeping costs in check.

title: In Colin Barretts Young Skins, a Small Irish Towns Aimless Denizens
description: I am young, one of Colin Barretts narrators tells us, and the young do not number many here, but it is fair to say we have the run of the place.

title: Awash in Information, Historians Fear Loss of Rich Material
description: When Hillary Rodham Clinton disclosed that she had destroyed more than 30,000 emails about personal matters during her tenure as secretary of state, it was painful for historians and biographers. Some imagined themselves or their successors in 20 or 50 years prowling the archives with little success for the most intimate, revealing raw material.

title: For Love of Country, by Howard Schultz and Rajiv Chandrasekaran
description: Howard Schultz and Rajiv Chandrasekaran are a formidable team. Chandrasekaran, a reporter and editor for The Washington Post who is about to start a media company in partnership with Starbucks, has served as a foreign correspondent in Iraq and Afghanistan, and is the author of compelling books on those wars. Schultz, the chief executive of Starbucks, has initiated comprehensive programs in that corporation to hire veterans. His account in the books introduction of a trip to West Point, where he realized the extent of the disconnect between ordinary Americans and those who serve in their military forces, is itself inspiring.

title: Terry Pratchett, Novelist, Dies at 66
description: Terry Pratchett, the immensely popular British fantasy novelist whose more than 70 books include the series known as Discworld, died on Thursday at his home near Salisbury, England. He was 66.

title: O.E.C.D. Will Advise Greece on Economic Overhauls
description: PARIS  Greece will get advice from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development on ways to revamp the countrys economy, under a deal announced on Thursday.

title: Surprise! Its the Former Secretary of State
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton gave a paid speech at the headquarters of eBay in San Jose, Calif., on Wednesday, a previously undisclosed appearance that fell a day after a news conference in which she explained her use of a private email account while she was secretary of state.

title: Hope of Finding Survivors in Army Helicopter Crash Fades
description: ATLANTA  The Coast Guard suspended its search-and-rescue operation in the waters off the Florida Panhandle on Thursday, an acknowledgment that the seven Marines and four Army soldiers aboard the Black Hawk helicopter that crashed Tuesday in Navarre, Fla., were unlikely to be found alive.

title: Commerzbanks Settlement With Federal and State Authorities
description: Commerzbank agreed to pay nearly $1.5 billion to settle civil and criminal charges related to its role in enabling a huge accounting scheme and other illicit transactions.

title: The Political Art of Not Being a Scientist
description: Florida Gov. Rick Scott is one of many prominent Republican politicians who prefer to say Im not a scientist as they avoid specific policy positions on climate change and global warming. Even so, the allegedly unwritten policy of his administration for the past four years has been a ban on the use of those very terms  climate change and global warming  by state environmental officials, according to an investigative report published Sunday in the Miami Herald.

title: Lyft Raises $530 Million
description: Uber, the ride-hailing start-up, is a $40 billion juggernaut, but it is not without competition.

title: Big East Tournament: On a Familiar Court, St. Johns Again Exits With a Listless Showing
description: It had been so long that even Coach Steve Lavin could not remember the last time St. Johns won a game in the Big East tournament. He had near-perfect recall of games he lost while at U.C.L.A. in overtime  who hit the shot, the time on the clock, the most minuscule of details  but the Red Storms record at Madison Square Garden in postseason play escaped him.

title: tk
description: tk

title: 16-Year-Old Arrested After Fight at a Brooklyn McDonalds
description: A 16-year-old high school student was arrested on Thursday after being seen on video taking part in the beating of another girl at a McDonalds in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: The Top 10 Moments From Fall/Winter 2015 Paris Fashion Week
description: Ts market director rounds up the most memorable happenings both on and off the runways.

title: A Cheese Product Gains Kids Nutrition Seal
description: Kraft Singles, those individually wrapped slices of processed cheese that have long been a staple of school lunches, are the first product to earn a nutrition seal from the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics, the trade group representing 75,000 registered dietitians and other nutrition professionals.

title: Artists of Earth and Sky
description: A look at a new show of art by the Plains Indians, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Capital Confusion at the FOMC
description: Ambrose Evans-Pritchard raises a good point about the debt-deflation effects on much of the world caused by a rising dollar; he also, in passing, mentions that some members of the FOMC apparently think that flows of capital into the US strengthen the case for a rate hike. Really?

title: Irish Artifacts and Provenance
Kerry Washington to Play Anita Hill in HBO Film
description: Kerry Washington cannot stay away from Washington D.C. As first reported by The Hollywood Reporter, the Scandal star will portray Anita Hill in an HBO movie titled Confirmation. Ms. Washington confirmed the news on her Twitter account. The film will deal with the 1991 Supreme Court confirmation hearings in which Ms. Hill, a law professor, detailed accusations of sexual harassment against Clarence Thomas. No date has yet been set for the films HBO premiere.

title: Pictures of the Day: The United States and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the United States, Bangladesh, Iraq and India.

title: Bravery and Ordinary Foolishness at 3,000 feet
description: At the turn of the 20th century, George Fiske photographed travelers atop Overhanging Rock, an outcropping about 3,257 feet above Yellowstone Valley.

title: March 12, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the United States, Bangladesh, Iraq and India.

title: What 3 Banks May Have Cut to Pass the Stress Tests
description: One important number usually remains under wraps when the Federal Reserve conducts its annual health checks of large banks.

title: First Draft Focus: Stop Me if Youve Heard This One
Comentario: Las lecciones que aprendemos durante los 40
description: PARS  Si todo sali conforme a lo planeado, habr cumplido 44 aos poco tiempo despus de la publicacin de esta columna. Hasta ahora en mi vida adulta, no he logrado entender el objetivo principal de una dcada sino hasta mucho tiempo despus de que ha terminado. Resulta que en vez de haber pasado mis 20 buscando esposo con desesperacin, deb haberme concentrado en mi carrera y en disfrutar el ltimo suspiro de libertad. Posteriormente, en mis 30 me la pas rumiando las cosas que me hicieron sentir inconforme a los 20.

title: Charles Ray at Matthew Marks
description: Charles Rays Baled Truck is a machine-milled, stainless-steel rendering of a truck that was compacted into a 10-foot-long box shape weighing 13 tons. Its the only object occupying the gallerys main showroom, which has been constructed into a cruciform layout like that of a minimalist church interior. The sculpture sits at the intersection of transept and nave like a coffin. Its conceptually interesting, but visually inert.

title: Olivier Zahm, Miriam Odemba and the Faces of New York Fashion Week, Part Two
description: The illustrator Damien Florbert Cuypers shares his impressionistic portraits of the stylish personalities around the City of Light this week.

title: Audra McDonald Will Return to Broadway in Shuffle Along
description: In the annals of Broadway history, the 1921 musical Shuffle Along holds a special, if little-known, place: it was the rare all-black show, and started the career of Josephine Baker, among others.

title: The Painter of Modern Life at Anton Kern Gallery
description: Given its title, taken from an essay by Baudelaire, you might suppose that The Painter of Modern Life would offer an alternative to the abstract and conceptually self-reflexive approaches to painting that are so prevalent today. But while its a lively and engaging show, it doesnt have a lot to do with life as ordinarily construed. Organized by the independent curator Bob Nickas, it presents more than 70 works by 21 artists, most of whom focus on formal and procedural aspects like surfaces, shapes, repetition, color and sensually assertive materials.

title: Barry Gerson: The Parting of the Clouds
description: Barry Gerson was a well-known member of the generation of 1960s and 70s Americans working alongside minimalism and associated with experimental  known as structuralist  filmmaking. After exhibiting his work at most of the major museums in the city and following his inclusion in the 1983 Whitney Biennial, Mr. Gerson quit making films for two decades. This small, thoughtful show offers a reintroduction  for many, a first glimpse  of his work.

title: Frozen 2 Is on the Way, Disney Says; More Star Wars Plans Revealed
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The blizzard continues: Frozen 2 is coming to theaters.

title: The Top 10 Moments From Fall/Winter 2015 Paris Fashion Week
description: Ts market director rounds up the most memorable happenings both on and off the runways.

title: Judge Refuses to Lift Injunction on Argentine Bond Payments
description: A New York judge at the center of a multiyear battle between Argentina and a group a hedge funds has dug in his heels once again.

title: New York Attorney General Suspends Automatic Email Purge in His Office
description: Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York State attorney general, will suspend a policy started by his predecessor, Andrew M. Cuomo, in which emails in his office are automatically deleted after 90 days, his office said on Thursday.

title: Visit the Barber? Maybe Not, Says Holder
description: Gerard Contee, a participant in President Obamas My Brothers Keeper mentoring initiative, told the president last month that he wanted to be attorney general someday during a luncheon at which the young men in the program went around the table stating their dream jobs.

title: Olivier Zahm, Miriam Odemba and the Faces of Paris Fashion Week, Part Two
description: The illustrator Damien Florbert Cuypers shares his impressionistic portraits of the stylish personalities around the City of Light this week.

title: Asia Week Celebrates an Array of Art as Vast as a Continent
description: New Yorks museums are filled with stellar exhibitions devoted to Asian art  and several more open on Friday. A much-anticipated exhibition of ukiyo-e prints featuring cats debuts at the Japan Society. The Queens Museum opens a survey of art in India from 1947 to 1997 and the Rubin Museum introduces a show of masks from Tibet, Nepal and other regions. An exhibition of works by the Iranian abstractionist Monir Shahroudy Farmanfarmaian joins the Guggenheims already lauded show about the conceptual painter On Kawara. Meanwhile, the Asia Society continues a season of programming dedicated to the art of Myanmar.

title: Michael Graves, 80, Dies; Postmodernist Designed Towers and Teakettles
description: Michael Graves, one of the most prominent and prolific American architects of the latter 20th century, who designed more than 350 buildings around the world but was perhaps best known for his teakettle and pepper mill, died on Thursday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 80.

title: Venice Biennale Shows its Political Stripes
description: The curator of the 56th Venice Biennale, which opens May 9  and which celebrates the 120th anniversary of the international art exhibition  announced his lineup of artists on Thursday, a highly diverse global group whose work often focuses on the tangled aftermath of colonialism and the effects of late capitalism.

title: Who Are Pope Franciss Critics?
description: The latest cover of the new New Republic features Elizabeth Stoker Bruenig taking onconservative anxieties about Pope Franciss possible radicalism.The essay isnt just about the pope; it offers a larger critique of the way that conservatives, Catholic and otherwise, relate to and interpret the human/Western/Christian past. I have a few disagreements with this depiction, and a few criticalgeneralizations Id make about theliberaltendency in Catholic thinking and debate right now. But Ill save those for another post; for now I think it would be helpful for the discussion of Catholicism in the Francis era to spend some timedistinguishing between the different groups who have doubts, or flirt with having doubts, about this pontificate, because in Bruenigs account they run together a bit and I think the distinctions are actually enormously important.

title: The East Harlem Explosion, One Year Later
description: Family members, emergency workers and politicians paid tribute to the eight people who died in the explosion on Thursday.

title: Japanese Coastal Town Still Struggling to Rebuild From 2011 Tsunami
description: OTSUCHI, Japan  The spot where the towns center once stood is now a dusty construction site filled with diggers and dump trucks toiling amid huge, man-made mesas of earth and gravel. The work is part of an $850 million project to elevate the land by seven feet and shield it behind a towering 48-foot wall.

title: A Moment Atop the World for Bhutans Last-Ranked Team
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  Nikola Kavazovic sat alone in the hot and sticky interior of Sugathadasa Stadium this week, waiting for someone to talk to.

title: New Year-Round Routes on Eurostar Trains
description: Travel between England and France is about to be streamlined with new, year-round routes on the Eurostar direct to Lyon, Avignon and Marseille from London and Ashford.

title: Charles Atlas: The Waning of Justice
description: The career of the American filmmaker Charles Atlas has been a steady but slow-burning fire for more than 40 years, beginning in the 1970s, when he initiated a series of video collaborations with Merce Cunningham. Those videos went well beyond being documents of Cunninghams dance  though they were certainly that  to become acts of filmic choreography in themselves. Over time, the network of Mr. Atlass collaborators expanded to include other choreographers (Douglas Dunn, Yvonne Rainer, Michael Clark) and the transgender performer Leigh Bowery, with whom he did extraordinary work.

title: Artists of Earth and Sky
description: A look at a new show of art by the Plains Indians, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Subodh Gupta: Seven Billion Light Years
description: Subodh Guptas latest gallery show makes the best, and worst, argument for his art.

title: Here Comes Trouble
description: New picture books include Use Your Words, Sophie! and Wolfie the Bunny.

title: Police Officers Shot in Ferguson, Mo.
description: Two police officers were shot outside the Ferguson police station early Thursday, the St. Louis County police said.

title: On Sascha Braunigs Trippy Canvases, Op Art Meets Surrealism
description: The New Museums recently opened triennial exhibition Surround Audience has largely been praised for its embrace of genres influenced by technological advances  so its a bit curious that one of the shows most talked about talents is the thoroughly analog painter Sascha Braunig. Based in Portland (Maine, as opposed to the West Coast bastion of progressive proclivities), Braunig creates portraits that have frequently been described as a merging of Op Art and Surrealism. She terms her approach superficial realism, as the undulating, trippy forms she commits to canvas are faithful interpretations of still lives she stages herself. Typically, she molds and lights sculptures as the subject of each piece, before entering a meditative state in which she skins her creations with ornate patterns.

title: Honda, to Hasten Takata Airbag Fixes, Turns to Ad Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  With millions of its cars still under recall but not yet repaired, Honda Motor said on Thursday it was beginning an advertising campaign aimed at persuading owners to get them fixed.

title: The Living Room and Irish Arts Center Celebrate St. Patricks Day
description: St. Patricks Day, like its cousins SantaCon and Halloween, has a tendency to make people wince. Theres something about a drunken reveler, stumbling down the sidewalk and wearing an oversize green top hat, that many people just dont find endearing.

title: Life of Cats
description: Works highlighting the infiltration of felines in a nations cultural landscape are in a new show at Japan Society.

title: Review: Life of Cats Spotlights a Centuries-Old Fascination in Japan
description: Cats are strange. Aloof, elegant and always clean, they radiate Buddha-like equanimity and spiritual superiority. A cat will gaze intently into your eyes and then look away as if you were not of the slightest interest. They can be maddeningly passive-aggressive opportunists and zany clowns, as attested to by countless, stratospherically popular YouTube videos of cats behaving badly and ridiculously. (See, for example, YouTube cats knocking things off tables.)

title: Review: Peter Saul: From Pop to Punk, a Firebrand Willing to Offend
description: The New York art dealer Ileana Sonnabend once avowed  somewhat self-servingly  that the best collectors are people in her line of work. Every so often the evidence mounts, as it does with Peter Saul: From Pop to Punk at Venus Over Manhattan. This poetically named art gallery established in 2012 by Adam Lindemann, a collector and occasional writer for The New York Observer, does not represent artists, but it regularly stages relevant exhibitions, and this is one of his best.

title: European Fine Art Fair Showcases Shaker Furniture
description: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands  For a moment, as you peer through the window and see that plain wooden chest next to that plain wooden bedstead, you could be in New Hampshire 180 years ago, rather than in a 1990s exhibition center in the middle of the eurozone.

title: Mayor de Blasio Marks Anniversary of Fatal Explosion in East Harlem
description: One year after a gas explosion leveled two buildings in East Harlem and left eight people dead, Mayor Bill de Blasio visited the site on Thursday with the families and friends of those killed.

title: Review: Long Story Short, Till Death Do Us Part
description: Time is doing odd things on and off Broadway. Its fracturing in Constellations, hopscotching in Bright Half Life, and in Long Story Short, a newish musical by Brendan Milburn and Valerie Vigoda, it is executing a halfhearted loop-de-loop.

title: Childbirth in Bolivias High Plains
description: Mistrust of modern medicine has been a factor in high infant mortality rates among indigenous communities in Bolivia. Recent efforts seek to stem the crisis while respecting traditions.

title: Review: Avi Avital and the Venice Baroque, in Sizzling Communion
description: The words superstar and mandolinist still look odd next to each other. Yet in the classical world they are starting to be joined with some frequency to describe two players who, in very different ways, combine virtuosity on an instrument with generous helpings of onstage charisma. One is Chris Thile, an American trained in bluegrass who has recently made notable ventures into classical repertory. The other is the Israeli-born Avi Avital, who on Wednesday gave a performance of 18th-century Italian concertos at Zankel Hall with the Venice Baroque Orchestra that was nothing short of electric.

title: Secret Service Agents Said to Have Driven Into Police Investigation Before Crash
description: WASHINGTON  Two Secret Service agents suspected of drinking were captured on video last week driving a car that bumped into a barricade and rolled to a stop in an area cordoned off by the police because of a suspicious package, two people briefed on the video saidThursday.

title: Jackson Sees Opportunity as Knicks Visit Lakers
description: LOS ANGELES  If there was one Knicks road game that Phil Jackson was certain to attend, it was Thursday nights visit to Staples Center for a second and final meeting with the Lakers, the team he coached to five N.B.A. titles from 2000 to 2010 and whose co-owner Jeanie Buss has been his longtime companion.

title: One Agency in Harper Lee Inquiry Ends Its Role, Saying Author Is Aware of Book Deal
description: An Alabama agency that had been helping with an investigation into whether Harper Lee, 88 and infirm, was manipulated into agreeing to publish a second novel this summer said on Thursday that it had ended its role in the inquiry.

title: Review: Paul Taylors American Modern Dance Opens Its Season
description: For all the fanfare surrounding the new structure of the Paul Taylor Dance Company, things werent too different on Tuesday at the inaugural performance of Paul Taylors American Modern Dance. The biggest change was the live music, played by the terrific Orchestra of St. Lukes under Donald Yorks baton, a major upgrade from the troupes usual taped accompaniment. But whereas other programs this season will feature, for the first time in the companys 61-year history, outside artists  the Limn Dance Company in Doris Humphreys Passacaglia, Shen Wei Dance Arts in Mr. Shens Rite of Spring  opening night at the David H. Koch Theater was devoted to Mr. Taylor.

title: The New Net Neutrality Rules
description: The Federal Communications Commission is to take a more active role in regulating the Internet as a public utility, which is expected to provoke court cases from major broadband providers.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Review: The Royals on E! Is Another Pretender to the Throne
description: The Royals, a new E! scripted series that begins on Sunday, is trying to usurp the throne of reality televisions reigning monarchy, which debuts a 10th season of Keeping Up With the Kardashians on that network the same night.

title: Review: Mivos Quartet Performs Gesualdo, Berg and Kate Soper
description: It might seem odd to open a concert of new string quartets with arrangements of vocal madrigals by Carlo Gesualdo, as the indispensable Mivos Quartet did in its impressive evening with the composer-soprano Kate Soper at Columbia Universitys Italian Academy on Wednesday.

title: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
description: 90 YEARS AGO

title: Remote New York, a Tour From Brooklyn to Greenwich Village
description: ON a rainy afternoon this week, passers-by may have paused to wonder about a headphone-wearing group assembled in front of a guardhouse at Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, staring at a nondescript commercial strip outside the gates before suddenly bursting into applause.

title: Review: Kirill Gerstein Plays Liszts Transcendental tudes
description: Kirill Gerstein is evidently determined to prove his mettle as one of the great piano virtuosos of the day, and he made a strong case to be considered as such with his recital at Zankel Hall on Monday evening. In a fascinating program consisting of pedagogical forms run more or less amok, he ended with a dazzling performance of Liszts 12 Transcendental tudes, some of the most difficult music ever written for piano.

title: Review: Brandi Carliles Life Is Embedded in Her Music
description: Stakes are high in Brandi Carliles songs: emotionally, romantically, meteorologically, spiritually. Vocally, too. Playing a rare club show on Wednesday night at the Music Hall of Williamsburg  shes usually in theaters  Ms. Carlile sang about family, memories, mortality, guilt, hurricanes, starry skies, suicide and eternal love, scaling personal experience up to grand pronouncements. In The Stranger at My Door, with a verse about watching a house burn down, she sang, An all-consuming flame, that refines and new begins/Itll take your family heirlooms, but it can take your darkest sins.

title: Paul Taylor Chooses Three Choreographers to Make New Work
description: When the choreographer Paul Taylor reinvented his company as Paul Taylors American Modern Dance, his plan called for it to continue to present his work along with other modern dance masterpieces and new dances by contemporary choreographers.

title: A Dream, or a Premonition, Leads to a New Beginning
description: As a single parent, I was trying to make a go of it in Laguna Beach, Calif. My daughter wasnt even a year old and my partner of many years hadnt wanted to make it legal, so he was back East, as were the rest of my family and friends.

title: Antonio Cromartie Is Reunited With Darrelle Revis on the Jets
description: Darrelle Revis and Antonio Cromartie, who formed a stifling secondary for the Jets from 2010 to 2012, were reunited Thursday as the team reached an agreement with Cromartie.

title: Review: In Brothers From the Bottom, Jousting About Gentrification
description: In a scene from Jackie Alexanders timely and sympathetic Brothers From the Bottom, at the Billie Holiday Theater, two men stand on a shared front porch and argue about the fate of their neighborhood. Trey (Wendell Franklin) is involved in a plan to replace rundown houses with gleaming condos. His brother, Chris (Wendell Pierce of The Wire and Treme), is skeptical.

title: Nancy Snyderman Resigns as NBCs Chief Medical Editor
description: Dr. Nancy Snyderman has stepped down from her post as NBCs chief medical editor, following a controversy that erupted last fall when she broke a self-imposed quarantine after returning from covering the Ebola outbreak in Liberia.

title: Frank, Barney Franks Memoir
description: Barney Franks career in Congress spanned enough time and elevated him to enough prominence that most of the significant American political figures from the last four decades flitted through it, playing some part. And many make cameos, at the least, in his autobiography, Frank.

title: FEMA to Review All Flood Damage Claims From Hurricane Sandy
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency has agreed to review every flood insurance claim filed by homeowners affected by Hurricane Sandy, amid accusations that damage assessment reports were fraudulently altered to minimize claims.

title: Theater Listings for March 13-19
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Administration Asks Court to Lift Order Halting Immigration Programs
description: The Obama administration, fighting a lawsuit by 26 states against the presidents executive actions on immigration, asked a federal appeals court Thursday to lift an order by a judge in Texas that halted the programs.

title: Comedy Listings for March 13-19
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for March 13-19
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Once Unique, LeapFrog Has Rivals in the Educational Toy Market
description: On a weekday afternoon, Flora Bojadziev, a chef from Harlem, browsed through a Toys R Us in Manhattan.

title: Review: In It Follows, a Shape-Shifting Horror Stalks a Teenager
description: The nameless, shape-shifting horror that stalks the blond, 19-year-old Jay (Maika Monroe) in David Robert Mitchells cool, controlled horror film, It Follows, might be described as the very incarnation of paranoia. The menace, which only she can see, takes any number of forms, from a naked man standing on the roof of a house to an unsmiling old lady heading purposefully in her direction. When it appears, it is usually first glimpsed from a distance, walking slowly toward her like an expressionless zombie. Although Jay repeatedly flees, she can never shake the sense that it is out there somewhere and knows her precise location.

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for March 13-19
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for March 13-19
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Truth and Consequences
description: My daughter lost her wallet on her college campus. Someone returned it to the campus police. (With all of its contents!) But when my daughter picked it up, the officer berated her for having a fake ID. Her drivers license was in plain sight, so there was no need to rummage through the wallet. He told her possessing a fake ID was a crime, but he wasnt going to charge her. (Is he even an actual police officer?) Instead, he would report her to the dean, who may put her on probation. I think he was way out of line; she wasnt using the ID. You?

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for March 13-19
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for March 13-19
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for March 13-19
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for Children for March 13-19
description: Math Celebrations

title: Spare Times Listings for March 13-19
description: Around Town

title: Giants Lose Safety Antrel Rolle to Bears
description: The Giants search for help at safety began in earnest on Thursday after Antrel Rolle, a defensive mainstay for the last five seasons, left to sign a three-year contract worth $11.25 million with the Chicago Bears. He received $5 million in guaranteed money.

title: The Problem Is Bigger Than Ferguson
description: The Justice Departments expos of the bigoted law enforcement practices at play in Ferguson, Mo., has rightly led to an exodus of officials from the town government. In the week since the report was made public, the police chief, the city manager and the municipal court judge have all stepped down, and the citys court has been placed under state supervision.

title: Language of Greek Crisis Shifts From Financial Jargon to Humiliation
description: BERLIN  Greeces financial crisis has often been framed in the dry, impersonal language of finance. At issue were credit ratings, bond yields and repayment schedules. The pulse of a collapsing nation was often measured in technical jargon about borrowing costs and primary surpluses.

title: Key Chicago Figure, Despite a Plea by Obama, Gives a Lift to Emanuels Rival
description: CHICAGO  Several weeks ago, President Obama was at an event in Chicago when he approached Willie Wilson, a businessman who had challenged Rahm Emanuel in the mayors race, with a gentle plea, Mr. Wilson said.

title: Senators Remain at Impasse Over Bills Abortion Provision
description: WASHINGTON  Senators on Thursday continued to struggle to come to terms with an unexpected impasse over a bipartisan human trafficking bill, with the sides refusing to yield their positions on a provision that would ban money from a victims fund from being used for abortions.

title: Ebola, Thief of Rituals, Leaves No Graves to Decorate
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  Finda Fallah sat in her tiny one-bedroom apartment, boiling up rice and leftovers with one of the few children in her family still alive.

title: This Weeks Movies | March 13, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Cinderella, Going Clear and Seymour: An Introduction.

title: Univision Fires HostRodner Figueroa for Insult to Michelle Obama
description: Univision fired the talk show host Rodner Figueroa after he said that Michelle Obama looked like someone from the cast of the film Planet of the Apes.

title: From the Gates Foundation, Direct Investment, Not Just Grants
description: The Ebola crisis underscored a problem that vexes experts in global health: Vaccines are one of the most cost-effective ways to save lives, especially in developing countries, yet traditional vaccines can take years to develop.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Cinderella
description: Kenneth Branagh narrates a sequence from the film.

title: Kenneth Branagh Narrates a Scene From Cinderella
description: In this video, the director Kenneth Branagh discusses a sequence from the new version of Cinderella, featuring Lily James and Richard Madden.

title: Iran: New Appeal for Detained Reporter
description: The Iranian lawyer for Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post reporter incarcerated in Iran for nearly eight months, has requested a five-day release for him starting March 21, the beginning of Irans New Year, so he can be with his family, Mr. Rezaians brother, Ali, said Thursday at a news conference in Washington. Ali Rezaian also said the lawyer, Leila Ahsan, had not yet been allowed to meet with Mr. Rezaian, a native Californian of Iranian descent, but had been given access to the case files. Iranian officials have not disclosed the nature of the charges but have hinted that they are related to espionage.

title: Clip: Seymour: An Introduction
description: A scene from the documentary.

title: Review: Seymour: An Introduction Is a Lesson in Perseverance
description: As its title suggests, Seymour: An Introduction doesnt try to offer the final word on its subject, Seymour Bernstein, the pianist, composer, teacher, philosopher and ultimate New Yorker. Instead, in 81 transporting minutes, this intimate, big-hearted documentary draws you so completely into his world that you feel as if you know all there is to know, even as questions linger. So effectively does it close the distance between you and Mr. Bernstein that afterward you may find yourself scanning the streets, hoping to catch sight of him, as if for an old friend.

title: His Skill Finally Unmasked, Goaltender Devan Dubnyk Finds a Home
description: ST. PAUL  The idea sprang as a brainstorm from a first-time father. After Nathaniel Dubnyk was born in August 2013, his father, Devan Dubnyk, then a goaltender for the Edmonton Oilers, asked the noted Swedish mask designer David Gunnarsson to incorporate an image of the baby on the mask he planned to wear that season.

title: Senator Corker Pushes Obama for Congressional Vote on Iran Deal
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee urged President Obama on Thursday not to seek a United Nations endorsement of the emerging nuclear agreement with Iran without first giving Congress a chance to vote on it.

title: Californias Ailing Sea Lions
description: Record numbers of sea lions are being discovered up and down the states coast.

title: Starving Sea Lions Washing Ashore by the Hundreds in California
description: CAPISTRANO BEACH, Calif.  By the time Wendy Leeds reached him, the sea lion pup had little hope of surviving.

title: Lila Honored as Top Fiction by National Book Critics Circle
description: Marilynne Robinson won the National Book Critics Circle Award on Thursday for her novel Lila, the final book in her trilogy set in the fictional Gilead, Iowa.

title: Stopping Online Harassment Before It Starts
description: Yik Yak, created in 2013, is a relatively young social network. But it already has a problem with harassment.

title: Review: In Cymbeline, a Drug Kingpin
description: Was the director Michael Almereyda watching an episode of Sons of Anarchy when he decided to tackle Cymbeline? For an overextended seven seasons (2008-14), that FX show retold Hamlet through the trials and tribulations of a violent motorcycle gang and its circle. Back in 2000, Mr. Almereyda, an independent American filmmaker, wittily conceptualized his own Hamlet to suit the indie-movie times, casting Ethan Hawke as a film student who wonders whether to be or not while strolling in a Blockbuster video store near a sign labeled action.

title: Serena Williams Strikes the Right Note in a Time of Turmoil
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  Serena Williams officially ended her 13-year boycott of the annual tennis tournament held here when she addressed members of the news media Thursday to explain why she returned.

title: Just as Ferguson Was Making Progress, Shooting Deals a Setback
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  In her three years as a city councilwoman, Kim Tihen has not been afraid to speak against the powers in her own city.

title: Review: In Cinderella, Disney Polishes Its Glass Slippers
description: Poor Cinderella  she still cant catch a break. In the 1950 Disney animated musical, her friendly neighborhood mice know the score and give it song: Night and day, its Cinderelly! Make the fire, fix-a breakfast, wash the dishes, do the mopping, and the sweeping and the dusting. They always keep her hopping! In Disneys latest version, directed by Kenneth Branagh, the mice stick to squeaking and look about as real as most computer-generated rodents. And, fascinatingly, much remains the same, including a fairy tale that opens with clear skies but soon plays the poor-little-girl blues before you-know-who comes along. Maleficent and its revisionism are so last year.

title: Holder Calls Ferguson Gunman a Punk
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. condemned the attacks on two police officers in Ferguson, Mo., calling the attacker a damn punk.

title: De Blasio Names 3 to Rent Board as Annual Fight on Increases Nears
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio has appointed three new members of the board that sets rents for about one million rent-stabilized apartments in the city, completing the process of filling all nine seats with his selections just in time for the annual fight over rent increases.

title: Events in Connecticut for March 15-21, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island for March 15-21, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey for March 15-21, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester for March 15-21, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Jurors Hear Harrowing Account of Boston Bombers Hostage
description: BOSTON  The murderous rampage of the Tsarnaev brothers that engulfed this city two years ago began to come apart when they encountered someone they could not possibly have seen as a threat: a mild-mannered apps designer who had pulled his car over to text a friend.

title: Suddenly, It Seems, Water Is Everywhere in Solar System
description: Oceans trapped under ice appear to be pretty common in the solar system and one of them, on a small moon of Saturns, appears to be quite hot.

title: Move Over, Clinton. Albany Email Farce Takes Center Stage.
description: This may be the first time in history that a column about digital storage must be rendered as a kind of drawing room comedy.

title: Powerful Lasers Easy to Buy, Experts Say
description: Stargazers use them to pick out constellations, teachers to direct students eyes, and pet lovers to make their cats dance.

title: Review: 3 Hearts, With Three Stars, by Benot Jacquot
description: The French filmmaker Benot Jacquots 3 Hearts has the incalculable advantage of teaming three of Europes most revered actresses, Charlotte Gainsbourg, Chiara Mastroianni and Catherine Deneuve, in a proudly old-fashioned romantic melodrama. Those names alone make it sound delectable, and in its outlines, this quintessential Gallic bodice-ripper might be described as a hybrid of An Affair to Remember and the German filmmaker Dominik Grafs recent Beloved Sisters.

title: In New Hampshire, Clinton Backers Buckle Up
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  If Hillary Rodham Clinton is dying to roll her eyes at all the questions about her private email server, she has a soul mate in Laura Donohoe, who did just that, in utter disgust, as she defended Mrs. Clinton on Thursday between spoonfuls of clam chowder.

title: Dawns Direction
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Lets talk about the voices I hear. Dont call my doctor, Im not hearing random ones. Today, Id like to talk about the very distinctive voices of the puzzle constructors we love. Because, if you listen very carefully when you solve a puzzle, you can hear them. Will Shortz edits the clues, but he is very good at letting the original voices of the constructors comes through.

title: Patz Judge Denies Mistrial Request Over Suspects Drug Use
description: A prosecutor cross-examining an expert witness on Thursday suggested the hallucinations of the man on trial for the murder of Etan Patz could have been caused by cocaine abuse, not mental illness. That line of questioning prompted the defense to move for a mistrial because the judge had only recently allowed it.

title: Review: In Run All Night, Liam Neeson Sticks to What Works
description: Yes, Run All Night is another action film starring Liam Neeson, with a title as generic as you might expect. But the movie, directed by Jaume Collet-Serra, who directed Mr. Neeson in the efficient airborne thriller Non-Stop, has two saving graces: a tight script and terrific acting.

title: New Rules Are Issued for Testing of Medical Devices
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that it was toughening testing procedures for manufacturers of reusable medical devices. It issued the new requirements in the wake of news that two people in a Los Angeles hospital had died from a deadly bacteria traced to medical scopes.

title: Review: Champs Tyson, Holyfield and Hopkins Recount Careers
description: Champs spends about a third of its time perpetuating the myth of boxing as a path out of poverty, a third of it taking a cursory look at whats wrong with the sport and a third being a greatest-hits compilation.

title: At Baruch, a New York Rental to the Stars, the Wood Floors Tend to Squeak
description: As the N.C.A.A. tournament approaches, the best basketball scene in the country is not Rupp Arena, home of the undefeated Kentucky Wildcats, or even Cameron Indoor Stadium, the Duke Blue Devils noisy home. Rather, it is a nondescript gym in Manhattan, home of the commuter school Baruch College.

title: Review: The Cobbler, With Adam Sandler, a World in Others Shoes
description: The good news is that The Cobbler isnt another Grown-Ups sequel. Adam Sandler, as he did with Jason Reitmans little-seen Men, Women & Children, works outside his sophomoric-humor comfort zone in this urban fairy tale directed by Tom McCarthy (The Station Agent). The bad news is that he is not very well served. The Cobbler, which Mr. McCarthy wrote with Paul Sado, speaks to the fabulist side of Mr. Sandler, the one that appeared in Click and Bedtime Stories. But its an uneasy fit, in a trite story.

title: At Chinese Political Meetings, the Fashion Is Restraint
description: Simple meals, plain boiled water instead of the bottled mineral kind, a paucity of designer logos.

title: After Bilking Victims of $10 Million, Serial Swindler Is Sentenced to Nearly 22 Years
description: Like many white-collar criminals, William Lange spent freely with the money he made from his fraud: $115,000 on Harley-Davidson motorcycles; a $2,350 stay at the Mirage in Las Vegas; landscaping work and $5,000 worth of fancy railings for his Gig Harbor, Wash., waterfront mansion; a testosterone-laden moose hunt.

title: Review: In Eva, Robot Designer Loves Cute Kid
description: Robots havent become an integral part of the everyday world as quickly as some people had predicted, but in the not-too-distant future of Eva, an appealing film from Spain, theyre very much a factor. We learn this early on, when the central character, Alex (Daniel Brhl), steps off a plane trailed by his robotic cat.

title: Where Beijings Trash Is Reborn
description: When The New York Times asked Sim Chi Yin, a photographer based in Beijing, to photograph a story about beginnings, she started thinking about the outskirts of her city, which she has been exploring for the past year as part of her continuing work on urbanization in China. This week, we are marking the launch of our primary Instagram account, @nytimes, with images of beginnings by seven photographers around the world. The photos by @chiyin_sim were published on the account over the course of the day on Thursday.  Kerri MacDonald

title: Review: In Home Sweet Hell, Married Life Isnt Heaven
description: Mona (Katherine Heigl), the chief villain of the shrill comedy Home Sweet Hell, is the sort of terrifying suburban status seeker who might inspire fond memories of the 1994 John Waters film Serial Mom. She insists that her children argue constructively and requires nothing less than perfect hedges. She indulges in casual bigotry and refuses to mingle with the employees of the furniture company she runs with her husband, Don (Patrick Wilson). She lists 15 precise minutes of sex with him on her calendar. She keeps an album of goals for her perfect family.

title: Not to Worry: Masahiro Tanaka Looks Like His Old Self
description: TAMPA, Fla.  With 19 precise pitches, Masahiro Tanaka did more to calm the nerves of anxious Yankees fans than any of his declarations of good health possibly could. People needed to see it live, and Tanaka, the right-handed pitcher who sneered at the surgical knife last summer, put his ability on display Thursday with striking resolve.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Thursday, March 12, 2015
description: March 12, 2015

title: Obama Discusses Ferguson With Jimmy Kimmel
description: LOS ANGELES  President Obama on Thursday said that whoever shot at police officers in Ferguson, Mo., this week were criminals and should be arrested, but added that their actions should not detract from the civil rights issues that have been raised.

title: Review: Like Sunday, Like Rain, a Sentimental Intersection of Two Lives
description: Leighton Meester of Gossip Girl acquits herself quite well in Like Sunday, Like Rain, and so does a young newcomer named Julian Shatkin. Its a bittersweet story that thins out toward the end as it turns too obviously sentimental, but its still a nicely etched tale of the intersection of two unrelated lives.

title: Funeral for Shannan Gilbert Is Outlet for Familys Grief, and Suspicion
description: AMITYVILLE, N.Y.  The scene at the cemetery here on Thursday was rather quotidian: a silver-colored coffin topped with pink-and-white carnations in union beneath the kind of light-pink ribbon bow normally found atop a wrapped gift.

title: Rangers Klein, Injured by Puck, Will Miss at Least Three Weeks
description: The Rangers said Thursday that Kevin Klein, a stalwart defenseman who has a knack for scoring key goals, would miss three to four weeks with an upper-body injury.

title: Review: The Lovers Portrays Romances Intertwined Across Time
description: The title of The Lovers refers not just to characters but also to two rings that join together. In this inert, exasperatingly proportioned phantasmagoria from Roland Joff, who wrote the screenplay and directed, the jewels fortunes in 1778 India have a ripple effect on a futuristic diving mission hundreds of years later. Or perhaps its the other way around.

title: Review: Walter Is Obsessed With Fate
description: In Walter, the title character is a ticket taker at a multiplex, a good gig for someone who enjoys fantasy. Walter, an obsessive-compulsive in his early 20s, believes himself to be a son of God, required to decide the final destination  heaven or hell  of every individual he sees. Folks lining up to get into the theater just make his true calling easier.

title: Review: The Wrecking Crew Hails the Music Behind the Faces
description: THE WRECKING CREW

title: NASA Mission to Study Magnetic Explosions Lifts Off
description: A NASA mission to study magnetic explosions high above Earth successfully launched to orbit on Thursday night.

title: As Protesters Disparage Bratton, an Unlikely Defender Emerges: City Council
description: With relations between New York City lawmakers and police officials warming, it was left to a handful of protesters at a budget hearing at City Hall on Tuesday to voice outrage over current policing policies.

title: Staten Island Judge Allows Suit on Teacher Tenure to Proceed
description: Opponents of New York States teacher tenure laws won a small but important victory on Thursday, when a Staten Island judge allowed a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of those rules to move forward.

title: Big East Tournament: Xavier Advances With Overtime Victory Over Butler
description: Even the most ardent of Big East rivals can usually wrap up a game in regulation. That was true of Butler and Xavier in their two regular-season meetings this year.

title: Alexander McQueen-Inspired Tea Treats: Almost too Pretty to Eat
description: As Fashion Month comes to a close and London ramps up for a longer-running fashion presentation of sorts  the March 14th opening of Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty at the Victoria and Albert Museum  the Berkeley hotel is feting the exhibitions European launch with its own very McQueen-inspired spin on the afternoon teatime ritual.

title: A Notebook With Pop-Art Bona Fides
description: Those who still prefer to carry around a physical notebook, rather than relying on Evernote (or just tweeting every passing thought), are a peculiar bunch possessed of inflexible loyalties: whether youre a Moleskine or a Rhodia person tells journal snobs everything they need to know. (Theres some ego involved, to be sure: Our notebooks give us away, as Joan Didion famously wrote, for however dutifully we record what we see around us, the common denominator of all we see is always, transparently, shamelessly, the implacable I.)

title: Life or Movie? Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter and The Wolfpack Blur Lines
description: In a dark apartment in Tokyo, a lonely woman is transported to the snowy vistas of Minnesota. She gets lost in the fuzzy images on her TV, fast-forwarding, rewinding and pausing, searching for clues and meaning. When the worn-out tape is snarled in her VCR, she pulls the unspooled mess into her face and inhales reverently.

title: Boy, 15, Dies Trying to Jump Between Rooftops in Brooklyn
description: A 15-year-old boy fell to his death in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, on Thursday when he tried to jump from the top of one four-story apartment building to the top of another, the police said.

title: Word of the Day | prolixity
description: prolixity  \pro-lik-s-te\  noun

title: Mardy Fish Ends Hiatus but Falls at Indian Wells
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  In his first singles match in more than 18 months, Mardy Fish held two match points in the third set Thursday at the BNP Paribas Open before falling to Ryan Harrison, 6-4, 4-6, 7-6 (3).

title: In La Sapienza, Eugene Greens New Film, a Man Works on His Artistic Soul
description: In the early 1970s, when the director Eugene Green first visited the church SantIvo alla Sapienza, a Baroque masterpiece in Rome, he encountered Roman intransigence. The guardian kept saying he didnt have the key; one of his colleagues had the key. Then along came a tourist.

title: Agitating With Animation: When the Wind Blows and Coonskin
description: No one, post-Charlie Hebdo, can doubt a cartoons capacity to change the world  R. Crumbs breezy remonstrance Its only lines on paper, folks! notwithstanding. Animated cartoons are generally more circumspect than static drawings, but some have been agitators as well.

title: The Letter From John Lennon Behind Danny Collins
description: In 1971, a British folk singer named Steve Tilston gave an interview to ZigZag  a small, underground-rock rag named for a Captain Beefheart jam and a popular brand of rolling papers  in support of his debut LP, a collection of earnest, fingerpicked guitar songs that recall Nick Drake and Jackson C. Frank. When asked if he thought fame and fortune might prove toxic to his songwriting, Mr. Tilston did not equivocate. Yes, yes, of course it will, he recalls saying. My heart will suffer.

title: SEC Chooses Greg Sankey as Its Next Commissioner
description: Greg Sankey will be the next commissioner of the Southeastern Conference, replacing Mike Slive, the conference announced Thursday. Sankey, currently the SECs executive associate commissioner and chief operating officer, will be introduced Friday morning in Nashville, where the conference is holding its mens basketball tournament.

title: Jenna McMahon Dies at 89; Created Popular Sitcoms
description: Jenna McMahon, who teamed up with Dick Clair, her partner in a comedy act, to create the long-running sitcom The Facts of Life, died on March 2 in Monterey, Calif. She was 89.

title: Childbirth in Bolivias High Plains
description: Correction appended below.

title: Yoshihiro Tatsumi, Formative Manga Artist, Dies at 79
description: Yoshihiro Tatsumi, a Japanese cartoonist whose dark, psychologically astute tales helped establish the genre of adult comics and graphic novels, died on March 7 in Tokyo. He was 79.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Feb. 13
description: Photographs from the past week from New York City and the region include images from Cardinal Egans funeral Mass and the end of winter.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 10:30 A.M. (Encore) HOOSIERS (1987) Norman Dale (Gene Hackman) is the new basketball coach in a small Indiana town in this tale of competition and redemption set in the early 1950s. His unorthodox coaching style initially rankles the townspeople and alienates the players but ultimately proves successful. Dennis Hopper, in an Oscar-nominated role, plays Shooter Flatch, an alcoholic who helps coach the team. Who could resist a tiny Middle Western town where the barber shop is called Roosters and the game of basketball is foremost on every mind? Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times about this sports classic, directed by David Anspaugh. Probably no one, and the quaintly innocent Hoosiers is irresistible in much the same way.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: This was not someone trying to bring healing to Ferguson. This was a damn punk, a punk who was trying to sow discord.

title: Corrections: March 13, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Book on Sandy Alderson Set for Release as Mets Try to Turn Page
description: In his first four seasons as the general manager of the Mets, Sandy Alderson put together a body of work that included a lot more losses than victories, a surprising number of quips and a steadfast ability to never point a finger at the teams owners for repeatedly saddling him with payrolls that were meager by major-market standards.

title: St. Josephs Coach Phil Martelli Finds Grandson Mellows Him
description: This week, for his preschool classs show and tell, Philip Stephen Martelli brought in a printout of the Atlantic 10 tournament bracket and demonstrated how teams advance to the championship.

title: Q. and A.: Michael Meyer on Living and Writing In Manchuria
description: The American writer Michael Meyer first arrived in China in 1995 as a Peace Corps volunteer and has since documented changes in disparate corners of the country.

title: Why We Need to Keep Forces in Afghanistan
Is the Yik Yak Social App a Force for Good, or Ill?
description: To the Editor:

title: Anti-Vaccine Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: Cab Rides to Nowhere
description: To the Editor:

title: Shocks of Climate Change
description: To the Editor:

title: A Focus on Violence Against Women
We Have a President for a Reason
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  THE letter that 47 Senate Republicans addressed to Iranian leaders this week, warning them about making a nuclear deal with President Obama, came as a surprise to many Americans. But it would not have surprised our earliest forefathers. After all, it was not uncommon, in the years immediately following the American Revolution, for individual Americans to negotiate directly with representatives of foreign governments.

title: Hillary Clintons Big Test
description: The political world is stuck in the middle of an accelerating protocol crisis. All sorts of customary acts of self-restraint are being washed away. It used to be that senators didnt go out campaigning against one another. It used to be they didnt filibuster except in rare circumstances. It used to be they didnt block presidential nominations routinely.

title: The Southwestern Water Wars
description: WIMBERLEY, Tex.  WE dont want you here, warned the county commissioner, pointing an accusatory finger at the drilling company executives as 600 local residents rose to their feet. We want you to leave Hays County.

title: Congresss Duty on Authorizing Force
description: The Republicans in the Senate seem to have had no trouble inserting themselves into the Iran nuclear negotiations, when they had no business interfering. Yet they have shown little interest in carrying out a job that is squarely within their constitutional mandate  drafting an authorization for war against ISIS that Democrats can support and President Obama will sign.

title: Strength Is Weakness
description: Weve been warned over and over that the Federal Reserve, in its effort to improve the economy, is debasing the dollar. The archaic word itself tells you a lot about where the people issuing such warnings are coming from.
