Its an allusion to the ancient practice of replacing pure gold or silver coins with debased coins in which the precious-metal content was adulterated with cheaper stuff. Message to the gold bugs and Ayn Rand disciples who dominate the Republican Party: Thats not how modern money works. Still, the Feds critics keep insisting that easy-money policies will lead to a plunging dollar.

title: Digital Dog Collar
description: I hate the new Apple Watch. Hate what it will do to conversation, to the pace of the day, to my friends, to myself. I hate that it will enable the things that already make life so incremental, now-based and hyper-connected. That, and make things far worse.

title: Reaching Math Students One by One
description: Like middle school math teachers everywhere, the seventh-grade math teachers at Middle School 88 in the southern part of Brooklyns Park Slope have an impossible job. At this high-poverty school, which not long ago was considered failing, students enter with levels of math skills ranging from kindergarten to eighth grade. How can anyone teach to them all?

title: North Korea Is Said to Fire 7 Missiles Off Its East Coast
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea has fired seven surface-to-air missiles into waters off its east coast, South Korean officials said on Friday, in the countrys latest missile test coinciding with joint United States-South Korean military exercises.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Ambush Seen in Shooting of 2 Police Officers in Ferguson
description: In 2 Police Officers Shot in Ferguson Ambush Are Released From Hospital, John Eligon and Richard Prez-Pea report on more violence in Ferguson, Mo.

title: Test Yourself | One Last Dance at Johnsons Barn
description: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 25 article, Johnsons Barn, a North Dakota Institution, Plans Its Last Dance.

title: Valerie Jarrett: I Intend to Stay Until the Lights Go Off
description: The presidents senior adviser and confidante on immigration, working with Republicans and whether shes the Democratic Dick Cheney.

title: How Much Should Fans Be Allowed to Distract Opposing Teams?
description: Isnt basketball, baseball or any other sport supposed to be about great athleticism and sportsmanship? May the best team win? Or are fans part of the game too?

title: Carly Fiorina Shapes Herself as the Republican Foil to Hillary Clinton
description: WASHINGTON  She has been the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, a senior adviser to a Republican presidential nominee and a candidate for the United States Senate. But Carly Fiorina recently took on her boldest role yet: Hillary Rodham Clintons loudest critic.

title: Key to Hawks Team Play: Nourish the Individual
description: ATLANTA  The Hawks practice gym has bare walls, some cardio equipment crammed behind a baseline and patchwork flooring, a result of a recent leak. Most N.B.A. teams have gleaming, multimillion-dollar facilities. The Hawks spend their time in something that looks straight out of the Cold War.

title: Vague Email Rules Let Federal Agencies Decide When to Hit Save or Delete
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. used an email alias named for the Temptations, the Motown group. Lisa P. Jackson, a former Environmental Protection Agency administrator, used Richard Windsor  a combination of her dogs name and a New Jersey town  for her electronic alter ego.

title: Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side Is Forgotten but Not Gone
description: If you were prone to quick and superficial judgments, you might take one look at Anne Saxelby, a young and winsome purveyor of costly artisanal cheeses on the Lower East Side, and cast her in the role of bad witch in your own little gentrification play. For nearly a decade, Saxelby Cheesemongers has occupied a stall in the Essex Street Market, a municipal food hall built by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia. And yet few have done more than Ms. Saxelby to work to preserve the markets character and unite its disparate group of vendors, among them old-school Hispanic grocers dealing in unusual root vegetables and other inexpensive produce and retailers of the meticulously cured, the refined and the handcrafted.

title: Wet Wipes Box Says Flush. New Yorks Sewer System Says Dont.
description: With its sewer system under siege, tallying millions of dollars in equipment damage across its underground maze, New York City is confronting a menace that has gummed the gears of plumbing networks around the world: the common wet wipe.

title: For Brooklyns District Attorney, Year One Is a Trial by Fire
description: One Sunday morning in February, Kenneth P. Thompson, the Brooklyn district attorney, showed up with some fellow politicians to celebrate the 249th anniversary of the African Wesleyan Methodist Episcopal Church. The event, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, was supposed to be one of those occasions elected officials love: a straightforward, stress-free gathering of voters that focused on history, not headlines.

title: Battered but Unbowed, ISIS Is Still on Offensive
description: WASHINGTON  The Islamic State is facing growing dissension among its rank-and-file fighters and struggling to govern towns and villages it has seized, but the militant Sunni group is still managing to launch attacks and expand its ideological reach outside of Iraq and Syria, senior American officials said.

title: The Last Flight of Poxl West, by Daniel Torday
description: Early on in The Last Flight of Poxl West, Daniel Tordays expertly crafted first novel, an irksome grad student with dandruff asks the title character if we have reached a point of saturation with all the first-person accounts of World War II.

title: Ask Well: Arsenic in Rice Crackers?
description: Question:

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Chinas Middle Class Chafes Against Maze of Red Tape
description: BEIJING  A rambunctious girl with a fondness for drawing and robots, Jessica Cherry looks like a typical 5-year-old. But in the eyes of the Chinese government she is invisible.

title: New York Today: Global Trekker Rolls Into Town
Putin Has Vanished, but Rumors Are Popping Up Everywhere
description: MOSCOW  Wheres Putin?

title: Official Report Describes Blunders in Deadly Police Raid in Philippines
description: MANILA  A botched police raid that killed 44 elite officers and jeopardized a landmark peace deal in the Philippines involved blunders by officials from the field commander all the way up to President Benigno S. Aquino III, according to a report released on Friday.

title: Daily Report: New Rules for Net Neutrality May Set Stage for Legal Battles
description: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday released extensive details of how it would regulate broadband Internet providers as a public utility, producing official wording that almost certainly sets the stage for extended legal fights, Rebecca R. Ruiz reports.

title: UBS Chief Executives Pay Rose Nearly 5% in 2014
description: LONDON  Sergio P. Ermotti, the UBS chief executive, saw his compensation increase nearly 5 percent in 2014, despite the Swiss banks financial performance for the year being tempered by legal and regulatory charges, the lender said on Friday.

title: With Plan to Join China-Led Bank, Britain Opens Door for Others
description: BEIJING  A surprise decision this week by Britain to join Chinas new development bank for Asia, despite opposition from the Obama administration, will almost certainly encourage other American allies to become members, particularly Australia and South Korea, analysts said Friday.

title: Leatherback Turtles Dont Need Google Maps
description: Leatherback turtles can travel thousands of miles through the ocean each year. Yet when females are ready to nest, they somehow manage to return to the same beach again and again.

title: Tracing Jewish Heritage Along the Danube
3 Day-Cruises Worth the Trip
description: Itineraries in Chicago, San Francisco and New York offer the chance to admire the cities architecture, nature and history  in just a few hours.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: healthy cheese, happy conservatives and simple concussion tests. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Skiing
description: If I hadnt become a writer, Id be living in a rusty car with a ski rack, roaming the Rockies in perpetual pursuit of fresh powder. I dream of skiing constantly; as soon as the first snowflake of the season starts its descent from the gray skies of Chicago to its flatlands, I begin following snowfall reports from various ski resorts, occasionally and arbitrarily informing my wife, Teri, that Jackson Hole or Alta got a foot overnight. The thought that some skiable place somewhere has received fresh powder makes life worth living between November and April  and beyond, and forever.

title: The Last Volunteer
description: It was 1937, and the Fascists had already revolted in Spain. I was walking down a street in Hollywood when I saw a sign  Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade  written on the side of a building. I turned the corner, opened the door and went in. The people inside said, What can we do for you? I said, I want to go to Spain. They couldnt legally send people to Spain, they told me, but did I want to help? I did. My life started with poverty and then came the Depression. I felt a certain responsibility to help the Spanish workers and farmers.

title: How to Teach a Bird to Talk
description: A single parrot cannot forage for fruit and watch for predators at the same time; it depends on its chittering flock for protection. Therefore, to teach a bird that can talk  parrots, parakeets or mynas, for example  to talk, find one that for lack of better options thinks of you as its flock. Dont get an old, disappointed bird, says Sri Ganapathy Sachchidananda Swamiji, a 72-year-old guru who, when not traveling the world playing synthesizer concerts for his followers, can be found at his bird sanctuary in Mysore, India, home to more than a thousand birds, including some 40 trained talkers. Buy a baby bird. Specifically, opt for one bred in captivity (or rescued) rather than one snatched from the wild.

title: Starting to Show
description: In this poem, the visual delight of the imagery  the suns brightness in the belly of the sky  is undergirded by a pattern of rhyme and almost-rhyme. With the rhyme occurring in the middle of a line instead of at the end, combined with the rhythm of the short lines, the poem calls to mind the activity of the unborn child, a counterpoint to what is seen: that which is felt in the body. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

title: Jane Goodall Is Still Wild at Heart
description: Jane Goodall was already on a London dock in March 1957 when she realized that her passport was missing. In just a few hours, she was due to depart on her first trip to Africa. A school friend had moved to a farm outside Nairobi and, knowing Goodalls childhood dream was to live among the African wildlife, invited her to stay with the family for a while. Goodall, then 22, saved for two years to pay for her passage to Kenya: waitressing, doing secretarial work, temping at the post office in her hometown, Bournemouth, on Englands southern coast, during the holiday rush. She had spent her last few days in London saying goodbyes and picking up a few things for the trip at Peter Jones, the department store in Chelsea. Now all this was for naught, it seemed. The passport must have fallen out of her purse somewhere.

title: 19th-Century Tourists Took Silly Vacation Photos, Too
description: On the cover of this weeks magazine, Alex Honnold peers over the edge of Overhanging Rock, a famed outcropping at Glacier Point in Yosemite National Park. Honnold, one of the worlds greatest rock climbers and a master of climbing alone and without ropes, is known for doing things few others do  but this isnt one of them. The adventurous, or at least vertigo-unafflicted, have been inching out onto Overhanging Rock for photo ops for more than a century.

title: Mets Hitters and New Coach Start to Mesh, With Help From a Net
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  When batting practice ended on Tuesday morning, Ruben Tejada stuck around the field for extra work. Kevin Long, the Mets new hitting coach, wanted him to try a new drill that Long had developed.

title: Hillary Clinton, and Names Fit to Print
description: It has been nearly 46 years since Hillary Clintons name first appeared in The New York Times. Were she to win the Democratic nomination for president in 2016, her time in the news in this publication before becoming a presidential nominee would be longer than that of any other Democrat.

title: Link to Protests Unknown in Ferguson Police Inquiry
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Investigators pursued several leads on Friday as they tried to determine who shot two officers standing outside the police station at a protest here, but they said it was unknown how many suspects were involved or whether there was any link between demonstrators and those who fired the shots.

title: Assanges Lawyer Welcomes Swedish Prosecutors Officer to Question Him in London
description: LONDON  A lawyer for Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder who has taken refuge in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London since June 2012, welcomed an offer by Swedish prosecutors on Friday to travel to Britain to question him on allegations of sexual assault, and suggested that the offer would be accepted.

title: Today in Politics: Republicans Set Sights on First Primary State
description: Good Friday morning from Washington. After a week filled with discussion of email servers and smartphones, President Obama revealed to Jimmy Kimmel that he delegates his tweeting and never sends a text. Former President George W. Bush, motivated by the situation in Myanmar, made a rare foray into foreign affairs; and dont try pestering Supreme Court justices about coming decisions  they dont budge. But in the meantime, for those seeking a campaign fix, the Granite State is the place to look this weekend.

title: For Michaela DePrince, a Dream Comes True at the Dutch National Ballet
description: AMSTERDAM  Michaela DePrince was appearing here in the third act of Balanchines Jewels with the Dutch National Ballet on a recent evening. There were about a dozen ballerinas in bejeweled white tutus arrayed across the stage, and there she was all the way stage right in the front line.

title: An Update on Our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest
description: First of all, thank you for your enthusiasm.

title: Defense in Marathon Bombing Has Echo of Clarence Darrow
description: BOSTON  When Judy Clarke, the lead defense lawyer for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, announced at the outset of his trial last week that her client was responsible for the Boston Marathon bombings, she was following a strategy laid out by Clarence Darrow almost a century ago.

title: Morning Agenda: Commerzbank in U.S. Settlement
description: COMMERZBANK IN U.S. SETTLEMENT | Commerzbank, one of Germanys biggest lenders, agreed on Thursday to pay nearly $1.5 billion and dismiss some of its employees to resolve an array of charges in the United States, DealBooks Ben Protess reports. The case, the latest black eye for a giant global bank accused of sending tainted money through the American financial system, closes the book on several investigations into Commerzbank, he adds.

title: Can an Evil Man Change?
description: CAPE TOWN  South Africas most notorious apartheid-era assassin, Eugene de Kock, has received parole after spending 20 years in prison. The governments decision to let him walk free has unleashed a sort of identity crisis among South Africans. Could a man once known as Prime Evil really have changed? Why are we showing such charity to the deadliest cog in apartheids racist machine? And more important, why are so many South Africans  mostly white  so angry that this specific prisoner has been freed?

title: If Its Thursday, It Must Be Home  No More
description: For many longtime readers of The Times, Thursday was tinged with sadness. One of their favorite weekly sections, Home, was no longer in the paper. The section was discontinued after the March 5 edition, almost exactly 38 years after its debut.

title: How to Survive the College Admissions Madness
description: HERE we go again. At Harvard, Emory, Bucknell and other schools around the country, there have been record numbers of applicants yearning for an elite degree. Theyll get word in the next few weeks. Most will be turned down.

title: Whats On This Week Around The World
description: London

title: Police Failed to Address Sexual Abuse in Northern British City, Report Says
description: LONDON  The recent revelations that teenage girls were systematically raped and trafficked by gangs of older men over long periods of time in several British cities prompted a host of inquiries into why the authorities had seemingly turned a blind eye for so long.

title: What Do You Call Someone From St. Croix?
description: Dear Diary:

title: Backstage Moves Intensify as Fight Against Islamic State Widens
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi government forces and allied militias continued on Friday to battle Islamic State militants who defended their remaining positions in the city of Tikrit with snipers and roadside bombs.

title: For Holdout Renters, Condo Conversions Can Be Messy
description: In New York, elbowing aside others to make money in real estate is as old as the founding of the city itself.

title: Womens Wear Weekly, Beats by D&G and Julianne Moore Just Says No
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Andy Samberg Will Host the Emmys
description: Years of performing on live TV is probably the best practice one can have for the job of hosting a widely televised award show. In recent years Saturday Night Live alumni like Amy Poehler, Tina Fey, and Seth Meyers have all hosted a major award show. (Ms. Poehler and Ms. Fey did the Golden Globes for three years in a row and Mr. Meyers was the host of the 2014 Emmys.)

title: Behind the Curved Glass of New Yorks Residential Towers
description: At the construction site morphing skyward at 50 West Street, a curvaceous 64-story glass-and-steel condominium whose distinguishing exterior motif will be its transparent assemblage of rounded corners, Daniele Petroni, protected from a flutter of snowflakes by his fashionably gray hard hat, gave a huge curved glass panel near the base a paternal pat.

title: 1867: An Irish Republican Army Funeral
description: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

title: Nerds, High Priests, and the State of Economics
description: Ill spend much of this weekend at the New York Review of Books conference on whats wrong with the economy and economists; and it seems to me that its important, in these things, to ask, Compared to what?

title: Rotary and Peace Corps Find Relevance With Retirees
description: THREE years ago, Douglas Crumley sold his financial planning practice in Fair Oaks, Calif., and he and his wife, Ann, left the country.

title: Will Ferrell Is Taking Your Questions
description: We dont know how to put this, but Will Ferrells kind of a big deal. And hes taking your questions.

title: Got College Admissions Frenzy? Read Where You Go Is Not Who Youll Be
description: It really is the season. Facebook updates, most at least self-depreciating, have begun announcing the college choices of my friends children. Many include some big names in the campus world  but for a lot of reasons, many dont. Many, if not most, of my old friends kids are off to places like Kansas University, Wichita State, Washburn University in Topeka, or maybe to Southern Methodist University or even the University of Texas at Austin. Im delighted for them. Im thrilled.

title: Verbatim: Valerie Jarretts Long Haul
description: Valerie Jarrett, in an interview with Jim Rutenberg for The New York Times Magazine, on how long she plans to stay at the White House.

title: Harper Lee Agent Says Author Is Delighted New Book Will Be Published
description: The literary agent for Harper Lee said Friday that the author was in full possession of her mental faculties, and delighted that a second novel she wrote will be published this year, rebutting suggestions that Ms. Lee was not capable of assenting the books release.

title: A Bespoke Perfume Doesnt Come Cheap
description: As part of a trip to France in 1984 to study floral painting, Dianne Bernhard spent time in Monets gardens at Giverny. It was there, among the flowers that inspired him, that she heard Cartier was creating a new perfume in Paris made with jasmine, roses and vanilla.

title: Video Reviews of Cinderella, Going Clear and Seymour: An Introduction
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Cinderella, Going Clear and Seymour: An Introduction. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: First Draft Focus: One for the Road
Obama Reads Mean Tweets
description: President Obama appeared on Jimmy Kimmel Live and read mean things people have said about him on Twitter.

title: Obama Reads Mean Tweets About Himself
description: It turns out that President Obama really does read the tweets, or at least some of the meaner ones.

title: Layers of Spring
description: Lasagna, that many-layered marvel, is a dish that shifts with the seasons. Like fashion, it comes in different hues and textures that match the weather.

title: From The Upshots Editor: Political Mysteries
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Letters: James Baldwin, Richard Wright
description: James Baldwin, Richard Wright

title: Editors Choice
description: DEAD WAKE: The Last Crossing Of The Lusitania, by Erik Larson. (Crown, $28.) The 100th anniversary of the great ships sinking is the occasion of this entertaining book by the masterly author of The Devil in the White City.

title: Mario Vargas Llosas Discreet Hero
description: When I think of the writers I adored in my 20s, during the 1970s and 80s, it almost makes me think that winning the Nobel Prize in Literature must not be so hard, because nearly every one of them has won it: Garca Mrquez, Bellow, Morrison, Coetzee, Naipaul, Grass and, in 2010, the youngest and only surviving member of the Latin American boom, Mario Vargas Llosa. I mention this not to pitch myself as a reliable Nobel handicapper but to point out the futility of ascribing any politically correct left-wing bias to the Swedish Academy, since at least three of those favorites  Bellow, Naipaul and Vargas Llosa  are about as politically correct as Margaret Thatcher. All three have been identified with the cultural and political right, none more so than Vargas Llosa, who ran seriously for the presidency of Peru and who to this day is probably, partly through the opinion columns he publishes in Spains El Pas, the Spanish languages most prominent conservative intellectual.

title: The Illuminations, by Andrew OHagan
description: The literature of war is by its very nature political. If a writers sentences are personal  what else, really, can they be?  and a writer has trained his lens on a bloody battleground, in reading him we will come to know where he stands, where his passions lie. When it comes to fiction, this passion can often result in rhetoric-spouting characters whose sole purpose is to service the authors ideas. But in The Illuminations, the Scottish novelist and critic Andrew OHagan has created a story that is both a howl against the war in Afghanistan and the societies that have blindly abetted it, and a multilayered, deeply felt tale of family, loss, memory, art, loyalty, secrecy and forgiveness.

title: The Unraveling of Mercy Louis, by Keija Parssinen
description: American television would have it that high schools are the site of endless intrigue: In cult favorites like Twin Peaks and Veronica Mars, teenagers enact adult dramas in miniature, sleuthing in trench coats before joining their peers in ill-fitted dresses and wrinkled suits at prom. Such is the lot of the American teenager, a creature at once juvenile and jaded.

title: Rock n Write
description: Kim Gordons memoir, Girl in a Band, is reviewed this week by the musician, writer and producer Questlove. Gordon, a founder of the seminal art-rock band Sonic Youth, is the latest in a cavalcade of rock stars (of a certain age) to write a memoir. Odds are that if you were on MTV at anytime in the 1980s, youve published your life story in the past decade.

title: Religious History
description: THE NUNS OF SANTAMBROGIO

title: The Tell-Tale Heart, by Jill Dawson
description: Patrick Robson, the main character in Jill Dawsons novel The Tell-Tale Heart, is a 50-ish divorced British academic whose least complicated relationship is with his BMW. A well-practiced philanderer, Patrick juggles Helen, his ex-wife, and Lucy, a former mistress, as well as a scorned girlfriend, a younger (of course) colleague who avenges herself by bringing Patrick up on sexual harassment charges before a university committee. Patrick knows hes a rogue; he also admits to being the worlds worst father to his two children: Alice, his daughter with Helen, and Ben, his son with Lucy.

title: Reif Larsens I Am Radar
description: Set aside for the moment the black baby born to white parents, the avant-garde puppeteers and the quantum physics that swirl around the whole kit and caboodle. The most interesting facet of Reif Larsens 600-plus-page novel, I Am Radar, is that it reads like something far more compact than its bulk might suggest. There are maps, diagrams and pictures (e.g., an elephant plummeting from a bridge, a Cambodian prisoner of the Khmer Rouge) that remind one of the visual arrangements in W.G. Sebalds novels. Then there is a deeply patterned narrative that darts easily from small-bore domestic dramas to sweeping historical catastrophes with just the right fillip of silliness and levity to keep the whole text eminently approachable.

title: Inside the List
description: The Insider: Joseph Kanons seventh historical thriller, Leaving Berlin, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 11. Kanon first cracked the list with his debut novel, Los Alamos, in 1997  but he was already well known in the book business before then, having spent some 30 years as an editor and publishing executive, including a stint as president of Dutton. During that long first act, Kanon worked with fiction writers including Muriel Spark, Louis Auchincloss, Frank Conroy and Jayne Anne Phillips. But he never dreamed of writing a novel himself, he told an Australian newspaper in 2009. I didnt have manuscripts secretly in the bottom drawer, he said. Honestly, I didnt. I was happy in publishing. I was in the service of other peoples books. The last thing you want is to be in competition with your writers. That all changed after Kanon left the industry in the mid-1990s, when he vacationed in New Mexico and was struck by the idea for a crime novel set during the Manhattan Project. I never told anyone I was doing it, he said. I didnt even tell my wife. I didnt know if I could do it. What could be more embarrassing than a publisher who couldnt write?

title: Mary Helen Spechts Migratory Animals
description: Tales of nave Americans abroad may have defined our national fiction around the turn of the last century, but the literature of the early 21st abounds with an entirely more sophisticated sort of traveler, perfectly exemplified by Flannery, the hard-as-nails heroine of Mary Helen Spechts delightfully ambitious first novel, Migratory Animals. A far cry from Henry Jamess Isabel Archer, Flannery  like many of her generation and station  is on the lam from both her middle-class, middlebrow roots and the lifestyle-driven superficiality carefully honed by her onetime college friends. She has settled in Nigeria less because her work as a climate-change scientist has repercussions for local farmers and more because its a few continents away from her sister, Molly, an emotional tar pit for whom Flannery served as a surrogate mother during the years when the girls actual mother was slowly, grotesquely deteriorating from Huntingtons disease.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE SPLENDID THINGS WE PLANNED: A Family Portrait, by Blake Bailey. (Norton, $15.95.) Bailey, the biographer of Richard Yates, John Cheever and Charles Jackson, takes up his own familys turbulent history in this achingly honest memoir. He tells of his failings and his parents  his father was a prosperous Oklahoma lawyer, his mother a German immigrant with a bohemian streak  but the dark heart of the story is Baileys older brother, Scott, and his alcohol- and drug-fueled fall from grace.

title: In Every Way, by Nic Brown
description: It sounds impossible: Give up your baby for adoption and still spend every day with her. But Maria, the 19-year-old protagonist of Nic Browns novel In Every Way, does just that, becoming the full-time nanny of the daughter she gave away. This is an ingenious feat, considering Maria opted for a mostly closed adoption. That the reunion is nonetheless entirely believable is a credit to Browns gift for realism, and evidence that there is no anonymity in the digital age.

title: The Death of Caesar, by Barry Strauss
description: Among the most poignant objects that survive from the era of the Ides of March  March 15, 44 B.C., the day Julius Caesar fell to the knives of Brutus, Cassius and perhaps 21 other senators  is a dime-size silver denarius, minted by Brutus a year or two after the murder. One side of this rare coin shows military-style daggers flanking a felt pileus cap, a symbol of freedom from slavery, and the abbreviation EID MAR. On the other side, remarkably, Brutus had his own portrait stamped. Before this, Caesar was the only Roman who had dared put himself on a coin, for to do so was to assume the stature of a monarch  or a god.

title: The Rebellion of Miss Lucy Ann Lobdell, by William Klaber
description: There are only two basic plots in fiction, writers occasionally say: Somebody goes on a journey and, the other side of the coin, A stranger comes to town. Brilliantly, William Klaber has managed to combine them. In this deeply satisfying historical novel, he recreates the voice of Lucy Ann Lobdell, a real mid-19th-century New York woman who abandoned her young daughter and set out  dressed and passing as a man  to find the independence (and money) denied her as a woman. After many years of wandering as Joseph Lobdell, she married another woman and eventually found herself locked away as a lunatic.

title: Abandonment Issues
description: The older I get, the more preoccupied I become with the number of things Ive given up on over the years. Im fond of the line, often attributed to Paul Valry, about how a work of art is never finished, merely abandoned, but as I look back with mounting unease at a path strewn with half-started and half-finished projects, I wonder if I might have taken this counsel too much, and too literally, to heart.

title: EQT and Goldman Sachs Funds Sell Remaining Stake in ISS
description: LONDON  The Swedish private equity firm EQT Partners and funds advised by Goldman Sachs have sold their remaining stake in the Danish outsourcing company ISS for about $1 billion a decade after acquiring the company.

title: Facing Steep Climb, Lakers Are Rungs Ahead of the Knicks
description: LOS ANGELES  For a voice of experience on how a very bad N.B.A. team can quickly be transformed into a formidable one, Byron Scott should be your man.

title: Hillarynomics: Big Policy Questions for Clinton
description: Barring an unexpected economic boom over the next year and a half, the 2016 Democratic nominee for president will probably not base her campaign around being President Obamas heir.

title: Newark Valentines Day Homesteaders Face Financing Challenge
description: The city of Newark generated plenty of publicity on Valentines Day, when more than 500 hopeful buyers lined up for a shot at purchasing one of 100 vacant lots being offered for $1,000 apiece.

title: Jazzs New Home in New Orleans
description: Jazz in New Orleans is getting a new home with the April 2 opening of the Peoples Health New Orleans Jazz Market in the Central City neighborhood.

title: Exclusive | 120 East End Avenue
description: A grandly proportioned 17-room maisonette in a white-glove co-op opposite Carl Schurz Park is poised to re-enter the market.

title: Stuff We Liked
description: Winters chill has broken and we must have been thinking about getting out, if what delighted us on the web this week is any indication.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Last Flight of Poxl West
description: This week, Daniel Torday discusses The Last Flight of Poxl West; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Frank Bruni talks about Barney Franks new memoir; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Last Flight of Poxl West
description: This week, Daniel Torday and Frank Bruni.

title: Muslim Teachers May Wear Head Scarves, German Court Rules
description: BERLIN  The Federal Constitutional Court ruled on Friday that female Muslim teachers may wear head scarves in school.

title: Paris Fashion Week Street Style
description: Fashionable men and women at the fall 2015 collection shows.

title: Bringing Bolshoi Ballet to Movie Theaters
description: The Bolshoi Ballet is coming to a movie theater near you. Well, in all likelihood: the 2015-16 season of Bolshoi Ballet in Cinema, presented by Path Live and BY Experience, will show seven full-length ballets  three prerecorded (so the casts are known) and four shown live or on the day of performance  in some 450 spots across the United States and Canada.

title: Upper East Side Maisonette for $18 Million
description: A grandly proportioned 17-room maisonette in a white-glove co-op at 120 East End Avenue opposite Carl Schurz Park is poised to enter the market with an asking price of $18 million. The monthly maintenance charge for the residence, which has a private entrance on the avenue and a formal entry via the buildings discreet lobby on East 85th Street, is $9,467.

title: 1940: Ex-Governor of Punjab Slain
description: LONDON  A mysterious assassin today [March 13] shot and killed Sir Michael ODwyer, former Lieutenant Governor of the Punjab, and wounded Lord Zetland, Secretary of State for India, Sir Louis W. Dane and Lord Lamington at the conclusion of a meeting in Caxton Hall while 150 of Britains highest ranking civil servants looked on in horror. The outrage is believed to be an act of vengeance arising out of the Amritsar shooting of 1919.

title: In China, a Building Frenzys Fault Lines
description: As the real estate market in the United States was collapsing in the mid-2000s, Wall Street went in search of new terrain, and found it in China. All across the country, from Beijing to Shenzhen, sprawling housing developments and business districts were popping up, seemingly overnight. Real estate prices were soaring. Western banks, hedge funds, private equity firms and other investors wanted a piece of the action.

title: Netanyahu Shifts Tactics as His Likud Party Appears to Slip in Final Surveys
description: JERUSALEM  When Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu made an unannounced visit this week to the Mahane Yehuda market here, he did not invite the local news media. Instead, selected scenes from his tour were filmed and the video released by his campaign.

title: Paris Fashion Week Street Style
description: After a monthlong marathon of shows, Paris Fashion Week is the last chance for insiders to peacock their carefully planned outfits. The Tuileries Garden, the hub for all things style (and Paris itself in itsfinery), is the perfect backdrop for showgoers to parade their looks. Here, some noteworthy moments from outside the shows.

title: Love or Hate Christian Laettner, but It Is Time to Honor Him
description: Christian Laettner is not a member of the Basketball Hall of Fame as an individual. But an objective look at a player whom fans loved to hate says he should be.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: 5 Womens Rights Activists Are Formally Detained in Beijing
description: BEIJING  The police in Beijing have put five young female activists under formal detention on suspicion of picking quarrels and provoking trouble, lawyers for four of the women said on Friday. The charge is one that the Chinese authorities have increasingly used in recent years to quell activism and discussion of social and political issues.

title: Israel Chooses
description: Scenes from the campaign trail earlier this year, as Israelis grappled with a rapidly evolving political landscape.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Last Flight of Poxl West
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Teddy Wayne reviews Daniel Tordays first novel, The Last Flight of Poxl West. Mr. Wayne writes:

title: Greenwich Village Townhouse Brings $9,500,000
description: A 20-foot-wide townhouse in Greenwich Village, with a dual-personality exterior that includes an unassuming brick front and a whimsical rear facade boldly accented with a rainbow of colors, sold for $9,500,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Letting a Broken Arm Heal Without Surgery
description: Broken arms are routinely treated with surgery, but a randomized trial has found that many breaks can be allowed to heal on their own.

title: Notes on an Idiots Guide to Retirement
description: My article in this weeks special section on retirement was an attempt to get off my behind and actually think about my finances. As the article points out, Ive been avoiding any real confrontation with issues like retirement for many years, though I always made sure to set up a regular contribution to a 401(k) account. Was it enough? Finding out was the point of the article. And since, like many reporters, I do almost nothing without a deadline, having an assignment to write on the subject made me finally take my own financial life seriously.

title: 1890: Revelers Pack Paris Streets
description: Paris offered yesterday a perfect picture of metropolitan bliss. Years have passed since the city had enjoyed itself so thoroughly on the occasion of the Mid-Lent festival. It was not that the masks were more numerous or the perambulating blanchisseuses more gaily attired than in former ftes of the Mi-Carme, but simply that the sun shone down with spring-like warmth and brightness, giving an extra glitter to every spangle, and making each peal of laughter sound with double merriment.

title: Vaccines Face Same Mistrust That Fed Ebola
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  West Africas Ebola epidemic may be waning, but another outbreak in the future is a near certainty, health officials say.

title: Childless by Choice
description: ALTADENA, Calif.  I WENT to a fortuneteller when I was 25. Her house was on a busy street, its shingled siding a strange, marigold orange, the trim a clashing bright red and blue. A banner advertised: Special: $5.

title: Readers Respond: On Republican Idiocy on Iran
description: For many readers of Thursdays editorial on the subject, Republican senators open letter to Iran represents a dangerous new low in U.S. politics and international relations.

title: Fortum Agrees to Sell Swedish Power Distribution Grid for $6.9 Billion
description: LONDON  Fortum, the state-controlled Finnish utility, said on Friday that it had agreed to sell its Swedish electricity distribution network to a consortium of Swedish funds and Borealis Infrastructure Management of Canada for 6.6 billion euros, or about $6.9 billion, including debt.

title: Fear of Frying
description: Nutritionists will tell you that butter is back is not quite the right message to be sending to the public about the significance of fat in a healthy diet. We can, however, let go of our fear of frying, especially if we use monounsaturated fats like olive oil and polyunsaturated fats like grapeseed oil. Study after study has indicated that refined carbohydrates play a much more insidious role in our national health problems than fats do, and that a moderate-fat (but low-saturated fat) diet like the Mediterranean diet (about 40 percent calories from fat) is a healthy way to eat, and even more important, an enjoyable, very easy way of eating to adhere to.

title: What I Love | James Klein and David Reid
description: Two ceramists live with their own and others works, vintage furniture and a few beloved unidentified objects.

title: In Queens, Ceramics, History, and a Bit of Mystery
description: The ceramists James Klein and David Reid came to live in the borough of Queens as many do, after a stint in Brooklyn.

title: The Trouble With Advance Directives
description: The man had written an advance directive four years ago, before his advancing dementia had made communication difficult. He had been very specific.

title: All You Need to Know About Income Inequality, in One Comparison
description: The Wall Street bonus pool for last year is roughly double the total earnings of all Americans who work full time at the federal minimum wage.

title: Valeant Said to Be Planning to Raise Its Bid for Salix Pharmaceuticals
description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals is planning to team up with Pershing Square Capital Management and other top shareholders, including ValueAct Capital, to raise its bid for Salix Pharmaceuticals this weekend, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Watching Fresh Off the Boat at Asia Roma in Chinatown
description: According to the Tuesday-night bartender, Asia Roma used to be an Italian mobster bar when it was still known as Antica Roma.

title: Tumblr 486  489
description: Tumblr 486  489

title: Like Taking a Luxury Bus: Via, a Ride-Share App, Offers Manhattan Trips
description: Ive recently started using the citys public bus system, and I love it. Its not the fastest or most efficient way to get from Point A to Point B. But its very comfortable, its somewhat relaxing, and it feels as if Im participating in a new aspect of civic life.

title: Progress Is Slow at V.A. Hospitals in Wake of Crisis
description: PHOENIX  The nations largest hospital system has made only halting progress in hiring new doctors, replacing incompetent supervisors, upgrading outdated computers and rebuilding trust with veterans, nine months after President Obama concluded that a corrosive culture had led to systemic problems at hospitals run by the Department of Veterans Affairs.

title: Assanges Lawyer Welcomes Questioning
description: Per Samuelson, a lawyer for Julian Assange, said he welcomed the decision of a Swedish prosecutor to question the WikiLeaks founder Mr. Assange in London over sexual assault accusations.

title: Grilling a Supreme Court Justice Is No Easy Task
description: The trick to interviewing a justice of the Supreme Court as it prepares to issue major decisions is to ask seemingly general questions that might nonetheless elicit a preview of what is to come.

title: Cookie Is an Empire Builder for Fox
description: Who is your favorite character on Empire? Is it Jamal, the multitalented gay singer-songwriter? It is Porsha, the constantly put-upon, but ever loyal, assistant? Could it possibly be Hakeem, the immature rapper with the Kid n Play-esque flattop?

title: A Chess Master Tries to Turn Rabbits Into Wolves
description: In the rear of a Harlem chess club last Sunday night, amid the hubbub of trash-talking players, a group of polite schoolchildren took turns playing speed chess against a large man whose dreadlocks were mostly covered with a wool hat.

title: Tobias Jesso Jr.s Take on His New Album, Adele and Fame
description: The first time Tobias Jesso Jr. performed a song from his album, Goon, with other musicians was last month on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon. His backing band was the Roots.

title: Ben Mendelsohn: A Good Bad Man to Have Around
description: The most terrifying moment in the premiere episode of Bloodline, Netflixs dark new drama, occurs when the actor Ben Mendelsohn stands up.

title: Ballet West Comes to the Joyce
description: We suffer physical pain and shocking injuries, a female voice intones as images of calloused and bandaged toes flash across the screen. Theres rivalry, says a pretty brunette, and relationships. Cut to a glimpse of an anxious dancer biting her lip in the studio, followed by a couple gazing into each others eyes while locked in a balletic embrace. Why do we do it? the voice continues. To have that one single moment onstage when everything comes together. Then: We do it, pause, to be perfect.

title: Courtney Barnett Prepares Her Debut Album
description: The Australian songwriter Courtney Barnett writes about the little, not always simple, things in life. An asthma attack. Insomnia in hotel rooms. House-hunting on a meager budget. Trying (and failing) to impress the swimmer in the next lane at the pool. Roadkill. And all sorts of ambivalence: about success, romance, the state of the world. Im no sociological genius, she said via Skype from her home in Melbourne. I just know what I know.

title: When Employee Engagement Turns Into Employee Burnout
description: Is there a company of any significant size that doesnt seek and venerate employee engagement?

title: In Israeli Race, Winning First Place Is No Guarantee of Becoming Premier
description: JERUSALEM  When the first election results begin to flow in on the night of March 17, Israelis may need to get out their calculators.

title: Things To Do When Youre Dead To Davos
description: The Greek government has deployed a lot of populist and nationalist rhetoric, and eurocrats seem shocked. But the miracle is that this hasnt happened until now.

title: Will Hillary Clinton Follow Democrats on Capital Gains?
description: As my colleague David Leonhardt notes, one of the big policy questions for Hillary Clinton is how eager she is to tax the rich. But this isnt just a question of the top rate on wages. If she runs for president, it will be very interesting to see whether Mrs. Clinton takes a position substantially to Barack Obamas right on capital gains taxes, as she did in 2008.

title: An Avant-Garde Odyssey FromLes Dlices Ensemble at Columbia
description: For years, Ulysses has roamed the campus of Columbia University. The hero of Homers The Odyssey is an annual specter for students here: The epic is mandatory reading for every freshman. This year theyve been able to encounter him up close in the exuberant collages of Romare Beardens Black Odyssey, part of an exhibition at the Wallach Art Gallery that closed this month. The Odyssey is also the subject of a program of French baroque music titled Myths and Allegories, which the period-instrument ensemble Les Dlices is scheduled to present at the universitys Miller Theater on March 28 with the soprano Clara Rottsolk.

title: In Mexico Oil Market, Mood Moves From Excited to Anxious
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexico kicked off the opening of its oil industry to great fanfare. At a packed event at the Technology Museum here seven months ago, maps flashed on a giant screen showing dozens of oil fields that would be put up for bid to private companies for the first time in more than 75 years.

title: Crash Victims Include Decorated Marine
description: ATLANTA  Before a military helicopter disappeared into a thick bank of fog off the Florida coast, killing all 11 servicemen aboard, military officials had conducted an operational risk assessment and determined that the weather was safe enough to fly in, Maj. Gen. Joseph L. Osterman, commander of the Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command, said Friday.

title: On the Front Lines in Ferguson
description: John Eligon has been reporting on the developments in Ferguson, Mo., since last summer, when Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, was killed by a white police officer.

title: Some Wedding Sites Also Play Hard to Get
description: When Julia Greenberg, 27, became engaged last Thanksgiving to her longtime boyfriend, Carl Wolf, she didnt realize she would have to wait more than a year and a half to get married at her favorite place, the Adler Planetarium in Chicago. In January, with other couples circling, they quickly signed a contract for a Saturday in July 2016.

title: Looks Real, but Look Closer
description: A new trend rocked the New York art world in the late 1960s: Photorealist painting, in which people, places and things were rendered with shocking lucidity. One of the genres best practitioners was and still is Richard Estes, a Chicagoan who has lived in New York since 1958. Working from photographs that he takes himself, Mr. Estes paints images of cars, storefronts, subways, bridges and theater marquees, incorporating the ordinary, banal and overlooked into formally acute and uncannily vivid images. You see as if through the eyes of someone whose perceptions have been somehow intensified.

title: Speed Propels Rangers to Front of Pack in East
description: As a youth hockey player in Boxford, Mass., Rangers forward Chris Kreider was always the fastest skater on his team. Even as he shot up to what he is today  a 6-foot-3, 226-pound menace  he has maintained his superlative speed.

title: They Still Bristle and Snarl
description: The Pop Group emerged in the post-punk scrum of late-1970s England, where abrasive sounds and political outrage forged an enduring alliance. The Pop Group was pioneering and extreme; Nick Cave has called it unholy, manic, violent, paranoid, painful music. Its songs crunched together tight funk, deranged noise, exotic instruments, free-jazz improvisations, electronic manipulations and sonic anarchy, while Mark Stewart yowled, screamed, barked, ranted and occasionally sang about the depredations of money and power. The band lasted from 1977 to 80 and released only two albums, though Mr. Stewart went on lead his own punk-funk band, Mark Stewart and the Maffia, in the 1980s.

title: Collective Percussion
description: Kodo, the sensational Japanese drum ensemble, plays the Brooklyn Academy of Music as part of Kodo One Earth Tour: Mystery, a new work. This acclaimed troupe practices a tradition of massed drumming that traces back to the sixth century and often includes other instruments and even some singing. (7:30 p.m. Thursday-Saturday, Howard Gilman Opera House, 718-636-4100, bam.org.)

title: New Music From War on Women, Rixton and Mourn
description: War on Women

title: Intimate Ties Above and Below
description: Of Horses and Men, the acclaimed first feature by the Icelandic stage director Benedikt Erlingsson, explores the man-beast relationships between short-legged Icelandic horses and human characters. Its extraordinary scenes of equestrians and high-strung animals interacting in the stunningly beautiful Icelandic countryside point up the temperamental similarities between species.

title: This Old Thing? Its Back in Style
description: Reality shows built around fashion, whether Project Runway or Say Yes to the Dress, tend to rely on histrionics  competing designers argue, frantic brides melt down, and so on. The Smithsonian Channels L.A. Frock Stars, which returns for a second season on Thursday night, is a different animal, a mix of history and Hollywood glamour that is still a guilty pleasure but makes you feel a little smarter for having watched it.

title: Verbatim: Walker Calls Bush a Name From the Past
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, talking to The Tampa Bay Times about his rival Jeb Bush.

title: Mets Bolstered Rotation Is Again in Doubt
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets decided years ago to build their team around elite young pitching, a strategy that carried some inherent risk. Strong and vibrant pitchers are lost to arm injuries every year, so general managers almost have to walk around with their fingers crossed, hoping for the best.

title: Lights! Camera! Food!
description: For the past seven years, photographer Andrew Scrivani has tempted our taste buds with delicious food photographs for the Recipes for Health series. This video report gives a behind-the-scenes look at food photography and how he captures food looking its best.

title: Blurred Legal Lines
description: Ben Sisario, Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the Blurred Lines copyright trial.

title: Know Your Heirloom and Ancient Grains
description: WHEAT BERRIES Whole kernels of wheat, with the bran intact. Depending upon the variety of wheat, wheat berries can run from mild and starchy in flavor to earthy and mineral.

title: 3 Persian Gulf Nations Pledge $12 Billion in Aid for Egypt
description: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt  Three Persian Gulf monarchies on Friday pledged a total of $12 billion in aid to Egypt, adding to a total of more than $20 billion already contributed since the military ouster of President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood nearly 20 months ago.

title: Beyond Quinoa: The New Ancient Grains
description: Youve cooked your way through quinoa of every color, dabbled in amaranth and moved beyond millet. That farro and kale salad? Its been in your dinner party rotation for at least two years.

title: Is Your Babysitter an Employee? It Matters to Tax Liability
description: TAX time can be particularly taxing for families who pay an in-home caregiver or housekeeper.

title: How Josh Lebowitz of Brother Jimmys Spends His Sunday
description: March Madness is here, so let the basketball bacchanal begin. Outfitted with multiple screens and school logos, Brother Jimmys, the barbecue chain, blends school spirit and Southern hospitality. This time of year, college sports fans flock to its five Manhattan restaurants, overseen by Josh Lebowitz, chairman of Dining Entertainment Group. Not that the 45-year-old comes from a sports powerhouse; he played squash for Tufts University. On Sundays, Mr. Lebowitz is more likely to be at home, taking parent-proud videos with his phone (while monitoring restaurant security feeds), rather than out, carousing with regulars. He and his wife, Adriana, live with Logan, almost 3, and Wyatt, 5 months, in a TriBeCa loft.

title: G.M. Settles Switch Suit, Avoiding Depositions
description: DETROIT  In a notable victory for General Motors, a lawsuit that helped spur the biggest safety crisis in the companys history has been withdrawn in exchange for a settlement from its compensation program, according to two people briefed on the agreement.

title: The Blurred Lines Between Homage and Plagiarism
description: The Blurred Lines trial wrapped up in Los Angeles this week. Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams were ordered to pay the family of Marvin Gaye about $7.4 million in damages and profits earned, for what a federal jury understood to be a copyright infringement.

title: Because Its Friday
description: Michelle Obamas latest part of the Lets Move! initiative is called GimmeFive, which asks Americans to share five things theyre doing to live a healthy life.

title: French Prosecutor Seeks Trial for HSBCs Swiss Operation
description: PARIS  HSBCs Swiss unit, the source of so much recent trouble for the British bank, has further problems.

title: U.S. Targets Shabab Unit in Somalia
description: WASHINGTON  The United States has carried out airstrikes against a senior member of the Shabab extremist group who is believed to have helped plan the 2013 attack on the Westgate mall in Kenya, American officials said Friday.

title: Kosher Supermarket Attacked in Paris to Reopen
description: PARIS  Hyper Cacher, the kosher supermarket here that was targeted in a terrorist attack in January that left four people dead and deeply shook Frances Jews, will open its doors on Sunday, senior Jewish officials said on Friday.

title: For Love of Country, and Each Other
description: When Capt. Lorelei M. Gaus moved from Camp Lejeune in North Carolina to Washington, D.C., in 2011, she was looking forward to living in a bustling city where her dating prospects would extend beyond Marines.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a four-bedroom ranch on one-third of an acre in Flower Hill, N.Y., and a four-bedroom Tudor-style house in Summit, N.J.

title: A Race Among Equals, and Also Dogs
description: Gender matters little in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, in which mushers drive their dogs through extreme Alaskan terrain and weather. Nearly a third of this years entrants were women.

title: Enduring theIditarod as Equals
description: It is difficult to tell if the musher standing behind a sled pulled by 16 dogs and wearing a puffy red parka and a face protector shrouded in frost is a man or a woman. But in competitive sled dog racing, it does not really matter.

title: Guardrails Said to Pass Safety Tests
description: WASHINGTON  A potentially dangerous guardrail cleared a crucial hurdle on Friday when federal officials released their analysis of four crash tests and gave the product passing grades, even for the final test, in which the drivers door was severely damaged.

title: Trinity Guardrail Crash Test
description: Video from the eighth crash test of a Trinity guardrail, which shows a Geo Metro spinning out after hitting the guardrail, causing the drivers door to strike a bent piece of metal.

title: International Criminal Court Formally Ends Case Against Kenyas President
description: PARIS  Criminal proceedings against President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya were formally closed on Friday by the judges of the International Criminal Court, three months after the prosecution dropped charges linking him to postelection violence in his country.

title: Israels Inequality Election
description: I havent been following Israeli politics at all  actually, if truth be told, after being out front so much against the Iraq venture, Ive spent the era of financial crisis taking a personal vacation from Middle East issues. But I have noticed that Netanyahu is in big trouble  not over foreign policy and security, but over economics. Oddly, however, much of the reporting seems to either neglect or downplay the background here, which is the extraordinary rise in Israeli income inequality over the past generation. Heres Israel compared with the US, from the LIS data:

title: 3 Brooklyn Men Accused of Plotting to Aid ISIS Plead Not Guilty
description: Three Brooklyn men accused of plotting to join the Islamic State gave bare biographical details in response to a judges questions as they pleaded not guilty to various charges on Friday.

title: Activists Crowd Into Bank of New York Mellon Fight
description: Bank of New York Mellon is under fire. Again. Marcato Capital Management is seeking to oust Gerald Hassell, chief executive of the $44 billion financial institution. Thats after Nelson Peltzs activist hedge fund Trian Fund Management secured a board seat. Activism is starting to look like a crowded strategy.

title: Fashionably Frozen in Time, Cobblestones Sells Vintage Clothing in the East Village
description: Well, how are we today, young man? the glamorous proprietor of Cobblestones, Delanee Koppersmith, sang out to a New York University student in horn-rimmed glasses who gingerly entered her vintage clothing store one snowy Tuesday. He was shopping for a gift for his long-distance girlfriend  always an intimidating prospect. The man broke into a relieved smile as Ms. Koppersmith started singing along to the Ella Fitzgerald tune playing in the store: No, no, they cant take that away from me ...

title: Neighborhood Joint: Cobblestones
description: Cobblestones, an East Village shop, is known for its vintage clothing, and for its convivial owner.

title: Islamist Websites in Turkey Manage to Evade Strict Internet Censorship
description: ISTANBUL  The websites of an atheist association, the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo and a Kurdish separatist organization are blocked to Turkish Internet users. But many sites that promote extreme Islamist messages  even some that are outright sympathetic to the Islamic State, the militant organization that has marauded through Iraq and Syria  escape Turkeys censors.

title: A Site Finds the Fastest (and Slowest) Flights
description: As dynamic as its selection can be, browsing the Hudson News store or hunting for open electrical outlets isnot what most travelers look forward to when heading to the airport. Booking a flight has never been easier, but completing one seems to be proving more and more difficult.

title: A Race Among Equals, and Also Dogs

title: Credit Suisse Promotes New Bankers to Lead Mergers Advisory Unit
description: Credit Suisse has reshuffled its mergers and acquisitions ranks, according to an internal memo signed by James Amine, head of the investment banking division.

title: Review: Andras Schiff Turns Mischievous at Carnegie Hall
description: What was Andras Schiff, the eminent Budapest-born pianist, up to when he sat down to begin a recital program, the first of two, at Carnegie Hall this week? A part-time London resident who was knighted last year by Queen Elizabeth II, Mr. Schiff commands international respect as a paragon of refinement and musical integrity. Yet, on this night, as he settled into recital mode, was that a glint of mischief I caught in his eyes?

title: Review: ThomasAds Leads the Philharmonic, andBjrk Listens
description: That elusive mix came to Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday: a real musical event that drew a packed house and a young audience  and even Bjrk. Listening was close, the excitement palpable and the applause spontaneous.

title: Jay Z Buys the Music Streaming Firm, Aspiro
description: Its official: Jay Z is buying an online streaming company that competes with Spotify and Apple.

title: Bolaos 2666 Coming to the Stage, Thanks to a Powerball Jackpot
description: An actor and stage manager turned Episcopal monk who pledged last year to give away much of his $153 million Powerball jackpot to support the performing arts has made his first grant  to a theatrical production as improbable as his own story.

title: Movie Review: Going Clear
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief.

title: Vote for the Next Big City Book Club Selection
description: We recently asked readers to suggest the selection for our next installment of the Big City Book Club, and great ideas came forth, with dozens of books nominated. We have narrowed the field down to three, representing a range of interests and eras, that also fit the criterion of being widely available, and we are asking you to vote on the final choice. The nominees are:

title: Review: Jose Llana Radiates Youthful Bravado in American Songbook
description: Jose Llana may be 38. But this Filipino-American singer, who made his Broadway debut in 1996 singing We Kiss in a Shadow, in a revival of The King and I, radiated the eagerness and enthusiasm of a young pup in his American Songbook concert at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse on Thursday evening.

description: The discrimination accusations made last year by a former Mets executive portrayed the team and its chief operating officer, Jeff Wilpon, as intolerant of a pregnant, unmarried woman.

title: Challenger Offers a Financial Plan for Chicago
description: CHICAGO  After spending months avoiding questions about how he would solve Chicagos dizzying fiscal problems, Jesus G. Garcia released a plan on Friday that he said would right the citys listing financial ship.

title: Housemate Takes Blame for Shining Laser at Planes in Bronx
description: After being charged this week with injuring several pilots by shining a laser beam at their planes, Frank J. Egan was held up as a pest, his arrest an example of pinpoint investigative work leading the authorities to a typically elusive target.

title: The Social Security Maze and Other U.S. Mysteries
description: In recent years, the Boston University economist Laurence J. Kotlikoff has made something of a game  and then, eventually, an art  of cornering smart people and convincing them that they were leaving tens of thousands of Social Security dollars on the table.

title: Clinton Said to be Close to Choosing Brooklyn for Campaign Headquarters
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons aides are close to locking in space for a campaign headquarters in Brooklyn, people familiar with the decision confirmed.

description: The current hosts of The View are Whoopi Goldberg, Rosie Perez and Nicolle Wallace. Here is what their predecessors have gone on to do after leaving the show.

title: Steve Ditkos Thugs and Mystics
description: An occasional series on vintage comics.

title: The Rise of Early-Morning Dance Parties
description: It was around 7:15 on a recent Tuesday morning when I realized, arms linked through his and lying, face up, on his back, that I had known this man  his name was Dijon, and he was wearing leggings  for only 10 minutes. We were in the middle of a partner yoga session at one of the San Francisco editions of Daybreaker, an early-morning dance party that descends, every month, on an increasing number of cities around the world.

title: For Homeless Photographers, Pride of Place in Paris
description: PARIS  The images capture a different Paris from the one beloved by tourists: refuse in a garbage bag that could be mistaken for a bloom on water; a dank tunnel opening onto a light-filled avenue of trees; a longhaired figure in a heavy coat silhouetted in a window, deeply alone.

title: The Problem With Fat Talk
description: ON Tuesday, in the wake of an online petition signed by thousands of people, Facebook announced that it was removing feeling fat from its list of status update emoticons. The petition argued that the offending emoticon, with its chubby cheeks and double chin, reinforced negative body images, and Facebook seemed to agree.

title: Review: C.O.A.L (Confessions of a Liar) Opens at 59E59 Theaters
description: When Tommy Maloney, a cocky first grader, mentions his $10-a-week allowance, Coal announces that he gets $100. And not only that, little Coal adds: My dad is a pirate.

title: Rand Paul Focuses on Criminal Justice in Talk to Black Students
description: BOWIE, Md.  Senator Rand Paul laid out his vision on Friday for a legal system that makes it easier for people with criminal records to get jobs and to vote, telling students at a historically black college here that he believes there are still two Americas as the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said almost a half century ago.

title: Village Vanguard Celebrates Its 80th, Adding Poetry and Comedy to Jazz
description: The Village Vanguard is unlike most of the rest of New York life: a rarefied basement thats been here since before most of us were born and will be here after we die. (Or perhaps not, but there seems no other way to think about it.) It is not a grasping or anxious place. It remains idiosyncratically competitive in the cultural marketplace, cultivates its own favorites, presents them regardless of whether the bands have something new to promote.

title: In the Northeast, Retreating Snowbanks Hint at Spring, but Winter Is Not Over Yet
description: For two months, there was an intensifying sense of when will it end here in the Northeast, as persistent cold sustained banks of snow built by an exhausting sequence of storms.

title: Review: Alabama Shakes Lifts Soul to a Different Plane
description: A straightforward soul revival would be too banal for the Alabama Shakes, who finished a sold-out two-night stand at the Beacon Theater on Thursday night. It would be easy for the band to stay retro. Its lead singer, Brittany Howard, can be achingly subtle or an unstoppable force of nature; she also happens to be an authoritative lead guitarist. Ms. Howard and the rest of the band are steeped as well in the patient grooves and storytelling strategies of soul, particularly the sounds of Memphis and Muscle Shoals.

description: France and More  Pictures of the Day

title: March 13, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from France, Syria, Ukraine and China.

title: More Networks Jumping on the Biblical Bandwagon
description: Television is largely a godless place, some would say, but not this month. Programs with biblical or other religious themes are sprouting up, some in places where you might not expect them. If nothing else, costumers who traffic in robes and sandals are doing a booming business.

description: Email use, college debt and appearances by 2016 White House hopefuls made headlines again this week.

title: Cabaret and Hedwig Get Tougher Onstage
description: The things a girl has to endure to get ahead in show business. The humiliation, the rejection, the objectification, the manhandling and  worst of all  the being treated as if you didnt even exist. Its enough to make even the sunniest chorine feel burned out by the end of a working night.

title: A Bridge Deal From the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams
description: NEW ORLEANS  The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams is the premier event at the Spring North American Championships here. Last years final was between the two favorites, Monaco (Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness) and Nickell (Nick Nickell, Ralph Katz, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell).

title: Remembering Lisa Adams
description: Wendi Aarons stood in her kitchen in Austin, Tex., and looked at her iPhone. She felt a sudden rush of tears. She glanced at her husband and children, who were eating breakfast. She wasnt sure she could articulate her sadness to them, so she turned to the place where she knew others would understand. It is hard to explain to your family why youre crying over the loss of someone youve never even had a cup of coffee with, she posted to her Facebook page.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Review: Paul Taylors American Modern Dance Gala Looks to Past
description: Paul Taylors Sea Lark, which had its New York premiere on Wednesday, is entirely disappointing. A trivial frolic set to Poulencs irresistibly energetic Les Biches, the dance, new in October, is a boating adventure, with painted waves, a large toy sailboat and boring young people being frightfully jolly. There are pleasures to be found in the bright color schemes of the costumes and sets by Alex Katz, a long-term Taylor collaborator, but they cant save the day.

description: Wall Street bonuses are galling, a point that was driven home again this week with the release of the annual report on bonuses by the New York State comptroller.

title: Taking On the Food Industry, One Blog Post at a Time
description: On a recent Thursday, Vani Hari, perhaps Public Enemy No. 1 of big food companies, sat at ABC Kitchen in the Flatiron district wearing a purple sweater with a giant pink heart and pink heart-shaped crystal earrings. Ms. Hari, 35, who is better known as Food Babe, the name of her blog, flipped through photographs of her that her mother had recently unearthed, pausing at one taken immediately after college at a Mexican restaurant.

title: Stockard Channing and Friends Usher in a New Chelsea Bar
description: Shopworn volumes lined the room, lanterns shed an amber light, and a pair of ancient bed irons weighed down the tartan tossed across the bed. Those cozy atmospherics didnt escape Stockard Channing, who had gusted into the Lodge at Gallow Green, a new rooftop bar in Chelsea, on a blast of sleety air the other night.

description: LOS ANGELES  Kelly Sawyer Patricof does not seem like the kind of woman who would devote her life to diapering the children of the poor.

description: A short visit with a friend led Rony Zakaria to spend years exploring how faith shapes the relationship between people and nature in Indonesia.
