description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  There was something about the way the University of Alabama at Birminghams mens basketball team took the court here at midday Thursday that made me think that the Blazers fan holding a sign that said U.A.B. Shock the World might not be so crazy after all.

title: Solar Eclipse and Supermoon Have Europe Energy Providers Watchful
description: BERLIN  Germany has enthusiastically embraced the sun as an important source of energy, but a strange celestial trifecta on Friday evoked a shiver of ancient fears  and the more practical concern that the lights might go out.

title: Review: In Metalhead, an Icelandic Girl Drowns Her Sorrows in Music
description: Ragnar Bragasons Metalhead  about a disaffected teenage girl on an isolated farm who finds salvation in heavy-metal music  could have been set in a Great Plains town or in any American agricultural hamlet. But it takes place near Svarthamar, an empty, rural corner of Iceland, where much social activity revolves around the church.

title: Review: Please Be Normal, a Couples Dawning Desperation
description: It takes courage to ask your partner Are we happy? especially if, like Mary (Elisabeth Waterston), youre pregnant and your boyfriend, Victor (played by Ms. Waterstons husband, Louis Cancelmi), seems increasingly detached from his imminent fatherhood. That detachment, its cause and consequence, forms the shrouded heart of Please Be Normal, a tiny, piercing study of dawning desperation thats all the more remarkable for being virtually silent.

title: Coverage of Arctic Sea Ice Shrinks to a Winter Low
description: There was less sea ice coverage in the Arctic this winter than in any year since satellite measurements began nearly four decades ago, researchers said Thursday. The National Snow and Ice Data Center, a government-sponsored research group, said that in late February ice cover in the Arctic Ocean reached its maximum extent, 5.61 million square miles, which is about 7 percent less than the average from 1981 to 2010 and about 1 percent less than the previous lowest year, 2011. The center said that changes in the jet stream created warmer than normal conditions on the Pacific side of the Arctic. While the extent of Arctic sea ice is naturally variable, it has been generally declining over the past several decades as the region warms more quickly than other parts of the planet.

title: Review: The Heidi Chronicles, With Elisabeth Moss, Opens on Broadway
description: Do the responsibilities that come with age inevitably erode the ideals of youth? Can women achieve the most in their careers while enjoying a fully satisfying family life? Is sadness a natural  as opposed to pathological  response to the realization that life will not bring us everything we had hoped it would?

title: Augustus, to Julius Caesar
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Today marks another debut by a constructor from Canada named Roland Huget. He introduces himself in his notes, so I will limit myself to the puzzle.

title: Review: In Spring, Romance Gives Way to a Beastly Horror
description: Justin Benson and Aaron Moorhead dont yet have many movies to their credit, but with Spring, which they directed, they show that they already possess something that many makers of horror films never develop: patience.

title: Hostility From U.S. as China Lures Allies to New Bank
description: BEIJING  When Xi Jinping, then the newly minted Chinese leader, first broached the idea of a new Asian development bank in a public speech in 2013, few in Washington paid it much heed.

title: Mayor de Blasio Defends Efforts to Help Struggling Schools
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio defended his administrations efforts to fix New York Citys troubled schools on Thursday, describing those efforts as a cross between a war and a policing operation  the educational equivalent of house-to-house combat.

title: Patz Trial Jury Is Told Suspect Was Prone to Confessing
description: Pedro Hernandez, the man who has confessed to strangling Etan Patz, was susceptible to giving a false confession while being questioned by detectives because of his low intelligence, a psychologist serving as a defense witness testified on Thursday.

title: The Gesture That Turned a Fiscal Crisis Into Twitter Fodder  or Did It?
description: PARIS  Did he flip Germany the bird?

title: M.L.B. Exhibition Possible in Cuba Next Year
description: Major League Baseball continues to highlight its intention to play at least one exhibition game in Cuba, bringing the game to the homeland of some of the leagues best players.

title: U.S. Must Step Up Capacity for Cyberattacks, Chief Argues
description: WASHINGTON  The admiral who directs American cyberforces told a Senate committee on Thursday that the United States was at a tipping point where it needed to increase its ability to conduct cyberattacks, to create a deterrent against other countries that are attacking it.

title: Greco-German Fingergate Gets Curiouser and Curiouser
description: Amid tense negotiations between Greece and its European creditors, the eyes of the German media remained firmly focused Thursday on the Greek finance ministers middle finger  specifically on the question of whether a two-year-old video clip of him extending that digit in Germanys metaphorical direction was real or fake.

title: Review: Secret of Water Studies Liquid as an Archive of History
description: Theres a whole lot of hogwash in Secret of Water, a cheesy documentary stuffed full of pseudoscience masquerading as profound truth.

title: Short-Handed Cincinnati Rallies Past Purdue
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Playing without its coach and suddenly its leading scorer, No. 8 seed Cincinnati rallied in regulation and defeated No. 9 seed Purdue, 66-65, in overtime in a Midwest Region game Thursday night.

title: Review: In Tracers, Taylor Lautner Joins a Shady Parkour Gang
description: Part urban crime film, part romantic fantasy, Tracers begins by zipping along with the street-level symbol of heedless New York motion, a bike messenger. When this particular speed demon, Cam (Taylor Lautner), has an accident, he slams into a young woman practicing another kind of perpetual motion, parkour, an equipment-free sport that treats urban spaces as obstacle courses. Corny twists and exchanges ensue in the wobbly story, but, delightfully, Daniel Benmayors film shows love not just for stunts but for the dynamic surfaces of the city.

title: Utah Holds Off Stephen F. Austins Upset Bid
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Utah, one of the countrys best defensive teams, clamped down high-scoring Stephen F. Austin, staving off an upset bid and advancing to the round of 32.

title: Head of Secret Service Denies Crash
description: Joseph P. Clancy, the director of the Secret Service, disputed reports that an incident at the White House involving his agents was a car crash.

title: Virginia Just Cant Win With Critics of Its Style
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  On the way to winning 29 games and a second consecutive Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season crown, Virginia has managed to help provoke one of the more fascinating academic discussions on the state of college basketball as we know it.

title: Charles N. Shaffer Jr., Lawyer Who Bolstered Case Against Nixon, Dies at 82
description: Charles N. Shaffer Jr., a fastidious litigator whose painstaking defense of John W. Dean III, the White House counsel, helped cost Richard M. Nixon the presidency during the Watergate scandal, died on March 15 at his home in Woodbine, Md. He was 82.

title: In a Battle of the Lowly, the Knicks End Up a Bit Lower
description: After nearly five months of futility, the Knicks and the Minnesota Timberwolves showed up at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night with matching records: 14-53, which qualified them as the two worst teams in the N.B.A.

title: Review: In Zombeavers, the Flesheaters Have Overbites
description: Great careers have begun with flesh-eating creatures. Take the writer-director John Sayles (Lone Star), who got his start in movies writing trash classics like Piranha and Alligator. Now the director Jordan Rubin, a former writer for Comedy Centrals Crank Yankers, and Evan Astrowsky, a producer of Eli Roths horror film Cabin Fever, pool their talents for Zombeavers, an intermittently diverting stew of low-budget effects and potty-mouth humor. Unsurprisingly, its writers and soundtrack composers, the brothers Jon and Al Kaplan, wrote the music for Syfys Piranhaconda and Dinocroc vs. Supergator. (More intriguingly, they also created Silence!, the stage parody of The Silence of the Lambs.)

title: Review: Cant Stand Losing You, Andy Summerss Version of the Police
description: The most exciting moment in Andy Grieves rather dull documentary, Cant Stand Losing You: Surviving the Police, comes when we learn that Stings can of hair spray exploded in his face right before a 1978 television appearance. Had the actual detonation been recorded, it would have livened up a movie singularly lacking in rock-doc unpredictability and verve.

title: Malcolm Fraser, a Leader Given Power During Crisis in Australia, Dies at 84
description: Malcolm Fraser, who was appointed prime minister of Australia by the British crown during a constitutional crisis and led his country for eight years, winning three elections, died on Friday. He was 84.

title: Against North Carolina State, L.S.U. Lets One Slip Away
description: PITTSBURGH  The problem with being the team that came closest to beating mighty Kentucky, as Louisiana State has discovered, is the burden of expectations. The Tigers know how well they are capable of playing, but then there are the days when they lose to conference doormats like Auburn and Mississippi State, and how do they explain that?

title: Elizabeth Alexander: Eat, Memory
description: The poets memoir recounts her romance with her late husband, but it also tells the story of their romance with food. In her Manhattan home, the tastes and scents of their shared life linger.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New Starring Zaha Hadid and Ricky Gervais
description: Ricky Gervais and Zaha Hadid curl up in a birds nest while considering a floor-scrubbing robot and a lamp made from a weed.

title: Word of the Day | centigrade
description: centigrade  \sen-t-grad, sn-\  adjective

title: Yankees Jacoby Ellsbury Expects to Play on Opening Day Despite Oblique Strain
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Yankees center fielder Jacoby Ellsbury said Thursday that the mild oblique strain that had sidelined him since Sunday would not prevent him from being in the lineup on opening day, which is less than three weeks away.

title: Treating Exotic Pets
description: Correction appended below.

title: A Hulking New Mexico State Front Line Prepares to Face Kansas
description: OMAHA  New Mexico State center Tshilidzi Nephawe stands 6 feet 10 inches with an intimidating natural scowl that belies an engaging manner. Nephawe, a South African, anchors a hulking front line for the No. 15-seeded Aggies (23-10), the Western Athletic Conference champions who often dominate teams inside.

title: Northern Iowa and Wyoming Share a Familial Connection
description: SEATTLE  If you put a couple dozen people in a room together, there are good odds two of those people will share a birthday.

title: ASAP Yamss Cause of Death: Accidental Drug Intoxication
description: ASAP Yams, the hip-hop executive and co-owner of the ASAP Worldwide record label, died of an acute mixed drug intoxication (including opiates and benzodiazepine), a spokeswoman for New York Citys chief medical examiner said on Thursday in an email. The death was ruled an accident.

title: St. Johns Will Be Short-Handed Against San Diego State
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Having made the N.C.A.A. tournament for only the second time in Coach Steve Lavins five-year tenure, and only the second time since 2002, No. 9-seeded St. Johns will be short-handed in its South Region game against San Diego State (26-8), the No. 8 seed, Friday in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Arkansas Avoids the No. 5 Jinx by Edging Wofford
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Few teams cherish having a No. 5 seed, a position that seems cursed with upsets against opponents with nothing to lose. So Arkansas was in a tough spot Thursday night as it tried to fend off the 12th-seeded Wofford Terriers, who were looking for their first N.C.A.A. tournament victory in four appearances.

title: Watch a Total Solar Eclipse Without Venturing to a Remote Island
description: By a lucky coincidence, the moon and the sun appear to be almost the same size, each subtending about half a degree of arc in diameter. As a result, the endless and repetitive wobbly dance of the worlds causes the moon to pass directly in front of the sun every year or two, sometimes hiding it completely in a total solar eclipse.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 11 P.M. (Pop) THE DESCENDANTS (2011) Matt King (George Clooney, in an Oscar-nominated role), whose ancestors include the earliest white settlers in Hawaii, struggles to make the right decision about his familys birthright, a pristine tract on Kauai  should it be sold to developers?  while his wife, Elizabeth (Patricia Hastie), lies in a coma after a boating accident. Not long after Matt learns he is about to become a widower and a single father to unruly daughters, Scottie (Amara Miller) and Alex (Shailene Woodley), he discovers that his wife had an affair. And Elizabeths father (Robert Forster) blames Matt for his daughters condition. The director Alexander Payne, with a light touch and a keen sense of place  this Hawaii is as real and peculiar as the Nebraska of About Schmidt or the California wine country of Sideways  has made a movie that, for all its modesty, is as big as life, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Its heart is occupied by grief, pain and the haunting silence of Elizabeth, whose version of events is the only one we never hear. And yet it is also full of warmth, humor and the kind of grace that can result from our clumsy attempts to make things better.

title: Against Kentucky, Hampton Keeps It Close, for 12 Minutes
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  There was drama here for 12 minutes. No. 1 Kentucky led 16th-seeded Hampton, 18-14, with 8 minutes 27 seconds left in the first half, and John Calipari, the Kentucky coach, fumed at his players from the bench for misdeeds in execution.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Mar. 19
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of a public art sculpture in Queens, the St. Patricks Day parade and a comedian named Des Bishop.

title: Midmajor Upsets Are Just Part of the Tournament
description: SEATTLE  On Thursday afternoon at KeyArena, several Northern Iowa players gathered around a smartphone in a locker room to watch the end of the Baylor-Georgia State game. The tension built as the time passed and Georgia State mounted an improbable rally.

title: Mets Dillon Gee Looks Solid in Start; Daniel Murphy Tweaks Hamstring
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  On a day when the Mets looked to plug one hole, moving Dillon Gee from the bullpen to the rotation, another leak emerged, albeit not one as major as losing starting pitcher Zack Wheeler to season-ending Tommy John surgery.

title: SXSW Music 2015: A Surprise Appearance From Miley Cyrus
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The biggest buzz around town on Thursday, as the South by Southwest music mayhem hit its stride, was not about a breakout band from Brooklyn or Sweden, nor was it focused on the previous nights exclusive Iggy Azalea set for Samsung. Instead, the increasingly loud whispers around Austin came straight from trending topics for 2013: Miley Cyrus was rumored to be making an appearance.

title: Georgetown Finally Lives Up to Its Seeding and Outmuscles Eastern Washington
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Having built an unwanted reputation in recent years for losing to teams seeded far lower than itself, No. 4 Georgetown dominated No. 13 Eastern Washington, 84-74, on Thursday in the N.C.A.A. tournaments round of 64.

title: European Leaders Urge Greece to Accelerate Overhaul Efforts
description: BRUSSELS  With Greece rapidly running out of money and again teetering on the edge of default, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany stood firm early Friday against pleading by the Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, and prodded him to speed up efforts to overhaul his countrys gasping economy in return for cash.

title: Rosetta Follows a Comet Through Perihelion
description: The Rosetta spacecraft is following Comet 67P/C-G as it makes its closest approach to the sun.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I personally think we are just not smart enough  and wont be for a very long time  to feel comfortable about the consequences of changing heredity, even in a single individual.

title: Corrections: March 20, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Anti-Semitism in Hungary
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping the Victims in Syria and Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Leniency for General Petraeus: His Lawyers Argument
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding This Lost City in Honduras Was the Easy Part
description: RIGHT now, in the jungle some 50 miles inland from the Mosquito Coast of Honduras, sits an astounding cache of ancient artifacts, until this month most likely unseen by human eyes for somewhere between 600 and 1,000 years. I traveled there three weeks ago with a team of archaeologists, anthropologists, ethnobotanists, filmmakers and Honduran soldiers, who were following up on lidar images  a laser-based aerial surveillance technology  that suggested the presence of ruins.

title: The Zero-Sum Moment
description: National elections take place within a specific global moment. In the 1990s, there was a presumption that we were living in an age of rapid progress. Democracy was spreading. Tyranny was receding. Asia was booming. The European Union was building. Conflict in the Middle East was lessening. The world was cumulatively heading toward greater pluralism, individualism, prosperity and freedom.

title: Trillion Dollar Fraudsters
description: By now its a Republican Party tradition: Every year the party produces a budget that allegedly slashes deficits, but which turns out to contain a trillion-dollar magic asterisk  a line that promises huge spending cuts and/or revenue increases, but without explaining where the money is supposed to come from.

title: The Case for Free-Range Parenting
description: BETHESDA, Md.  ON her first morning in America, last summer, my daughter went out to explore her new neighborhood  alone, without even telling my wife or me.

title: Our Federal Policy on the Use of Ethanol
The Schneiderman Remedy for Sleaze
description: Calling for an end to a golden age of graft in Albany, Attorney General Eric Schneiderman of New York laid out a series of adventurous ethics proposals in a speech to Citizens Union on Monday. Though in some cases his ideas will need further exploration and debate, they represent a challenge to Gov. Andrew Cuomos promised reforms.

title: U.S. Allies, Lured by Chinas Bank
description: The Obama administration, to its embarrassment, has been spurned by Western allies flocking to a China-led Asian development bank, defying White House pleas to stand back. In a surprise announcement last week, Britain said it would become the first Western nation to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, a potential rival to the American-led World Bank.

title: Test Yourself | Wake Up and Dance
description: Here are several paragraphs from a March 13 article, The Rise of Early-Morning Dance Parties.

title: The Metro Areas With the Largest, and Smallest, Gay Populations
description: The Census Bureau asks Americans about subjects as varied as race, age, annual income and even their source of home heating. But there is one glaring demographic omission: The census does not ask people about their sexual orientation. As a result, there has long been a shroud of uncertainty around the geography of gay and lesbian Americans.

title: Hackers Attack GreatFire.org, a Workaround for Websites Censored in China
description: For years, a group of anonymous activists known as GreatFire.org has monitored online censorship in China, provided access to blocked websites and collected messages deleted by censors.

title: The Salt of the Earth Presents a Photographers Life and Lens, in Focus
description: The German film director Wim Wenders was walking down La Brea Avenue in Los Angeles one day in the mid-1980s when out of the corner of his eye he caught sight of some startling photographs in the window of a gallery. Intrigued, he immediately entered, learned that the photographer was a Brazilian named Sebastio Salgado, and emerged an hour later the owner of a pair of prints  one from Mr. Salgados now-celebrated Serra Pelada series from a gold mine in the Amazon, the other from the Sahel in Africa  that continue to this day to hang over the directors desk in his Berlin office.

title: 6 Qs About the News | The Next Frontier: The Great Indoors
description: In The Next Frontier: The Great Indoors, Carl Zimmer writes about scientific interest in the indoor biome.

title: Adam Horovitz, a Beastie Boy in Middle Age
description: Longtime fans of the Beastie Boys could be forgiven for imagining that the rappers would be perennially young, forever New Yorks impish hometown heroes, ollieing past authority on their way to after-hours fun.

title: Amour by the Seine and the Nevada Desert
description: Abandoned yet nearly perfect, Jean Renoirs A Day in the Country (1936) is a movie whose incomplete aspects only accentuate its freshness and spontaneity.

title: Cement Giants Holcim and Lafarge Say Merger Is Back on Track
description: PARIS  Holcim and Lafarge, the two European cement giants, have broken a deadlock that threatened their merger plans, they said on Friday, expressing confidence that they would close the $46 billion deal this summer.

title: At Least 32 Killed After Express Train Strikes Barrier in Northern India
description: NEW DELHI  An express train hit a safety barrier at a railway station in northern India on Friday morning, killing at least 32 people and injuring dozens more after two coach cars and the engine derailed, the authorities said.

title: After the Kodak Moment
description: Kodak has prioritized its patent portfolio and the Eastman Business Park since it declared bankruptcy in 2012. Despite some success, the company might never live up to the legacy of its own past.

title: Brazils Slumping Economy and Bribery Scandal Eat Away at Dilma Rousseffs Popularity
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  President Dilma Rousseff ran for office declaring that she would harness an oil bonanza in Brazil to supercharge the economy while avoiding the corruption and mismanagement that have plagued other oil-rich countries in the developing world.

title: Mitch McConnell Makes Changes, but Senate Gridlock Remains
description: WASHINGTON  When he became majority leader, propelled by sweeping Republican victories last year, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky vowed to run a more productive and traditional Senate than his Democratic predecessor, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada.

title: Nigerian Army Noticeably Absent in Town Taken From Boko Haram
description: DAMASAK, Nigeria  Boko Harams black flag is everywhere in the town of Damasak, deep in Islamist-held territory in northern Nigeria: It is painted on former administrative buildings and schools, and on the side of abandoned gas stations.

title: What Woman Would You Want to See on the $20 Bill?
description: The year 2020 is the 100th anniversary of women gaining the right to vote in the United States, and a campaign has started to put a womans face on paper money  to replace Andrew Jackson on the $20 bill.

title: Refusing to Give Up on Kodak
description: What happens after a tech company is left for dead but the people left behind refuse to give up? At Kodak the answer is to dig into its legacy of innovation.

title: At Kodak, Clinging to a Future Beyond Film
description: Of the roughly 200 buildings that once stood on the 1,300-acre campus of Eastman Kodaks business park in Rochester, 80 have been demolished and 59 others sold off. Terry Taber, bespectacled, 60, and a loyal Kodak employee of 34 years, still works in one of the remaining Kodak structures, rubble from demolition not far from its doors.

title: TSB to Recommend That Investors Accept Spanish Banks Takeover Offer
description: LONDON  TSB Banking Group, the lender spun out of the Lloyds Banking Group last year, said on Friday that its directors had agreed to recommend that investors accept a takeover offer from Banco Sabadell of Spain that values it at 1.7 billion pounds, or about $2.5 billion.

title: Biogen Reports Its Alzheimers Drug Sharply Slowed Cognitive Decline
description: An experimental drug for Alzheimers disease sharply slowed the decline in mental function in a small clinical trial, researchers reported Friday, reviving hopes for an approach to therapy that until now has experienced repeated failures.

title: Ask Well: Whiter Teeth
description: Question:

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get the Morning Briefing in your inbox first thing? Sign up.)

title: Q. and A.: Chang-rae Lee on His Tale of Migrants From an Environmentally Ruined China
description: Starting with his first novel, Native Speaker, the Korean-American author Chang-rae Lee has written of immigrant experiences in the United States. His latest novel, On Such a Full Sea, centers on a Chinese woman named Fan who is a laborer in a city called B-Mor, a future version of Baltimore. The novel is a dystopian tale, set in an era when nations around the world are suffering from overwhelming environmental degradation. Fan is one of tens of thousands of Chinese from smog-choked Shanxi Province who have taken jobs as food production workers in B-Mor to escape their toxic homeland.

title: New York Today: Unbeloved Sculptures
description: Good morning on this final winter Friday.

title: Gay America
description: A new analysis offers the most detailed estimates yet about where people who identify as gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender live.

title: Foreign Liberators Control the Streets of Damasak
description: Soldiers from Chad and Niger liberated Damasak from Boko Haram this week after a fierce firefight, and were surprised by the absence of the Nigerian Army.

title: Europeans (Carefully) Gaze Upward for Glimpse of the Solar Eclipse
description: PARIS  Crowds across Europe gazed skyward on Friday to witness a solar eclipse, one where the moon came between the earth and the sun and its shadow blocked the sun in its entirety at some viewing points.

title: Outgoing Credit Suisse C.E.O. Took Slight Pay Cut in 2014
description: LONDON  Brady W. Dougan, the outgoing chief executive of Credit Suisse, took a slight pay cut in 2014 as the Swiss bank faced what it described as a challenging macroeconomic environment and saw its annual results hurt by legacy legal issues.

title: Traitors to Their Class
description: You probably know from his weepy reminiscences that the speaker of the House, John Boehner, once worked as a bartender and a janitor, and took seven years to get out of college. Maybe youve heard that Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin is a preachers son who churned out burgers and fries at McDonalds. And you had to catch that bit from Senator Joni Ernst about putting bread bags over her shoes while growing up kind of poor in rural Iowa.

title: 11 Books About Obsessive Searches
description: As the author of Turn Right at Machu Picchu, about a trek to find the lost city of the Incas along a relatively unknown route, and Meet Me in Atlantis, about amateur explorers passionate attempts to locate the sunken island metropolis, Im intimately familiar with travel books that might be categorized as obsessive quests. My favorites are those written by authors who undertake adventures of their own. Here is a selection.

title: Tranquil, Sandy Refuges From Bustling Santiago
description: The 35-story-tall sand dunes of Concn are grand formations that took shape over millions of years, growing into seemingly insurmountable mounds that draw thrill-seeking sand-boarders and lumbering climbers alike.

title: My Quest for Atlantis
description: Theres nothing like a vigorous sea-to-summit hike up the Rock of Gibraltar to clear the jet-lagged mind, especially when youre trying to solve a nearly 2,500-year-old mystery. Following the zigzagging lines on the colorful paper place mat Id been handed at the Gibraltar welcome center when Id asked for a map, I climbed a steep set of concrete and stone stairs high into the green solitude of the Upper Rock Nature Preserve. As the path cut through a thick tangle of scrub, the southern coast of Spain appeared to the west, far below. A little farther on, the view widened to take in the cinched waist of the Strait of Gibraltar. A few steps later, the northern shore of Africa emerged through the last of the mornings light mist.

title: Casino Dream
description: Two months ago, my brother asked me if I remembered playing with our father when we were children. I dont. I remember that my father left the house early in the morning and came back in the evening, late. He always brought some chocolate for me and always put it in the same place, the kitchen cabinet. He was the kind part of the family, with a low voice. I saw him as the calm of the evening. But memories change the facts.

title: Binoculars
description: A flicker is a type of woodpecker, but here the poet captures the words multiple meanings: the actual bird, wavering light and, most profoundly, how the past returns again and again, as a momentary confrontation with the things memory and self-reflection  that telescopic, magnifying lens  will not let us forget.Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

title: Re: Is Most of Our DNA Garbage?
description: Is there garbage in our genome? Carl Zimmers March 8 article about the debate in the scientific community over junk DNA sparked a conversation that spread to the blogs of half a dozen scientists.

title: Recycling Unused Medicines to Save Money and Lives
description: It always troubled Deane Kirchner to throw away good medicine. When residents of the Lincoln Glen long-term facility in San Jose, Calif., where she is the director of nursing, changed dosages, had adverse reactions, or died, she did what health professionals regularly do: sent their unused medicines to be destroyed.

title: How to Negotiate a Prenup
description: Sometimes in the thick of a messy and awkward prenuptial agreement negotiation, Laura A. Wasser, a Los Angeles-based family lawyer, reminds her clients: This is not someone you got into a fender bender with. This is someone you want to spend your life with. So be nice, for starters. Wasser pushes clients to sign all the paperwork at least a month before the wedding, but she suggests broaching the subject much earlier. Sit down to talk with a good bottle of wine, but dont drink so much that you end up drunk and fighting, she says. Bring it up when things are good, not when youre bickering.

title: Daily Report: F.A.A. Gives Amazon Limited Permission on Drones
description: Federal regulators have given Amazon a green light to begin testing drones, but it will most likely take years before the online retailer can start delivering packages from the air to peoples homes, writes Nick Wingfield.

title: Morning Agenda: Bank of New York Mellon in Settlement
description: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON IN SETTLEMENT | Federal and state authorities announced on Thursday that the Bank of New York Mellon would pay $714 million to settle accusations that it cheated government pension funds and other investors for more than a decade, DealBooks Ben Protess reports. The settlement is part of a broader deal requiring the bank to dismiss some employees and overhaul its foreign exchange operation.

title: Today in Politics: With Talk of Building Ties, Clinton Draws Subtle Contrast With Obama
description: Good Friday morning from Washington, where the National Cherry Blossom Festival officially begins despite a forecast of flurries. Congress is busy finding creative new ways to approve spending without voting, and theres a very good chance a potential presidential candidate is streaming live video right now on an app called Meerkat. If that sounds too Back to the Future for you, at least one person who might like to move back to the White House is yearning for the good old days of bipartisanship.

title: No Child Left Behind Law Faces Its Own Reckoning
description: CLEVELAND  Ginn Academy, the first and only public high school in Ohio just for boys, was conceived to help at-risk students make it through school  experimenting with small classes, a tough discipline code and life coaches around the clock.

title: HSBC to Shuffle Board Roles of Several Directors
description: LONDON  The British bank HSBC said on Friday that it planned to shuffle the roles of several members of its board of directors.

title: For Europe, a Rare Glimpse at a Total Solar Eclipse
description: Fridays event offered some Europeans a look at an unusual marvel.

title: Whats On This Week Around The World
description: Frankfurt

title: Video Reviews of The Gunman, Insurgent and Backcountry
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on The Gunman, The Divergent Series: Insurgent and Backcountry. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Europe Is Treated to a Solar Eclipse
description: People in parts of Europe and other areas of the world lucky enough to have clear weather on Friday enjoyed spectacular views of the solar eclipse.

title: NYTLNreads | Being 12
description: Last week, as part of a collaboration with our friends at WNYC, we asked students to tell us what they remembered best about being 12.

title: Suicide Attacks at Mosques in Yemen Kill More Than 130
description: SANA, Yemen  An affiliate of the Islamic State that had not previously carried out any major attacks claimed responsibility for coordinated suicide strikes on Zaydi Shiite mosques here that killed more than 130 people during Friday Prayer, bringing to Yemen the kind of deadly sectarian fighting that has ripped apart Syria and Iraq.

title: The Mysterious 3:30 A.M. Roof Parties
description: Dear Diary:

title: Simon Property Raises Offer for Mall Rival Macerich, a Reluctant Target
description: The Simon Property Group made what it called its best and final offer for a rival mall operator, the Macerich Company, on Friday, raising its unsolicited bid to $23.2 billion.

title: When the 13-Year-Old Picks a $14 Million Condo
description: A year and a half ago, Skye van Merkensteijn was shooting hoops with a friend who lives at the Aldyn, a condominium-rental hybrid on Riverside Boulevard with its own indoor basketball court, climbing wall and bowling alley.

title: An Online Sale Collects Rare Vintage Mens Accoutrements from Hermes, Cartier and More
description: This weekend, an online sale put together by the vintage impresario Alan Bedwell for the auction site Paddle8 proves its the accessories that separate the man from the gentleman. Bedwell, the founder of the vintage accessories brand Foundwell, pulled together a range of vintage and antique items  equally practical and whimsical  to outfit the proper bar, desk and dressing room. For drinks, theres an opulent sterling silver and crystal Champagne bottle from 1898, alongside a quirky 1960s Cartier flowerpot jigger. According to Bedwell, a beautiful letter opener should be a part of anyones desk, and the sale has several to offer, including an 1898 model bearing the brand DuPont Explosives and another created in 1970 by Herms in a comically extended dachshund shape. An equally lively pair of French agate hamburger cufflinks from the 70s are fun, but exquisitely crafted  each element was hand-cut, dyed and polished. The real standouts, though, act as conversation starters, like an 80s Asprey rubber-band gun and a silver-plated peanut dish from the 50s. You do stumble across these amazing crazy pieces every now and then, Bedwell says, and you just think, Wow, I cant believe somebody actually sat down and made that.'

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Militants Attack Police Station in India
description: NEW DELHI  Two heavily armed militants wearing Indian Army uniforms opened fire on a police station near the Pakistani border early Friday, killing three Indian security personnel and a civilian, officials said.

title: A London Loft Designed With a Nod to New York
description: When Eric Perlberg, a photographer, decided to retire and renovate his London apartment, he thought about the best attributes of places where he had lived throughout his life: SoHo and Woodstock in New York, and Basel, Switzerland.

title: Rolling With the Punches, at Any Stage of Life
description: OVER the last eight years, Teresa Mears has cycled through enough change to last a lifetime: a partners death, helping to care for a mother with Alzheimers, leaving a steady job just before the recession hit, and the loss of her house.

title: Cuomos Youngest Daughter, 17, Is Taken to the Hospital
description: The youngest daughter of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was taken to the hospital on Wednesday after being found unconscious at the Westchester County home of Mr. Cuomos ex-wife, Kerry Kennedy.

title: Solar Eclipse Videos Across the Globe
description: Time-lapse videos from space, above Svalbard, Norway, and over the Faroe Islands captured a solar eclipse early Friday morning.

title: John Boehner to Visit Israel at End of the Month
description: House Speaker John A. Boehner is set to visit Israel during the congressional vacation at the end of the month, his office said on Friday.

title: On Empire: The Show, the Music and the Calamitous Finale
description: Jon Caramanica and Gilbert Cruz, of The Times, and Justin Charity, of Complex, discuss Empire.

title: Topographic Tops
description: From Rick to Raf, designers take in the view.

title: Graco to Pay $10 Million for Delay in Recall of Defective Child Seats
description: Graco Childrens Products has agreed to pay $10 million to settle claims that it failed to recall promptly about four million child car seats with a defective buckle that could make it difficult to free a child in an emergency, federal regulators said on Friday.

title: Review: Joyce DiDonato Blends Bel Canto and Emotion at Carnegie Hall
description: Detractors of the bel canto style typically dislike it because, they argue, it is only that: beautiful singing. In the music of composers like Donizetti and Bellini the action stops and words take a back seat. All that matters, for the duration of an aria, is the glory of the human voice and its ability to dart up and down octaves while dashing off trills and other ornaments in a fizzy display of vocal pyrotechnics.

title: Latest Iran Talks End Without a Deal
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland  An intensive round of talks on limiting Irans nuclear program ended abruptly on Friday with the two sides still divided over some important issues.

title: What Else Can We Add to a Smoothie?
description: Over the years I have given you a number of Recipes for Health devoted to smoothies  fruit smoothies with nuts and seeds; smoothies with vegetables; dairy free smoothies. I thought I had pretty much covered all the smoothie bases. Then I came across a recipe for a Fresh Peach, Banana and Warm Millet Smoothie in Bryant Terrys impressive new cookbook Afro-Vegan, and a bell went off. Cooked millet in a smoothie? I had never seen such a thing; yet breakfast is a great meal for cooked grains, and also for smoothies. So why not? Adding cooked grains to smoothies would be a perfect way to thicken the drinks and bulk them up. Its also a delicious way to incorporate more grains into your diet.

title: After Backtracking on Trans-Atlantic Flights, Ryanair Learns Its Lessons
description: PARIS  In the little more than a year since Ryanair made a belated push into the digital age, the Irish budget airline has adopted an arsenal of tools aimed at improving communications with the flying public.

title: Rick Perry Disavows Aides Comments on Women in the White House
description: Former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas late Thursday disavowed an email sent four years ago bya newly hired senior adviser that suggested women are unfit for the presidency.

title: Caramoor Season to Offer Classical Music, Jazz and Belly Dancing
description: The pianist Hlne Grimaud; Wynton Marsalis and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra; a night of belly dancing; and several nights of bel canto  including a semi-staged production of Donizettis La Favorite  will all be featured this summer as Caramoor celebrates its 70th-anniversary season, the festival announced this week.

title: Aftermath of Mosque Bombings in Yemen
description: Residents combed through the rubble in Sana, Yemen, after two suicide bombers attacked the Badr mosque during Friday Prayer.

title: Finding Success, Well Past the Age of Wunderkind
description: AS a girl growing up in Jamaica, Queens, Lucille Gang Shulklapper dreamed of being a writer and having a househusband like Edna St. Vincent Millay.

title: A TriBeCa Townhouse for $24,500,000
description: A five-story penthouse atop a boutique condominium in TriBeCa known as the Munitions Building, which served as a warehouse during the 19th century for the Remington Arms Company and later stored Champagne bottles for the G. H. Mumm Company, sold for $24,500,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Catfish Farmers, Seeking Regulation to Fight Foreign Competition, Face Higher Bills
description: WASHINGTON  In 2008, faced with increased competition from Vietnam and China, catfish producers in the United States did the unthinkable: They asked for more regulation of their industry.

title: Winter Vegetables for Spring Holidays
description: Its that time of year again, on the East Coast at least, when spring is in the air but not in your shopping basket.

title: 1890: Hotel de Balzac Demolition
description: One of the landmarks of literary and historic Paris is now being removed. This is the hotel at the junction of the rue Berryer, rue de Balzac and rue du faubourg St. Honor, formerly the residence of Balzac, from whom it took the name Hotel de Balzac. The hotel proper, which stood in a garden hid from the street, has already been demolished, while the more recently erected structure on the street is shortly to have the same fate. Of this mansion, which with its carved stonework, ogival windows and massive, iron knobbed door, and finally its desolate appearance, rendered the feature of the upper part of the faubourg, only a small portion, containing carved woodwork of great value, will be left standing.  The New York Herald, European Edition, March 21, 1890

title: Thrift, by Andrew L. Yarrow
description: National Thrift Week, originally organized by the Y.M.C.A. in 1917, was the signature event of a nationwide moral crusade by elites to mold Americans behaviors. During seven days centered on Benjamin Franklins Jan.17 birthday, thrift advocates taught people how to open savings accounts, buy insurance, purchase homes, pay bills promptly and share with others. By the early 1920s, Thrift Week was observed by more than a thousand cities in the United States, and still more around the globe. Thrift was put forward as the antidote to many of the nations perceived ills: working-class radicalism, urban poverty, squandering of natural resources and excessive consumerism.

title: Spring Is Due at 6:45 P.M., With Snow
description: Go home.

title: Financial Advisers Seek to Inject a More Human Element
description: BREAK your financial life into chapters. Assign a high point, a low point and a turning point to each chapter. Whats the story and what stands out?

title: Paula Vogels Indecent Will Have Its Debut at Yale Rep
description: A new play with music by Pulitzer Prize winner Paula Vogel, about a controversial moment in Jewish cultural history, and two other world premieres by up-and-coming women playwrights will be part of Yale Repertory Theaters 2015-16 season.

title: Mortgage Amounts Rising More Quickly Than Home Prices
description: Mortgage amounts are rising more quickly than home prices, an unusual phenomenon that seems to confirm continued weakness at the lower end of the housing market, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association.

title: Breast Milk Becomes a Commodity, With Mothers Caught Up in Debate
description: CITY OF INDUSTRY, Calif.  When Gretty Amaya took an unpaid maternity leave five months ago, she started what she calls a part-time job to help pay the bills. Ms. Amaya, who lives in Miami, has made more than $2,000 so far by pumping breast milk and selling what is left over after feeding her baby daughter.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Opposite of Spoiled
description: This week, Ron Lieber discusses The Opposite of Spoiled; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Harris Irfan talks about Heavens Bankers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Judi Dench Joins Cast of Live Election-Night Play in Britain
description: LONDON  In the very moments that Britons cast their vote for the next Parliament, a Dame will flicker across the nations TV screens.

title: Afghan Leader Said to Be Centralizing Power as Unity Government Plan Stalls
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Through a tumultuous first six months as president of Afghanistan, Ashraf Ghani has been living up to his promises to transform the office. But rather than decentralizing the posts powers, as he had vowed, he has instead been quietly creating an even more dominant presidency, according to a range of current and former Afghan officials.

title: Heavens Bankers, by Harris Irfan
description: Tell non-Muslims or people who work outside the financial industry that you write about Islamic finance, and you will almost certainly receive one of two reactions (not including blank stares). The first  in which people assume Islamic finance is synonymous with or inherently linked to the bankrolling of terrorism  is both the most depressing and the most easily dismissed, because it is untrue. People slightly more familiar with Islam might have some notion that Islamic finance entails interest-free banking, but beyond that things get murky pretty quickly.

title: The Seventh Day, by Yu Hua
description: In Yu Huas surreal, mordant novel The Seventh Day, the victims of Chinas explosively expanding market economy include the still conscious, still suffering, still impoverished dead. They cant afford burial plots. Theyve been separated from their families and uprooted from their ancestral homes. Unable to be mourned in the proper Chinese way, theyre fated to roam a hazy, indistinct city where snow swirls around their legs and they have the opportunity to reflect upon their lives and the circumstances of their deaths. The limping shades may then encounter the dead former friends and loved ones who also inhabit this characteristically Chinese mega-necropolis.

title: The Way We Read Now
description: This week, the Book Review looks at the ways we make, spend and obsess over money in its second annual Money Issue.

title: Take the Money and Run
description: The career criminals in genre novels dont have money problems. If they need some, they just go out and steal it. But such financial transactions can backfire, which is what happened back in 2004 when the Texas gang in Michael Robothams LIFE OR DEATH (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $26) robbed $7 million from an armored truck. That ill-fated enterprise ended with four people dead. One robber was shot and captured alive, but the surviving gang member was never seen again and the money was never recovered.

title: The Opposite of Spoiled, by Ron Lieber
description: Im one of those people who are overcome with a strange combination of discomfort and ennui whenever they think about their children and money. Each time my husband brings up the topic of allowance, I wriggle out of the conversation, all but la la la-ing with my hands over my ears. Now I find Im not alone. In his new book, The Opposite of Spoiled, Ron Lieber suggests that our unease about money prevents us from raising fiscally responsible kids. Open dialogue, he suggests, is the answer. Ask your children questions; listen to their answers. So I tried it. My husband and I waylaid our 16-year-old daughter, Lucy, as she headed out the door. How much do you think we earn every year? we asked. Lucy, whos a pretty smart, sophisticated kid, replied after a moments thought: Maybe around $10,000? I dont need to have an open dialogue with you, dear reader, but I will confess thats not quite our income. I began to see how in the dark I have kept my children about our finances.

title: The Great Beanie Baby Bubble, by Zac Bissonnette
description: Beanie Babies, the small stuffed animals that retailed for $5, were introduced in 1993 and soon languished with mediocre sales. Then, a handful of neighbors in the Chicago suburbs discovered that each had a small collection and started trading with one another. They established some informal rules: Two Tabasco the Bull Beanies were equivalent to one of the rarer Kiwi the Toucan Beanies. Their trading spread and, eventually, went national. There were articles and TV segments about moms and dads who traded a $5 toy for thousands of dollars. Peggy Gallagher, an early trader, discovered that the Beanie craze hadnt hit Germany yet and placed an order with a distributor in Nuremberg. She paid $2,000, including shipping, for a box of the toys that, back in the United States, had a value of $300,000, a return of nearly 15,000 percent. If she were a hedge fund trader with those numbers, shed be the talk of Wall Street for generations. Instead, she was the talk of countless parents, who came to believe they, too, could fund their kids college education or an early retirement if they just got their hands on the right Beanies. The frenzy coincided with the start of eBay and the rise of home Internet use. Early on, Beanie Babies represented 10 percent of eBays sales.

title: Filthy Lucre
description: SWEETLAND

title: Editors Choice
description: THE LAST FLIGHT OF POXL WEST, by Daniel Torday. (St. Martins, $25.99.) A World War II memoir by Tordays protagonist, a Jewish bomber pilot with the British Royal Air Force, is this utterly accomplished first novels book-within-a-book.

title: The Monopolists, by Mary Pilon
description: The national card game of the worlds first market democracy naturally turned out to be poker, in part because money is its language, raison dtre and means of keeping score. Our favorite board game, of course, is Monopoly, which has also gone global, and for similar reasons. Played by everyone from Jerry Hall and Mick Jagger to Carmela and Tony Soprano, it apparently scratches an itch to wheel and deal few of us can reach in real life. The game is sufficiently redolent of capitalism that in 1959 Fidel Castro ordered the destruction of every Monopoly set in Cuba, while these days Vladimir Putin seems to be its ultimate aficionado.

title: Karen E. Benders Refund
description: Money is ostensibly the fuel that powers Karen E. Benders new collection, Refund. In the title story, a couple falsely advertises a TriBeCa sublet just before 9/11 to pay for a fancy nursery school. In Reunion, a woman impulsively buys an unseen plot of land on credit. Smaller risks prove to be, if not turning points, then those moments remembered in relief as emblematic of the Before  splurging on beef Wellington for supper, say, or setting up a kids lemonade stand  by those now living in the After. The theme works as an organizing tenet, but Benders subtler preoccupation is the eroding effect of emotional want.

title: Paperback Row
description: MY PROMISED LAND: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel, by Ari Shavit. (Spiegel & Grau, $17.) Drawing on historical documents, interviews and private diaries and letters  as well as his own familys story  Shavit, a columnist for Haaretz, examines the entirety of the Israeli experience, expressing both solidarity with and criticism of his countrymen. Shavits book is an extended test of his own capacity to maintain his principles in full view of the brutality that surrounds them, Leon Wieseltier wrote here.

title: Wake Up Happy Every Day, by Stephen May
description: Theres a reason many readers will forgive the comic novel a clunky narrative structure or uneven pacing; a reason theyll forgive a predisposition to tangents, tics or lack of emotional depth. The reason is simple  because funny is hard, both to execute and to resist.

title: The Looting Machine, by Tom Burgis
description: Back in the Mobutu era, I worked as a stringer in Kinshasa, the capital of what was then Zaire. So, what do they want? my driver Pierre would ask whenever I exited a Western embassy after a chat with a diplomat. Whats the plan? His question captured the sense of powerlessness that pervaded the country, a product of Big Man rule, Cold War interference and brutal colonial experience. If there was something of which Pierre felt certain, it was that he was not master of his fate.

title: Coined, by Kabir Sehgal
description: Nothing had an effect on people like money, recalled a Stanford neuroscientist who once experimented with scanning peoples brain activity while they played high-stakes financial games. Not naked bodies, not corpses. It got people riled up. Like food provides motivation for dogs, money provides it for people.

title: Gods Bankers, by Gerald Posner
description: Ask a devout, theologically literate Roman Catholic to describe the institution of the church, and youre likely to be told that it was founded by Jesus Christ at the moment he gave his disciple Peter the keys to the kingdom of heaven and vowed that whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven. This made Peter the head of the universal church, empowered to administer the sacraments, spread the Gospel, save souls and forgive sins until Christs return, as well as to pronounce with infallible authority on matters of Christian faith and morals. Christ also promised Peter that the gates of hell shall not prevail against the church  meaning that no matter how corrupt the institution might appear at any given moment of history, it will never be so consumed by evil that it ceases to be capable of fulfilling its God-appointed tasks.

title: Inside the List
description: Snow and Mo: Dennis Lehanes new novel, World Gone By, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 8. Lehane remains closely identified with his native Boston, but this historical thriller  which continues a series about the fictional gangster Joe Coughlin  is set mostly in Florida and Cuba, while Lehane himself moved to Southern California a year and a half ago. He recently told The Hollywood Reporter that he was sorry to miss his hometowns record snowfall this winter. Bostonians, for better or worse, tend to like hard things, he said. You dont really feel like something is fully worthwhile unless its hard-earned. Its that sense of working-class pride, which, yeah, can be kind of annoying but can be really cool. So when I saw my friends emailing about getting the snow record, I thought, What a bunch of sick bastards, but I really dig it. Im jealous Im not there, in a way. Lehane added that his pleasure reading these days is confined to childrens books. The go-to guy is Mo Willems, he said. Anyone outside of the childrens world has no idea who Mo Willems is. I didnt. But anyone who has kids, he literally takes you from the very first book to all these great books Im reading with my 5-year-old. Hes the Dr. Seuss of our time.

title: On Empire': The Show, the Music and the Calamitous Finale
description: This week on Popcast: Reviewing the first season of Empire, which came to a calamitous end on Wednesday night with a two-hour episode that  spoiler alert  featured a murder, an attempted murder, an announced pregnancy and an arrest. The show has been renewed for a second season, and it will likely take the several months before it returns to process all that happened  Empire moves quickly, and does not stop for explanations.

title: Akademgorodok
description: Inside the nuclear-physics laboratories in Akademgorodok, Siberias education capital.

title: What I Love | Megan Fairchild and Andrew Veyette
description: The principal dancers with New York City Ballet live in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: New Federal Rules Are Set for Fracking
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday unveiled the nations first major federal regulations on hydraulic fracturing, a technique for oil and gas drilling that has led to a significant increase in American energy production but has also raised concerns about health and safety risks.

title: Why Is British Economic Discourse So Bad?
description: Still at SXSW, which accounts for lack of blog posts  I mean, seize the day and all that. Not much action this morning, except a discussion with Snoop Dogg, which Im not going to; but whenever I think about Mr. Dogg, I think about Alan Simpson. Which brings me to the subject of this post.

title: Tune In to The Times
description: The New York Times contributor Jessica Bennett appeared on NBCs Today show to discuss her exclusive interview with Monica Lewinsky.

title: Nick Cave Goes Straight to Fans With The Sick Bag Song
description: Nick Cave, the Australian-born poet, novelist, actor, composer and rock band frontman, has been known to cross-pollinate his various creative pursuits. His 2009 novel about a sex-addicted beauty product salesman, The Death of Bunny Munro, was available as an iPhone app that blended text with an audiobook narrated by Mr. Cave, set to music by one of his fellow band members. His book tour featured live music.

title: My Childhood Pet
description: Ten artists recall the special creatures that found their way into their young lives.

title: At Versailles, a Sumptuous Seven-Course Celebration of French Cuisine
description: The dinner celebrated Got de France, an international initiative to advance French gastronomy.

title: The Strange Beauty of Soviet-Era Nuclear Relics
description: Two years ago, the Russian government invited the Mexican photographer Pablo Ortiz Monasterio to come and photograph the country in advance of the Group of 20 summit meeting in Moscow. Ortiz Monasterio proposed a project on brilliant minds, documenting the people who work in the countrys space program or on nuclear submarines.

title: Playful Parting Gifts Show Heads Arent Inflated at the Fed
description: The Federal Reserve delivered a clever parting gift to a pair of retiring reserve bank presidents who have repeatedly warned it is heading down a path that may lead to dangerous inflation.

title: A New Documentary Shines a Light On the Artist Who Gave Shape to Eloise
description: Fantasy is probably the most important drive in my life, Hilary Knight says in Its Me, Hilary: The Man Who Drew Eloise, an HBO documentary that offers a unique view into the one-of-a-kind mind of the illustrator behind the Eloise books. Produced by Lena Dunham, whose friendship with Knight began through her love of Eloise, the six-year-old resident of the Plaza Hotel whose antics were featured in a series of childrens books first published in 1955, the film creates a portrait of a man whose life and art are completely intertwined. Over 35 minutes, it traces Knights childhood as the son of two illustrators, the creation of Eloise, his creative tussles with the Eloise writer Kay Thompson and a post-Eloise career thats included work for Vanity Fair, the publication of his own books and the illustration of posters for Broadway shows like Gypsy. Most compelling are the scenes of Hilary moving through his magically curated home, decorated with staged bird nests, an underwater-themed bathroom and countless pieces of his parents work, dressing up in a full gorilla suit or directing a short musical film in his backyard.

title: Stuff We Liked
description: We spotted many wonderful things around the web this week.

title: Were Frighteningly in the Dark About Student Debt
description: Imagine that a big, complicated company holds a huge portfolio of loans, many of which are in default or delinquency. The companys leadership and some vocal shareholders demand a detailed review but receive a thin and incomplete report from the loan division.

title: Netanyahu's History on Palestinian Statehood
description: On the eve of the recent Israeli election, the prime minister said that no Palestinian state would be created on his watch. Two days later, he began to backtrack.

title: Too Old to Commit Crime?
description: DZHOKHAR TSARNAEV is facing the death penalty or life in prison for the Boston Marathon bombing. But what if, instead, the maximum prison sentence were just 21 years?

title: Netanyahu Tactics Anger Many U.S. Jews, Deepening a Divide
description: Long before the latest election in Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu was a polarizing figure among American Jews. But even many of his supporters said this week that they were appalled at his last-minute bid to mobilize Jewish voters by warning that Arabs were going to the polls in droves, and his renunciation of a two-state solution to the Palestinian crisis.

title: Megan Fairchild, Ballet Dancer, at Home in Westchester
description: Just so there are no misunderstandings, Megan Fairchild, a principal dancer with New York City Ballet, is thrilled about making her Broadway debut in the acclaimed revival of the 1944 musical On the Town. She loves playing the would-be actress Ivy Smith, a.k.a. Miss Turnstiles; she loves her cast mates, loves adding a different sort of role to her extensive rsum.

title: 5 Babies Found Dead in French Village
description: PARIS  The bodies of five babies, including four hidden in a freezer, were discovered in a house in southern France after a man told the police he had found the corpse of a baby in a cooler bag in his home, a senior police official said Friday.

title: Azzedine Alaas Collection
description: During four mini-shows that culminated just after Paris Fashion Week, Azzedine Alaa presented pieces that demanded an intimate viewing.

title: At Alaa, Clothes That Are Ready for Their Close-Ups
description: Paris Fashion Week officially ended on March 11, but for fashion insiders it lasted until last Monday  the final day of Azzedine Alaas series of four minishows. Though they took place off-schedule  Mr. Alaa has his own time clock, and holds presentations when, and if, a collection is ready; never before  they were, for those who got to see them, entirely on point.

title: French Court Orders Picassos Electrician to Return Nearly 300 Artworks
description: PARIS  A court in the town of Grasse in southern Franceon Fridayfound a retired electrician and his wife guilty of possessing 271 stolen works by Pablo Picasso, rejecting the couples claims that the trove of art was a gift from the artists wife.

title: Letter From the Editor: Illuminating Gay America
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Opposite of Spoiled
description: This week, Ron Lieber and Harris Irfan.

title: 1915: Zeppelins Attack Paris
description: It was announced early this morning [March 21] that, despite the measures taken to guard against a Zeppelin raid over Paris, two of these German dirigibles succeeded in reaching the capital soon after midnight. Two incendiary bombs were dropped in the rue Dulong and the rue des Dames, in the Batignolles quarter, but they did not cause any fire. A fire broke out, however, in a house in the rue Chauveau, at Neuilly, just outside of Paris, and this is believed to be due to another incendiary bomb.

title: Richard Fisher, Often Wrong but Seldom Boring, Leaves the Fed
description: DALLAS  In a decade as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, Richard W. Fisher was frequently mistaken in his economic predictions but seldom boring.

title: Guardian Names Katharine Viner as Editor
description: The Guardian appointed its first female editor on Friday, giving Katharine Viner, the current editor in chief of The Guardians United States operation, the job of leading the liberal British newspaper and media group as it seeks to expand its global ambitions.

title: Gone Spearfishin
description: The sturgeon spearfishing season at Lake Winnebago, the largest lake in Wisconsin, attracts ice fishermen to the lake and relatives and neighbors to the check-ins.

title: Sturgeon and the Spear
description: It had been four years since Steve Krueger speared a sturgeon, but the outlook in his shanty was brighter this year. In the first four days of the 2015 Winnebago lake system spearing season in Wisconsin, his friends and family caught and registered three.

title: A TV Version of the Noahs Ark Story That Chooses Restraint Over Rain
description: The UP channel, expanding its efforts to grab some of the family-and-faith market, acquits itself pretty well Sunday night with Noahs Ark, a film treatment of the religious story that relies on restraint and credible performances rather than literal and figurative thunder and lightning. Not a drop of precipitation falls until the final 10 minutes in this version of the oft-told tale; the focus is on a mans personal ordeal rather than Gods rainy wrath.

title: European Lawmaker Pushes Europe to Take Stronger Stance on Google
description: An outspoken European critic of Google said Friday that European Union antitrust regulators should bring formal charges against Google, after new documents showed that a report had recommended an American agency take a similar step three years ago.

title: Book Review Podcast: Teaching Kids About Money
description: In this weeks special Money Issue of The New York Times Book Review, Claire Dederer reviews Ron Liebers The Opposite of Spoiled. Ms. Dederer writes:

title: Miami Beach Celebrates Its Centennial
description: Incorporated in 1915, the city of Miami Beach will celebrate its 100th anniversary in fitting style, with a beach party.

title: After a Sleepover With Mayor de Blasio, a Friendship Formed
description: The overnight guest had brought a pie. Apple, the host recalled. It went untouched.

title: The Music, Revelry and Personalities of SXSW
description: The photographer Jackie Lee Young documents scenes from the South by Southwest festival.

title: Elton John vs. Dolce & Gabbana, Giseles Extreme Non-Retirement and Fashion Police Pulls Over
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Hillary Clinton Reaching Out to Catholics
description: In what could signal a coming pitch for the Catholic vote, Hillary Rodham Clinton met last week with Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York, and on Monday she sat near the Rev. John I. Jenkins, president of the University of Notre Dame, at a St. Patricks Day-themed luncheon.

title: Gene-Altered Apples and Potatoes Are Safe, F.D.A. Says
description: The Food and Drug Administration said on Friday that genetically engineered nonbrowning apples and bruise-resistant potatoes were as safe and nutritious as their conventional counterparts.

title: Off-Duty Officer Among 2 Killed in a Wrong-Way Crash on Staten Island
description: A car carrying three off-duty New Jersey police officers who had been at a Staten Island strip club hurtled the wrong way down an expressway early on Friday before colliding head-on with a tractor-trailer, killing one officer and another person in the car, the authorities said.

title: NBCs The Slap Finds Resonance in Park Slope, Brooklyn
description: One day last month, Louise Crawford, a 56-year-old with two grown children, was walking southward on Seventh Avenue in Brooklyn when a boy came hurtling toward her on a scooter at Nascar speed. This was already vividly contested space  Park Slope, where children on scooters have a long and menacing history and some people have practically called for legal interdiction. On this particular occasion, Ms. Crawford leapt out of the way, toward a Citibank, to avoid getting hit and in the moment, much to her surprise, found herself hurling a particularly non-PG expletive at her little would-be assailant. (The phrase she used began with, Get the, and ended with, off the street.)

title: A Scary Movie: Filling Your 401(k) With Company Stock
description: Weve seen the movie before, when employees of Enron and Lehman Brothers lost large sums of money in their 401(k) plans because of investments in company stock. And now, coming to a theater (and, inevitably, a courtroom) near you, is a sequel, surely not the last, this time featuring RadioShack.

title: Draft Joe Biden Group Urges Race Against Hillary Clinton
description: Amid Hillary Rodham Clintons email problems and Senator Elizabeth Warrens reluctance to run for president, the Draft Joe Biden movement is getting real.

title: Pirellis Largest Shareholder Is Said to Be in Talks With China National Chemical
description: LONDON  The holding company Camfin, the largest shareholder of the Italian tire maker Pirelli, is in talks to sell its stake in the company to China National Chemical Corporation in a deal that could pave the way for a full takeover of Pirelli, according to a person briefed on the discussions.

title: SXSW Music 2015: And Now for a Hiatus, at Willie Nelsons Ranch
description: LUCK, Tex.  I wanted a break from the music festival, so I went to a music festival. It was the Heartbreaker Banquet, held at Willie Nelsons ranch, a place called Luck, Tex., located in the dry, rolling scrubland of Spicewood, Tex. Its about 45 minutes northwest of Austin and a universe away from the frantic miscellany of SXSW. For me, it was a glimpse of the Austin I was introduced to in the early years of SXSW  one thats still there, as evidenced in the annual Austin Music Awards held on Wednesday night, but a local flavor that gets inundated during SXSW with newer, flashier events.

title: Turning Off the Android Texting Nanny
Merkel Warns That Greece Will Receive Aid Only if Reforms Are Met
description: PARIS  With Greece rapidly running out of money and again teetering on the edge of default, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said Friday that the Greeks would receive a desperately needed financial aid payment only after creditors approved a package of reform measures that the Greek government has promised to send them soon.

title: The Movie White God Unleashes a Cast of Hundreds
description: At the start of the drama White God, a girl in a hoodie is biking through the eerily deserted streets of Budapest. Then, in slow motion, as a sweeping score fills the soundtrack, a large group of dogs comes running after her. Not 10, not 25, but more than 200. The scene is devoid of digital imagery. These dogs are real. Large, small, furry or short-haired, and all very determined, racing toward the camera en masse. Its an astonishing sequence revisited in greater detail later, and it sets up a moment when subjugated animals rise up against their oppressors, fighting back, taking over and leaving audiences in awe.

title: Outsider Artist Gets Stamp of Approval
description: The United States Postal Service plans to issue five commemorative forever stamps on March 26 honoring the outsider artist Martn Ramrez, each with an image taken from one of his works.

title: Kansas Rolls Past New Mexico State
description: OMAHA  New Mexico States tall front line and extended zone defense were supposed to pose matchup problems for Kansas, the No. 2 seed in the Midwest Region of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament. Instead, the Jayhawks found open shots everywhere, especially behind the arc, and repeatedly beat the slow-to-react Aggies down the floor to win easily, 75-56.

title: Abiding Rifts Within Israel Threaten to Widen With Netanyahu Win
description: SDEROT, Israel  Stores in the rundown center of Sderot, a working-class Israeli border town plagued by years of rocket fire from Gaza, were still festooned with blue-and-white Likud banners at the end of this week.

title: SXSW Music 2015: All Rise (Too) Early for Snoop Dogg
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  With parties and performances lasting well into the early morning hours all week, the music portion of the South by Southwest Conference was certainly asking something of its attendees by scheduling this years music keynote address, a Q. & A. with the incomparable Snoop Dogg, for 11 a.m. on Friday. This is not a place for morning people.

title: White House Antagonism Toward Netanyahu Grows
description: WASHINGTON  The White House is stepping up its antagonism toward Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu despite his victory in this weeks elections, signaling that it is in no rush to repair a historic rift between the United States and Israel.

title: Parades of Might
description: Lavish pageants of military hardware and marchers in formation.

title: House Benghazi Committee Requests Hillary Clinton Email Server
description: The Congressional committee investigating the Benghazi attacks formally requested on Friday that Hillary Rodham Clinton turn over the email server that housed the personal account she exclusively used when she was secretary of state.

title: Despite Top Lawyers Fears, Regulators Can Be Held in Check
description: The Wall Street lawyer H. Rodgin Cohen hit a sour regulatory note this week. Mr. Cohen, Sullivan & Cromwells top bank advocate, thinks watchdogs have gone overboard to prove theyre not captured by the industry.

title: Can Washingtons Gift Economy in Marijuana Work?
description: It sounds like an idea a stoner might come up with.

title: Musicians Discuss the Influence of Pierre Boulez
description: Pierre Boulez, the distinguished composer, conductor, pianist and theorist, turns 90 on Thursday. Hes peerlessly influential, yes  but how, exactly? Six musicians explored the different facets of that influence in interviews; their replies have been condensed and edited.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties include a loft in Madison Square, a studio in the Gramercy area and a two-bedroom in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Michigan State Holds Off Georgia
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Reaching the N.C.A.A. tournament is enough of a rarity at Georgia that the Bulldogs celebrate each appearance on a banner that hangs in Stegeman Coliseum and lists every year they have made the field. The annual expectations at Michigan State, where the banners honor national championships and Final Four appearances, are just a tad higher.

title: Review: Piotr Anderszewski Goes for Dim Lights and Intimacy at Carnegie Hall
description: In Unquiet Traveler, a revealing 2008 documentary that follows the great pianist Piotr Anderszewski on a tour through his native Poland, this powerfully individual artist speaks of the extreme loneliness of a recital, of the heroism but also of the cruelty involved.

title: SXSW Music 2015: And Now, for a Horror  Make That Ho99o9  Show
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Every festival needs one all-out barrage, and I got mine on Thursday night from Ho99o9 (pronounced horror). Its a hip-hop group from Newark that blasts every way it can think of, which is plenty: Im an overload, one song truthfully announced.

title: An Illegal Boxing Club in the Bronx
description: Though unsanctioned, BX Fight Club aims to foster respect and redirect aggression among young men in the rougher sections of the Bronx.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks houses include a four-bedroom in Stamford, Conn., and a five-bedroom in Syosset, N.Y.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York Region:

title: Clinton Backers Say Criticizing Netanyahu  Can Wait
description: Some supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton, a longtime supporter of Israel, say she need not worry about excessive blowback from moderate Jewish supporters even if she were to join progressive Jews in criticizing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Lottery-Fueled Foundation Announces Second Theater Grant
description: The Roy Cockrum Foundation, established recently with part of the proceeds of a $153 million Powerball jackpot, has announced that its second grant will go to the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago, to support a production of Mary Page Marlowe, a new play by the Pulitzer Prize-winner Tracy Letts (August: Osage County).

title: A French Politician Who Has Helped Refine the National Front Party
description: ST.-MACAIRE-EN-MAGUES, France  Florian Philippot was about to take the stage in this small western village in the hope of lifting the fortunes of the local candidates of the far-right National Front party.

title: At Versailles, a Sumptuous Seven-Course Celebration of French Cuisine
description: When the French have a serious point to make, the countrys pull-out-all-the-stops invitation is to dinner at the Chteau de Versailles, the vast royal palace 14 miles from Paris that remains as awe-inspiring in the age of Instagram as it was when the oil paintings of French royals that crowd its walls were created centuries ago. The French foreign minister Laurent Fabius and the chef Alain Ducasse convened Pariss diplomatic community to a sumptuous seven-course dinner there last night to celebrate Got de France (rather infelicitously translated in the bilingual program as Good France), an international initiative intended to reestablish the reputation of the French culinary arts around the world.

title: Liberia Reports First Ebola Case in Weeks
description: A patient in Liberia has tested positive for the Ebola virus, health officials said Friday, more than two weeks after the last known case in the country had been discharged from the hospital.

title: An Underground Boxers Struggle
description: Chris Cunningham stood wearing a white apron behind the checkout counter at Schaller & Weber, a butcher shop on the Upper East Side, ringing up a mink-draped customer. Under the rim of his crisp paper cap, Mr. Cunninghams brow was visibly swollen, yet his smile was quick and generous  both products from the previous nights championship bout at an illegal boxing club in an industrial section of the Bronx.

title: How Tim Gunn of Project Runway Spends His Sunday
description: Tim Gunn doesnt balk at sharing his point of view, whether its favorable (Your clothes have beautiful construction details. There is a real voice here.), controversial (The fashion industry has an inability to accept real women and their size and shape. I find it disdainful and disrespectful.) or confessional (Im terribly shy. Every time Im in front of a camera Im nervous.). In his new book, Tim Gunn: The Natty Professor, the Project Runway co-host and mentor shares such observations and musings.
