description: Ever since the oil tycoon Henry Flagler turned the alligator-infested jungle known as Lake Worth into a tropical paradise for the 1 percent (it was the Gilded Age, after all) with palatial hotels and a railroad to serve them, Palm Beach has been synonymous with the biggest and the best: fortunes, jewels, scandals. The 16-mile-long island of extravagant mansions, tony retailers and fanciful landscaping is rich in history and significant landmarks, from the magnificent Mar-a-Lago estate (completed in 1927 for Marjorie Merriweather Post, now Donald Trumps private club) and the Paramount Theater (a former movie palace that houses a trove of vintage screen star photos) to St. Edwards church (where the Kennedys worshiped) and Greens Pharmacy (where John F. Kennedy enjoyed burgers in the luncheonette). But Palm Beach is also a small gem offering simple pleasures. You can ride a bike anywhere or linger over coffee at a lunch counter and never be more than a block or two from the beach. Even the new Orange Line trolley that shuttles riders between arts destinations in Palm Beach and neighboring West Palm Beach adds a down-to-earth touch to this high-rolling town (and its free!). When the season ends after Easter, parking spots and dinner reservations are readily available once again (not to mention discounted restaurant and hotel prices), making this perhaps the best time of all to visit.

title: Dozens Arrested in Raids to Stem Illegal Influx of Kosovars
description: BERLIN  The police in seven countries, trying to stanch the mass migration of Kosovars through Serbia and into the European Union, arrested 77 people accused of running a smuggling operation, the European authorities said on Wednesday.

title: Report by the F.B.I. 9/11 Review Commission
description: The report, released on Wednesday, examined the bureaus progress since the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Jets Accuse Patriots of Tampering
description: The Jets have accused the Patriots of tampering because of comments that Robert K. Kraft, owner of the Patriots, made Monday about Darrelle Revis, the star cornerback who signed with the Jets this month.

title: HBO Cancels Looking'; Series to Conclude With a Special
description: Following the second-season finale of Looking on Sunday, the New York Timess Mike Hale asked:

title: Barbican Announces Packed New Season
description: LONDON  A monthlong living exhibition organized by the multimedia artist Doug Aitken and an international Shakespeare festival are just two of the highlights of the Barbican Centers extensive 2015-16 season, announced on Wednesday.

title: Ghani Addresses Congress, Eager to Rebuild Afghan-U.S. Ties
description: WASHINGTON  When Ashraf Ghani, the president of Afghanistan, stepped up to speak at a formal dinner in his honor this week at the State Department, he looked out at a room of familiar faces, a fact he quickly made clear.

title: Big Home
description: The Strange and Radical Humaneness of Norways Halden Prison

title: Alessandra Ambrosios Brazilian Discovery
description: The supermodel and designer was enchanted by Trancoso, a small fishing village on the countrys east coast, when she visited last month.

title: Verbatim: Keeping Promises
description: President Obama, marking the 5th anniversary of the Affordable Care Act.

title: UPS Workers Pregnancy Discrimination Suit Reinstated by Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday revived a pregnancy discrimination lawsuit against United Parcel Service, saying that lower courts had used the wrong standard to determine whether the company had discriminated against one of its drivers.

title: This Time Around, Only a Nine-Year Run for The Fantasticks
description: The Fantasticks, the long-running Off-Broadway staple, will close (again) next month, succumbing to weak ticket sales in an increasingly competitive theater market.

title: Obama Praises Affordable Care Act on Its 5th Birthday
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama marked the fifth anniversary of the Affordable Care Act by mocking the laws longtime critics as wrong about their predictions that its passage would doom Americas health care system.

title: Jeremy Clarkson Loses Contract as Host of BBCs Top Gear
description: LONDON  Jeremy Clarkson has reached the end of the road, at least with the BBC.

title: Court Blocks Jihadist Website Used to Recruit Turks to Islamic State
description: ISTANBUL  A website popular with jihadists that has been used to recruit Turks to the Islamic State was blocked by a court here on Wednesday, after years of publishing extreme Islamist content and evading Turkeys strict Internet regulations.

title: As the Opera World Mourns Plane Crash Victims, Video of Their Last Production
description: Two opera singers were among the victims of the Germanwings crash on Tuesday: the contralto Maria Radner and the baritone Oleg Bryjak. Both had been performing in Siegfried, the third opera in Wagners Ring cycle, at the Liceu opera house in Barcelona, Ms. Radner as the earth goddess Erda and Mr. Bryjak as the scheming dwarf Alberich.

title: Dj Vu in the F.B.I.
description: Stop me if youve heard this one: The Federal Bureau of Investigation does not have enough linguists, intelligence analysts, computer experts or internal communication systems to handle an expanding and growing threat from terrorist groups.

title: Mark Morris Dance Group | LAllegro
description: An excerpt from the PBS Great Performances recording of the Mark Morris Dance Group staging of Handels oratorio LAllegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato.

title: Zayn Malik Quits One Direction
description: If the tween in your life seems extra surly today or the Snapchat servers melt down, it might be because of a disturbance in the One Direction universe: The British boy band announced today on Facebook that Zayn Malik, one of its five members and perhaps the most recognizable after Harry Styles, has left the group.

title: Unhappy With a Moderate Jeb Bush, Conservatives Aim to Unite Behind an Alternative
description: OSKALOOSA, Iowa  Fearing that Republicans will ultimately nominate an establishment presidential candidate like Jeb Bush, leaders of the nations Christian right have mounted an ambitious effort to coalesce their support behind a single social-conservative contender months before the first primary votes are cast.

title: Two Opera Singers Final Roles
description: Oleg Bryjak and Maria Radner were among the 150 passengers and crew killed in Tuesdays plane crash in the French Alps. They were returning from performing in Wagners Siegfried in Barcelona, Spain.

title: In German Town, Crushing Grief at Losing 16 Students and 2 Teachers in Jet Crash
description: HALTERN AM SEE, Germany  Even after word began to spread around the Joseph-Knig-Gymnasium on Tuesday morning that a plane on its way from Barcelona to Dsseldorf had gone down in France, Ulrich Wessel, the principal, kept alive hope that his students were not aboard that aircraft.

title: Hook, Line, and Thinker (Trivial)
description: Apropos of nothing much, the British magazine Prospect has done a poll to identify the worlds leading thinkers. Some very odd characters there.

title: Facebook Opens Messenger for App Developers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook changed how 1.4 billion people share their baby photos, major life events and goofy cat videos with friends. Now it wants to change their one-on-one conversations, too.

title: Obama Hails Health Care Law Anniversary
description: President Obama spoke on Wednesday at a White House event on the fifth anniversary of the Affordable Care Act, saying that the law is saving both lives and money.

title: Alessandra Ambrosios Brazilian Discovery
description: Last February, after hearing from multiple trusted sources about the wonders of Trancoso, a small fishing village located in Bahia, on the east coast of Brazil, Alessandra Ambrosio, the supermodel and designer of le by Alessandra, took a six-day holidaytherewith her entire family. Her friends recommended she stay at Uxua, a small hotel owned by the former Diesel creative director Wilbert Das and comprised of 11 casas situated on the edge of the Quadrado, Trancosos 500-year-old town square. I was a little concerned because its not on the beach, she admits. But her mind changed as soon as she saw the colorful, charming property and the energy and scenery around it: Its pretty incredible, she says. Ambrosio and her family stayed at two of Uxuas casas  one that faced the Quadrado and another with a second-story room where her children, Anja and Noah, slept. My kids loved it because it felt like a little room in a treehouse, she says.

title: Searching for Evan S. Connells Bohemian Sausalito
description: On the back wall of the No Name Bar in Sausalito, Calif., crowded among pennants of the Giants and 49ers, the legendary teams on the south side of the Golden Gate Bridge, there is a poster that the bar printed for its 50th anniversary, six years ago. The poster says: No Cover. No Plastic. No Pretense. And whoever made it might as well have added, No tourists.

title: App Smart | Board Games on Your Phone
description: Old-fashioned board games like Monopoly and Life get a new spin when they migrate to the smartphone.

title: Video Feature: Classic Board Games, Reimagined for a Mobile App World
description: WE still play board games in my family, with real bits of cardboard and plastic. But we also love to play classic games that have had an app-based refresh. Theyre frequently worth the money, sometimes for new features, but also because the apps do all the onerous scoring for you.

title: Lumber Liquidators Faces U.S. Safety Inquiry
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission formally announced on Wednesday that it was investigating whether Lumber Liquidators, one of the nations largest discount flooring retailers, sold products with dangerous levels of formaldehyde.

title: Supreme Court Rules Against Alabama in Redistricting Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday sided with black and Democratic lawmakers in Alabama who said the State Legislature had relied too heavily on race in its 2012 state redistricting by maintaining high concentrations of black voters in some districts.

title: Remembering the Happy Land Fire in the Bronx, 25 Years Later
description: Eighty-seven people in a Bronx social club died in 1990 in the worst fire in New York City since the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire in 1911.

title: Officials Discuss Victims on Airbus
description: The managing director of Germanwings confirmed on Wednesday that two Americans were among the 150 killed when an Airbus crashed in the French Alps.

title: Polish Ex-Priest Sentenced to 7 Years on Abuse Charges
description: WARSAW  A former priest was sentenced Wednesday to seven years in prison on charges of sexually abusing eight children in Poland and the Dominican Republic, a spokesman for the regional court in Warsaw said.

title: Brazilian Investor 3G Capitals Big Food Deals
description: With deals involving Burger King, Kraft and the company behind Budweiser, 3G Capital and one of its backers, Jorge Paulo Lemann, have become powerhouses in the world of food brands.

title: Bowe Bergdahl Charged With Desertion and Misbehavior Before the Enemy
description: WASHINGTON  In the five years he was held captive by the Haqqani insurgent network, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl recalls that he tried to escape 12 times. The first time was just a few hours after he was captured in Afghanistan in 2009.

title: Pakistani Army Begins Offensive to Drive Militants From Tirah Valley
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Dozens of militants and Pakistani soldiers have died in fierce fighting as part of a new effort by the military to gain control of the Tirah Valley, a notorious militant sanctuary on the border with Afghanistan, Pakistani civilian and military officials said Wednesday.

title: Ghani Acknowledges U.S. Soldiers
description: President Ashraf Ghani, in an address to a joint meeting of Congress on Wednesday, said Afghanistan owed a profound debt to the U.S. soldiers who were killed and wounded in Afghanistan.

title: A Painting Sold by the Met Is Declared a True Rubens
description: Two years ago, the Metropolitan Museum of Art sold off a painting believed to be of Peter Paul Rubens daughter after deciding it was by a follower of Rubens, not by the artist himself. But now the Rubenshuis, a museum in Antwerp devoted to works by the Flemish artist, has decided the painting really was created by the old master.

title: In Icelands DNA, New Clues to Disease-Causing Genes
description: Scientists in Iceland have produced an unprecedented snapshot of a nations genetic makeup, discovering a host of previously unknown gene mutations that may play roles in ailments as diverse as Alzheimers disease, heart disease and gallstones.

title: Over 2 Dozen Charged in Rockland County Drug Scheme
description: More than two dozen people have been charged with having roles in a sprawling oxycodone and heroin trafficking operation in New York Citys northern suburbs, the authorities said.

title: Italian Court Postpones Ruling in Amanda Knox Case
description: ROME  Italys highest court postponed until Friday its ruling on whether to uphold the murder convictions of Amanda Knox and her Italian former boyfriend.

title: Messaging Apps Offer Do-It-All Services in Bid for Higher Profits
description: MESSAGING apps do a lot more these days than send messages.

title: Alex Garlands Sci-Fi Faves
description: Here, the screenwriter of 28 Days Later, Never Let Me Go and Dredd on his five favorite genre offerings.

title: Parrying the Latest Predictions of Facebooks Demise
description: Every few years, a strange affliction breaks out in Silicon Valley. The disease, Facebook Second Guessing Syndrome, has as its worst symptom an embarrassing tendency to predict an early peak for the fortunes of the worlds largest social network.

title: Investigator: Audio Retrieved From Plane
description: Rmi Jouty, director of Frances Bureau of Investigation and Analysis, confirmed that audio of voices had been recovered from the black box in the crash of the Germanwings plane in the French Alps.

title: Krafts Investors Bet on Same Formula That Helped Heinz
description: H.J. Heinzs operating margins rose to 26 percent from 18 percent after 3G Capital and Warren E. Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway took the ketchup maker private two years ago. In welcoming a merger that creates a company worth perhaps $80 billion, Kraft Foods investors are betting on more of the same.

title: Hunger Strike for Dream Act
description: About 50 immigration activists in Manhattan, including Guadalepe Muller, center, announced their intent to go on a hunger strike on Wednesday. The group of people, who would be affected by the proposed Dream Act, have pledged to not eat until the measure is included in the New York State budget, which has an April 1 deadline.

title: Reviews: New Books From Thomas McGuane, Hanif Kureishi and More
description: SIGNS PRECEDING THE END OF THE WORLD

title: Through Suffering and Distress, the Reporting Carries On
description: I can remember crying in the newsroom of The New York Times only once. When part of your job is covering the daily disastrous events in a huge city  from shootings that kill one to building explosions that kill dozens  you have to learn to keep your hands typing and your tear ducts dry.

title: Key Findings from the F.B.I. 9/11 Report
description: A panel found that the F.B.I. has made improvements since the Sept. 11 attacks, but pointed to areas that still need strengthening.

title: Ukraine Arrests 2 Officials as Nation Watches on TV
description: MOSCOW  In a carefully orchestrated spectacle calculated to dramatize a newly aggressive anticorruption campaign, the Ukrainian authorities on Wednesday arrested two senior government officials during a televised cabinet meeting in Kiev. Prime Minister Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, who was in the room, declared it a warning to public officials about abusing their offices or stealing from taxpayers.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: Photos from France, Libya, Ukraine and Afghanistan

title: The Eyes Have It
description: These new board books and picture books challenge, explore and celebrate the visual.

title: Hidden Life Forms: Investigating Microbial Diversity on Our Bodies and in Our Homes
description: Overview | In this lesson, students learn about how and why scientists are studying the biodiversity of previously unexplored places, such as the insides of homes and the surface of the human body. They then sample the microbes living in their own belly buttons and consider the implications of this newly discovered microbial diversity.

title: March 25, 2015  Photos of the Day
description: Photos from France, Libya, Ukraine and Afghanistan.

title: Globe-Trotting Denis Ten Aims to Break New Ground
description: If the pieces and the votes all fall into place, Denis Ten just might compete in the 2018 Winter Games in South Korea, his ancestral home, and in the 2022 Winter Games in Almaty, Kazakhstan, his home city.

title: Whats Troy Murphy Doing at Columbia? Studying
description: Troy Murphy, 34, who left Notre Dame early to begin his 12-year N.B.A. career, is completing his undergraduate degree at Columbias School of General Studies.

title: Arrests in Ukraine Are Seen on Live TV
description: The head of the Ukrainian state emergency service, Serhiy Bochkovsky, and his deputy, Vasiliy Stoyetsky, were arrested and charged with corruption during a televised government meeting.

title: Review: The Big Picture with Kal Penn Looks at the Data Driving the Stories
description: The world seems to be adjusting to legalized marijuana, but can it adjust to Kumar as a statistics-wielding socio-scientific analyst?

title: Readers Respond: On Angelina Jolie Pitt: Diary of a Surgery
description: Readers responded with gratitude, good wishes and laments about the cost of health care Tuesday when Angelina Jolie Pitt revealed her decision to have surgery to remove her ovaries and fallopian tubes.

title: A Big Man in the N.B.A., but Not on Campus at Columbia
description: It was just before 9 oclock Tuesday morning, and the entire Columbia University campus seemed to want just a few more hours of sleep. In Milbank Hall, a 119-year-old building on the northern edge of the Barnard College quad, students filtered wordlessly into a third-floor classroom where a course called Introduction to Logic was about to begin.

title: Kendrick Lamar Is No. 1
description: The surprise release last week of Kendrick Lamars new album, To Pimp a Butterfly, made him the toast of the Internet, racking up critical accolades and generating more streams on Spotify than any album has had in a single day.

title: Review: Nikolai Lugansky Plays Schubert and Tchaikovsky
description: Maybe Im making too much of this. Still, the fact that the Russian pianist Nikolai Lugansky was born in Moscow to two research scientists reveals a great deal about his remarkable artistry.

title: The Country of Ice Cream Star, by Sandra Newman
description: Go ahead and add Sandra Newmans supersize third novel, The Country of Ice Cream Star, to the growing list of books set in a catastrophic near future. Our current fascination with postindustrial wastelands makes perfect sense, of course, given the daily dire warnings about our planets fate. At least our literature appears to be responding to climate change even if our energy policy isnt.

title: Review: In Harvey Beaks on Nickelodeon, Life Isnt Disney Perfect
description: Perhaps your children are still obsessed with that danged Frozen movie, with its inescapable anthem and its spun-off books, ice-skating show and video games. If so, sit them down in front of Harvey Beaks, an animated Nickelodeon series that begins on Sunday night. Its important for them to know that life isnt really a gorgeous-looking, tuneful, tidily plotted Disney movie. Its sloppy and incongruous, and its messages and meanings frequently require excavation.

title: Letters: The Best Intentions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: WOODEN: A Coachs Life, by Seth Davis. (St. Martins Griffin, $18.99.) Ten N.C.A.A. championships in 12 seasons, an 88-game winning streak  John Woodens U.C.L.A. basketball teams reached incomparable heights in the 1960s and 70s, but it was his off-the-court behavior that elevated him to the status of American icon. Daviss exhaustively researched account of Woodens 99 years shows how hard he strove for success while revealing the man, and his human failings, behind the legend.

title: Verbatim: A Little Bipartisan Teasing
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to Senator Lindsey Graham, the South Carolina Republican and potential presidential candidate, as he slapped his old Senate colleague on the back in the Capitol.

title: First Draft Focus: Ghani Gets a Warm Welcome
description: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan addressed a joint meeting of Congress in Washington on Wednesday.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE MONOPOLISTS: Obsession, Fury, and the Scandal Behind the Worlds Favorite Board Game, by Mary Pilon. (Bloomsbury, $27.) The real story behind Monopoly, and the woman who went unrecognized for her role in its creation.

title: SXSW Pays Off for the Prettiots
description: For baby bands, the annual South by Southwest Music Conference and Festival in Austin, Tex., can be like screaming into the abyss as thousands of struggling musicians spend their own money to play a marathon of unpaid concerts for industry machers.

title: Vanessa Hudgens as a Gigi Tailored for the Instagram Age
description: Vanessa Hudgens, victim of many a leaked-photo scandal, was naked again  but calm yourselves. This time she was safely sequestered in a dressing room at the back of the Alice & Olivia store in SoHo, trying on possible outfits for an opening-night party celebrating a new Broadway version of Gigi, in which she stars.

title: German School Mourns Students in Crash
description: Ulrich Wessel, the principal of Joseph-Knig-Gymnasium in Haltern Am See, Germany, expressed grief after 16 students and two teachers from his school where killed in a plane crash in the French Alps.

title: John Robic Is an Assistant Happy to Sweat the Small Stuff for Kentucky
description: CLEVELAND  When Kentuckys basketball team emerges from timeouts, the last coach to speak to players tends to be not John Calipari but John Robic, his assistant. As the huddle breaks up, Robic grabs as many players as he can and shows them a diagram of the court on a whiteboard, walking them through what is about to happen one more time.

title: Egyptian Woman Reveals 42-Year Secret of Survival: Pretending to Be a Man
description: AL AQALTAH, Egypt  She has worked for more than 30 years among the shoeshine men of Luxor. She sits with men in coffee shops, prays with them in the local mosque and dresses just as they do in pants or a traditional floor-length tunic known as a galabeya.

title: The Enigma of Haute Couture
description: These clothes couldnt look any more modern  dramatic silhouettes, dark colors, floral appliqus  yet they are created in the most traditional manner. Is custom-made fashion a treasure or a relic?

title: Rangers Lundqvist Will Be Backup Thursday as He Nears Return
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  In the surest sign that goalie Henrik Lundqvist is close to returning, the Rangers assigned the rookie Mackenzie Skapski to Hartford of the American Hockey League on Wednesday. That will allow Lundqvist to serve as the backup to Cam Talbot on Thursday against the Ottawa Senators.

title: George Osborne Says British Bank Tax Is Here to Stay
description: LONDON  In 2010, Britains chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, announced a bank levy, or tax on bank balance sheets, to force the industry to pay for the mess it had made.

title: Chip Kelly Opens Up About Eagles Moves as Coaches Hold Court
description: PHOENIX  Maybe it was a coincidence, but on Wednesday, Philadelphia Eagles Coach Chip Kelly sat in the same chair that New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick did Tuesday.

title: Mark Morriss Transcendent LAllegro, Captured on Film for PBS
description: Since its premiere in 1988, Mark Morriss full-length dance staging of Handels oratorio LAllegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato has provoked two widespread reactions. One: How blessed we are to live in an age in which such miraculous beauty is made! Two: When will this be filmed and made available to a wider public?

title: Review: Debbie Harry Begins a Run atCaf Carlyle
description: I dont know: Have we fulfilled our obligation? Debbie Harry nervously wondered out from the stage of Caf Carlyle on Tuesday evening after performing around a dozen songs. Behind that question was an implied plea: How soon will this torture end, so can I get out of here?

title: New Guidelines to Treat Victims of Chemical Weapon Exposure
description: The under secretary of the Army, Brad R. Carson, apologized for the militarys treatment of American service members exposed to chemical weapons in Iraq and released new steps to provide medical support to those with lingering health effects.

title: At N.F.L. Owners Meeting, Roger Goodell Confronts the Aftermath of Abuse Cases
description: PHOENIX  N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell may be relieved that last season is over, but he is still grappling with the fallout from domestic abuse scandals and the leagues botched attempts to penalize players who dominated the headlines in 2014.

title: Spring North American Championships Winners
description: The American Contract Bridge Leagues Spring North American Championships ended on Sunday. The 60-board final of the premier event, the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, was won by Lavazza (Norberto Bocchi, Agustin Madala, Giorgio Duboin and Zia Mahmood), which defeated Diamond (John Diamond, Brian Platnick, Eric Greco, Geoff Hampson, Marc Jacobus and Eddie Wold) by 145 international match points to 110.

title: Mitch McConnells Drive to Keep the Coal Fires Burning
description: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has never been so busy or so aggressive in his role as the defender of Big Coals interests as he is now. Earlier this month, the powerful Republican from coal-rich Kentucky made an unusual move in reaching beyond Congress and directly urging state governors not to cooperate with the Obama administrations pending new regulations to reduce carbon pollution from coal-fired power plants, the nations largest source of greenhouse-gas emissions.

title: Veterans Hurt by Chemical Weapons in Iraq Get Apology
description: WASHINGTON  The under secretary of the Army on Wednesday apologized for the militarys treatment of American service members exposed to chemical weapons in Iraq, and he announced new steps to provide medical support to those with lingering health effects and to recognize veterans who had been denied awards.

title: Matthew Crawford and How to Survive Brain-Eating Distractions
description: RICHMOND, Va.  On a recent Sunday morning, it was business as usual at Classified Moto, a custom motorcycle shop in a former mule barn here.

title: In China, Supporters of Detained Feminists Come Under Pressure
description: Like a modern-day Leviathan scenting challenges to its rule, the Chinese state appears to have a new target: young women.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Review: Becoming Steve Jobs Focuses on Another Apple Era
description: The main point of the new business-oriented biography Becoming Steve Jobs, by Brent Schlender and Rick Tetzeli is that Steve Jobs has been misrepresented. Blame Walter Isaacsons Steve Jobs (2011), as the authors do, for the public perception that Mr. Jobs never outgrew the managerial style of the scheming, screaming, cheating, smelly hothead he may  may  have been in his early years. Instead, Mr. Schlender and Mr. Tetzeli say in their new book, Mr. Jobs developed a wise, mature, deliberate executive style for which he is seldom given credit, one that helped lead Apple to glorious heights.

title: California Seeks to Head Off Initiative to Execute Gays
description: LOS ANGELES  The California attorney general, Kamala D. Harris, moved Wednesday to block a proposed voter initiative that would mandate the execution of sexually active gay men and women, calling it patently unconstitutional and a threat to public safety.

title: Earths Untallied Biological Bounty, from L.A. Suburbs to Deep Seabed Sediments
description: The extent and diversity of Earths sheath of living things continues to surprise scientists, making Howard Ensign Evanss classic 1966 book Life on a Little-Known Planet ever more germane. Here is fresh evidence from some Los Angeles back yards and the deadest depths of deep-sea sediments:

title: Medical Marijuana Eases Childhood Seizures
description: Some parents desperate to ease their childrens epileptic seizures have moved to Colorado to seek relief through medical marijuana.

title: The Musical The Demo at Stanford Recreates the Dawn of the Digital Age
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In December 1968, the computer scientist Douglas Engelbart sat on a stage here and introduced the world to modern computing. He brought together for the first time a mouse, word processing, multimedia communication and networking to demonstrate interactive computing before an audience of a thousand leading computer scientists. His presentation would become known as the Demo.

title: Apple and Beats Developing Streaming Music Service to Rival Spotify
description: In what would be the biggest change to its music strategy in years, Apple is pressing ahead with a sweeping overhaul of its digital music services that would allow the company to compete directly with streaming upstarts like Spotify.

title: Review: Platform 2015 at St. Marks Church
description: When does a rehearsal become a performance? In one of the last events on Danspace Projects two-month Platform 2015 at St. Marks Church, the choreographer Pam Tanowitz created a dance in a day (a dance adrift in the cosmos). Spectators could come and go between 1 and 7:30 p.m. to watch Ms. Tanowitz, the composer-musician Dan Siegler and six dancers make a piece.

title: Army Charges Bergdahl With Desertion
description: An Army spokesman, Col. Daniel King, said that Sgt. Bowe R. Bergdahl, who disappeared from his outpost in Afghanistan in 2009 and was captured by the Taliban, was being charged with desertion.

title: Remembering the Happy Land Fire in the Bronx, 25 Years Later
description: On March 25, 1990, a fire ripped through the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx, killing 87 people. The fire began after a man quarreled with his ex-girlfriend, who worked at the club, and then set the club on fire. He was convicted of murder and arson.

title: What Model and Musician Hannah Cohen Likes to Wear and More Style News
description: A model and musician who likes vintage mens Levis and playing dress-up; springlike suits and sneakers; bags that are luxurious but not precious; and lucky shoes.

title: A Reading of Video Baby Monitor by Craig Morgan Teicher
description: A poets ode to his sleeping son.

title: The New Venue for American Art
description: Donna De Salvo, the chief curator and deputy director for programs at the Whitney Museum of American Art, speaks to the direction the collection has taken over since its beginning in 1930.

title: Amex to Ask for Stay of Ruling Prohibiting Merchants From Promoting Other Cards
description: The chief executive of American Express said on Wednesday that the company would seek a stay of a ruling that could ban a longstanding Amex practice: prohibiting merchants from encouraging customers to pay with lower-cost cards.

title: Trans-Pacific Partnership Seen as Door for Foreign Suits Against U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  An ambitious 12-nation trade accord pushed by President Obama would allow foreign corporations to sue the United States government for actions that undermine their investment expectations and hurt their business, according to a classified document.

title: The New Whitney
description: Images of the Whitney Museum in its new location in the meatpacking district.

title: Dean Smith Documentary Pays Homage to Visionary Coach
description: Dean Smith, the new documentary about the North Carolina basketball coach, is purely a homage. The portrait is not of a difficult or meanspirited man but of one whom any recruits parents would want to have in their home: polite, old-fashioned, supportive, averse to cursing (but not occasional sarcasm), hypercompetitive, humble, colorblind and pro-education (really).

title: A Chance to Soar
description: Young equestrians commute to Florida for their sport.

title: Teenage Snowbirds? Just Part of Being a Young Equestrian
description: Wellington, Fla.  Each Sunday evening of the winter months, a sea of girls in riding breeches, muddy paddock boots and fitted navy blazers crowds the JetBlue gateways in West Palm Beach, Fla., heading home to the New York area for the school week.

title: A Toast to the Final Episodes of Mad Men
description: For the cast of Mad Men, the goodbyes took place last July when the critically acclaimed show filmed its final episode.

title: First Lady Sings Lullaby
description: A campaign for early childhood development will feature a lullaby, sung by New York Citys first lady Chirlane McCray.

title: The Early-Morning Workout Flash Mob
description: Where most people see beloved New York locales, John Honerkamp, Paul Leak and their merry band of some 100 followers see prime exercise sites.

title: Before Writing for Mayor de Blasio, He Wrote About Love
description: The author works from a basement desk at New York City Hall, his following gone but his audience grown, riffing anonymously on paid sick leave and prekindergarten.

title: How Kanye West Dominated Fashion Month (No Surprise, It Involved Social Media)
description: Lights down, arms up.

title: Amid Affordable Care Act Fight, a Health Center Program Struggles to Stay Alive
description: Dr. Savita Gopal, a 27-year-old resident physician at the Family Health Center of Harlem, sat in front of a computer last Thursday, peppering Jacob Doble, a 10-year-old from Harlem, with questions for 20 minutes.

title: Justices Side With Black Lawmakers in Alabama
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday sided with black lawmakers challenging an Alabama redistricting plan and revived a pregnancy discrimination lawsuit against United Parcel Service.

title: Disco Pioneer Nicky Siano Hasnt Lost the Beat
description: Coney Island is a long way to go for a party. But that didnt stop nearly 500 people from making the trek last Saturday night for the disc jockey Nicky Siano, the music pioneer who helped spawn the 1970s disco scene with his club the Gallery and a stint spinning at Studio 54. He was turning 60.

title: Judge Rejects N.H.L.s Bid to Dismiss Concussion Suit
description: In a decision that may prompt a financial settlement, a federal judge in Minnesota on Wednesday denied an N.H.L. motion to dismiss a case brought by retired players who accused the league of concealing from them the risks of repeated head trauma and promoting violence on the ice.

title: Victims of Germanwings Flight 9525
description: Passengers from at least 15 countries were aboard the flight from Barcelona, Spain, to Dsseldorf, Germany, including 72 Germans and 35 Spaniards. Here are profiles of some of the 123 victims whose families have been notified.

title: The Happiest Hour in Greenwich Village
description: It seems fitting that the 1950s, a period of conformity and affluence, would inform a downtown night-life scene that could be described the same way. Such blitheness is on display at the Happiest Hour, a cocktail bar from Jon Neidich (an owner of Acme) and Jim Kearns (bartender at NoMad Hotel and Pegu Club) that opened last fall in Greenwich Village.

title: F.T.C. Addresses Its Choice Not to Sue Google
description: Several members of the Federal Trade Commission defended on Wednesday the actions taken by the agency in its antitrust investigation of Google, nearly a week after an internal document came to light, raising questions about the process.

title: 3G Capital, Warren Buffetts Favorite Partner in Deals Worth Billions
description: Warren E. Buffett has made a habit of criticizing ruthless Wall Street bankers and rapacious private equity firms over the years. As recently as last month, he railed against both in his annual letter to his shareholders at Berkshire Hathaway.

title: Gregory Walcott, Actor in Plan 9 From Outer Space, Dies at 87
description: Gregory Walcott, a character actor whose rsum included numerous television westerns, several Clint Eastwood movies and prestige films like Norma Rae  but who was probably best known as one of the stars of Plan 9 From Outer Space, often called the worst movie ever made  died on Friday at his home in the Canoga Park neighborhood of Los Angeles. He was 87.

title: Netanyahu Told to Mend Ties With Washington
description: JERUSALEM  Israels president on Wednesday officially handed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu the task of forming a new government, saying its first priority was to repair relations with the United States and indirectly chiding Mr. Netanyahu for his  Election Day warning that Arab citizens were flocking to polling places in droves.

title: Museum in Little Italy Seeks to Evict a Living Link to the Past
description: Adele Sarnos father, a longshoreman, emigrated from Naples, and she grew up in Manhattans Little Italy. As a child, she served as princess for the annual Feast of San Gennaro, she said, and one year was even crowned the queen.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (2) vs. Denmark (3)
description: AARHUS, Denmark  The United States national team endured yet another late-game collapse Wednesday, losing on a cold, rainy night by 3-2 to a Denmark team that was far superior in nearly every aspect of the game.

title: Increased Military Spending Wins Out After Dueling Budget Votes in House
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans beat back protests from fiscal hawks and narrowly passed a budget that increases war spending but slashes domestic programs and begins to privatize Medicare with a goal of balancing the federal books in nine years.

title: House Leaders Confident of Passing Medicare Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Leaders of both parties in the House expressed confidence on Wednesday that their chamber would soon approve sweeping changes in Medicare, even though the Congressional Budget Office released figures showing that the bill could add more than $140 billion to federal budget deficits in the coming decade.

title: Steven Smith, a Marco Polo of American Tea, Dies at 65
description: Steven Smith, a tea company founder who, steeped in memories of sweet Red Rose brewed by his grandmother, helped transform the nations tea-drinking habits as much as any American since that party in Boston Harbor in 1773, died on Monday in Portland, Ore. He was 65.

title: New York Police to Use Social Media to Connect With Residents
description: The New York Police Department has faced its share of pushback on social media, most memorably when it solicited photos of police interactions on Twitter under the hashtag #myNYPD. Images of aggression by officers upended that campaign.

title: Cost a Factor in Streaming Flight Data in Real Time
description: The crash of a German passenger jet in the French Alps has once again raised the question of whether commercial airplanes should transmit flight information in real time.

title: Former University of Oklahoma Student Apologizes for Racist Chant
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  A former University of Oklahoma student captured on video leading a racist chant apologized Wednesday, saying he was sorry for his role in the incident and ashamed that he participated.

title: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
description: On Thursday from 5 to 8 p.m., the boutique Coop & Spree will host a trunk show with the Kempner designer Meggie Kempner, granddaughter of Nan Kempner, during which you can enjoy 20 percent off tweaked classics like a structured boyfriend blazer with leather detail on the sleeves ($520, originally $650). At 202 Elizabeth Street.

title: Arizona Bill Would Delay Disclosure of Names of Officers in Shootings
description: PHOENIX  Gov. Doug Ducey has until Monday to decide whether to sign or veto a bill requiring state agencies to keep confidential for 60 days the identities of law enforcement officers involved in deadly or serious shootings.

title: S.E.C. Is Investigating Dov Charneys Departure, American Apparel Says
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened an inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the departure of Dov Charney, the founder of American Apparel who was ousted last year, the retailer said in a filing Wednesday.

title: Winter Weather Stays; Its Clothes Do Not
description: You know the look.

title: Thousands Protest Plan to Oust University Chief in Mississippi
description: OXFORD, Miss.  Raising handwritten signs and clutching scripts for protest chants, more than 2,500 people on Wednesday demonstrated at the University of Mississippi to resist last weeks unexpected decision to oust the schools chancellor, Daniel W. Jones.

description: To the Editor:

description: March 25, 2015

title: Notre Dames Star on Offense, Defense and the Mound
description: CLEVELAND  In March, the differences between the pulsating energy of a basketball arena during the N.C.A.A. tournament and the quiet chill of a Midwestern collegiate baseball field could not be more stark.

title: Florida: Ex-Salvadoran Official Is Detained Pending Deportation
description: A former defense minister of El Salvador accused of human rights violations during the civil war in the 1980s was detained by immigration agents in Palm Coast, the first step in his deportation. In a precedent-setting decision, an immigration appeals court on March 12 upheld a deportation order for the official, Gen. Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova, finding that he had participated in torture and killings by his troops when he was the highest Salvadoran military officer. The court found that Gen. Vides had aided a cover-up in the killings in 1980 of four American churchwomen. He has been living as a legal resident in Florida since 1989.

title: Part of Washing
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  There are clues that you get right away and there are clues that you ponder for what seems like an eternity before the light bulb goes on.

title: My Biggest Financial Lesson
description: Most of us have one, or sometimes more than one: a turning point or a moment when our feelings about money crystallize. When that happens, we know it and resolve to think about our finances in a different way while saving, spending or giving away money much more carefully.

title: Michael P. Kelly, a Familiar Face, Is Returning to New York Citys Housing Agency
description: A former general manager of New York Citys public housing authority is returning to the job at a time when the agency faces financial pressures even more dire than when he left.

title: Amnesty International Sees Evidence of Palestinian War Crimes in 2014 Gaza Conflict
description: JERUSALEM  Amnesty International has accused armed Palestinian groups, including the military wing of Hamas, of displaying a flagrant disregard for the lives of civilians during the 50-day war in Gaza last summer. In a report published early Thursday it said there was evidence that several deadly Palestinian rocket and mortar attacks amounted to war crimes.

title: Paying for College and Learning a Lesson for Life
description: When it came time to apply for college in the fall of 1988, my parents and I didnt know the first thing about the financial aid process. But my mother, a veteran personal shopper who has always had a knack for figuring out just who to call to solve consumer mysteries of all sorts, knew someone who knew someone. A guy. The guy.

title: Need Financial Advice? Ask the Future You
description: Eureka moments are supposed to happen in unlikely locations, like the one Archimedes had in his bath. But my revelation about planning and money came in a terribly likely spot, a centuries-old ceremonial hall at Oxford University.

title: Spent, a Song About Financial Hardship
description: An original song by Amy Speace and Neilson Hubbard about how hard it is to save for the future when you are barely making payments on todays bills.

title: Chinese Cabbies Query Prompted an Epiphany
description: With the Mandarin language skills of a buffalo, I began chatting with my taxi driver in Shanghai, a polite man with plenty of questions about the United States. It was early 2007, and sitting in a back seat that reeked of stale cigarettes and body odor, I certainly didnt see a financial epiphany coming. Then, the driver went straight for the jugular.

title: Money Admonitions From 9/11
description: In the last 30 years, presidents, governors, mayors and others have delegated to me the unenviable task of putting a value to the lives of people who are already dead.

title: An Excuse to Splurge on Her Girls
description: After I spent a weekend packing away toys that my children had outgrown, Elizabeth, Felicity, Julie, Kaya, Kirsten and Kit were nestled safely in plastic bins.

title: Amy Speace, a Singer-Songwriter, Just Trying to Make Do
description: NASHVILLE  I live in East Nashville, a bohemian neighborhood in Music City right across the Cumberland River from downtown that, for many years, has been home to one of the most diverse populations in this city. Bisected by Gallatin Pike, where an ber-trendy coffee shop might sit in between a discount liquor store and a check-cashing shop, this area is peppered with quaint cottage homes that only a short time ago were affordable to the artist class.

title: How the Year 2000 Turned My Life Upside Down
description: Ill admit it now: All those Y2K predictions had me scared about what would befall the world when 1999 became 2000.

title: Making Money Secondary in Decisions
description: I was 22 years old, starting my first job out of college and at lunch with my boss, John W. Rogers Jr., the founder and chief executive of Ariel Investments. I hung on Johns every word, filing away his every utterance.

title: Breaking a Rule on Hiring, and Paying the Price
description: During the 12 years Ive owned a marketing strategy company, I have set many guidelines and recommendations for myself and my employees, but few hard rules.

title: A Teenagers Harsh Lesson Is an Adults Buffer
description: The day after my high school graduation, at the age of 17 and with an acceptance letter to an Ivy League university in hand, my foster mother asked me to move out of her house in San Diego.

title: Kim Gordon on Not Spending Money
description: Kim Gordons memoir, Girl in a Band, a New York Times best seller, details her life as a founding member of Sonic Youth and her marriage to her band mate Thurston Moore.

title: A Costly but Valuable Lesson in Debt and Self-Confidence
description: The interest rate made my stomach drop: 27.6 percent.

title: Finding Surer Footing
description: We left the trail head at 1 a.m. and headed for the summit of the Grand Teton. I had made this climb several times, but my friend was still new to mountaineering. This trip was his first attempt at the popular peak. Our goal was to reach the top by sunrise so we had enough time to get back down before afternoon thunderstorms made the trail dangerous.

title: Slim Thugs Real Estate Game Plan, Dashed by a Dalliance
description: HOUSTON  Theres never much surprise when hearing stories of artists mixing business with pleasure, but it is surprising when too much mixing results in the artist ending up with financial losses.

title: Passing Along the Financial Genes
description: When you get right down to it, its my dads fault. My relationship with money, I mean. Its not weird or anything like that. Its just casual. Like, whether you have it or you dont, everythings going to be all right somehow.

title: Its a Jump Ball. Kentucky Wins.
description: CLEVELAND  In all of sports, no event may combine so much spectacle with so little meaning as the jump ball. It is competition at its purest: two players trying to jump higher than the other to get the ball. Once it is done, though, all that has happened is one team has the ball; the next team will soon enough.

title: Pick Up the Tab: The Wages of Virtue
description: Dont even bother, my big-shot executive pal warned me as I reached for my college-era Visa. We hadnt seen each other since my undergrad days. You never pay for the meal of someone whos better off than you.

title: Shrieking About Questionable Whistles in the N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  On Friday night at Nationwide Arena here, the most pivotal moment in a contest between Dayton and Providence to advance to the N.C.A.A. tournaments round of 32 was not a 3-pointer feathered in at the last second. It was not a thunderous dunk that brought the fans to their feet. It was not a stirring defensive stand. Instead, it was a technical foul.

description: Season 2, Episode 4

title: The Americans Recap: You Should Trust the Organization

title: Alarmed About Masahiro Tanakas Velocity? Slow Down, He Says
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Masahiro Tanaka stood with his back to the wall, his right elbow and shoulder heavily wrapped. He frowned, fidgeted and shook his head while a group of reporters asked why the velocity on his fastball appeared to be down.

title: The Crisis in Yemen: What You Need to Know
description: Yemen, the poorest country in the Middle East, is embroiled in a struggle for power that has serious implications for the region and the security of the United States.

title: Small Debris Indicates Germanwings Plane Didnt Explode in Air
description: Among the unusual elements of Tuesdays crash of a Germanwings Airbus A320 in the French Alps is that debris strewn across the site was in tiny pieces rather than large chunks, with one witness describing the plane as having been pulverized.

title: Collages that Challenge the Perception of Private Moments
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: The Anxiety of Fatherhood
description: The poet Craig Morgan Teicher and the artist Idris Khan search for solace from the endless nights of early parenthood in a simple surveillance camera.

title: The Centuries-Old Italian House Where Cy Twombly Thrived
description: The artist painted some of the 20th centurys great works in the hilly coastal town of Gaeta. All the while, Nicola Del Roscio, who watched over him, quietly created his own Eden.

title: Drones Beaming Web Access Are in the Stars for Facebook
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.  In classical mythology, Aquila is the eagle carrying Jupiters thunderbolts skyward. At Facebook, it is the code name for a high-flying drone, indicative of the social networking companys lofty ambitions.

title: Word of the Day | ravage
description: ravage  \ra-vij\  verb and noun

title: Iran Nuclear Deal May Be Done by Next Week, U.S. Official Says
description: LAUSANNE, SWITZERLAND  In the Obama administrations most hopeful prognosis on its talks with Iran, a senior State Department official said Wednesday that it was possible to conclude a new accord on that nations nuclear program by early next week.

title: Health Agency Reports Lowest Weekly Total of New Ebola Cases
description: The World Health Organization on Wednesday reported the lowest weekly total of new Ebola cases so far this year in the three nations of West Africa that have been afflicted by the deadly virus. The organization said a total of 79 new cases were reported for the week that ended Sunday: 45 in Guinea, 33 in Sierra Leone and one in Liberia. The Liberian case in particular has raised concern because the country had reported no new Ebola cases for the previous three weeks, and the precise source of the new infection, in a 44-year-old woman from the Monrovia region, has not yet been determined. The latest weekly Ebola statistics showed that 10,311 people have died from the outbreak since it began last year.

title: Reunion Tour Continues for Arizona Coach Sean Miller
description: Arizona Coach Sean Miller gave Sister Rose Ann Fleming, the academic adviser at Xavier since 1985, a hug in the dank hallway of Staples Center. They were chatting when the Xavier coach appeared.

title: West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins Wrote the Book on the Press. Two, Actually.
description: All season, West Virginia won by challenging opponents everywhere on the court, trying to force turnovers.

title: Wisconsin Uses Fakes to Gain an Edge
description: LOS ANGELES  North Carolina forward Kennedy Meeks ended the regular season with at least one blocked shot in each of the Tar Heels final eight games. Meeks, who finished eighth in the Atlantic Coast Conference with 46 blocks, will face a tall order deflecting Wisconsin shots when the teams meet Thursday in an N.C.A.A. West Regional semifinal in Los Angeles. And not just because he has been nursing a sprained knee.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (Spike) OCEANS THIRTEEN (2007) After Reuben Tishkoff (Elliott Gould) has a heart attack when his business partner Willy Bank (Al Pacino) pulls a fast one on him, Danny Ocean (George Clooney) gets the gang back together for a revenge plot. The gang includes characters played by Brad Pitt, Matt Damon, Don Cheadle, Casey Affleck, Scott Caan, Bernie Mac and others. They use gadgets and seduction to carry out their convoluted plan in this third film in a series directed by Steven Soderbergh. Part of what makes the Oceans films, even the self-indulgent second installment, so enjoyable is that theyre not only about Mr. Soderberghs obsessive aesthetic investment in every single shot, but theyre also about him trying to make the audience love his images every bit as much as he does, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Playing inside the box and out, he has learned to go against the grain while also going with the flow. In Oceans Thirteen he proves that in spades by using color like Kandinsky and hanging a funny mustache on Mr. Clooneys luscious mug, having become a genius of the system he so often resists.

title: Applications for Asylum Are Surging, United Nations Says
description: UNITED NATIONS  The war in Syria, now in its fifth year, has not only flooded countries in the region with millions of refugees. It has driven up the number of people seeking asylum across the world to a 20-year high, according to the United Nations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: To me, the scandal is that we had protocols in place and the medical community knew what they were, and yet we failed in some cases to implement this across the theater. That was a mistake, and I apologize for that.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: From Microsoft, a Novel Way to Mandate Sick Leave
description: It is difficult to imagine, at least in the current political climate, that the federal government will require paid sick leave for workers, let alone vacation time.

title: For Childrens Seizures, Turning to Medical Marijuana
description: By the time Grace Brunno was 3, she was suffering 400 epileptic seizures a week. Her parents, desperate to ease her suffering, took a drastic step: They left their home in Missouri and moved to Colorado so their child could start a regimen of medical marijuana.

description: To the Editor:

title: An Obama Friend Turns Foe on Coal
description: LAURENCE H. TRIBE, the liberal icon and legal scholar, has grabbed headlines in recent weeks for publicly attacking President Obamas signature climate change initiative  the Clean Power Plan  which would regulate carbon emissions from power plants. He was retained as an independent expert by Peabody Energy, the worlds largest private-sector coal company, and is representing it in a lawsuit that seeks to invalidate the plan.

title: When Nancy Met Johnny
description: Today, concerned citizens, we will consider when we want our elected representatives to just throw in the towel and get something done.

title: Deadly Force in Philadelphia
description: In 1994, three years after the country viewed the infamous video of Los Angeles police officers brutalizing Rodney King, a black motorist, Congress gave the Justice Department the power to restructure police departments engaged in unconstitutional practices.

title: Backing Away From Zero Tolerance
description: Schools across the country are rightly backing away from zero tolerance disciplinary policies under which children are suspended for minor misbehavior that once would have been dealt with by the principal and the childs parents or with a modest punishment like detention. The schools are being pushed in this direction by studies showing: that suspensions do nothing to improve the school climate; that children who are thrown out are at greater risk of low achievement and becoming entangled with the juvenile justice system; and that minority children are disproportionately singled out for the harshest, most damaging disciplinary measures.

title: A Rebuff to Indias Censors
description: Indian officials have repeatedly undermined the countrys right to free speech recently by seeking to ban films, intimidating authors and arresting Internet users. Thats what makes a recent Indian Supreme Court ruling striking down restrictions on Internet speech so important.

title: To Stop Irans Bomb, Bomb Iran
description: FOR years, experts worried that the Middle East would face an uncontrollable nuclear-arms race if Iran ever acquired weapons capability. Given the regions political, religious and ethnic conflicts, the logic is straightforward.

title: Linking Artist and Artisan
description: The Carpenters Workshop Gallery now has a center north of Paris where the artists it represents can work directly with skilled craftsmen.

title: Test Yourself | Michelle Obamas Travel Wardrobe
description: Here are several paragraphs from a March 24 article, For Michelle Obama, Girlie Clothes That Lean In.

title: Fatal Descent of Germanwings Plane Was Deliberate, French Authorities Say
description: PARIS  Andreas Lubitz was breathing, steady and calm, in the final moments of Germanwings Flight 9525. It was the only sound from within the cockpit that the voice recorder detected as Mr. Lubitz, the co-pilot, sent the plane into its descent.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Car Crash Videos Highlight Risk of Multitasking With Phones
description: In Car Crash Videos Highlight Risk of Multitasking With Phones, Matt Richtel reports on a new study about distracted driving.

title: As Dollar Heats Up Overseas, U.S. Manufacturers Feel a Chill
description: The dollars sharp rise in recent months has left Robert Stevenson and Eastman Machine, his familys 127-year-old Buffalo company, feeling the heat on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: C.I.A. Officers and F.B.I. Agents, Meet Your New Partner: The Analyst
description: Call it the revenge of the nerds, Washington-style. The gun-toting F.B.I. agent and the swashbuckling C.I.A. undercover officer are being increasingly called upon to share their clout, their budgets and even their Hollywood glamour with the humble, deskbound intelligence analyst.

title: Viewers Choice: Meaningless Bowls Over Playoff Basketball
description: March Madness is huge, right? This year, the multiweek extravaganza has had its usual share of upsets, an exhilarated coach falling off his rolling chair after a victory and the presence of a dominant Kentucky team. Nearly 11.6 million brackets were submitted to ESPN.coms annual contest. So what in college sports could be a bigger fan draw than the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament?

title: Chirlane McCray, in Evolving Role and in Song, Finds Her Voice
description: Inside City Hall in October, some three dozen commissioners and administration officials gathered to discuss childrens issues, rattling off statistics on cognitive development in toddlers.

title: In Menendez Inquiry, Government Renews Push for Friends Cooperation
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Robert Menendez, the powerful New Jersey Democrat, and Dr. Salomon Melgen, a wealthy Florida eye surgeon, have been close friends for years. Mr. Menendez may soon find out just how close their friendship remains.

title: The Whitney Museum, Soon to Open Its New Home, Searches for American Identity
description: When the Whitney Museum of American Art opens its new building in Manhattans meatpacking district on May 1, its the big things everyone will notice first: the sweeping views west to the Hudson River; the romantic silhouettes of Manhattans wooden water towers; the four outdoor terraces for presenting sculptures, performances and movie screenings; and the tiered profile of its steel-paneled facade, intentionally reminiscent of the Whitneys Modernist, granite-clad Marcel Breuer building on Madison Avenue, which had been the museums home since 1966.

title: A New Irish Rebellion, This Time Against Water Fees
description: DUBLIN  Miranda Lumsden, 43, a single mother of four, had never protested against anything before the Irish government introduced new water fees last summer.

title: Is Our Culture of Online Shaming Out of Control?
description: Do you know who Monica Lewinsky is? She calls herself the Patient Zero of losing a personal reputation on a global scale almost instantaneously and says that young people know her mostly through references in rap songs.

title: Richard John Neuhaus, by Randy Boyagoda
description: At the time of his death six years ago, the Rev. Richard John Neuhaus was arguably the most prominent conservative Roman Catholic in America. He was leader of the theocons, as critics labeled them, right-leaning Christian intellectuals grouped around First Things, a journal Neuhaus founded. Popes John Paul II and Benedict XVI knew him personally, as well as by his work, and George W. Bush sought Neuhauss counsel before and during his time as president. His 1984 book on the place of faith in politics, The Naked Public Square, has been credited with helping to define the climate in which Ronald Reagan won re-election.

title: Lyft Adds Profiles to Make Ride Sharing More Personalized
description: In 1971, Herb Kelleher, a founder of Southwest Airlines, had an idea: As competition in the burgeoning airline industry intensified, he wanted to make his small, regional carrier stand out among aviation giants.

title: Facebooks Yann LeCun Discusses Digital Companions and Artificial Intelligence (and Emotions)
description: Yann LeCun is director of artificial intelligence research at Facebook, and founding director of New York Universitys Center for Data Science.

title: An Upbeat Emotion Thats Surprisingly Good for You
description: This article appeared in the March 29 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Take the Habit Personality Quiz
description: This story was first published in 2015, and were resurfacing it for Smarter Living.

title: R.B.S. Sells $3.2 Billion in Stock of Citizens Financial Group
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Thursday that it sold $3.2 billion in shares of the Citizens Financial Group in a larger-than-expected offering as it seeks to reduce its holdings in the American retail bank after an initial public offering last year.

title: New York Today: Celebrations of Spring
description: Good morning on this drippy Thursday.

title: Richard III Gets a Kingly Burial, on Second Try
description: LEICESTER, England  For an English monarchy that has lasted more than 1,000 years, there can have been few more improbable occasions than the ceremony of remembrance here on Thursday for the reburial of one of the most bloodstained medieval sovereigns, King Richard III, who was slain in battle seven years before Christopher Columbus set sail for the New World.

title: As Twitter Introduces Periscope, Tech Titans Bet on Live Streaming Video
description: Tyra Banks smiled a toothy grin and chatted idly with a captive audience this week, showing off her new pixie haircut. She later flipped a blond-streaked auburn lock at the crowd, asking in a half-mocking tone, How do you like me now?

title: Borse Dubai Sells Its Stake in London Stock Exchange Group
description: LONDON  Borse Dubai said on Thursday that it had sold its entire 17.4 percent stake in the London Stock Exchange Group, ending its nearly eight-year ownership in the stock market operator.

title: Of Catfish Wars and Shooting Wars
description: THANH BINH, Vietnam  I drove out through a watery landscape, the rice paddies shimmering, watermelon being planted in muddy fields. There were ducks on the canals, graves and shrines in the light green rice fields, the dead among the living, not hidden but recalled daily. Women in conical hats pushed bicycles over rickety wooden bridges. The breeze was warm, the viscous coffee sweet. Cafes set with hammocks, some advertising Wi-Fi, offered sugar cane juice pressed through small hand-cranked mills. Everything felt liquid, soft, fluid here in the Mekong Delta, an aqueous microclimate.

title: Daily Report: Facebooks High-Stakes Bet on Drones to Deliver Internet Service
description: A V-shaped unmanned vehicle, which has about the wingspan of a Boeing 767 but weighs less than a small car, is the centerpiece of Facebooks plans to connect with the five billion or so people it has yet to reach, Quentin Hardy and Vindu Goel report.

title: Egypt Says It May Send Troops to Yemen to Fight Houthis
description: CAIRO  Egypt said Thursday that it was prepared to send troops into Yemen as part of a Saudi-led campaign against the Iranian-backed Houthi movement, signaling the possibility of a protracted ground war on the tip of the Arabian Peninsula.

title: Today in Politics: Health Fix Heralds Rare Moment of Congressional Compromise
description: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky is looking to capture some of the limelight seized by Senator Ted Cruz of Texas this week, while Mitt Romney seems to be enjoying the life of a noncandidate. Ben Affleck and Bill Gates have come to tell the Senate a thing or two about diplomacy and President Obama is leaving town for Birmingham, Ala., to highlight economic gains. And Congress appears to be on the brink of a bipartisan breakthrough.

title: Officers Race Matters Less Than You Think
description: This week, the Department of Justice released a report about use of force by the Philadelphia Police Department (P.P.D.). I found it fascinating, but not necessarily for the reasons that resonated in subsequent headlines.

title: N.C.A.A. Bracket Results: When Upsets Are a Good Thing
description: This years N.C.A.A. basketball upsets have ruined many brackets in traditional contests, but readers playing our risk-adjusted bracket game may see the surprises in a more positive light: as well-earned payouts to smart gambles.

title: A Town on New Yorks Hudson River Reinvents Itself
description: Curled along the Hudson River 150 miles north of Manhattan, Troy made shirt collars that could be detached and washed, back when such fashions were in vogue in the 19th century. When that look faded, Collar City hit a rough patch. But new stylish restaurants, quirky boutiques and a craft brewery in a downtown rich with Victorian architecture are helping Troy, population 50,000, become the latest Hudson Valley address to mount a comeback. A former department store is giving way to the Tech Valley Center of Gravity, a start-up incubator, which joins the Troy Savings Bank Music Hall, a Beaux-Arts stage for comedy, bluegrass and Bach.

title: High in the Mountains and Monasteries of Georgia
description: When paying so little for lodging, you can hardly complain if your host describes your homemade breakfast rather enigmatically, as Nana Kokiashvili, proprietor of Nanas Guest House in the walled hilltop town of Sighnaghi, Georgia, did when she brought it to us: Porridge, special stomach, maybe eat sugar, no sugar, tasting.

title: Prison Planet
description: Different nations take very different approaches to the convicts they deem the most dangerous. From Russias prison island to Saudi Arabias unexpectedly cushy cellblocks, here are some of the most notable.

title: Baby, Meet Iowa
description: We expected the baby in June, and our lease ended in July. Under the best of circumstances, I dread packing. To move is to endure a weekslong confrontation with your past selves and their poor consumer choices. You reckon with useless gifts retained from guilt, find birthday cards from the deceased. Now we were adding all that to the triage of newborn care.

title: Is Improving Schools All About Money?
Morning Agenda: Buffetts and 3Gs Bold Bet on Kraft Foods
description: BUFFETTS and 3GS BOLD BET ON KRAFT FOODS | The giant deal to merge H.J. Heinz and Kraft Foods is a big bet on conventional staples of the American cupboard, even as consumers are shifting away from processed foods,  David Gelles writes in DealBook.

title: Throwback Thursday | The Scopes Trial
description: On March 23, 1925, the State of Tennessee banned the teaching of evolution (PDF):

title: Matt Stainbrook Drives Strangers Around, and Xavier Onward
description: LOS ANGELES  Somewhere in suburban Cincinnati lives a woman who lost her job a few months ago and whose company, because she had car-pooled that day, arranged for her ride home. She was driven by Xaviers leading scorer and rebounder, a 6-foot-10, 270-pound Uber driver named Matt Stainbrook.

title: Is Mistress a Word That Has Seen Its Best Days?
description: Language evolves. Words come and go. And sometimes, as words go, they need a little push getting out the door.

title: Oil Prices Jump as Saudi and Yemen Fighting Escalates
description: LONDON  Oil prices rose sharply on Thursday amid concerns that fighting in the Arabian Peninsula between a Saudi-led coalition and Houthi rebels in Yemen could disrupt supplies.

title: U.S. Airstrikes on ISIS in Tikrit Prompt Boycott by Shiite Fighters
description: AL RASHID AIR BASE, Iraq  By Day 2 of the American airstrike campaign against militants holed up in Tikrit, the mission appeared beleaguered on several fronts on Thursday: Thousands of Shiite militiamen boycotted the fight, others threatened to attack any Americans they found, and Iraqi officials said nine of their fighters had been accidentally killed in an airstrike.

title: A Fortune Cookie Coincidence
description: Dear Diary:

title: A Good Kitchen on the Upper East Side
description: During her six years of graduate school in New York, Tracey Van Kempen lived in student housing.

title: A First Look at the Samsung Galaxy S6 and S6 Edge
description: As Samsung begins taking orders on Thursday for its new high-end phones, its only a slight exaggeration to say that this could be the South Korean electronics giants last best shot in the smartphone business.

title: With Chosen, American Idol Meets YouTube Meets Mobile Devices
description: Eventually, it seems, every successful form of entertainment gets its own app. Now it may be time for the mobile version of the TV talent show.

title: The Radical Humaneness of Norways Halden Prison
description: Like everything else in Norway, the two-hour drive southeast from Oslo seemed impossibly civilized. The highways were perfectly maintained and painted, the signs clear and informative and the speed-monitoring cameras primly intolerant. My destination was the town of Halden, which is on the border with Sweden, straddling a narrow fjord guarded by a 17th-century fortress. I drove down winding roads flanked in midsummer by rich green fields of young barley and dense yellow carpets of rapeseed plants in full flower. Cows clustered in wood-fenced pastures next to neat farmsteads in shades of rust and ocher. On the outskirts of town, across from a road parting dark pine forest, the turnoff to Norways newest prison was marked by a modest sign that read, simply, HALDEN FENGSEL. There were no signs warning against picking up hitchhikers, no visible fences. Only the 25-foot-tall floodlights rising along the edges hinted that something other than grazing cows lay ahead.

title: Inside Americas Toughest Federal Prison
description: In prison, Rodney Jones told me, everyone had a nickname. Joness was Saint Es, short for St. Elizabeths, the federal psychiatric hospital in Washington, best known for housing John Hinckley Jr. after he shot Ronald Reagan. Jones spent time there as well, having shown signs of mental illness from an early age; he first attempted suicide at 12, when he drank an entire bottle of Clorox. Later, he became addicted to PCP and crack and turned to robbery to support his habit.

title: Denmark Steps Into the Skinny Model Debate
description: The debate over skinny models is once again rearing its controversial head. After the news that France is considering a skinny models law, Denmark on Thursday entered the arena, albeit with a somewhat different strategic approach to the problem: one that focuses more on peer pressure withinthe industry and less on legislative pressure.

title: Writers Old and Young: Staring Across the Moat
description: A moat? Then is it no more than the venerable if tedious question of the generations, the superannuated versus the vernal? Or is it a more principled divide? Somewhere among the profusion of his essays Edmund Wilson describes the life span of magazines, how they mimic human life itself: they rise to their prime and gradually decline, until in their undeniable irrelevance they give up the ghost  after which they fade from discourse altogether. Where now is the American Mercury, where now is Partisan Review? And where, after its posthumous transmigration into a vertically integrated digital-media company, is The New Republic?

title: Shrinks, by Jeffrey A. Lieberman with Ogi Ogas
description: One of the most miserable experiences of my young adulthood, in the mid-1980s, was the year I spent in formal Freudian psychoanalysis. How well I remember lying on that uncomfortable couch with its built-in simulacrum of a pillow, as I struggled desperately to just let my mind go, to free associate, to disinter childhood memories or impulses that might prove remotely useful to me or at least satisfy my psychiatrist, who often seemed to be picking distractedly at lint on her skirt. She was a brilliant woman, no doubt about it, yet I always left her office feeling like a failure, and the science writer in me couldnt help wondering, Where is the clinical evidence that this excruciating and expensive ordeal really works?

title: Prosecutor: Co-Pilot Crashed Plane
description: Brice Robin, the chief Marseille prosecutor, said on Thursday the co-pilot of the Germanwings Airbus A320 deliberately crashed the plane that killed himself and 149 others aboard in the French Alps.

title: The 9/11 Survivor Tree Returns Home
description: For five years, I have been documenting the design and creation of the landscaping at the National September 11 Memorial plaza, the grove of swamp white oak trees planted in a green roof that shelters the 9/11 museum. Ive followed the growth and progress of these 400 trees, and the stories of the men and women who tended them and designed and built the plaza, in a feature-length documentary, The Trees.

title: At a Paris Museum, a Portrait of Tintin
description: The Herg Museum was created in 2009 in the cartoonists native Belgium, but people will be able to see his work in Paris at the Muse en Herbe through Aug. 31.

title: China Raids Offices of Rights Group as Crackdown on Activism Continues
description: BEIJING  Chinese security agents raided the offices of a leading human rights organization, according to its employees, the latest sign of the authorities mounting hostility toward nongovernmental groups, especially those that receive foreign funding or promote civic activism.

title: Obama and Pope Francis to Meet at White House
description: President Obama will meet with Pope Francis at the White House when the pontiff visits the United States in the fall, the White House said Thursday morning.

title: When the Curtain Never Comes Down at the American Folk Art Museum
description: A strange and wonderful view of outsider art.

title: 1940: Paris Subway as War Shelter
description: While Parisians have not become completely reconciled as yet to the restrictions which the war has imposed on the Mtro  their favorite means of transportation  it is beginning to be generally realized that in modern warfare the subway of a great city has functions even more important to fulfill than the mere conveyance of passengers. A recent survey reveals that the Paris Mtro, on its present war-footing, is equipped to give shelter during air-raids to 300,000 persons, while maintaining traffic between 211 stations on 90 miles of tracks.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 27, 1940

title: Review: A Strange and Wonderful View of Outsider Art
description: Performance art is all the rage these days, among museums, young artists and art students alike. Similarly, performative is the current buzzword  high praise even for traditional art objects. So it was probably inevitable that the performance-art lens would be turned on the complex realm of outsider art.

title: Haversham Holdings to Buy BCA Marketplace for $1.8 Billion
description: LONDON  Haversham Holdings said on Thursday that it had agreed to buy the British used car auctioneer and reseller BCA Marketplace in a cash and stock deal for 1.2 billion pounds, or nearly $1.8 billion.

title: South Korea Plans to Join Regional Development Bank Led by China
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea on Thursday became the latest American ally to announce its intention to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank despite Washingtons qualms about the Chinese-led regional development bank.

title: Kevin Love Shows What He Can Do as Cavaliers See What They Can Be
description: MEMPHIS  Kevin Love has spent large chunks of the season camped out in corners, waiting for passes that seldom arrive. It has been his traveling act with the Cleveland Cavaliers, who have no absence of scrutiny, and no player on the roster faces more of it than Love. Considering that the Cavaliers employ LeBron James, this is no small feat.

title: Sleep Training at  8 Weeks: Do You Have the Guts?
description: A few months ago, my husband and I took our newborn daughter to her two-month doctors appointment at Tribeca Pediatrics, the largest pediatric practice in New York City. We were feeling tired, but happy with our daughters progress. She was gaining weight, nursing like a champ, and  best of all  giving us six- to eight-hour stretches of sleep pretty consistently. When we told our pediatrician, she seemed less impressed.

title: Collages that Challenge the Perception of Private Moments
description: The photographer Charlie Engman forges a new visual language with images from that emerge from the edges of his consciousness.

title: Bargain Hunting With a Strong Dollar in Europe, but Finding a Mixed Bag
