description: JI-PARAN, Brazil  As the night sky enveloped this outpost in Brazils Amazon basin, the ceremony at the open-air temple began simply enough.

title: Ex-Yemeni Leader Urges Truce and Successors Ouster
description: CAIRO  Under pressure from a Saudi Arabian-led campaign of airstrikes, the former leader of Yemen who is backing the group that has seized the countrys largest cities said on Saturday that he was pleading for a truce, urging negotiations, but standing by demands for the ouster of his Saudi-backed successor.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photographers featured this week on @nytimes took viewers from an explosion in the East Village to a small village in Egypt.

title: Nigeria Votes in Sharply Contested Presidential Election
description: KANO, Nigeria  Eager voters waited to cast ballots all day as the most contested election in Nigerias post-independence history wound down to a tense conclusion on Saturday amid fears that the polarized electorate would clash regardless of the outcome in a country sharply split on ethnic and sectarian lines.

title: Strong Dollar Yields Savings From Tour Operators
description: With the dollar strengthening against many foreign currencies, travel abroad may be cheaper than in the past, inspiring tour operators to offer booking rebates and increase departures.

title: Stress and Hope In Tehran
description: As Iran and world powers including the United States try to reach a deal on nuclear controls in exchange for the lifting of sanctions, Iranians from all walks of life are watching and hoping for a new start.

title: Masquerading As a Two-Family Home
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: A.C.P.T. 2015: Welcome to the Show
description: SPECIAL POST  Stop me if youve heard this one. Its not so much a joke as a moment of recognition; a moment in a crowded elevator when you realize that, amongst a group of strangers, youre home.

title: Germanwings Pilot Andreas Lubitz Sought Treatment for Vision Problems Before Crash, Authorities Say
description: DSSELDORF, Germany  Andreas Lubitz, who was flying the Germanwings jetliner that slammed into a mountain in the French Alps on Tuesday, sought treatment for vision problems that may have jeopardized his ability to continue working as a pilot, two officials with knowledge of the investigation said Saturday.

title: After Germanwings Crash, a Week of Mourning and Questions
description: Memorial services were held for the victims as investigators looked into Andreas Lubitz, the co-pilot who plowed the plane into a mountain.

title: Two Men Remain Missing as Remnants of Explosion Are Scoured in Manhattan
description: With hopes fading in the search for two men who have been missing since an explosion jolted a stretch of the East Village, emergency workers on Saturday continued to scour the debris of the three buildings that were destroyed on Thursday in the blast and ensuing fire.

title: Somali Troops End Siege at Hotel as Death Toll Rises to 15
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Somali troops ended a 16-hour siege at a hotel in Somalias capital on Saturday, during which gunmen killed 15 people, officials said.

title: Spring Pasta Night!
description: Spring cooking means fresh vegetables and simple dishes. This week Martha Rose Shulman offers a new simple pasta dish with mussels. Its a meal that tastes like you went to a lot of work, but only you will know how simple it was to put it on the table.

title: Linda Zecher of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt: The Danger of One Size Fits All
description: This interview with Linda K. Zecher the chief executive of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, a publishing house that also provides educational content, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Variety: Marching Bands
description: Administrivial Get More Puzzles Alert! Do you love the Marching Bands variety puzzles as much as I do? The devious constructor and man-about-town Brendan Emmett Quigley is beginning a Kickstarter campaign that will result in a whole slew of these wonderful puzzles landing squarely in your email inbox every other week. Click here for more information.

title: At U.S. Companies, Time to Coax the Directors Into Talking
description: Its shareholder meeting season again, corporate Americas version of Groundhog Day.

title: Helping Veterans Get Hired
description: Nick Swaggert, 33, is the veterans program director for Genesis10, a technology staffing and services firm. He is based in its St. Paul office.

title: Wainwright House, a Haven for the Spirit on Long Island Sound
description: Before the second installment of Linda Richichis three-part Soul Vision workshop started at Wainwright House in Rye on a recent sunny Sunday, Joanne Mendola was feeling hopeful about dissolving what remained of her spiritual blockages.

title: Mild Winters and Crank Economics
description: Neil Irwin writes about migration patterns within the United States, and points out that they overwhelmingly reflect just two factors. Most important, people are moving to places with mild winters:

title: Make Way for Generation Z
description: I recall the exact moment the temperature changed in the workplace. It was 2005, and I was speaking to an audience of 100 young professionals. I was relating my experiences building a career as a Gen Xer (born 1964-79) in a world of traditionalists (born before 1945) and baby boomers (born 1946-63).

title: No. 2 Negotiators in Iran Talks Argue Physics Behind Politics
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland  At the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the mid-1970s, Ernest J. Moniz was an up-and-coming nuclear scientist in search of tenure, and Ali Akbar Salehi, a brilliant Iranian graduate student, was finishing a dissertation on fast-neutron reactors.

title: The Mystery of the Missing Mask
description: Our episode about one mans maddening efforts to get reimbursed by Optum, a health services provider, elicited some me too email from other frustrated and unhappy consumers. There was also an interesting email from a therapist, who asked that she not be identified, mostly because she could see no upside in speaking out against the company.

title: Iraqi Forces in No Hurry to Expel ISIS From Tikrit
description: TIKRIT, Iraq  Here at the headquarters of Iraqi ground forces, after three days of American airstrikes that at times witnesses here described as carpet bombing, Iraqs military seemed in no great hurry on Saturday to press its advantage.

title: Unreal Keynesians
description: Brad DeLong points me to Lars Syll declaring that I am not a real Keynesian, because I use equilibrium models and dont emphasize the instability of expectations.

title: A Wi-Fi Barbie Doll With the Soul of Siri
description: Ever since Siri appeared as a regular feature on the iPhone, certain young children  and, lets face it, some of their parents  have spent hours chatting up the virtual assistant, curious about the details of her humanoid back story.

title: In Bid to Inspire Faith in Senate, Kennedy Institute Has the Floor
description: BOSTON  When creators of the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate set out to rebuild the crumbling image of the worlds greatest deliberative body, they started from the ground up.

title: All Grown Up and In Charge of the Seder
description: EVERY person I know remembers a specific moment, a signpost marking the day, or the year, that childhood was left behind.

title: In the N.C.A.A. Tournament, Games Are Big, but Life Is Bigger
description: LOS ANGELES  The victories against Coastal Carolina and Oregon cleared Wisconsins path to the West Regional semifinal, but long after the details of the N.C.A.A. tournament games in Nebraska are lost to memorys slow leak, the Badger players will recall their go-karting excursion in Omaha.

title: A Review of Encore Bistro, in Rye
description: There must be a company called Parisian Bistro Decorators that specializes in giving American restaurants the look and feel of something approaching French charm. Diners can take it all in at Encore Bistro in Rye, with its white ceramic tile walls, black and white hexagonal tile floor, posters in saturated colors and a horizontal mirror over a long banquette. Additional niceties please as well, like the appealing bottles of tap water that arrive after orders have been taken and the dish towels that make sturdy napkins.

title: Sri Lankan Presidents Brother Dies From Ax Wounds
description: A brother of Sri Lankas president, Maithripala Sirisena, died on Saturday from severe head wounds he suffered in an ax attack two days earlier, according to a statement by the Sri Lankan government.

title: A.C.P.T. 2015: The Standings Emerge?
description: SPECIAL POST  With three puzzles in the bag, the standings are starting to be posted for Puzzle 1.

title: Athletes Finding Their Voice in Derek Jeters Digital Venture
description: David Ortizs blustery rant about being unfairly branded a cheater for testing positive for a banned substance in 2003 made newsThursday, not only for its strident tone, but for where it appeared.

title: The Chinese-Americans
description: A photographer explores his place in the countrys social landscape.

title: Embracing My Chinese-American Identity
description: WHEN I was in eighth grade, in Queens, in the early 2000s, I was often picked on by other children for my almond-shaped eyes, beige complexion and jet-black hair  essentially, my Chinese face. Theyd ask me if I ate vermin and felines and constantly mocked my native language. These adolescent experiences planted within me seeds of self-hatred, and for years I tried to rid myself of my cultural heritage.

title: Altered Visions and Changing Vistas
description: Ansel Adams, the master photographer of the American West, made small, soft-edged prints early in his career and high-contrast, large-scale prints later on. Michael Mattis, who with his wife, Judith Hochberg, owns the 41 early Adams prints (1920s to 1950s) now at the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages, compares the early prints to chamber music and the later ones to brass bands. (The analogies are apt, since Adams, who died at 82 in 1984, started out as a concert pianist.)

title: Campus Safe Spaces
description: Readers discuss whether colleges should be protecting students from distressing ideas.

title: Stand Up for Your Cats
description: TAYLOR SWIFT, I salute you.

title: Ready for 45?
description: MIAMI  JAMES BAKER can take credit for two presidencies and one vice presidency in the Bush family.

title: What Starbucks Is Ditching Along With CDs
description: I CURRENTLY possess around six large moving boxes of compact discs tossed beneath a tarp in the dank cellar of my apartment building. Since 1999, I have been receiving promotional copies of CDs, an occupational hazard of my job as a professional music critic.

title: The Method to Obamas Middle East Mess
description: LETS recap the state of Americas commitments in the Middle East. Our military is fighting in a tacit alliance with Iranian proxies in Iraq, even as it assists in a campaign against Iranian-backed forces in Yemen. We are formally committed to regime change in Syria, but were intervening against the regimes Islamist enemies. Our strongest allies, officially, are still Israel and Saudi Arabia, but were busy alienating them by pushing for dtente with Iran. And please dont mention Libya or Al Qaeda  youll confuse everyone even more.

title: Pregnant, Obese ... and in Danger
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  ONE recent night on my delivery shift, eight out of 10 of my laboring patients were too heavy, with two weighing over 300 pounds.

title: Progress on Payday Lending
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took the most important step in its brief four-year history this week when it issued a preliminary proposal aimed at protecting the working poor from the payday lending industry, which bills itself as a source of easy short-term loans but earns its profits by luring borrowers into debt traps. If finalized, rules based on this proposal would protect millions of people from deceptive, predatory loans that can wreck their already fragile finances. The bureau could better protect consumers by closing one loophole that would allow some lenders of relatively small amounts to keep making high-cost loans.

title: Preparing for Tomorrows Storms
description: Californians are understandably focused on the states severe drought, now in its fourth year. But drought is not the only environmental risk the states residents face.

title: Afghanistans Next Chapter
description: Now that President Obama has decided to slow the withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan, he and the new Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani, have an obligation to prove that the additional American investment will be worth it. It will not be easy, and it may not be possible. For more than a decade, the Afghan government has stubbornly resisted taking most of the political, economic and military steps needed to put the country on a firm footing.

title: Why Reconstruction Matters
description: THE surrender of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee at Appomattox Court House, 150 years ago next month, effectively ended the Civil War. Preoccupied with the challenges of our own time, Americans will probably devote little attention to the sesquicentennial of Reconstruction, the turbulent era that followed the conflict. This is unfortunate, for if any historical period deserves the label relevant, it is Reconstruction.

title: Katherine Meyer
description: Katherine Meyer is a Washington, D.C.-based lawyer who specializes in animal welfare, advocating on behalf of circus elephants, sea turtles and wild horses.

title: A Little Respect for Dr. Foster
description: ONE sign of a landmark shift in public attitudes: A poll last year found that Americans approved more of gays and lesbians (53 percent) than of evangelical Christians (42 percent).

title: Trying to Fool Cancer
description: CLEVELAND  WHEN it airs on Monday, the Ken Burns-produced documentary Cancer: The Emperor of All Maladies will emphasize how much more we now know about the genetic basis for cancer. This year, according to President Obama, cancer research and funding will focus on so-called precision, personalized or targeted medicine  using cancers molecular underpinnings to develop drugs that attack the genes or gene products that make up cancers factory while sparing normal cells. What a beautiful concept.

title: Tweeting Moms Goodbye
description: My mother finally closed her eyes amid the grim bleats of the intensive care unit for a little sleep. I slipped my hand from hers and sat back. I picked up my phone to call my wife but saw it was 3 in the morning. I looked at emails, but didnt really read them. Then I remembered something my mother had said a couple of hours before, as we knew our time together was winding down. It had made me smile; and now I sent out a tweet:

title: To Longtime Geno Auriemma Assistant, Theres No Better Place Than UConn
description: ALBANY  It is the little things that have kept Chris Dailey by Geno Auriemmas side for 29 years, and counting.

title: Coffeehouses Where the Brew Is as Crucial as the Bean
description: On a recent Saturday afternoon, Jenna Martiello, 20, sipped a cup of coffee and admired the nearly six-foot tall roaster occupying center stage at Gentle Brew Coffee, a little coffeehouse in Long Beach. The stainless steel roaster with blue enamel accents was as shiny as a new car parked in a living room, surrounded by cafe tables, chairs and several armchairs.

title: Plucking Notes, and Strings, of Long Ago
description: In 1640, Andreas Ruckers of Antwerp was producing harpsichords of such clarity and consistency that they were the envy of Northern Europe. Most of those harpsichords, like others of their vintage, have disappeared or been radically altered, sometimes with disastrous results.

title: Man Killed by Bus at Port Authority Terminal Is Identified
description: A man struck and killed by a bus at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan this week was identified by the authorities on Saturday as Samuel Rodriguez, 67, of Garrison, N.Y.

title: After Kleiner Trial, Expect Less Shooting From the Hip in Silicon Valley
description: SAN FRANCISCO  John Doerr really needed a win, and late Friday the esteemed venture capitalist got one of the biggest of his career: a jurys complete dismissal of gender discrimination claims against his firm, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.

title: A Review of Falls Village Inn Restaurant in Connecticut
description: One of the most stately buildings in Falls Village in the town of Canaan is the Falls Village Inn, built in the Italianate style in 1834. Nine years ago, the former stagecoach stop closed, was sold, and then reopened in 2010.

title: Playing Shortstop for the Mets, Wilmer Flores. Really? Yeah, Really.
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  A few weeks before spring training, Sandy Alderson, the Mets general manager, was summoned to jury duty at a Manhattan courthouse. At one point in the selection process, he was asked, What do you do in your spare time?

title: Review: At Le Malt, Food Makes an Appearance but Cocktails Rule
description: Daylight saving time had just begun as I drove Route 1 to Le Malt early one evening, and the sun slanted over the strip malls. Heaps of exhaust-stained ice were melting, and one could have leapt for joy. But instead I walked into a windowless, beige bunker that, from the outside, looks like nothing so much as a strip club. I blinked hard, waited for my pupils to triple in diameter. Goodbye daylight, goodbye saving.

title: A.C.P.T. 2015: Everyone Hates Puzzle 5
description: SPECIAL POST  Its a well-known fact that many people competing in the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament consider Puzzle 5 to be their personal Rubicon. Anyone can fill in as many squares as possible in Puzzles 1-4. If you make it through the devilishly hard Puzzle 5, youve crossed the line into hardcore solving.

title: No Winner or Loser When a No. 1 Pick Goes Under the Knife
description: In the movie The Program, Alvin Mack, a college linebacker played by the actor Duane Davis, appears destined for the N.F.L. That is, until a knee injury instantly rewrites his future. In a span of minutes, Mack goes from a potential first-round pick to a former player considering a future in coaching.

title: Privatization Memories
description: Dave Weigel has one of the more interesting Harry Reid retrospectives, focusing on his role in fighting back Bushs attempt to privatize Social Security  and in particular on the way he forged an alliance with liberal bloggers.

title: Air Conditioning and the Rise of the South
description: Just a short further note on this subject. (If youre wondering why Im doing posting so much on a Saturday, Im housebound with a cold, so why not?)

title: Elite Chess Teams Reach Final Four, Which Should Be a Quiet Affair
description: Elite college basketball programs are battling in the N.C.A.A. tournament this weekend to reach the Final Four. For fans of chess, the top four teams are squaring off now.

title: Henrik Lundqvists Return to Rangers Is Ruined by Bruins
description: BOSTON  Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist had waited almost two months for this day. Sidelined by a serious neck injury, he had gone through a couple of practices this week and was cleared to start Saturday against the Bruins.

title: Moving Onward With Cool Passion
description: Glaciers can be cool and awesome as they move inexorably onward. That may also describe Liz Gerrings glacier, as presented by her Liz Gerring Dance Company. Neither a choreographic travelogue nor a geological survey, Ms. Gerrings abstract dance demands cool passion of its eight dancers, requiring them to move with unbroken stamina but often at a far from glacial pace. Although it has nothing to do with ice and snow, glacier may nonetheless convey a sense of an awesome territory. Ms. Gerring has said that one of her inspirations was a memory of a visit to the vast North Dakota prairie where her mother grew up. Michael J. Schumachers taped score combines instruments like guitar, harp, cello, clarinet, recorder and piano with natural sounds recorded during a residency at Glacier Lake in Colorado. (Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday at 8 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, Chelsea; 212-242-0800, joyce.org.)

title: Neglected No More, A Rich Latin Legacy
description: Preparing for the Museum of Modern Arts Latin America in Construction: Architecture 1955-1980, which opens on Sunday, was a process of excavation. Barry Bergdoll, who organized the show with Carlos Eduardo Comas, Patricio del Real and Jorge Francisco Liernur, made multiple visits to the region, scouring architects offices, tracking down architects descendants and borrowing material from state archives.

title: A Last Call For Cougar Town
description: In the world of television, being flashy and new gets you attention. So does being dumb and tasteless. But what keeps TV percolating are the shows that fit neither profile; theyre just reliably good week after week, season after season. One of those, Cougar Town, has its final episode at 10:30 on Tuesday night on TBS.

title: Hollywood Hero Of the Second Rank
description: He wasnt ever as front-tier as Cary Grant or Jimmy Stewart, but Joel McCrea shared the same camera-ready ease and light touch that defined Hollywoods biggest stars as the studio system hit its stride in the 1930s and 40s. While directors from Alfred Hitchcock (Foreign Correspondent) to Preston Sturges  Sullivans Travels is, arguably, both mens greatest film  sought him out, McCrea, a natural-born horseman, focused on westerns for the later years of his career.

title: An Immersive History Lesson
description: The New Orleans-born pianist and singer Henry Butler, now in his mid-60s and a Brooklyn resident, delivers gigs as if they were full-immersion lessons: in old New Orleans repertory, gospel music, American theater songs, 1960s jazz, Southern rhythm and blues and soul. Hes a virtuosic pianist and a startling baritone singer; hes inevitably the focus of whatever bands he plays in, and exactly the right performer to hear playing unaccompanied, tracing a casually authoritative history of American music. At Mintons, the Harlem jazz club that has been tightening up its bookings in exciting ways, hell play on April 16, with sets at 7 p.m. and 11 p.m. (206 West 118th Street, 212-243-2222; mintonsharlem.com.)

title: A Worshiper At Bachs Altar
description: People are religious or not, but Bach makes you believe in something, and for sure, Lisa Batiashvili, the Georgian star violinist, said in a recent interview. A frequent guest soloist with the New York Philharmonic, she is the orchestras artist in residence this season. The run of concerts, conducted by Alan Gilbert, that begins on April 8 has a special significance for her. It features the music of Bach, which she only recently recorded after a long period of awe-struck distance, and brings her together, in Bachs gorgeous Concerto for Violin and Oboe, with her husband, the marvelous oboist Franois Leleux.

title: 7 Wounded in Spring Break Shooting in Florida
description: Spring break turned bloody when seven people in their early 20s were shot with a .40-caliber handgun early Saturday at a house in Panama City Beach, Fla. The shootings were described on an official Facebook page for Frank McKeithen, the Bay County sheriff.

title: Portraying Bill Bradley, a Star Who Had a Sense of Where He Was
description: As Harvard and Yale played for the Ivy League mens basketball title earlier this month at the Palestra in Philadelphia, the writer John McPhee, 84, was a block away at Franklin Field. As a faculty fellow of Princetons mens lacrosse team  which means, he said, I stand around looking interested  he watched the Tigers beat the Penn Quakers, 17-11.

title: Speed on Display at Retooled IndyCar
description: The IndyCar season finally arrives this weekend with a street race in St. Petersburg, Fla., featuring a familiar-looking cast of drivers but an array of perhaps less familiar Chevrolet- and Honda-powered machines.

title: For Golden State Warriors, Winning Isnt the Only Thing
description: MEMPHIS  What is most remarkable about the Golden State Warriors season has nothing to do with their N.B.A.-best record or their league-leading shooting percentages or the ease with which they regularly dismantle opposing teams of highly paid professionals.

title: A Franchise-Changing Player
description: Connor McDavid is only 18, but he is already being compared to some of the sports best players.

title: Hockeys Next Great One Draws a Crowd
description: ERIE, Pa.  For Connor McDavid, an 18-year-old center for the Erie Otters of the Ontario Hockey League and the most anticipated N.H.L. prospect in decades, compliments accrue as steadily as goals and assists.

title: Insurgents Seize Much of Key Syrian City
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A coalition of Islamist insurgents, including a branch of Al Qaeda, seized most of the northern Syrian city of Idlib on Saturday after four days of heavy fighting. It was an unusually dramatic front-line shift in a four-year war that has long appeared to be at a stalemate even as it grows more bloody and complex.

title: Big Decision (and Plenty of Advice) for Hockey Prospect
description: BOSTON  The image is a lasting one for David Quinn. He recalls a somewhat disheveled and unusually conversant Phil Kessel making a surprising confession during the 2007 world hockey championships.

title: California, Here I Come
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Todays puzzle is a letter-insertion theme by Alan Arbesfeld, wherein the state abbreviation for California, CA, is inserted at various points in phrases (for you kids out there, REALLY BIG SHEW at 82 Across is how 1950s  60s television host Ed Sullivan used to introduce his weekly variety show, SHEW being a mispronunciation of show.)

title: Tailoring His Message, Ted Cruz Makes His First Swing Through New Hampshire
description: GREENLAND, N.H.  When Senator Ted Cruz declared his candidacy for president, he said a broad coalition of courageous conservatives would carry him to the White House. On his first campaign swing through New Hampshire, a two-day trip that ended Saturday, he showed how he hoped to build that coalition.

title: Liberia Recommends Ebola Survivors Practice Safe Sex Indefinitely
description: The Liberian government recommended on Saturday that survivors of Ebola practice safe sex indefinitely, until more information can be collected on the length of time the virus might remain present in body fluids including semen. Previously, male survivors were advised to abstain from sexual intercourse or to use condoms for three months, reflecting that the active virus had been detected for up to 82 days in semen.

title: Wanted at the White House: A Fence That Says Halt! (With Curb Appeal)
description: WASHINGTON  Just after a Secret Service official shouted Go! and started a stopwatch, an agent hurtled toward a 10-foot-high fence with curving rods at the top.

title: Tribes See Name on Oregon Maps as Being Out of Bounds
description: Grant County, a mountainous patch of eastern Oregon, has few Native Americans, but maps point to a different past, marking a spring, a rock, three meadows and several creeks with squaw in their names.

title: Fragile Cease-Fire in Ukraine Inspires Little Confidence in West
description: BRUSSELS  No one really expects Ukraine to get better before it gets worse, or for the promises contained in last months cease-fire agreement to be kept.

title: A Divided Nigeria Chooses Its President
description: Voters cast ballots in the most contested election in Nigerias post-independence history.

title: A Franchise-Changing Player
description: Connor McDavid is only 18, but he is already being compared to some of the sports best players.

title: Before I Die
description: When doctors diagnosed Karly Koch with a rare genetic disorder, they also made a grim prognosis.

title: To Avert Repeat of 2008, Clinton Team Hopes to Keep Bill at His Best
description: Bill Clintons hearing has faded. With his head of white hair and frail frame, he looks older than his 68 years  truly grandfatherly, as one friend said. He often jokes about what would happen if he were to drop dead.

title: Irans Top Negotiator Says Accord Can Be Drafted
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland  Irans chief diplomat said on Saturday that he had had productive discussions with his European counterparts and that Iranian negotiators were ready to begin drafting an initial agreement on a nuclear accord.

title: In a Win Over Arizona, a Resounding Repeat for Wisconsin
description: LOS ANGELES  It felt familiar, on both ends of the court and across the spectrum of emotions.

title: Months Before East Village Blast, Utility Found Gas Line Was Tapped in Dangerous Way
description: More than seven months before an explosion and fire destroyed three buildings in the East Village on Thursday, utility workers discovered that the gas line to a restaurant in one of them had been tapped in a dangerous way, Consolidated Edison and the restaurants owner said on Saturday.

title: Germanwings Crash Raises Questions About Shifting Ideas of Pilot Fitness
description: Aviation agencies in Europe and the United States once banned all pilots from flying if they disclosed a mental illness to their employers.

title: Teenagers Face Early Death, on Their Terms
description: Tumors had disfigured AshLeigh McHales features and spread to her organs. A year ago, AshLeigh, 17, flew from her home in Catoosa, Okla., to the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., with a thread-thin hope of slowing her melanoma.

title: Residents in Eastern Ukraine City Rally Against Separatism
description: DNEPROPETROVSK, Ukraine  Residents of this city held what they called a unity rally on Saturday meant to help mend a rift between President Petro O. Poroshenko and the regional governor he fired and ease worries that Ukraine, on top of everything else, is also now at risk of unraveling into privately ruled fiefs.

title: Louisville Coach Rick Pitino Keeps Recalling How to Dream
description: SYRACUSE  Rick Pitino is 62 years old and has been a basketball coach since 1974. That is old enough to have had a handful of former players grow into established, veteran coaches. That is old enough to have a son as a coaching rival. It is old enough to have first sparred with the N.C.A.A. over allegations of recruiting violations 38 years ago  when the N.C.A.A.s first president was in office.

title: Haji Wright, a Rising 17-Year-Old American, Is Said to Join the Cosmos
description: As the goals piled up for Haji Wright, a rising star for the United States under-17 national team, the biggest question was whether he would continue his development in M.L.S. or leave for Europe.

title: Duke Turns Up the Heat With a Slap of the Floor
description: HOUSTON  Its precise origin is ambiguous. Even the man who introduced the tradition at Duke does not remember when it began or who did it first.

title: Australia to Join Regional Development Bank Led by China
description: BEIJING  Australia plans to join an Asian infrastructure bank led by China, the government announced on Sunday, reversing an earlier decision taken at the urging of the United States not to become a member. The move made Australia the latest of a list of major American allies to sign up.

title: Vin Scelsa, Host of Radios Idiots Delight, to Retire
description: Vin Scelsa, a master of free-form radio who has been a standby on New York radio stations for nearly 50 years, will retire on May 2 with the last installment of his long-running show, Idiots Delight, on WFUV, he announced on the air Saturday night.

title: Despite Inexperience, Materiality Wins Florida Derby With Stretch Run
description: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla.  No horse that went unraced as a 2-year-old has won the Kentucky Derby since Apollo in 1882. Todd Pletcher, winner of a record seven Eclipse Awards as the leading trainer in North America, may have a horse capable of overcoming that daunting history.

title: Almost 37-1, Kentucky Isnt Done, Holding Off a Fearless Notre Dame
description: CLEVELAND  When the final buzzer sounded and the desperation heave by Jerian Grant had gone safely long, the Kentucky players swarmed off the bench to jump and hug their victorious teammates on the floor, a signal of how close they had come to heartbreak.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 28, 2015
description: March 28, 2015

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 29, 2015
description: When I saw him as an adult compared to a youth, I thought, He really amounted to something. He was confident, helpful. I thought, Man, hes someone who made it.

title: New Path to the Same Spot for Arizona: Just Shy of the Final Four
description: LOS ANGELES  They played a game within the game Saturday at Staples Center. During breaks in the West Regional final between Wisconsin and Arizona, the giant video screens at midcourt showed two nearly identical pictures and asked, Whats the difference?

title: Without Much Ado
description: Timepieces so perfectly minimal they leave you wanting for nothing.

title: A Wedding Album to Savor
description: This month we asked our couples to dish about what they served at their receptions.

title: Ashley Etienne and Nigel Stephens
description: Ashley Danielle Etienne and Nigel Audley Stephens were married Friday in Rock Creek Park in Washington by the Rev. Maxine Reed-Vance, a minister affiliated with Grace Baptist Church in Baltimore.

title: Somjen Frazer and Andrea Bowen
description: Melanie Somjen Frazer and Andrea Majanik Bowen were married Saturday at St. Stephen and the Incarnation Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Frank Dunn, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Kristen Tracey and John Davies
description: Kristen Hamelin Tracey, a daughter of Marcia J. Hamelin and Dennis H. Tracey III of Weston, Conn., was married Saturday to John Oliver Davies, the son of Rebecca B. Davies and David O. Davies of Irving, Tex. The Rev. Dr. Shane Scott-Hamblen performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary-in-the-Highlands, where he is the rector, in Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: Deena Tauster, Peter Feldman
description: Deena Megan Tauster, the daughter of Michelle H. Tauster and Paul G. Tauster of Lido Beach, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Peter Garrett Feldman, a son of Lynn E. Feldman and Samuel F. Feldman of Allentown, Pa. Cantor Kevin Wartell officiated at the Park Hyatt in Washington.

title: Geri Hirsch,  Darin Friedman
description: Geri Hirsch and Darin Michael Friedman were married Saturday evening at Kayne Griffin Corcoran, a contemporary art gallery in Los Angeles. Rabbi Ken Chasen officiated at the ceremony, which was led by Haley Gilbert Fisher, a friend of the brides family and a cantorial soloist.

title: Nathan Cardin, Benjamin Procter
description: Nathan Benjamin Cardin and Benjamin Butin Procter were married Saturday evening at the Annenberg Community Beach House in Santa Monica, Calif. William Scott Calvert, a friend of the couple who was appointed a deputy marriage commissioner by the state, officiated.

title: Sherry Shore, Auren Kule
description: Sherry Melissa Shore and Auren Justin Kule were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Gary M. Bretton-Granatoor at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Laura Goldin, Kenneth Ames
description: Laura Rachael Goldin and Kenneth Scott Ames are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Shmuel Herzfeld at the Sixth & I Historic Synagogue in Washington.

title: Amy Farkas, Samuel Levy
description: Amy Rachel Farkas and Samuel Paul Levy are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Mayer Perelmuter at Liberty House in Jersey City.

title: Haley Moss, Asher Schranz
description: Dr. Haley Arden Moss and Dr. Asher Jacob Schranz are to be married Sunday by Rabbi William Berman at the Foundry, an event space in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Emily Abate, Joshua Guttman
description: Emily Anne Abate and Joshua Lee Guttman are to be married Sunday at Pioneer Works, Center for Art and Innovation, in Red Hook, Brooklyn. Rabbi Amichai Lau-Lavie is to officiate.

title: Lily Lorenzo, Bryan Boisi
description: Lily Elizabeth Lorenzo and Bryan Patrick Boisi were married Saturday at the Church of St. Thomas More in New York. The Rev. Edwin B. Diaz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Emily Hom and John Le Gall
description: Emily Katherine Hom and Dr. John Brian Le Gall were married Saturday at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County in California. The officiant was Karen Chin, a cousin of the groom, who was temporarily appointed a deputy commissioner of civil marriages by Santa Clara County.

title: Margaret Lam, Stanley Wong
description: Margaret Chiu-Leung Lam, the daughter of Christine C. Lam and Kin C. Lam of Boston, was married there Saturday evening to Stanley York Wong, the son of Elaine H. Wong and Norman S. Wong of Edison, N.J. The Rev. Enoch Y. Liao, a minister of the Boston Chinese Evangelical Church, officiated at the Lenox Hotel.

title: Brittany Freda,  A.J. Somers
description: Brittany Michelle Freda and Alexander Justin Somers were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Yaron Kapitulnik at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Joanna Lack and Brendan Lowe
description: Joanna Alexander Lack, the daughter of Pamela L. Goldman of Manhattan and Andrew R. Lack of Bronxville, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Brendan Robert Lowe, the son of Bettina C. Lowe and Dr. Michael R. Lowe of Cherry Hill, N.J. Rabbi Will Berkovitz officiated at Pioneer Works, Center for Art and Innovation, in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

title: Lauren Loeb, Keith Doll
description: Lauren Joy Loeb and Keith Andrew Doll were married Saturday at the Reeds at Shelter Haven, a hotel resort and private events space in Stone Harbor, N.J. Carlos Cuartas, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Ariella Morrow and Ryan Tolkin
description: Ariella Sarette Morrow, a daughter of Livia F. Morrow and Joel I. Morrow of Merrick, N.Y., was married in Aspen, Colo., Saturday evening to Ryan Andrew Tolkin, a son of Maggie L. Tolkin and Bradley J. Tolkin of Brookville, N.Y. Rabbi Itzhak Vardy officiated at the St. Regis Aspen Resort.

title: Friends, First and Always
description: Leah Frances Greenberg, a daughter of Sara B. Anderson and Mark H. Greenberg of Chevy Chase, Md., was married Saturday evening to Ezra Philip Levin, the son of Ronda Jones Levin of Buda, Tex., and Daniel D. Levin of Austin, Tex. The ceremony, at the Mexican Cultural Institute in Washington, was led by Tom Perriello, a former Virginia congressman who received authorization from the District of Columbia as a temporary officiant.

title: Kezia McKeague, Eric Gettig
description: Kezia Frances McKeague and Eric Thomas Gettig were married Saturday at Dahlgren Chapel of the Sacred Heart on the campus of Georgetown University in Washington. The Rev. Salvador R. Jordan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Without David Villa, New York City F.C. Falls to Sporting K.C.
description: The atmosphere was different on Saturday at Yankee Stadium for New York City F.C.s second home game. The buzz outside the stadium before the clubs March 15 home opener was missing this time, and with the upper deck closed and the stadium in its reduced soccer configuration, the match against Sporting Kansas City hardly felt like a special event.

title: Neville Wakefields Many Muses
description: From the toy sailboats he made as a boy to the large-scale installations hes overseen in his career, the art world curator credits his rural childhood and his own children for sharpening his keen aesthetic.

title: Latin Glamour
description: Modern architects, artists and designers find inspiration in the colorful, sensuous landscapes and indigenous flora of the region south of the border.

title: Loving the Unlovable Decade
Air Canada Plane Lands Short of Runway in Nova Scotia
description: OTTAWA  An Air Canada Airbus A320 landed in an antenna array 1,100 feet short of a runway in Halifax, Nova Scotia, early Sunday morning, shearing off its landing gear, accident investigators said.

title: Notre Dame Is Just the Latest to Almost Defeat Kentucky
description: CLEVELAND  The most consistent lament of Kentuckys opponents this season has been, Almost.

title: Corrections: March 29, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) GOING CLEAR: SCIENTOLOGY AND THE PRISON OF BELIEF (2015) The Oscar-winning documentarian Alex Gibney directs this film about the Church of Scientology, based on Lawrence Wrights book Going Clear. Details about the church (above, its building in Los Angeles), which was founded by the science-fiction writer L. Ron Hubbard, are revealed through profiles and interviews with former members including the Oscar-winning screenwriter Paul Haggis. Drawing from a trove of archival material, including filmed interviews with Mr. Hubbard, Mr. Gibney paints a profile of a church that grew by leaps and bounds through profound faith and drag-out fights, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Gibney spends a lot of time on Scientologys celebrities, but those sections of the film pale next to the harrowing allegations of the churchs serious physical and psychological abuse, including exploited labor.

title: Beef Ban in India Reaches Into Cages of Lions and Tigers
description: MUMBAI, India  Palash, the largest tiger at the Sanjay Gandhi National Park in Mumbai, still paces his cage for the hour leading up to dinner and still pounces on his meal when his handlers lift the gate to his feeding room. But lately what the 440-pound feline finds is not his usual 15 pounds of raw beef, fresh from the slaughter.

title: For Hardware Makers, Sharing Their Secrets Is Now Part of the Business Plan
description: Facebook showed plans last week for drone aircraft that beam lasers conveying high-speed data to remote parts of the world.

title: Singapores Lee Kuan Yew, in His Own Words
description: The founder and first prime minister of Singapore, Lee Kuan Yew, was known for his blunt and pithy honesty, died in March 23 at the age of 91. Below are some of his memorable quotes.

title: Singaporeans and World Leaders Gather for Final Farewell to Lee Kuan Yew
description: SINGAPORE  Thousands of Singaporeans braved a torrential downpour on Sunday for a final farewell to the countrys founding prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew, whose funeral drew a long list of leaders and dignitaries from across the globe.

title: 1940: Russell Refutes Nudism Charge
description: NEW YORK  Bertrand Russell, British philosopher and peer, whose appointment as professor on the faculty of the New York City College was confirmed by the Board of Higher Education March 19 after a state-wide controversy, today [March 29] emphatically denied that he had ever conducted a nudist colony in England or gone in for salacious poetry, in answering charges made against him by Mrs. Jean Kay, wife of a Brooklyn dentist. After the board upheld the appointment by an 11-to-3 vote, Mrs. Kay, who said she was acting for irate taxpayers, gave the board eight days in which to show the action was not contrary to the public interest, before she resorted to legal action.

title: The Truck That Sparked Our Marriage Back to Life
description: When my husband was transferred back to the United States for work after we had been living in Germany for four years, we bought a house and moved in with our children and our dog. My parents donated their used minivan to our family cause, and we parked it in our new driveway, exhaling with relief. Life would be so much easier now, I thought.

title: A.C.P.T. 2015: Headed to the Big Boards
description: SPECIAL POST  Good morning! As the bleary-eyed competitors file into the ballroom at the Stamford Marriott, the large, final round boards are being built in a staging room behind the scenes.

title: Question in Boston Bombing Trial: For Tsarnaev to Testify or Not
description: BOSTON  He swaggers into the courtroom. Freed of handcuffs and leg manacles, he occasionally taps the witness box on his way to the defense table, where he takes his place between two lawyers. During most of the proceedings, he slouches in his chair like a bored student, picking at his goatee, his mind somewhere else.

title: An Ask Me Anything Chat on Climate Science and Coverage
description: The event described below has taken place and the video is now posted here:

title: Citi Bike Resumes Service After Weekend Maintenance
description: New York Citys bike-sharing program was up and running on Sunday after abruptly shutting down for part of the weekend.

title: A.C.P.T. 2015: The Tension Mounts
description: SPECIAL POST  Its currently unconfirmed, but the buzz amongst the judges is that there might be an upset in the top ranks.

title: Rising From Wreckage, Australia Sweeps to World Cup Title
description: Australia completed its climb from the depths to the heights of world cricket on Sunday when it won its fifth World Cup, defeating New Zealand by seven wickets in the final at the Melbourne Cricket Ground.

title: Arab Nations to Form Military Force to Counter Iran and Islamist Extremists
description: CAIRO  The Arab states said on Sunday that they had agreed to form a combined military force to counter both Iranian influence and Islamist extremism, a gesture many analysts attributed in large part to their drive for more independence from Washington.

title: Flea Theater Names Niegel Smith as Next Artistic Director
description: The Flea Theater, an Off Off Broadway company that proudly embraces being named for an irksome insect, has chosen a new artistic director who promises to continue producing risky theater while also seeking to reach out to families when the organization moves into a new TriBeCa home.

title: Talking Econoheads
description: A couple of events I was involved in are now online:

title: 1965: Pope Seeks Urgent Review of Birth Control Ban
description: VATICAN CITY Pope Paul VI has called for utmost urgency in reviewing the Catholic ban on birth control because the church cannot ignore the population explosion, the Vatican reported today [March 29]. The pontiff, in a speech to his secret birth-control commission, said the church must give absolutely clear indications on the controversial issue. The Pope stressed that thechurch owes an answer to the world and to men and women whose married life is too often impeded by uncertainties fromdeveloping according to the design of God. Pope Paul told over50 members of the international commission on Saturday to let mature what must mature, but you must understand the anguishof many souls. Work diligently without attention to criticism and difficulty. He added that the church at all times took care to give an adequate reply to the great problems facing men. The Vatican communiqu, released today, revealed that there were three married couples as well as other laymen on the commission, which includes doctors, psychologists, sociologists, population and family planning experts and theologians.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 30, 1965.

title: Pratt Institute to Offer Masters With a Focus on Public Space
description: Pratt Institutes Architecture School this fall plans to start a masters program in Urban Placemaking and Management, led by David Burney, the citys former commissioner in the department of design and construction.

title: After Outcry Over Pink Sculpture, Queens Councilman Wants Public Hearing on City Art Plans
description: After an outcry over a plan to install a boldly colored, government-financed sculpture in Queens, a councilman intends to submit a bill to the City Council this week that would allow for more public comment on public art commissions.

title: Gene Saks, Tony-Winning Director of Neil Simon Hits, Dies at 93
description: Gene Saks, an actor who switched to stage and film directing in midcareer, winning three Tony Awards and becoming the leading interpreter of the plays of Neil Simon, died on Saturday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 93.

title: OMalley Speaks Out Against Possible Dynastic Rematch for White House
description: Former Gov. Martin OMalley of Maryland, who has been promoting himself to Democrats as a potential alternative to Hillary Rodham Clinton in the 2016 race for the White House, on Sunday spoke out against the possibility of a dynastic rematch between Mrs. Clinton and Jeb Bush.

title: Family-Friendly Home Takes Top Box Office Spot
description: The crude Get Hard, a Warner Bros. effort described by some critics as homophobic and borderline racist, was cowed at the weekend box office by Home, a family-friendly adventure from DreamWorks Animation.

title: A.C.P.T. 2015: And the Winner Is
description: SPECIAL POST  Congratulations to Dan Feyer, the winner of the 38th American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, as well as to all who came to Stamford, Connecticut to be part of the fun. Dan took the championship away from Tyler Hinman yet again, with just a half second lead. Thats about as exciting as it gets without a total upset.

title: Cyclone Roller Coaster at Coney Island Gets Stuck at Top of Track
description: The Cyclone roller coaster at Coney Island got stuck near the top of its track on Sunday, marring its season debut and forcing passengers to walk down the tracks to safety, an amusement park official said.

title: Sullivan Fortner Wins 2015 Cole Porter Fellowship in Jazz
description: Sullivan Fortner has won the 2015 Cole Porter Fellowship in Jazz, presented by the American Pianists Association. The honor was awarded on Saturday night at the Hilbert Circle Theater in Indianapolis, after a final round of performances by the five finalists in competition. As the winner, Mr. Fortner will receive $50,000, the opportunity to record for Mack Avenue Records, and two years of professional career services and development.

title: Before Starbucks, a Bronx Cafe Blended Coffee and Racial Dialogue
description: Vernicia Colon did not know whether to be angry, amused or flattered when Starbucks announced its campaign to prompt barista-led conversations on race. She knew the complexities of being an overlooked other in the usual black-white discussions, and not just because she is the child of a Puerto Rican mother and a black father.

title: Boehner Reflects on Bipartisan Support for Medicare Bill
description: Lately, in the House of Representatives, all it takes to claim a major success is a bill passed with support from both Republicans and Democrats.

title: Operation Dragoon Ride
description: The commander of United States Army forces in Europe conceived of the convoy as people in Poland and elsewhere grew increasingly anxious about Russias intentions amid the long conflict in Ukraine.

title: An American Military Convoy in Europe Aims to Reassure Allies
description: DRAWSKO POMORSKIE, Poland  The line of 4-year-olds clutched hands tightly in their matching, reflective yellow vests and stared open-mouthed at the hovering Chinook helicopters kicking up grit last week in the school parking lot. Shy teenage girls took pictures beside grinning American soldiers while Polish families clambered over a line of Stryker armored vehicles.

title: Two Bodies Recovered at East Village Explosion Site
description: As firefighters worked on Sunday afternoon to pull two bodies from the scene of an explosion that demolished three buildings in the East Village, a brother of one of the men reported missing in the blast urged his friends and relatives not to give up hope.

title: Germanwings Crash Investigators Sorting Through Physical and Psychological Clues
description: DSSELDORF, Germany  As aviation experts in the French Alps piece together the shattered fragments of the Germanwings jetliner that crashed there on Tuesday, investigators here are engaged in a task that is at least as challenging: trying to understand what drove Andreas Lubitz, who was at the controls, to the apparent decision to fly the plane into a mountainside.

title: Review: So Youve Been Publicly Shamed Delves Into Infamy in the Age of Social Media
description: One of the people Jon Ronson interviewed for his latest book asked him a tough question. Given that my previous books were about such frivolous topics as military psychics (The Men Who Stare at Goats) and conspiracy theorists (Them: Adventures With Extremists), why did I suppose my readers would be interested in the important question of public shaming? Mr. Ronson was asked. Since his writerly persona is that of a stellar entertainer-explorer-clown, humiliation does seem weightier and less breezy than what he usually likes to handle.

title: Jacoby Swiss Teams Winners at the Spring Nationals
description: On March 22, the final day of the Spring Nationals in New Orleans, the Jacoby Swiss Teams was captured by Richie Schwartz of Aventura, Fla.; Allan Graves of St. Johnsbury, Vt.; Boye Brogeland and Espen Lindqvist from Norway; and Lotan Fisher and Ron Schwartz from Israel.

title: Michigan State Outlasts Louisville to Advance to the Final Four
description: SYRACUSE  The moment was worth savoring, so Michigan State stayed on the court long after the final buzzer sounded, the nets came down and Travis Trices back began tightening up enough to almost double him over. Matt Costello skipped around, and Lourawls Nairn Jr. wept. They stayed until there was no one left to hug. Then they went into the locker room and hugged some more.

title: Laura Marling Bids Goodbye to All That
description: The British singer-songwriter has always been precocious, down to her (very productive) midlife crisis at 23.

title: Review: A Present-Day Parsifal With a Nod to the Past
description: BERLIN  Dmitri Tcherniakovs suggestive yet stolid production of Wagners Parsifal, which opened on Saturday at the Staatsoper here, doesnt begin in a forest, as the libretto indicates. But it otherwise conforms to the description provided in the text: a scene shady and solemn, but not gloomy. The audience enters with the curtain already up on a great hall lined with columns joined by high arches, the smoky air cut by a thick shaft of afternoon light.

title: Review: Title Fight Trades Urgency for Depth at Webster Hall
description: Toward the end of Title Fights Friday night set at Webster Hall, Ned Russin, one of the bands two singers, introduced Rose of Sharon, a song from the bands new album, with a bit of hushed reverence.

title: Review: The Tempest Songbook Closes Gotham Chamber Operas Season
description: When the New York City Opera closed in 2013, talk soon started within opera circles about which smaller companies might be able to fill the void. There was special focus on the enterprising Gotham Chamber Opera. But its directors said that they had to be careful not to build beyond the companys means.

title: Globally Minded Books Win Bancroft Prize
description: Books on the international cotton trade and on the shipboard slave revolt that inspired Herman Melvilles short story Benito Cereno have won this years Bancroft Prize, considered one of the most prestigious honors in writing about history. Sven Beckerts Empire of Cotton: A Global History, published by Alfred A. Knopf, was cited as a masterful achievement in the burgeoning field of the study of capitalism. It was researched in archives on four continents, to provide a deeper understanding of the commodity that shaped the story of slavery, the Civil War and Reconstruction. Greg Grandins Empire of Necessity: Slavery, Freedom, and Deception in the New World, published by Metropolitan Books/Henry Holt, was similarly cited for its effort to decenter the history of African slavery in the Americas, while also telling a gripping story of the complex processes that brought a crew of New England seal hunters into fateful contact with a Spanish ship under the invisible control of the enslaved men and women it was supposed to be transporting. The prize, which comes with a $10,000 award, was established in 1948 by the Columbia University trustees with a bequest from the historian Frederic Bancroft.

title: At Yale, a New Home for Lincoln Portraits
description: The rare book and manuscript library at Yale has bought a vast private collection of photographs devoted primarily to Lincoln and the Civil War.

title: Yales Beinecke Library Buys Vast Collection of Lincoln Photos
description: Abraham Lincoln last visited New Haven in March 1860, when, as a likely presidential candidate, he gave a speech on slavery. He is now set for a triumphal return.

title: Hot Bench, a Court Show From Judge Judy, Is a Surprise Hit
description: LOS ANGELES  A plaintiff shuffled onto a courtroom set at Sunset Bronson Studios here with a simple complaint. She had lent money to a shady guy who  shocker  turned out to be a total deadbeat.

title: Review: Miami City Ballet in Heatscape, a Fleeting Chase of Romance
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  No ballet by the 27-year-old choreographer Justin Peck is much like another; with each assignment he sets himself new choreographic hurdles. But Mr. Peck has quickly become the most eminent choreographer of ballet in the United States  and two particular characteristics have propelled him to the top: the exciting formal architecture of his dances and the kinesthetic thrill of his movement.

title: Review: In Weird Loners, Four Single New Yorkers Dodge Commitment
description: Among televisions current epidemics  zombies, serial killers, reality-show families with gigantic numbers of children  one is easy to overlook: rootless single characters reluctant to commit to love or anything else. Undateable. About a Boy. The recently departed Mulaney. And so on.

title: Review: The Dovekeepers, a CBS Mini-Series Starring Cote de Pablo
description: Whatever happened to Ziva? Those still wondering can rest easy. She has been located on a mountaintop in the first century A.D.

title: 2016 Hopefuls and Wealthy Are Aligned on Inequality
description: Appearing at a candidate forum in late January, three likely Republican presidential contenders  Senators Ted Cruz, Marco Rubio and Rand Paul  all made a striking confession: They considered the increasing gap between rich and poor to be a problem.

title: No Net Ensnares Me
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Bruce Haight seems to be vying with Elizabeth Gorski for the title of grid artist, albeit in 1515 grids. Today, Mr. Haight takes flight with a puzzle that is all about our avian friends. Either that, or hes launched a whole lot of boomerangs. Im going to go with the bird theory.

title: News Companies See Movies as Opportunity for Growth
description: LOS ANGELES  When the digital wizards at a forward-leaning media company last year introduced their newest idea, an entertainment unit, they couldnt resist an antique touch: BuzzFeed Motion Pictures arrived with a video logo modeled on images from a primitive movie projector called a zoopraxiscope, invented by one Eadweard Muybridge, circa 1879.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of March 30
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: A Deadline for Greece, and U.S. Jobs Data
description: Here are some of the top business stories to pay attention to in the coming week.

title: Share the Pork, Be President for Life
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The Republic of Congos ruling party just joined the long list of regimes in Africa that are pushing to change constitutions to alter term limits and permit sitting leaders to extend their stays in office. The countrys 2002 Constitution limits the number of presidential terms to two. Now the Congolese Labor Party has had second thoughts, and is seeking to amend the law so that, the opposition says, President Denis Sassou Nguesso will be able to run for a third term.

title: In Delaying Vote on Loretta Lynch as Attorney General, G.O.P. Is in a Quandary
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans bolted for a two-week spring recess with the confirmation of Loretta E. Lynch as attorney general in jeopardy, and themselves in a quandary: Accept a qualified nominee they oppose because she backs President Obamas policies or reject her and live with an attorney general they despise, Eric H. Holder Jr.

title: Uzbeks Vote on Expected 4th Term for Authoritarian Leader
description: TASHKENT, Uzbekistan  Uzbeks went to the polls in droves on Sunday for an election in which the result was a foregone conclusion: maintaining President Islam Karimov in power in the authoritarian Central Asian state, which he has led since 1989.

title: Austerity, Big and Small
description: At this point its fairly common to look at the effects of austerity via cross-country scatterplots: one axis shows some measure of fiscal consolidation, while the other shows the change in GDP. Who started this practice? I think I did, here, although Im happy to cede credit to someone else if I missed it.

title: Duke Defeats Gonzaga to Advance to Its 16th Final Four
description: HOUSTON  Every day for the last two years, Quinn Cook has thought about one game, and it is not a game that he enjoys reliving. He remembers the confetti falling and Louisville celebrating and his Duke teammates consoling one another. Their faces, the sadness, he will never forget.

title: On Obama Delaying the Afghanistan Pullout
description: President Obama has decided to slow the withdrawal of troops from the country.

title: Official Says Commander of Group That Massacred 21 in Tunisia Is Dead
description: TUNIS  Tunisian security forces have killed the commander of the group responsible for the recent massacre of 21 foreign tourists at the National Bardo Museum, Tunisias prime minister, Habib Essid, announced on Sunday.

title: Grown-Ups Get Out Their Crayons
description: It may surprise fans of Johanna Basfords intricately hand-drawn coloring books that the artist is, by her own admission, pretty bad at coloring.

title: Secrecy on the Set: Hollywood Embraces Digital Security
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For years, Lulu Zezza has played one of the toughest roles in Hollywood.

title: Which States Make Life Easier or Harder for Illegal Immigrants
description: How different laws affect unauthorized immigrants in each state.

title: States Are Divided by the Lines They Draw on Immigration
description: Washington has long allowed immigrants without legal status to get drivers licenses. So Ofelia Rosas Ramos, a Mexican living illegally in Seattle, has had her license since 2008.

title: So Far, So Good: Alex Rodriguez Has Been on His Best Behavior
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  When Baltimore Orioles Manager Buck Showalter was asked his assessment of Alex Rodriguez, who had homered against his team Saturday, he paused to think. He asked some questions of his own. He offered a quip.

title: New York States Medical Marijuana Rules Shaping Up as Unusually Restrictive
description: ALBANY  When New York States lawmakers were mulling legalizing the medical use of marijuana last summer, some proponents feared that the proposed law was so restrictive that it would prevent many patients from receiving the drug.

title: Diversity in the Toss-Up States
description: Should Jeb Bush or Scott Walker become the Republican presidential nominee, their paths to victory would look very different.

title: Conservative Alliance Gains in French Voting
description: PARIS  The clear winner in the second round of Frances local elections on Sunday was an alliance of conservative parties that took control of at least two-thirds of the countrys departments, trouncing the Socialists.

title: Foreclosure to Home Free, as 5-Year Clock Expires
description: MIAMI  In September, Susan Rodolfi celebrated an unusual anniversary: five years of missed mortgage payments.

title: Jeb Bush and Scott Walker Point G.O.P. to Contrary Paths
description: HUDSON, N.H.  As Jeb Bush mingled with Hispanic workers on a company tour a few weeks ago on his first trip here as an all-but-declared candidate for president, he was able to guess the region in Colombia where one woman was born just from hearing her accent.

title: A Carriage Horse Drivers Viewpoint
description: Dear Diary:

title: Shooters Cant See? Fans, Cover Your Eyes
description: HOUSTON  A huge black curtain looms at each end of the raised court, creating an illusion that players are launching jump shots deep into another galaxy. Lights appear to give off an unusually strong glare, as if signaling a taverns last call or the intermission of a play.

title: Germanwings Crash Settlements Are Likely to Vary by Passenger Nationality
description: The extraordinary circumstances that led to last weeks crash of the Germanwings jet, where a pilot seemingly brought down an airplane, killing everyone aboard, means that the airlines insurers could end up paying hundreds of millions of dollars to the victims families, according to legal experts.

title: Popular Demand
description: Worldwide revenue in February for digital console games, which covers downloadable content played on machines like Playstation or Xbox connected to TV monitors, was $233 million, down 3.7 percent from February 2014.

title: Bumpy Road for Bill to Ban Credit Checks for Job Applicants
description: For nearly a year now, advocates for struggling New Yorkers have argued that the stars were aligned for passage of a powerful pro-worker statute: A law that would prohibit employers from denying jobs to applicants with poor credit histories.

title: Rangers Fall Flat at the End of a Lost Weekend
description: After a game to forget Saturday in Boston and a lackluster third period Sunday, the Rangers find themselves suddenly mired in a rare losing streak.

title: Jet Crash TestsGermanys Faith in Its Precision
description: BERLIN  Even in the nightmarish immediate aftermath of the plane crash in the French Alps on Tuesday, Carsten Spohr, the former pilot who runs Germanys Lufthansa airline, was sure of one thing: the co-pilot, Andreas Lubitz, 27, was 100 percent fit to fly.

title: Iran Backs Away From Key Detail in Nuclear Deal
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland  With a negotiating deadline just two days away, Iranian officials on Sunday backed away from a critical element of a proposed nuclear agreement, saying they are no longer willing to ship their atomic fuel out of the country.

title: With Late Surge, South Carolina Earns Its First Final Four Berth
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  There are only a handful of elite programs in womens college basketball, and every year, it seems, those same teams run through the N.C.A.A. tournament on the way to the round of 8 and the Final Four.

title: Win Is a Win, as the Nets Continue a Playoff Push
description: The Nets met the Los Angeles Lakers, one of the worst teams in the N.B.A., at Barclays Center on Sunday and had somewhat more trouble than they would have liked on their way to a 107-99 victory. But as they approach their final 10 games, tussling for one of the last playoff spots in the Eastern Conference, they will take every victory they can get, pretty or not.

title: Missouri Candidate Picks Up Where She Left Off After Rivals Suicide
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo.  Ever since Tom Schweich, Missouris auditor and a candidate for the Republican nomination for governor, took his own life in late February, his leading primary opponent, Catherine Hanaway, has quietly avoided the campaign trail.

title: Woman Killed in Kabul Transformed From Pariah to Martyr
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In indignant tones, the Islamic law student told her family about the superstitious practices she had witnessed earlier that day at a historic shrine in Kabul.

title: In Westchester, a Skinny House With Big Aims Vies for a Spot in History
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y.  The red-shingled house on Grand Street shares several attributes with its neighbors. It has three stories, a full basement, hardwood floors and a neat yard.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 30, 2015
description: The court will proceed to gargle in an effort to remove the lingering bad taste.

title: Indiana Governor Says Legislators May Clarify Religious Beliefs Law
description: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, moving to address a growing political firestorm over a religious freedom law enacted last week, said over the weekend that he would seek legislation to clarify the intent of the law, and rejected assertions that it sanctioned discrimination against gays and lesbians.

title: Turkey Moves to Close All Gates at Border With Syria
description: ISTANBUL  After maintaining an open-door policy throughout the four-year conflict in neighboring Syria, Turkey has moved this month to close the two remaining border gates between the countries, shutting out displaced Syrian refugees amid fears of a potential terrorist attack.

title: Wisconsins Frank KaminskyHopes for a Hollywood Ending
description: LOS ANGELES  An ascendant star heads west, with his best friends in tow, to Tinseltown, where boom times and madcap adventures await. As that star, Frank Kaminsky, winds down his Wisconsin basketball career, his life has begun to resemble one of his favorite television series, Entourage, right down to the guest appearance by a celebrity playing himself.

title: Review: Twelfth Night, in Two Plays, Blurs Identity
description: Every so often, evidence arises that acting might just be the most satisfying profession on the planet. Take the company called Bedlam, which is putting on not one but two inspired productions of Shakespeares Twelfth Night in a small and airless room in the garment district that seats about 50, and making you feel like its members are the luckiest people alive.

title: Russian Theater Director Fired for Offending Christians
description: MOSCOW  In the latest skirmish between the Russian Orthodox Church and the cultural elite, the culture minister on Sunday fired the director of a Siberian theater who included a controversial interpretation of the life of Jesus in the Richard Wagner opera Tannhauser.

title: The Good Wife Recap: Absence of Yes
description: Season 6, Episode 17: Undisclosed Recipients

title: Bronx Son of Yankees Fans Rekindles Fathers Dream With the Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Its been a long road from the Bronx to Queens, measured not in miles, but in lifetimes.

title: Deal Is Reached onNew York State Budget; Ethics Measures Are Included
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders on Sunday night reached an agreement on the next state budget, capping weeks of deliberations over issues like deterring public corruption and improving public schools.

title: Slater and Gordon, Australian Law Firm, to Acquire Arm of Quindell of Britain
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Slater and Gordon, the Australian law firm that was the first in the world to list on a stock exchange, said on Monday that it planned to buy the professional services unit of Quindell for 637 million pounds, or about $947 million, to become Britains leading personal injury law firm.

title: Off the Dribble and Into a Firestorm in Indiana
description: In an interview with The Indianapolis Star on Sunday, Mike Pence, the Republican governor of Indiana, tried to extricate himself from a cage of intolerance and divisiveness into which he had put himself and his state. After coming under ferocious criticism from around the country, he said that he would now support legislation to clarify that the states new Religious Freedom Restoration Act, which he signed into law last week, would not discriminate against gays and lesbians.

title: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard
description: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert weigh in on some of the contenders for the 141st Kentucky Derby, which is set to be run May 2.

title: Notre Dames Heartbreaking Defeat Should Hearten Wisconsin
description: CLEVELAND  In Notre Dames locker room after Saturday nights loss to Kentucky, the whiteboard still bore the coaches talking points in black Sharpie. On offense: Great Movement=Great Shots. On defense, the only instruction underlined in blue was Level 5 Team Rebounding.

title: Clinton Wants to Improve Ties With Israel
description: Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton told a representative of a group of prominent Jewish leaders on Sunday that she wanted to put the relationship between the United States and Israel back on constructive footing, the representative said.

title: Roger L. Mayer, Pioneer of Film Preservation, Dies at 88
description: Roger L. Mayer, a film executive who was instrumental in preserving and restoring countless classic movies and who also courted controversy by coloring some black-and-white ones, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 88.

title: De Blasio to Name Former Right-Hand Man of Boston Mayor as His Chief of Staff
description: Earning a place in Mayor Bill de Blasios close-knit inner circle is not easy. In choosing top aides, the mayor often seeks municipal know-how, liberal bona fides and the approval of those he trusts.

title: GNC to Strengthen Supplement Quality Controls
description: GNC, the countrys largest specialty retailer of dietary supplements, has agreed to institute sweeping new testing procedures on its herbal products that far exceed quality controls mandated under federal law.

title: Word of the Day | douse
description: douse  \daus also dauz\  verb

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 8:30 P.M. (ABC Family) THE GOONIES (1985) Richard Donner directed, Chris Columbus wrote the screenplay and Steven Spielberg wrote the story for this classic buddy adventure. Friends in Astoria, Ore., face the glum prospect of having their group broken apart as a country club tries to build a golf course on their properties. They a map they believe will lead them to buried treasure with which they can buy off the country club and keep their homes. They set off in search of the treasure. The Goonies themselves are an appealing bunch: There is a smart-alecky one (Corey Feldman), a mature one (Josh Brolin), a precociously responsible one (Sean Astin), a weirdly inventive one (Ke Huy Quan) and an effervescent fat one (Jeff Cohen) who steals half the film, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. The film has crooks, bats, cobwebs, skeletons, a lovable monster, an underground grotto and a treasure hidden by some of the most considerate, clue-loving pirates who ever lived. (The Goonies, above.)

title: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Clippers at Trail Blazers
description: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

title: Lincoln Continental Is Reborn, Inspired by Its American Roots and Chinese Tastes
description: DETROIT  It took the interest of Chinese consumers to persuade Ford Motor to revive a quintessentially American car, the Lincoln Continental.

title: The Walking Dead Season 5 Finale Recap: Rick, Do It
description: Season 5, Episode 16, Conquer

title: Corrections: March 30, 2015
description: NEW YORK

title: Talking Photography With Elliott Erwitt
description: I learned long ago that its best to approach your heroes with trepidation, because they rarely live up to expectations. So when I met Elliott Erwitt in Perpignan, France, years ago, when we both had shows for Visa Pour lImage, I was reluctant to talk to him. Imagine my surprise when he asked to trade prints. I upped the ante and asked whether if I bought his book, Personal Best, he would sign it for me.

title: A Truce in the War Over Family
description: THE war over the family has been a disheartening part of American politics for decades. Conservatives saw growing numbers of children born outside of marriage and thought the family as they knew it was in trouble, the result of a cultural decline  a decrease in personal responsibility, and a growing dependence on government social welfare programs. Liberals saw families struggling and thought the problems reflected poverty and the dearth of good jobs.

title: Immigration Reform: The Drawbacks of E-Verify
After 50 Years, Its Time for a Better Sound of Music
description: The Sound of Music, the movie, turns 50 this year, as popular as ever, a bedrock memory of untold millions of childhoods. Mine, for sure. Some far-off day, when neural engineers do a digital download of my dying brain, they will find, way back with the oldest grudges and PIN numbers, the Sound of Music soundtrack, every line and rhyme. She climbs a tree and scrapes her knee. When the dog bites. Yodel-ay-hee-hoo.

title: Stronger Dollar in a Weak Global Economy
description: In the last several months, the dollar has strengthened tremendously against other currencies like the euro, the pound and the yen. This largely reflects the realization among investors that the American economy will do much better than other major economies in the coming months.

title: Imaginary Health Care Horrors
description: Theres a lot of fuzzy math in American politics, but Representative Pete Sessions of Texas, the chairman of the House Rules Committee, recently set a new standard when he declared the cost of Obamacare unconscionable. If you do simple multiplication, he insisted, you find that the coverage expansion is costing $5 million per recipient. But his calculation was a bit off  namely, by a factor of more than a thousand. The actual cost per newly insured American is about $4,000.

title: For the Police, Quality Over Quantity
description: Is the thin blue line too thin? Should the New York Police Department staff up, adding more cops even though crime is at historic lows and a sense of civic calm  a peacetime dividend, as Commissioner William Bratton calls it  is evident across most of the city?

title: Ovarian Cancer: Learning the Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: The Beating of Floyd Dent
description: He was beating me upside the head, Floyd Dent, a 57-year-old longtime autoworker told a gaggle of reporters last week, according to The Detroit Free Press. I was trying to protect my face with my right arm. I heard one of them say, Tase the M...F.

title: Test Yourself | Street Dance in Performance
description: Here are several paragraphs from a March 27 article, In Flexn, Street Dance Gets a Grand Stage.

title: Ehud Olmert, Israeli Ex-Premier, Is Convicted of Fraud
description: JERUSALEM  Ehud Olmert, the former Israeli prime minister who was forced from office under a cloud of corruption, was convicted on Monday of fraud and breach of trust in a retrial of a case involving an American businessman, whose sensational testimony in a Jerusalem court in 2008 was instrumental in Mr. Olmerts downfall.

title: 6 Qs About the News | A Fire to Unite People Long Divided in Northern Ireland
description: In Healing Fire in Londonderry: The Temple Was Built to Burn, Katrin Bennhold writes about

title: Suspects Request to Testify Adds Wrinkle to Litvinenko Inquiry
description: LONDON  An inquiry into the poisoning death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer, whistle-blower and bitter foe of President Vladimir V.
