Putin of Russia, ran into a last-minute delay on Monday after one of the two suspects in the killing demanded a chance to clear his name and exonerate the Kremlin.

title: Pay for Performance Extends to Health Care in New York State Experiment
description: For a generation, doctors in New York Citys economically depressed neighborhoods have been the ugly ducklings of the medical hierarchy. Many are foreign born and foreign trained, serve mostly minority and immigrant patients, and often run high-volume practices to compensate for Medicaids low rate of payment.

title: Amid Inquiry, Menendez Finds Well of Support Among Jewish Leaders
description: FRANKLIN LAKES, N.J.  Senator Robert Menendez spoke in a level, matter-of-fact tone, but his words were grave. Anti-Semitism is on the march around the world, he said. Negotiations with Iran, he warned, have reached the witching hour, with the security of both the United States and Israel at stake.

title: Pioneering Combat Pilot Persists in Rise From Arizona
description: WASHINGTON  In 2012, Martha McSally, a political novice, came so close to defeating her Democratic opponent, Representative Ron Barber, in Arizona that she flew to Washington for orientation and even appeared in the freshman class picture. She ultimately lost by fewer than 2,500 votes.

title: The High Cost of Calling the Imprisoned
description: Since the police in Pennsylvania arrested Anthony Kofalt last March for walking out of a Walmart with 21 boxes of Crest Whitestrips he had not paid for, his wife, Heather, has spent $3,000  about $60 a week  on phone calls to the prisons and jails where he has been held.

title: Queens Clock Tower, Once the Tallest, Helps a 77-Story Skyscraper Rise Next Door
description: The hands have not moved in decades, and the lights behind them went dark a year ago. But the gargoyles still glower atop the Long Island City clock tower, alongside its castellated turret, copper windows and granite shields.

title: Chinese Outlets Say Security Official in Graft Case Had 6 Mistresses
description: BEIJING  Chinese corruption investigators looking into a top security and intelligence official have found that he had six mistresses and two sons by them, according to a report published by a respected newsmagazine that was carried Monday on the websites of state-run news organizations.

title: What Are Your Thoughts on Cats?
description: People say there are cat people and dog people, but is that really true? What if you happen to like both equally?

title: ABN Amro Managers Give Up Pay Increases After I.P.O. Delay
description: LONDON  A group of ABN Amros top managers has said that it would give up a pay increase after the Dutch government delayed a decision last week on an initial public offering of the state-owned lender and after an uproar by lawmakers over the executive salary increases.

title: Andreas Lubitzs Home City Is Left to Clear Away Emotional Wreckage
description: MONTABAUR, Germany  When employees at a Burger King in this city between Frankfurt and Cologne heard that one of their former co-workers had been aboard the Germanwings flight that crashed in the French Alps last week, they prepared a condolence card for the family.

title: South Korea Picks Contractor to Develop New Jet Fighter
description: SEOUL  The South Korean military preliminarily selected Korea Aerospace Industries on Monday as a partner in its $7.7 billion project to develop its own advanced jet fighter with technological help from the American military contractor Lockheed Martin.

title: The Path Toward Tomorrows Internet
description: High school students in Tennessee can see and manipulate ocean plankton under a superhigh-resolution microscope in Southern California, with a biologist in California serving as their tour guide.

title: Nuts Are a Nutritional Powerhouse
description: Sadly, for more than half my life, I had avoided some of natures most perfect and healthful foods: nuts and peanuts. I had been mistakenly told as a teenager that nuts were fattening and constipating, effects I certainly wanted to avoid.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Bank of England Outlines Parameters of 2015 Stress Test
description: LONDON  The Bank of England said on Monday that it would test major British banks on their potential performance against financial shocks including a global slowdown, a sharp drop in inflation and a reduction in worldwide appetite for risk.

title: Dufry to Undertake Bid for All of Its Rival, World Duty Free
description: LONDON  Dufry, the Swiss operator of duty-free and other airport retail locations, said on Monday that it would undertake a bid to acquire all of the outstanding shares of the rival World Duty Free after it struck a deal during the weekend to obtain a controlling stake.

title: UnitedHealth Group to Buy Catamaran in $12.8 Billion Pharmacy Benefits Deal
description: Two pharmacy benefits managers are combining forces in an effort to negotiate better deals with pharmaceutical makers, a move that could in theory lead to lower drug prices for consumers.

title: New York Today: Not Trickling Down
description: Good chilly Monday morning to you.

title: The Deer in the Garden
description: Eight deer of various sizes are grazing the winter azaleas and fringe of monkey grass just outside the front window. Several young ruminants are right up next to the house, tugging at a tattered rhododendron, occasionally bumping the window screen. Although the dog is flipping out in the hallway below, barking sharply, indignantly, the herd is unfazed.

title: Daily Report: Hollywood Increases Its Digital Security Efforts
description: Lulu Zezza has played one of the toughest roles in Hollywood, Nicole Perlroth reports.

title: Income Inequality: Its Also Bad for Your Health
description: We know that living in a poor community makes you less likely to live a long life. New evidence suggests that living in a community with high income inequality also seems to be bad for your health.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | March 30, 2015
description: Updated: March 31, 2015

title: Iran Matters Most
description: Do the Iran deal. Defeat the barbaric marauders of Islamic State. In the fragmenting mayhem of the Middle East, these must be the American and Western priorities.

title: Being There: Heidegger on Why Our Presence Matters
description: A cognitive scientist and a German philosopher walk into the woods and come upon a tree in bloom: What does each one see? And why does it matter?

title: Judging Forensic Science
Today in Politics: Obamas Countdown for His Ascent Predated Politics, Book Says
Rhodes Scholarships Expanding to Include Chinese Students
description: BEIJING  The organization that administers Rhodes scholarships, the prestigious grant program that sends promising students to the University of Oxford, is preparing to expand to the developing world and other countries and will soon begin naming scholars from China.

title: Morning Agenda: Lessons  From the Kleiner Perkins Trial
description: LESSONS FROM THE KLEINER PERKINS TRIAL | Though Ellen Pao  lost her gender discrimination suit against her former employer, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the trial has succeeded in putting Silicon Valley on notice that it cannot continue with its freewheeling ways. In Ellen Pao, the Valley has found its newest disrupter, contends Farhad Manjoo in the State of the Art column.

title: Horizon Pharma Offers to Acquire Hyperion Therapeutics for $1.1 Billion
description: The Irish pharmaceutical company Horizon Pharma said on Monday that it had offered to buy Hyperion Therapeutics of California for $1.1 billion in cash.

title: The Daily Show Names a New Host
description: Trevor Noah, a 31-year-old comedian from South Africa, will replace Jon Stewart as the host of The Daily Show.

title: Trevor Noah to Succeed Jon Stewart on The Daily Show
description: In December, Trevor Noah, a 31-year-old comedian, made his debut as an on-air contributor on The Daily Show With Jon Stewart, offering his outsiders perspective, as a biracial South African, on the United States.

title: Trevor Noah, New Daily Show Host, Has an Earnest and Comedic Profile on Twitter and YouTube
description: When Jon Stewart started as the host of The Daily Show, in 1999, Internet video was hard to come by, and social networks like Twitter didnt exist. During his years as a professional comedian, Trevor Noah, like many of his peers, has established a strong footprint on Twitter, YouTube and Instagram. His tweets and clips from his standup performances may offer clues about what kind of host hell be on Comedy Centrals crown jewel nightly program.

title: Ben Bernanke Blog Blogging
description: Ben Bernankes Brookings blog begins! And the subject of the first post is a defense of the Fed against the charge that it has been keeping interest rates artificially low and hurting savers.

title: Tricky Issues Remain as Deadline Nears in Nuclear Talks With Iran
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland  Negotiators from the United States, Iran and five other nations pushed into the night on Monday to try to reach a preliminary political agreement on limiting Irans nuclear program.

title: Singapore Arrests Teenager Over Video Critical of Lee Kuan Yew
description: HONG KONG  A 16-year-old who appeared in a video that criticized Lee Kuan Yew, the founding father of modern Singapore who died on March 23, was arrested because of his comments that disparaged Christianity, according to the Singaporean police and local news reports.

title: Teva to Buy Auspex, an American Drug Developer, for $3.2 Billion
description: Teva Pharmaceutical said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Auspex Pharmaceuticals, a developer of drugs that treat people with movement disorders, for about $3.2 billion in cash.

title: Mens Wear Continues Its Global Surge
description: Prada announced its 2014 results on Monday, and for anyone looking to see how the high-fashion wind is blowing, theresultsconfirm two major market trends: First, things may be looking up for sales in Japan and the United States, but China is still a challenge; and second, mens wear and footwear are still growing strong.

title: Q. and A.: Adam Fisk on Evading Internet Censorship in China
description: In recent months, Chinas Internet regulators have further restricted the already limited access that the nations 648 million Internet users have to the web. Several Google services, including Gmailand Gchat, have become inaccessible. Virtual private networks, or V.P.N.s, that once let users skirt online censorship have also been blocked.

title: Red Meat Is Not the Enemy
description: There are people in this country eating too much red meat. They should cut back. There are people eating too many carbs. They should cut back on those. There are also people eating too much fat, and the same advice applies to them, too.

title: Yoox Group in Talks With Luxury Online Seller Net-a-Porter
description: The Yoox Group, the Italian online fashion retailer, said on Monday that it was in discussions with Compagnie Financire Richemont of Switzerland about a potential business combination with Net-a-Porter, the luxury e-commerce pioneer.

title: R.B.S. Says Head of Its Corporate and Institutional Bank Will Leave
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Monday that Rory Cullinan, the recently appointed head of its corporate and institutional bank, was leaving the company at the end of April.

title: Bangladesh Killings Send Chilling Message to Secular Bloggers
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  When the steamy, clamorous evening had settled over this city, and Oyasiqur Rhaman had finished his days work at a travel agency, he would turn to one of his favorite pastimes: Poking fun at fundamentalist Islam.

title: In Atlanta, a Quest to Keep Its Airport the Worlds Busiest
description: ATLANTA  The typical flier might wonder why an airport would promote its designation as the worlds busiest. Images of long lines, crowded concourses and auxiliary parking lots in the next area code could be evoked.

title: Palestinian Discontent With Abbas Is Growing
description: AL AMARI REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank  Residents of this cinder-block ghetto, a few miles from the headquarters of President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority, recently removed his portrait from the camps entrance.

title: 1940: War Intrudes on Historians
description: LONDON  Great Britains official military historians are hard at work trying to finish the story of the last war and wondering when they will be able to start writing about his one. In another volume of the long series on the conflict of 1914- 1918, to be published tomorrow [March 31], the scribes have chronicled such events of 1917 as the Battles of Arras and the German retreat to the Hindenberg Line. Half the staff of writers and research workers is busy amassing and pigeon-holing data on the present war. A weary official said today: I dont know when we shall start writing it up. It depends on how long it lasts. It is far too early yet to get the right perspective.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 31, 1940

title: Germanwings Co-Pilot Was Treated for Suicidal Tendencies, Authorities Say
description: DSSELDORF, Germany  Before he received his pilots license or achieved his dream of flying passenger jets, the co-pilot of the crashed Germanwings jetliner was so troubled that he underwent treatment for suicidal tendencies, a prosecutor said Monday, raising questions about what the airline should have known about his condition.

title: Headgear Rule for Girls Lacrosse Ignites Outcry
description: Worried about the risk of serious head injuries in a sport where the players wield reinforced sticks and rifle shots with a hard, unyielding ball, Florida last month became the first state to require high school girls lacrosse teams to wear protective headgear.

title: N.C.A.A. Final Four Preview: Kentucky Heads a Familiar Four
description: Call it the Familiar Four.

title: The Price of Damming Tibets Rivers
description: NEW DELHI  CHINA has more than 26,000 large dams, more than the rest of the world combined. They feed its insatiable demand for energy and supply water for mining, manufacturing and agriculture.

title: President Obama to Visit Kenya
description: President Obama will visit Kenya this summer for an international business conference in his first trip to his fathers homeland since taking office, the White House announced on Monday.

title: Arrests After Bangladesh Bloggers Death
description: Biplob Kumar Sarker, a police official in Dhaka, spoke after a blogger was killed in a machete attack by three men in Bangladeshs capital on Monday.

title: Water Colors
description: Toshio Shibatas meditative photographs of infrastructure in Japan take the perspective of the ceaseless flow of water.

title: Israeli Ex-Premier Convicted Again
description: A state prosecutor and a lawyer representing Ehud Olmert spoke after the former Israeli prime minister was found guilty on Monday of accepting illegal payments from an American businessman.

title: As Jobs Become Scarce, Teenagers Drive Farther to Find Work
description: Many parents hold teenage work experience in the same high regard as good grades and extracurricular activities. But what happens when the corner drugstore closes, the family-owned supermarket shuts its doors, and the only jobs available for high schoolers are more than 30 minutes away?

title: Ask Your Easter and Passover Cooking Questions
description: Melissa Clark, Kim Severson, Julia Moskin and I will answer your questions about the Passover and Easter feasts all week long on the Food department Facebook page.

title: In Boston Olympic Bid Vote, More Is at Stake Than Games
description: BOSTON  In the glassy offices of Bostons headquarters for bidding on the 2024 Olympics, signs remind officials: Keep Calm and Bid On.

title: China Is Urged to Confront Its Own History
description: The tour guide outside the bloodstained classrooms of the Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum, the high school in the Cambodian capital of Phnom Penh transformed into a prison and torture center by the Khmer Rouge, paused to ask whether any tourists in the group were from China. Visibly relieved when no hands were raised, he went on to describe the enabling role that Beijing played in the Khmer Rouges murderous rampage that claimed the lives of an estimated 1.7 million Cambodians beginning in 1975.

title: A Singapore Story
description: SINGAPORE  An hour or so after the end of the funeral ceremony at the National University of Singapore, the crowds were only just beginning to thin out. Earlier, despite torrential downpours, they had stood six-deep in some stretches of the 10-mile route of the procession accompanying Lee Kuan Yews coffin. It was a last homage in a week of homages and an intense outpouring of national grief.

title: Poetry Everywhere, and They Mean Everywhere, in Miami Festival
description: On April 1 the organizers of the O, Miami Poetry Festival begin their annual monthlong campaign to put a poem in front of all 2.6 million residents of Miami-Dade County. Miamians should watch out for poems on buildings, on fences, in the mail, even in the bathroom, Scott Cunningham, the festival director, said.

title: Alex Garlands Sci-Fi Faves
description: The British novelist makes his directorial debut with Ex Machina, a sci-fi parable that he also wrote about the dangers of artificial intelligence. Here, the screenwriter of 28 Days Later, Never Let Me Go and Dredd on his five favorite genre offerings.

title: 1965: Bomb Kills 13 at U.S. Embassy
description: A video by British Path of the bomb attack on the United States Embassy in Saigon, Vietnam, in 1965. britishpathe.com

title: Walker Art Center to Begin $75 Million Renovation
description: MINNEAPOLIS  To celebrate its 75th anniversary as a public institution, the Walker Art Center will embark on a $75 million renovation of its rolling campus, the final stage of an expansion that began more than a decade ago with the addition of a new building by the architects Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron. The new project will restructure the museums grounds and add a highly visible entrance pavilion, and it will also tie the Walker more closely to the Minneapolis Sculpture Garden across the street, home to Spoonbridge and Cherry, the sculpture by Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen that has become a Minneapolis landmark.

title: Driver Killed as Stolen Car Enters N.S.A. Campus
description: WASHINGTON  The two young men who spent the night at a nearby motel with an older man and stole his car on Monday morning may not have known exactly where they were going. But they sped into a special highway exit reserved for employees of the National Security Agency.

title: Root to Leaf, a Field Guide to Vegetables
description: Where my friend saw nothing, I saw possibility.

title: Supreme Court Leaves Intact New Yorks Ban on Religious Services in Schools
description: The Supreme Court declined on Monday to review a case involving New York Citys ban on religious groups holding worship services in public school buildings, leaving in place a decision by a lower court that found the longstanding policy constitutional.

title: Indiana Races to Fight H.I.V. Surge Tied to Drug Abuse
description: AUSTIN, Ind.  Jeanni McCarty, a nurse and native of this threadbare city of 4,200, hurried up and down Main Street in Saturdays bright sun, handing out stacks of fliers to any business that would take them. They were announcing a hastily planned specialty clinic  FREE, they emphasized in red  that would provide H.I.V. treatment to anyone who needed it.

title: Hanya Yanagiharas A Little Life
description: The lock on the toolshed is smashed, the motel door is kicked in and a child emerges  blinky, freed from years of sexual service, the violence finally at an end. The newspapers celebrate another triumph of the human spirit, and move on. But does the victim do the same? How does someone go from years of suffering and shame to live out the rest of a life? This is the question Hanya Yanagihara, author of People in the Trees, takes on in her second novel.

title: Islamic States Grip on City Appears Firmer Than Iraqis Acknowledge
description: TIKRIT, Iraq  Iraqi officials insisted for weeks that Islamic State fighters had been all but exterminated in Tikrit, confined to a few pockets in the city center. Yet on Sunday, military officials in the city were reluctant to allow journalists to head back to Baghdad by road  even though the highway skirts Tikrit well to the west.

title: Fluoridated Water Helps Older Adults Keep Teeth, Study Says
description: Fluoridation of water supplies, long ago proved to protect children from cavities, also helps older adults keep their teeth, a new study from Ireland has shown.

title: All the Old Knives, by Olen Steinhauer
description: A middle-aged man, dazed, drunk and unsteady, clambers up a staircase to reach the fresh air of a rooftop. Pigeons scatter. He slumps, closes his eyes, loses sight of the London skyline, loses consciousness. He has done something wrong in the restaurant downstairs  though as the scene plays out, this transgression is revealed to be little more than drunkenness. Hes been acting distant and withdrawn at a lunch date with an old flame. He may leave the Soho restaurant feeling longing and regret, wounded by her criticism of his collection of poems, but there are thankfully no bullet holes. In this filmed version of Christopher Reids narrative poem The Song of Lunch, the slumping man is played by Alan Rickman. Emma Thompson is the woman whos been looking across the table at him with disdain. Shes gone by the time he descends.

title: Inquiry of Silk Road Website Spurred Agents Own Illegal Acts, Officials Say
description: On the so-called dark web, drug dealing and other illicit sales have thrived in recent years, the authorities have said, through hidden websites like Silk Road and hard-to-trace digital currencies like Bitcoins.

title: More Details on Co-Pilots Mental State
description: Christoph Kumpa, deputy spokesman for the prosecutors office, said before the Germanwings co-pilot received his license, Andreas Lubitz was seeking help from a psychotherapist.

title: Math Madness
New York Times Co. Appoints Kinsey Wilson to Expanded Digital Role
description: The New York Times Company has appointed Kinsey Wilson, a former NPR executive who joined the newspaper last month as an editor for strategy and innovation, to lead its companywide digital product and technology operations.

title: Rahm Emanuel, Chicagos Rough-Edged Mayor, Tries the Sandpaper
description: CHICAGO  Alderman Scott Waguespack was in a conference room at City Hall in the spring of 2011 for a formal sit-down with this citys newly elected mayor, Rahm Emanuel. Mr. Waguespack attempted some small talk, he said, but Mr. Emanuel was not much interested.

title: Dozens Are Reported Killed as Saudi-Led Strike Hits Camp for Displaced Yemeni Civilians
description: AL MUKALLA, Yemen  Dozens of civilians were killed when, according to aid workers and officials, what appeared to be an airstrike hit a camp for displaced families in northern Yemen on Monday. It was thought to be the deadliest single episode involving civilians since Saudi Arabia began a military campaign to drive back the Houthi movement five days earlier.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Financier Lynn Tilton of Defrauding Investors
description: Federal regulators have accused Lynn Tilton, who calls herself the turnaround queen, and her firm, Patriarch Partners, of defrauding investors by hiding the poor performance of assets she managed for them.

title: Islamic State Destruction Renews Debate Over Repatriation of Antiquities
description: Assyrian relics that have stood for 3,000 years smashed and desecrated. Ruins from Babylonian times bombed and bulldozed. Scrolls and shrines ravaged from Somalia to Timbuktu.

title: Spokesman for Missouri Official Who Committed Suicide Is Found Dead
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo.  Slightly more than a month after Tom Schweich, Missouris auditor and a candidate for governor, took his own life, Spence Jackson, a longtime Republican spokesman who worked for Mr. Schweich, appears to have done the same.

title: A Paris Picnic, Delivered
description: Paris Picnic is a made-to-order delivery service that offers an assist for the most quintessential of Parisian activities: laying down a blanket, breaking out some Brie and a baguette and basking in the City of Light.

title: Velvet Worms, Squirting Slime
description: Velvet worms undulate through leaf litter on many stubby legs until they find an insect or other small prey. Then the creatures, which are not worms at all, strike. They squirt slime in a wavy, oscillating stream, trapping the prey in a sticky net.

title: Secrets of Velvet Worm Slime
description: A new study sheds light on how exactly the velvet worm controls the jet of slime it sprays to deter would-be predators.

title: Stephen Posen (Yes, Zacs Dad) Finds Poetry in Paired Photos
description: The artists new book, Ellipsis, features 174 images juxtaposed in surprising, thought-provoking ways.

title: Russian History Receives a Makeover That Starts With Ivan the Terrible
description: MOSCOW  Ivan the Terrible, the Russian czar, should really be considered Ivan the Not So Bad, according to a wildly popular historical exhibition held recently near the Kremlin.

title: Scott Walker: From Eagle Scout to Commander in Chief?
description: It is a quadrennial political ritual: Although very few candidates for president in recent history have actually had any experience that qualified them to be the commander in chief of the armed forces, the contenders often feel compelled to act as though they have that experience.

title: Florida Highway Official on Van Crash
description: Lt. Gregory S. Bueno of the Florida Highway Patrol gave an update on the injured passengers after a church van crashed into a canal in Glades County, Fla., killing eight people.

title: Profiling the Distracted Driver: Young, Female and Solo
description: People younger than 25 are more than four times as likely as older people to use a cellphone while driving, a new study reports, and a driver talking on a phone is about 63 percent more likely to be a woman than a man.

title: Ready Thyself for an All-Night Philosophy Jam
description: It might be the most intense all-nighter ever staged in New York. For 12 hours, starting at 7 p.m. on April 24, the French Embassy on Fifth Avenue and its next-door-neighbor, the Ukrainian Institute of America, will be joint hosts of A Night of Philosophy, an event that combines elements of a teach-in, a triathlon and a sweat-lodge ceremony. Only the mentally strong will survive.

title: Stephen Posen (Yes, Zacs Dad) Finds Poetry in Paired Photos
description: The artists new book, Ellipsis, features 174 images juxtaposed in surprising, thought-provoking ways.

title: Verbatim: To Be More Like Ted
description: President Obama, speaking at the opening of the Edward M. Kennedy Institute in Boston.

title: The White House and Paid Leave: Let Flowers Bloom
description: Is it time for America to Lead on Leave  as in, finally join the rest of the industrialized world by requiring employers to offer employees some version of paid family and sick leave? The numbers suggest the leading ship sailed long ago: We are one of only four countries in the world not to guarantee paid family leave to at least some portion of our work force, and the only one of 22 countries ranked highly by the Center for Economic and Policy Research in terms of economic and human development that does not guarantee that workers receive paid sick days or paid sick leave. We have not led on leave. We lag on leave.

title: Charges Against Ex-Federal Agents in Silk Road Investigation
description: The two former agents, Carl Mark Force IV and Shaun Bridges, were accused of laundering Bitcoins, the digital currency used on the once-thriving website for drug dealing.

title: The Golden Age of Annual Reports
description: David W. Dunlap takes a look back at some of The Timess annual report covers that were influenced by Louis Silverstein, one of the papers design directors.

title: The Condition Cancer Research Is In
description: In a letter to colleagues announcing his departure as the director of the National Cancer Institute, Dr. Harold Varmus, 75, quoted Mae West. Ive been rich and Ive been poor, he wrote, and rich is better.

title: Lawmakers Focus on How S.E.C. Does Its Job
description: Congress has taken intensified interest in how the Securities and Exchange Commission should enforce the law, introducing several legislative proposals. Although quick passage of the bills is unlikely, they signal how much interest there is, at least among Democrats, about the agencys work.

title: Mannequins at the Museum
description: Though passers-by often fail to so much as notice them, mannequins can reveal as much about the culture of their time as the clothing they display does. And, with his family business and the help of creative collaborators, Ralph Pucci is single-handedly responsible for many of the major developments in the modern-day mannequin industry. Pucci joined his parents New York mannequin-repair company in 1976 and began manufacturing the forms, teaming up with such design talents as Ruben Toledo, Andre Putman and Maira Kalman to redefine the genre through diverse and dynamic new shapes, colors and body gestures. Now, in anticipation of Puccis 40th anniversary in the business, 30 of the companys greatest hits are featured in a new exhibition, Ralph Pucci: The Art of the Mannequin, opening tomorrow at the Museum of Arts and Design in Manhattan.

title: Video Shows Scene of N.S.A. Shootings
description: Aerial video shows damaged vehicles and debris at the gate to Fort Meade, Md., where the National Security Agency has its headquarters.

title: With Travis Trice in Control, Michigan State Keeps Calm and Moves On
description: SYRACUSE  Ten seconds remained in the N.C.A.A. tournaments tense East Regional final Sunday when the basketball unexpectedly ricocheted into the hands of the Michigan State senior guard Travis Trice.

title: Now That Ben Bernanke Is Blogging, Heres What He Should Write About
description: Welcome to the wonderful world of economics blogging, Ben Bernanke! The former Federal Reserve chairman rolled out a blog and a Twitter account Monday morning, promising to engage more publicly on a range of economic issues, and occasionally on baseball.

title: A Burrito Filled to the Brim Downtown
description: To Stuff: A Burrito Filled to the Brim

title: China Appears to Attack GitHub by Diverting Web Traffic
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government has long used a sophisticated set of Internet filters known as the Great Firewall as a barrier to prevent its citizens from obtaining access to foreign websites with information it deems threatening.

title: A Struggle to Save the Scaly Pangolin
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  With its scaly exterior, peculiar body shape and propensity for rolling into an armored ball when threatened, the pangolin has invited comparison to the artichoke and the pine cone.

title: Endometriosis Is Often Ignored in Teenage Girls
description: Senie Byrne began menstruating at 15, and she quickly became an expert in pain management. Every month, it felt as if 1,000 darts had plunged into her abdomen; she sometimes passed out from the cramps. She was often nauseated, constipated and exhausted. At times, she had diarrhea. She said she saw 22 doctors over the years, but none took her seriously.

title: Facts & Figures: Millennials More Accepting of Homosexuality Than of Abortion
description: In a survey conducted by the Public Religion Research Institute, 42 percent of millennial respondents said sex between two adults of the same genderwas morally acceptable, while 37 percent said the same of casual sex. Twenty-four percent said sex between minors was acceptable, and 21 percent said so of abortion.

title: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
description: This weeks schedule includes a few friendlies, one not-so-friendly and a rare low-stakes version of Der Klassiker in Germany.

title: A World Shared With H.I.V.
description: The grayest heads among us still think of AIDS as a terrible new disease. But younger adults have never known a world without it, and many of the youngest think of it only as an annoying condition you take a pill for. They know nothing of the anguish and heroism that once surrounded the word AIDS.

title: BSI Becomes First Swiss Bank to Settle Under D.O.J. Disclosure Program
description: LONDON  BSI, one of Switzerlands largest private banks, on Monday became the first Swiss lender to reach a settlement with the Justice Department under a disclosure program intended to encourage Swiss banks to cooperate in an inquiry into wealthy Americans who used secret Swiss accounts to avoid taxes.

title: In Vietnam, Rampant Wildlife Smuggling Prompts Little Concern
description: U MINH, Vietnam  Luc Van Ho slips through a tangled thicket of jungle, graceful as a dancer. A blanket of dried bamboo and melaleuca leaves on the forest floor barely crackles beneath his bare feet. Only the smell of cigarette smoke betrays his presence.

title: Indiana Legislators Say Theyll Clarify Beliefs Law
description: Indianas legislative leaders on Monday joined Gov. Mike Pence in saying that they planned to amend a new religious freedom law to make clear that it did not allow discrimination against gays and lesbians, while still insisting that the law did not do so in its current form.

title: UnitedHealths $12.8 Billion Deal Could Reduce Further Consolidation
description: A $12.8 billion prescription should address the chronic merger game among pharmacy benefit managers. The UnitedHealth Group is paying a 27 percent premium for the Catamaran Corporation and should generate more than enough savings to cover it.

title: Clintons Effort on Israel Viewed Dimly by American Jewish Leader
description: The prominent American Jewish leader who on Sunday talked with Hillary Rodham Clinton about the need to put the relationship between Israel and the United States back on constructive footing did not think her role as the administrations designated yeller at Israel as secretary of state was all that constructive.

title: Ask Well: Jet Crash Raises Questions on Mental Illness Risks
description: The crash of the Germanwings jetliner has raised questions about mental illness and its consequences. Authorities have said that Andreas Lubitz, the co-pilot believed to have intentionally crashed the plane into the Alps, had a mental illness that he hid from the airline, that he was treated for suicidal tendencies before he got his pilots license, and that antidepressants were found in his apartment.

title: A Cure for the Cacophony
description: Life in the big city can get overwhelming, which is why Beijings five-star Rosewood hotel, situated among the bustling bars and hustling bankers of the Chaoyang District, is opening Sense this month, for guests who want to sleep where they spa. In addition to 11 treatment rooms, there are five suites overlooking the skyline  all decorated with limestone, dark wood and a serene palette of muted beige and gray  so that guests can opt to enjoy the extensive menu of treatments in the privacy of their own palatial accommodations.

title: Major British Parties Struggle to Fend Off Challenges as Campaigns Begin
description: LONDON  And theyre off! Parliament was dissolved at midnight, making Monday the official start of what is already a bitter and bad-tempered effort to win the minds, if not the hearts, of Britains undecided voters, who by most accounts make up close to 40 percent of the electorate. This election promises to be one of the most unpredictable British elections in recent times.

title: Justices Hear Arguments on Intellectual Disability in Death Penalty Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday heard arguments in a death penalty case and issued decisions on the monitoring of sex offenders and on the significance of a lawyers brief absence from a criminal trial.

title: 1957: Frisbees Fly at Princeton
description: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

title: Greece Looks to Russia as Deal With Europe Stumbles
description: ATHENS  With the prospect of a default looming in Greece, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is preparing to meet next week with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as a European deal to give more aid to Athens falters.

title: How Not to Catch a Cold on a Plane
description: Q. What can you do to reduce the possibility of becoming sick when you are trapped on a plane with a sneezing, coughing fellow passenger?

title: Ignacio Mattoss Most Treasured Cooking Tool
description: The Microplane was never meant to be a grater. It was never designed to turn walnuts to dust, or lemon peel into sunny snow, or to make confetti of mojama  salt-cured, wind-hardened tuna loin from southern Spain  the way it does in the hands of Ignacio Mattos, the chef of the Manhattan restaurant Estela.

title: Parsing Ronald Reagans Words for Early Signs of Alzheimers
description: WASHINGTON  Even before Ronald Reagan became the oldest elected president, his mental state was a political issue. His adversaries often suggested his penchant for contradictory statements, forgetting names and seeming absent-mindedness could be linked to dementia.

title: Chirlane McCray, on the Germanwings Co-Pilots Mental Health
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. Punishes Falcons and Browns for Rules Violations
description: The N.F.L. penalized the Atlanta Falcons and the Cleveland Browns on Monday, suspending two team executives for off-the-field infractions last season.

title: Phytoplankton on Decline in Southern Ocean
description: A type of phytoplankton important for carbon storage in marine environments is declining in the Southern Ocean, possibly because of climate change, researchers reported in Geophysical Research Letters. Emiliania huxleyi secretes a calcite shell, helping transport carbon dioxide from the surface into the deeper reaches. From 1998 to 2014, there was about a 4 percent reduction in the calcification rate during the summer months in the Southern Ocean.

title: A Wing That Can Recover From Midair Collisions
description: A new robotic wing, inspired by those of birds and bats, recovers from midair collisions with a simple mechanism: a pin joint that allows it to bend.

title: Review: Soho Reps Washeteria, Staged in a Brooklyn Storefront
description: In recent years, Soho Rep has offered dramas like Blasted, Born Bad, An Octoroon and We Are Proud to Present a Presentation  tough, turbulent, troubling. But in the new show, Washeteria, the company is running on a much, much gentler cycle, with lots of fabric softener, too.

title: Britain Acts to Block Removal of Egyptian Statue
description: Britains Culture Ministry has temporarily barred the unidentified buyer of a $27 million Egyptian statue, purchased last year from a museum in the town of Northampton, from taking the 4,400-year-old antiquity overseas, according to the BBC.

title: Stephen Posen (Yes, Zacs Dad) Finds Poetry in Paired Photos
description: Its common knowledge that the designer and Project Runway judge Zac Posen has always had a quirky and creative eye  long before he began creating ethereal and dramatic gowns for the likes of Reese Witherspoon and Naomi Campbell, he was repurposing yarmulkes for Barbie doll dresses. Perhaps less known is how much of the designers appreciation for visual shape-shifting can be credited to his father, the artist Stephen Posen, whose new photography book, Ellipsis: Dual Visions ($75, Glitterati), is out this week.

title: Review: Paquito DRivera in Concert at Jazz at Lincoln Center
description: Paquito DRivera practiced an impish historical revisionism at the Rose Theater on Friday, in his first of two nights at Jazz at Lincoln Center. At one point his darting lines on soprano saxophone came girded by the triplet thump of a Peruvian land rhythm  not the usual musical setting for Beethovens Pathtique piano sonata. But Mr. DRivera had explained himself in an introduction to the piece: Beethoven was really from Machu Picchu, he said, agreeably. His name was not Ludwig but Luisito.

title: Mad Men: Megan Sings Zou Bisou Bisou
description: Jessica Par, as Megan Draper, performs the song in Season 5.

title: Questions For Indianas Critics
description: I know that I should say something about the backlash and debateover Indianas version of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, but its been hard to come up with something that I didnt already say in my column when it was Arizonas variation on the same law, vetoed under pressure, that was in the news.That column made the case that the only remaining question in the same-sex marriage debate was what kind of space, if any, an ascendant cultural liberalismwould leave to Americans with traditional views on what constitutes a marriage; that the correlation of forces (corporate now as well as cultural and legal) was such that the choice of exactly how far to push and how much pluralism to permit would be almost entirely in the hands of liberals and supporters of same-sex marriage. Thats still basically how it looks to me today:Elements of the Indiana debate have been particularly  striking, but none of it has been particularly surprising given how this played out in Arizona.

title: Harvey Weinstein, Producer, Questioned by New York Police After Groping Accusation
description: The film producer Harvey Weinstein was questioned by the police on Saturday after a 22-year-old woman accused him of touching her inappropriately during a meeting in Manhattan, according to two law enforcement officials.

title: Small Planes and Frequent Delays Dont Cool Ardor for Flying
description: IVE been with real estate trade associations for about 40 years. But its really only the last four years, after joining the National Association of Realtors, that my business travel has really expanded. The association is based in Washington, but I live in Madison, Wis. What I do is help run a political education program called the Realtor Party, and I work directly with more than 1,400 local and state Realtor Association chapters in every state.

title: Foreigners Are Attacking ... American TV!
description: American late-night television shows have probably never had so many anchors with foreign accents as they will have soon. Trevor Noah, a South African comedian, will become at least the third non-American native to host a popular TV comedy show later this year when he takes over The Daily Show from Jon Stewart. He will join two Britons, John Oliver of HBOs Last Week Tonight and James Corden, who recently started hosting The Late Late Show on CBS.

title: Conservative Gains in Local Elections Leave Left-Leaning Parties Adrift in France
description: PARIS  In the aftermath of balloting on Sunday, conservatives in France were well positioned to build momentum before the presidential election in 2017, political analysts said Monday.

title: Review: The Brothers and the Boston Marathon Bombing
description: The lead attorney for the accused Boston Marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev began his defense this month with a blunt and dramatic statement: It was him.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Iraq and Elsewhere  Pictures of the Day

title: Obama at Kennedy Institute Opening
description: President Obama attended the opening of the Edward M. Kennedy Institute in Boston and delivered remarks praising the longtime Massachusetts senator.

title: Obama Praises Edward Kennedy, and Mourns the Loss of Collegiality
description: BOSTON  President Obama on Monday condemned the demise of bipartisan compromise in American politics that he said had prompted voters to turn away in bitterness and disgust, using the dedication of the Edward M. Kennedy Institute to call for a new era of consensus-building.

title: March 30, 2015 Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Iraq, India, Colombia and Nigeria.

title: Jay Z Reveals Plans for Tidal, a Streaming Music Service
description: As Jay Z sees it, there is a clear solution to the problems facing musicians in the streaming age. They should band together  behind him, of course.

title: The Fifth Season of The Walking Dead Turned Into a Post-Apocalyptic Debate Club
description: The sword came off the wall, but it was too late to make a difference.

title: Fish Oil Claims Not Supported by Research
description: Fish oil is now the third most widely used dietary supplement in the United States, after vitamins and minerals, according to a recent report from the National Institutes of Health. At least 10 percent of Americans take fish oil regularly, most believing that the omega-3 fatty acids in the supplements will protect their cardiovascular health.

title: A Farmer Ants Unique Fungal Crop
description: Much like human farmers, fungus-farming ants meticulously maintain their subterranean gardens. They regularly fertilize, weed and tend to their crops.

title: Photos That Echo Russia and Ukraine
description: To commemorate Russias annexation of Crimea, five photographers are collaborating on image mash-ups that add layers of new meaning.

title: Walkabout: More Travel Warnings in Kenya; Luring Tourists to Appalachia
Review: Living Here Sends Gideon Irving to Wander City Apartments
description: There were only two dozen people in the audience when the folksy balladeer Gideon Irving performed Living Here: A Map of Songs, produced by the Foundry Theater, on Wednesday.

title: Letters to the Editor
Modern Explorers Seek a Place in a GPS World
description: Eric Larsen seemed ill at ease in his tuxedo. He is more inclined to trudge across an ice shelf than mingle at a fancy party in Manhattan. Yet here he was, in black tie, nibbling on canaps at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Review: In TV Lands Younger, a Woman Cheats the Clock to Land a Job
description: When it comes to stories about time travel, male characters often focus on what they would do. Mark Twains hero uses 19th-century technology to outsmart medieval sorcerers in A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthurs Court. The time traveler in Back to the Future can perform Johnny B. Goode years before that songs release.

title: Rubio Confirms Date of Big Announcement
description: The slow walk of candidates declaring they are running for president took another step forward on Monday with Senator Marco Rubio saying he plans to make a big announcement in a couple of weeks.

title: In Performance | Lena Hall
description: Ms. Hall, with Watt White on guitar, sings Falling Slowly, a ballad from the movie and Broadway musical Once.

title: Big Ears in Knoxville, Tenn.
description: The three-day festival of experimental music took place last weekend in Knoxville, Tenn.

title: Big Ears Festival Stars the Avant-Garde
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  The avant-garde is a notion shaped by discomfort, as well as defiance. No music gets that designation unless it makes people feel uneasy or threatened. Tanya Tagaq, a singer from Nunavut, the northernmost territory in Canada, gave an exemplary lesson in assuaging worry here on Saturday afternoon at Big Ears, an ambitious three-day festival of experimental music in a place without much of a history of nurturing it.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: The Wiz Will Be NBCs Next Live Musical and Then Return to Broadway
description: Earlier this year, Robert Greenblatt, the chairman of NBCs entertainment division, announced that after The Sound of Music Live in 2013 and Peter Pan Live in 2014, his networks next live musical production would be either The Wiz or The Music Man.

title: Excerpt: Bye Bye Birdie
description: Ann-Margret performs the opening credits for the 1963 film.

title: Review: Dawn Upshaw Gets Down to Earth at Town Hall
description: Certain musicians are often referred to as communicative performers, a particularly apt description in the case of the soprano Dawn Upshaw, who sang at the Town Hall on Sunday afternoon as part of the Peoples Symphony Concerts series.

title: Review: The Cellist Leonard Elschenbroich Played at the Frick
description: The German cellist Leonard Elschenbroich is a rising star on the European concert scene. On Sunday afternoon, together with the pianist Alexei Grynyuk, he presented his New York recital debut at the Frick Collection. In a program of just three works  one Classical, one contemporary and one Romantic  Mr. Elschenbroich not only revealed himself as a musician of great technical prowess, intellectual curiosity and expressive depth but also displayed an easygoing way of communicating with an audience.

title: Review: 20 Years Later, Jodeci Is Back, in The Past, the Present, the Future
description: A few months ago the soul savant DAngelo released a new album, Black Messiah, some 14 years after his previous one, Voodoo. On its own, it was an accomplishment, but it was also a reminder of many things that todays R&B mainstream lacks: political engagement, the warmth and tension of a live band, a voice with fascinating crevices.

title: Cabaret Says Auf Wiedersehen With Big Week at Broadway Box Office
description: The Kit Kat Klub closed up shop with a bang last week, as Sienna Miller led Cabaret to a strong finish in its run at Studio 54.

title: The Story Behind Woman in Gold: Nazi Art Thieves and One Paintings Return
description: There are many reasons that among the hundreds of thousands of cases involving artwork looted by the Nazis the story of Gustav Klimts Adele Bloch-Bauer I would particularly appeal to filmmakers. For one, there is the mesmerizing gold-flecked painting itself, which set a record price of $135 million when it was sold in 2006. Then there is the David-and-Goliath tale featuring a feisty octogenarian heroine  Ms. Bloch-Bauers niece Maria Altmann  taking on a recalcitrant Austrian government. And finally there is the satisfying conclusion. Ms. Altmann gets the portrait back. Justice prevails.

title: Review: Missy Mazzolis Unsettling Vespers for a New Dark Age
description: The composer and keyboardist  Missy Mazzoli has a thing for unlikely connections and startling gestures, and one of her gifts is the ability to tease out the hidden logic behind her choices. Her ravishing, unsettling album Vespers for a New Dark Age unfolds as a meditation on technology and spirituality, alienation and self-interest. Its ominous but propulsive score ranges from the chamber-operatic to the electronic and semiabstract.

title: Boy Locked in Manhattan Restroom With Mother Later Dies
description: A 1-year-old boy whose mother locked herself in a restroom with him at a restaurant in Midtown Manhattan on Monday was declared dead at Bellevue Hospital Center, where he was taken after workers who unlocked the door found him unconscious and foaming at the mouth, the police said.

title: Review: Sufjan Stevenss Quietly Moving Carrie & Lowell
description: A hushed, intent Sufjan Stevens contemplates death, grief, family and memory on his quietly moving new album, Carrie & Lowell, in songs that entwine autobiography and archetype. The music is restrained and meticulous, all graceful melodies, plucked strings and shimmery keyboard tones. But ungovernable circumstances and emotions course through the lyrics.

title: Obamas Passport Data Leaked in Australian Email Blunder
description: WASHINGTON  The government of Australia accidentally disclosed personal information about President Obama and 30 other world leaders who traveled there last fall for a summit meeting, according to a report on Monday in The Guardian.

title: Enterovirus 68 May Be Linked to Paralysis in Children, Study Says
description: A new strain of a common respiratory virus may be responsible for partly paralyzing scores of children nationwide, researchers reported on Monday.

title: Labors $15 Wage Strategy
description: Ebony Hughes works two jobs and still struggles to make ends meet. She is an example of the kind of worker that organizers are trying to galvanize under the banner of civil rights to raise wages.

title: Movement to Increase McDonalds Minimum Wage Broadens Its Tactics
description: ATLANTA  On a recent Friday, Kwanza Brooks, a $7.25-an-hour McDonalds worker, climbed into a 14-person van to take a four-hour ride from Charlotte, N.C., to Atlanta.

title: Teenager Faces Charges After Mocking Singapores Founding Father on YouTube
description: The Singaporean police confirmed on Monday that a teenage video blogger was arrested a day earlier for an obscenity-laced tirade posted on YouTube that celebrated the death of Lee Kuan Yew, the countrys founding father, and disparaged Christians.

title: Thoughts at the End of the Road, and a Word of Advice
description: ALL roads end, and now we come to the end of this one.

title: Heated Words as Iran Deadline Nears
Prosecutors Scrutinize Minority Borrowers Auto Loans
description: Minority borrowers were once starved for credit through redlining  banks refusal to provide mortgages in their communities.

title: Detroit Group Calls for Overhaul of Schools
description: A coalition of Detroits leaders called on Monday for sweeping changes to the citys educational system, including an end to emergency management of the troubled public schools, the transfer of the systems financial debt to the state, and creation of a commission to oversee the opening and closing of schools in the city.

title: Climate Change Threatens to Kill Off More Aspen Forests by 2050s, Scientists Say
description: The beloved aspen forests that shimmer across mountainsides of the American West could be doomed if emissions of greenhouse gases continue at a high level, scientists warned on Monday. That finding adds to a growing body of work suggesting forests worldwide may be imperiled by climate change.

title: Jeb Bush Defends Indianas Religious Beliefs Law
description: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida weighed in Monday on the debate that has engulfed Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana over a new religious freedom law in the state that critics are calling legalized discrimination.

title: N.C.A.A. Steps Up Pressure Over New Indiana Law
description: While Indianas legislature and governor said Monday that they would clarify a new law that critics say could condone discrimination against gay people, the Indianapolis-based N.C.A.A., days before the Final Four was set to begin in Indianapolis, left the door open to moving future events and its own headquarters.

title: Lauren Smithson,  Manfred Philogene
description: Lauren Elizabeth Smithson and Manfred Joseph Philogene were married Friday at Carlyle on the Green, an events space in Farmingdale, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Jerome D. Taylor, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

title: Miriam Bienstock, Co-Founder of Atlantic Records, Dies at 92
description: Miriam Bienstock, a co-founder of Atlantic Records who ran the business side of the company in its formative years, helping to lay the groundwork for what became a colossus of the recording industry, died on March 21 at her home in Manhattan. She was 92.

title: Religious Protection Laws, Once Called Shields, Are Now Seen as Cudgels
description: When the federal government adopted a religious protection act in 1993, same-sex marriage was not on the horizon.

title: Robert Hite, 95, Survivor of Doolittle Raid and Japanese Imprisonment, Dies
description: Lt. Col. Robert L. Hite, the last survivor among eight crewmen who were captured by the Japanese when American bombers brought World War II home to Japan in Jimmy Doolittles daring air raid in 1942, died on Sunday in Nashville. He was 95.

title: As U.S. and Iran Seek Nuclear Deal, Saudi Arabia Makes Its Own Moves
description: CAIRO  As America talks to Iran, Saudi Arabia is lashing out against it.

title: House Provision Offers Doctors More Protection Against Malpractice Suits
description: WASHINGTON  A little-noticed provision of a bill passed by the House of Representatives with overwhelming bipartisan support would provide doctors new protections against medical malpractice lawsuits.

title: Witnesses, Who Say Police Killed Activist, Areto Be Charged in Egypt
description: CAIRO  Egyptian prosecutors are bringing criminal charges against witnesses who said they saw the police kill an unarmed poet and activist during a demonstration, a lawyer who has seen the charges said on Monday.

title: Prosecution in Boston Marathon Trial Closes With Raw Details of Killings
description: BOSTON  The governments case against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the admitted Boston Marathon bomber, ended Monday where it began, with a raw, wrenching account of the carnage wrought nearly two years ago by Mr. Tsarnaev on Boylston Street.

title: Defense Witness Places Different Suspect in Etan Patzs Apartment
description: After weeks of trying to link a convicted child molester to the 1979 disappearance of Etan Patz, defense lawyers for Pedro Hernandez called a witness on Monday who placed the molester inside the Patzes SoHo apartment.

title: Arizona Governor Vetoes Bill to Shield Police Names
description: PHOENIX  With just hours left before a midnight deadline, Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona vetoed legislation on Monday that would have prevented law enforcement agencies from releasing the names of officers involved in serious or fatal shootings for 60 days.

title: Virginia: Suit Seeks to Prevent College From Closing
description: State authorities filed suit Monday to block the closing of Sweet Briar College, giving a boost to alumnae and faculty who are fighting to save the 114-year-old womens liberal arts institution near rural Amherst. The Amherst County attorney, Ellen Bowyer, argued in court filings that she has jurisdiction to sue on behalf of the state, and said shutting down Sweet Briar would violate the will of its founder, Indiana Fletcher Williams, who in 1901 bequeathed her former plantation for the purpose of educating young women to be useful members of society. A college spokeswoman had no immediate comment.

title: UConn Women Trail at Halftime but Surge to Another Final Four
description: ALBANY  Connecticuts steamroller of a womens basketball team met a head-on challenge for one half on Monday night but ultimately went merrily on its way to another Final Four, undented and undaunted.

title: Shopping for Yacht? New York Budget Offers a Tax Break
description: Of the thousands of items packed into Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos $150 billion budget for New York State, one in particular seemed to float to the top: a tax credit for buyers of luxury boats.

title: Obama, Last Election Behind Him, Plans First Visit as President to Kenya
description: WASHINGTON  For years, Kenya has been a political headache for President Obama and a geopolitical headache for the United States. But now in his seventh year in office, with his last election behind him, Mr. Obama has decided to embrace his heritage by visiting the land of his father for the first time as president.

title: Dietitians Group Negotiating to End Labeling Deal With Kraft Singles
description: The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics said it was working with the Kraft Foods Group to end part of a deal that allowed the food company to use one of the academys logos on packages of Kraft Singles.

title: 3 Injured in East Village Explosion Are Released From Hospital
description: Three of four people who were hospitalized in critical condition after an explosion and fire in the East Village last week have been released, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Monday.

title: Father Stays on Sideline as Georgia States R.J. Hunter Enters the N.B.A. Draft
description: ATLANTA  For its N.C.A.A. tournament coda, One Shining Moment, CBS could justify devoting an entire segment to the Hunters of Georgia State. During the first weekend alone, Ron, the coach-father, and R. J., the player-son, provided the types of images that endear the tournament to its rapt followers.

title: Role of Illness in Germanwings Crash Raises Worry About Stigma
description: An intense focus on the role of the co-pilots mental illness in the Germanwings jetliner crash has raised concerns that it risks unfairly stigmatizing millions of people with mental disorders and making it less likely they will seek treatment. That, in turn, could make it even harder to identify people working in high-risk professions who pose a threat to public safety.

title: Intersection | Seoul, South Korea
description: In the Hongdae neighborhood of Seoul, Mina Kwon, an illustrator, says her style is influenced by hip-hop and androgyny.

title: Fancy, Evasive Language
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  An easy theme today, perhaps to help us ease our way back into solving after the exciting weekend in Stamford, Conn., at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. If you want to watch a video clip that will have you on the edge of your seat, check out the last moments of the A Division finals below, provided by Ben Zimmer.

title: Cuomo Gets Timely New York Budget but Pays Price
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo started his second term with a zeal to address broad societal problems like income inequality, faltering public schools and waning trust in the criminal justice system.

title: An Anxious Wait in Syrian City Held by Insurgents
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Residents of the northern Syrian provincial capital of Idlib are waiting anxiously to learn who will govern them, and how, after Islamist insurgent groups hoisted their flags over the city last weekend.

title: Nigerias Presidential Race Stretches to Another Day
description: KANO, Nigeria  The most competitive presidential race ever in Africas largest democracy continued to play out late into Monday night, with the incumbent president facing a tough challenge as voting results poured in from distant states in this crowded and chaotic land.

title: Lawyer Asks Judge to Vacate Conviction in 2003 Killing of Fairfield Student
description: A lawyer for John Giuca, convicted of the 2003 killing of a Fairfield University student athlete, filed a motion on Monday asking a judge to vacate Mr. Giucas murder conviction.

title: Chris Mullin Is Set to Lead St. Johns Again, but This Time as a Rookie Coach
description: His floppy hair, puckered mouth and timeless shooting stroke captivated New York City and the Big East Conference in the early 1980s. Now, 30 years later, Chris Mullin will return to St. Johns as the coach of the mens basketball team, according to a person with knowledge of the agreement.

title: A Trial Partnership for 2 Jewish Cultural Institutions in New York
description: Two Jewish cultural organizations in New York City  one in need of a permanent home and the other in a quest for more visitors  have agreed to join forces.

title: Better Call Saul Recap: A Chimp With a Machine Gun
description: Season 1, Episode 9: Pimento

title: Old, New and Unusual Alliances in the Middle East
description: A look at where Iran exerts influence across the region and at the emerging Saudi coalition.

title: Citi Bike Says Shutdown Was for Fixing Software
description: Bear with us  Citi Bike is getting better.

title: Mets Owner Fred Wilpon Is Making Good on His Promise to Be More Engaged With the Team
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Word filtered through the Mets organization at the start of spring training that the owner Fred Wilpon would be around more and would be more engaged. With spring training winding down, Wilpon made good on that promise in an unusual way  at least by his standards.

title: Replace a Legend? These Yankees Did
description: The Yankees are in transition again  the tricky transition of replacing a revered player. Bob Sheppards recorded voice will not intone, Num-bah 2, Der-ek Jee-tah, Num-bah 2 this season. Didi Gregorius, obtained in an off-season trade, is the new shortstop. But because the Yankees have had so many revered players in winning a record 27 World Series, they have had to manage this transition every so often.

title: Derick Brassard and Mats Zuccarello Ignite the Rangers Line
description: On the surprising march to last springs Stanley Cup finals, the Rangers best line did not feature Derek Stepan, Martin St. Louis or Chris Kreider. And on the Rangers run this season to the top of the N.H.L., their best forward unit has not had any of those players either.

title: Word of the Day | congruent
description: congruent  \kn-gr-nt, kN-gr-nt\  adjective

title: IBM Scores Weather Data Deal and Starts Internet of Things Unit
description: Data partnerships are a key ingredient in IBMs long-term strategy, and the company is announcing a big one on Tuesday with the Weather Company.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 11 P.M. (Spike) CON AIR (1997) Cameron Poe (Nicolas Cage) kills a man with his fists while defending his pregnant wife (Monica Potter). In court, a judge says that because he is a United States Army Ranger veteran he is a deadly weapon, and sentences him to 7 to 10 years in prison. When it comes time for him to return home, he finds himself the only good man on a flight full of villainous convicts, played by Ving Rhames, Danny Trejo, Steve Buscemi and others. Led by Cyrus the Virus (John Malkovich), the convicts plan to hijack the plane. Cameron must prevent the hijacking so he can get home to his wife and daughter on her seventh birthday. As directed by Simon West and written wryly by Scott Rosenberg (Beautiful Girls), Con Air is a simple setup followed by endless stunts, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: They are profiting off of people in vulnerable situations. The cost determines when I can talk to my husband and when my son can read a book to him.

title: Corrections: March 31, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Yemen Evacuation Shows Chinese Navys Growing Role
description: China evacuated nearly 600 of its citizens from conflict-torn Yemen this week in Chinese warships, in a demonstration of Beijings increasing ability to extract its people from dangerous places.

title: Photos That Echo Russia and Ukraine
description: Photography is often a fairly solitary activity. The great work of previous centuries was usually a result of a lone photographer obsessively driven to explore a topic that provoked a response from the audience. That independent aspect has been one of its attractions for those practitioners who were, shall we say, a little socially challenged.

title: Yoox to Merge With Net-a-Porter in All-Share Deal
description: LONDON  The Yoox Group said on Tuesday that it had agreed to merge with its luxury e-commerce rival Net-a-Porter in an all-share deal.

title: The E.P.A.s Climate Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Outrage Over an Anti-Gay Law in Indiana
description: To the Editor:

title: Religious Liberty and Equality
description: Over the past few decades the United States has engaged in a great struggle to balance civil rights and religious liberty.

title: Ted Cruz and the New Politics of Texas
description: HOUSTON  AS soon as Ted Cruz announced that he was running for the presidency, I felt a sort of dread. My reaction didnt have to do with Mr. Cruz himself  well, not entirely  but with the wackiness that always attends a Texans running for higher office.

title: In Indiana, Using Religion as a Cover for Bigotry
description: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, who last week signed a religious-freedom law driven by bigotry against gays and lesbians, has been complaining that the laws opponents  which include top business leaders and civil-rights groups  are spreading misinformation.

title: Missing From New Yorks Budget
description: With an April 1 deadline looming, Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York and the two top legislative leaders announced on Sunday the framework of an agreement on next years $150 billion state budget. Details were scarce, but this much seemed clear: A lot of important items were missing from the deal, apparently  and disappointingly  put off for another day.

title: Test Yourself | Coloring Books for Grown-Ups
description: Here are several paragraphs from a March 29 article, Grown-Ups Get Out Their Crayons.

title: Philips to Sell Controlling Stake in LED Business for Up to $2.9 Billion
description: LONDON  Philips, the Dutch electronics giant, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to sell a controlling stake in its automotive lighting and LED components business for as much as $2.9 billion.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Trevor Noah to Succeed Jon Stewart on The Daily Show
description: In Trevor Noah to Succeed Jon Stewart on The Daily Show, Dave Itzkoff writes about Comedy Centrals pick for a new host on the highly successful satirical comedy show.

title: The Martyrs Daughter
description: A supporter of Irans Islamic revolution, Najiyeh Allahdad, sees it as her duty to speak up when in her view the government doesnt live up to the ideals for which her father fought and died.

title: Review: Charles Simic Displays a Poets Voice and His Passions
description: When our souls are happy, Charles Simic has written, they talk about food. When my soul is happy, often enough, I want to talk about Mr. Simic.

title: Baseball Striving to Add Voices to Translate From Spanish
description: TAMPA, Fla.  When Jose Pirela, a 25-year-old Venezuelan utility player for the Yankees, sat on a dugout bench last Tuesday to speak with more than a dozen reporters about the concussion he sustained two days earlier while crashing into an outfield wall, he did not feel comfortable speaking in English to a sizable gathering.

title: The Martyrs Daughter
description: This is the second episode of Our Man in Tehran, a seven-part video series on nytimes.com, produced with VPRO in the Netherlands. It is the first of two videos about issues facing women in Iran. Najiyeh Allahdad, the subject of this episode, and Thomas Erdbrink, answered readers questions below.

title: Robert Dursts Wife Steps Back After Years of Defending Him
description: Six weeks after learning that investigators had focused on his role in the years-old disappearance of his wife, Robert A. Durst married Debrah Lee Charatan, a driven New York real estate executive who has been a bulwark in his life for nearly three decades.

title: What Family Traditions Do You Want to Carry On When You Get Older?
description: When were children, family traditions often just happen to us. We eat, we sing, we get dressed up, often without much choice in the matter. But when we get older and make our own families, we can get the opportunity to decide what traditions we want to carry on as adults, whether holiday meals on Thanksgiving or Christmas, family summer camping trips or coming-of-age celebrations such as quinceaeras.

title: Owners in Discussions to Sell Dutch Auto Leasing Firm LeasePlan
description: LONDON  LeasePlan Corporation, one of Europes biggest automobile leasing and fleet managers, said on Tuesday that its owner, Global Mobility Holding, was in discussions with a group of investors to sell the Dutch company.

title: Gay Marriage State by State: From a Few States to the Whole Nation
description: How the number of states allowing same-sex marriage grew.

title: The Contender, a Biography of Andrew Cuomo
description: Andrew Cuomo is not running for president. Not in 2016  since the governor of New York is not about to throw himself in front of the freight train that is Hillary Clinton  and possibly not ever. Indeed, bypassing a White House bid would most likely be less a political than a personal calculation for Cuomo. He is the uncommon elected official with a streak of misanthropy, Jeffrey Toobin of The New Yorker recently wrote about him. Or as a former Cuomo aide told Toobin: Andrew will not run for president. Hed have to talk to too many people.

title: Becoming Steve Jobs, by Brent Schlender and Rick Tetzeli
description: In early 2009, Tim Cook presented Steve Jobs, his cancer-stricken mentor and friend, with a surprise offer: Cook wanted to donate a portion of his own liver to his ailing boss, who was stuck in dangerous limbo on Californias waiting list for liver transplants.

title: Consumer Prices in Eurozone Decline Again, but So Does Unemployment
description: PARIS  The eurozone continues to flirt with deflation, an official report showed on Tuesday, as consumer prices fell in March for a fourth consecutive month. A separate report, though, showed the unemployment rate in the zone, a 19-nation currency union, dipping slightly in February.

title: Style in Seoul, South Korea
description: See style in the Hongdae neighborhood of Seoul.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Iran Nuclear Talks Extended to Wednesday, Negotiators Say
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland  The United States and its negotiating partners on Tuesday extended their deadline for reaching a preliminary accord with Iran on its nuclear program until Wednesday.

title: Dont Worry About It Approach on Iran May Haunt White House, G.O.P. Lawmaker Says
description: It was always the dont worry about it clause, says Representative Ed Royce of California, the Republican chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee:

title: Daily Report: Jay Z Enters Streaming Music With Artist-Owned Service
description: As Jay Z sees it, there is a clear solution to the problems facing musicians in the streaming age. They should band together  behind him, of course, Ben Sisario reports.

title: New York Today: A New Season for Citi Bike
description: Good sunny Tuesday morning to you.

title: The House Democrats Who Are Voting With Republicans More Often
description: A small group of House Democrats has begun moving to the right in the current Congress, breaking from a majority of colleagues on votes that pit lawmakers from liberal areas against those from more rural and conservative districts.

title: Finding Acceptance
How You Do You Perfectly Captures Our Narcissistic Culture
description: You will recall the fable of the Scorpion and the Frog. The Scorpion needs a ride across the river. The waters are rising on account of climate change, or perhaps he has been priced out of his burrow, who knows? The exact reason is lost in the fog of pre-modernity. The Frog is afraid that the Scorpion will sting him, but his would-be passenger reassures him that they would both die if that happened. That would be crazy. Sure enough, halfway across, the Scorpion stings the Frog. Just before they drown, the Scorpion says, Arent you going to ask why I did that? And the Frog croaks, You do you.

title: Rory McIlroy Has the Best Swing in Golf
description: Even before Rory McIlroy could walk, he was envisioning the shots of his dreams. The story has been related to him countless times: how back in the early 1990s, his father, Gerry, then a bar manager at the local golf club in Holywood, County Down, Northern Ireland, would put his 18-month-old son  in his fathers daily care while his mother, Rosie, a night-shift worker at a nearby 3M plant, slept  in a pram and wheel him a half-mile or so from the McIlroys small, red-brick house on Belfast Road to the club, its 18-hole course on the outskirts of Belfast nestled into a tiered wooded hillside. When his day shift ended, Gerry, an avid golfer, would bring his son out to the range, set his pram just behind the practice tee and swat out buckets of balls before his transfixed toddler.

title: In Treatment, but in Which Language?
description: I have a psychotherapy practice in Madrid, but I often receive email requests for counseling from people in other parts of the world, since I also practice psychotherapy online, via Skype, in several languages: English, French, Italian and Russian. Alexs email looked like spam, and I nearly deleted it. He wrote in an abrupt English, with neither a greeting nor a sign-off. When I read more closely, I saw that he was seeking therapy, though he didnt say much else. In his brevity I sensed hesitation, a shade of doubt.

title: Today in Politics: Choosing Just the Right Stage to Set
Weekly News Quiz | March 24-30, 2015
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Video Review: The Chrysler 300 Is Serious, Just Shy of Luxurious
description: REAR-WHEEL drive, athletic moves, a high-end look and room for five describes the BMW 5 Series, Cadillac CTS and Mercedes E-Class. For buyers unwilling to tie up finances at that lofty level, the Chrysler 300 offers club membership at a more reasonable rate.

title: Driven | 2015 Chrysler 300S
description: The Chrysler 300S has been refreshed for the nameplates 60th birthday.

title: Obamas Strategy on Climate Change, Part of Global Deal, Is Revealed
description: WASHINGTON  The White House on Tuesday introduced President Obamas blueprint for cutting greenhouse gas emissions in the United States by nearly a third over the next decade.

title: The U.N.s War on Israel
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations is celebrating its 70th anniversary this year. It was intended to be a temple of peace, but this once great global body has been overrun by the repressive regimes that violate human rights and undermine international security.

title: The Road to Five Forks
description: Today in my Civil War obsession: some readers may recall that Im a big U.S. Grant admirer; the scene at Appomattox, where the dashing cavalier Lee surrendered to the stumpy, grimy Grant, marks the coming of the modern era. I also find the campaign that led to that moment fascinating. And that campaign began in earnest 150 years ago today.

title: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Did The Times Self-Censor?
description: Updated, April 8, 2015. Andrew Beach, a reader from Auckland, New Zealand, wrote to me recently after being disturbed by the following paragraph in a story about New York Universitys role in Abu Dhabi:

title: Crunching the Numbers: College Basketball Players Cant Wear 6, 7, 8 or 9
description: SYRACUSE  When the freshman forward Marvin Clark Jr. requested a uniform number in the single digits this fall  something, he said, that might help embellish his trim physique  Michigan States equipment manager, Dave Pruder, had a problem. There was not much to offer him.

title: Tricky Little Things
description: My colleague Jill Taylor notes that when it comes to commas, more is not necessarily better (Eats, Shoots & Leaves is the most commercially successful venture built on this principle).

title: In Performance: Lena Hall
description: This weeks video features the Tony Award-winning actress Lena Hall, with Watt White on guitar, performing Falling Slowly, a ballad from the movie and Broadway show Once. Ms. Hall will perform the number in her new show at Caf Carlyle, running April 7 through April 18.

title: Editors and Executives of News Website Malaysian Insider Are Arrested
description: HONG KONG  Three editors and two executives with a Malaysian news website were arrested this week in what critics called a troubling assault on press freedom.

title: Missing Deflation and the Argument for Inflation
description: Matthew Klein has been going through Fed transcripts from 2009, and notes that the Fed was surprised at the persistence of inflation despite the Great Recession.
